output.script: how far has Russia gone in strengthening its air power with the significant steps Russia has taken to strengthen its air power the development of the Russian aerospace forces has reached a crucial new stage In a report published by Ria Nosti and sourced from official statements by Rosstec's press service it was revealed that by 2025 the Russian Aerospace Forces had received the first batch of newly produced multi-roll SU35s fighter jets manufactured by the United Aircraft Corporation part of Rosstec a state-owned company playing a vital role in the development of Russia's defense technology These four plus generation fighter jets are not just additional equipment but rather a symbol of significant progress in Russia's military capabilities The SU35S has successfully passed the entire factory testing cycle and has been accepted by technical staff who will maintain and operate it Furthermore the aircraft has undergone a series of trials in various operational modes conducted by pilots from the Russian Ministry of Defense ensuring that it is ready to face the challenges of modern battlefields Russia is clearly not half-hearted in developing its air capabilities The manufacturers who are also part of the national defense industry complex have seriously fulfilled their duty to ensure the supply of the latest and most advanced aviation equipment for the armed forces In this regard the SU35S is not just an ordinary fighter jet but a bridge that marks the transition towards a more advanced fifth generation aviation system How has it managed to convince the Russian aerospace forces keep your eyes on the story Before we dive deeper into the details of this fighter jet and why it is often referred to as a bridge to the fifth generation let's take a moment to observe its role in the skies where important missions often depend on its resilience For example in a combat alert mission in the Korsk region the SU35S fighter jet played a vital role in protecting ground attack aircraft bombers and helicopters operating in the area Its presence was always on standby ready to move at a moment's notice during critical times At one point when two long range TU95MS bombers carried out a planned flight over neutral waters of the Sea of Okatsk and the Sea of Japan with a flight duration of more than 8 hours The SU35S along with SU30SM jets from the Russian Air Force closely escorted the bombers throughout their journey Now let's take a closer look at what the SU35S has to offer given its remarkable capabilities in the vast skies Russia recognizes the great potential of its fighter jets which is why the United Aircraft Corporation has taken significant steps to enhance the production capacity of its advanced aircraft In this grand plan the focus is on the production of fighter jets such as the SU35S SU34 and SU57 This capacity expansion process involves the development of facilities at aircraft plants in Kamsaq on Amore and Novosabersk which are currently being expanded Not only are the facilities being improved but staff training and upgrading production equipment are also key priorities to address any potential challenges and ensure smooth production Behind these efforts the SU35S a product of Russia's skilled craftsmanship draws attention once again The SU35S is designed to offer a combination of exceptional maneuverability long range strike capabilities and next generation avionics This aircraft is part of a larger plan to modernize the Russian aerospace forces which continues to strengthen its combat capabilities despite being caught in a prolonged conflict in Ukraine and facing Western sanctions imposed by the United States and the European Union So what makes the SU35S so special the key to its extraordinary flight performance lies in its new power plant featuring engines with digital control systems and vector-controlled thrust This technology allows the aircraft to perform much more agile maneuvers and achieve far better flight performance compared to its predecessors Not only that the SU35S also has adequate strike capabilities for both ground and sea targets Compared to previous models the SU35S is equipped with the IUS35 integrated information and control system which helps reduce the pilot's workload while improving situational awareness The aircraft's radar with a passive electronically scanned array has a detection range of up to 400 km enabling it to engage in long range air combat with various threats With a maximum takeoff weight of 34.5 tons and a top speed of 2,500 kmh the Su35S is ready to face challenges in the skies The aircraft is also equipped with advanced weaponry such as the GSH 3130mm cannon air-to-air missiles with varying ranges CAS series anti-ship missiles and a variety of guided and unguided bombs The SU35S is indeed an attractive option with even some Western media praising its extraordinary capabilities This is the tangible proof of its prowess According to TAS one of the outlets praising the SU35S fighter jet is the renowned German news portal Stern In its report Stern described the Su35s as the most dangerous fighter jet in the world today praising its exceptional maneuverability and its success in the global arms market Next the publication National Interest also expressed praise for the Su35s They quoted a senior Pentagon official who stated that this fighter jet is impressive and dangerous especially if produced in large quantities Even US fighter jets like the F-15 and FA18E would face significant challenges when engaging Russian jets like the SU35 exhausting considerable energy in each battle The Washington Times also aligns with this view stating that the SU35S is superior to most NATO weapons They assess that this fighter jet has great potential for modernization and will become a highly effective combat vehicle with capabilities that will evolve over time What do you think is the SU35S promising enough that's all for today and thanks for watching Hey hey hey

output.script: yesterday anthropic finally released Claude 3.7 Sona the highly anticipated large language model that's most loved and most feared by programmers their announcement video has everybody freaking out and the top comment on that video is people waiting for this video and let me just say I'm humbled and honored that you put so much faith into my half-ass AI reviews I've already burned through millions of tokens testing it and the tldr is that Claud 3.7 is straight gas hits different matte heat highkey goated on God no cap for real for real the new base model beat itself to become even better at programming while adding a new thinking mode to copy the success of deep seek R1 in the open AO models but the craziest thing they released is something called Claude code a CLI tool that allows you to build test and execute code in any project thus creating an infinite feedback loop that in theory should replace all programmers all the code influencers are telling us we're cooked and in today's video we'll find out if they're right it is February 25th 2025 and you're watching the code report a few weeks ago anthropic released a paper that studied how AI affects the labor force and what they found is that despite only making up 3.4% of the workforce over 37% of the prompts are related to math and coding and although it hasn't taken any human programmer jobs yet it has taken stack overflows job now there's a lot of AI slot word out there and it's hard to keep track of it all but for web development one of the better indicators is web dev Arena and Claude 3.5 the previous version is already sitting on top of that leaderboard but it was roughly tied with all of the other state-of-the-art models when it comes to the software engineering Benchmark which is human verif ified and based on real GitHub issues what's crazy though is that the new 3.7 model absolutely crushed all the other models including open AI O3 mini high and deep seek and is now capable of solving 70.3% of GitHub issues that is if we're to believe the Benchmark and after trying out the CLA code CLI I might actually believe it it's in research preview currently but you can install the CLA CLI with npm disclaimer though it uses the anthropic API directly and CLA is not cheap costing over 10 times more than models like Gemini Flash and deepsea $15 per million output tokens cost more than my entire personality once installed you'll have access to the CLA command in the terminal and that gives it the full context of existing code in your project one thing I noticed immediately though is that their text decoration in the CLI looks almost identical to SST an open source tool we've covered on this channel before that could be a coincidence but it appears the clo logo might also be plagiarized based on this drawing of a butthole by one of my favorite authors Kurt vonet now there's nothing wrong with designing your logo after a sphincter plenty of companies do it but I think CLA is just a little too on the nose here but now that I have CLA installed I can run the in command which will scan the project and create a markdown file with some initial context and instructions that's cool but now we have an open session and one thing you might want to do is see how much money you've lost by prompting so far with the cost command I can see that creating that AIT file cost about 8 cents now the first actual job I gave it was pretty easy and that was to create a random name generator in Dino after you enter a prompt it will figure out what to do and then have you confirm it with a yes or no like in this case here it wants to generate a new file it'll go ahead and write that file to the file system and then it also creates a dedicated testing file as well that's important because using a strongly typed language along with test driven development are ways for the AI to validate that the code it writes is actually valid if that test fails it can use the feedback to rewrite the business logic and continue going back and forth until it gets it right and in this example it wrote what I would consider perfect code but now let's do something more challenging and have it build an actual visual front end UI but instead of react we'll use spelt when I generated the config you'll notice that it understands the text stack is using typescript and tailwind and then I'll prompt it for a moderately complex front-end UI an application that can access my microphone and visualize the waveform after this initial prompt I had to confirm like 20 different things and as you can see it wrote a bunch of new components to my project it took a lot longer than just prompting claw in the web UI but the end result was worth the wait here in the application I can click through a waveform frequency and circular graphic that visualizes the sound of my voice as a control I had open aai 03 mini High generate the same thing and at first I got an error which was easy to fix but the end result looked like this an embarrassing piece of crap compared to Claude but upon closer inspection there were a lot of problems in claude's code like for one it didn't use typescript or Tailwind at all even though it should know that they're in our Tex stack it also failed to use the new spell 5 Rune syntax and the entire session cost me about 65 cents which would have been better spent on an egg or a banana but now I have one final test recently Apple had to discontinue ending and encryption in the UK because the government wanted a back door and apple refused to build one if you've been affected by this one thing you can do is build your own and an encrypted app I've been trying to do that myself in JavaScript but every single large language model that I've tried fails let's see if Claud code can fix this chat GPT garbage code it took quite a while and changed a lot of the code but for whatever reason it still fails to run and unfortunately because I become so dependent on AI I have no idea how to fix an error message like this and all I can really do is wait for the next best model to come out throughout the video we've seen how good CLA is at front end Dev but the other half to your application is the back end and if you like building apps fast you need to try out convex the sponsor of today's video it's an open- Source reactive database that provides typesafe queries scheduled jobs server functions real-time data sync like Firebase just to name a few of its features best of all though database queries are written in pure typescript giving us this beautiful IDE autocomplete across the entire stack but that also creates another side effect making convex really good at autonomous Vibe coding with AI models like Claude can more easily understand comvex code write it with fewer errors and thus be more productive with it if you know how to build a front-end app you're already halfway there now use the link on the screen to create a free convex project to build the other half this has been the code report thanks for watching and I will see you in the next one

input: main idea: Tell the story of how Iran developed the Saegheh fighter jet despite severe international sanctions, with a focus on engineering innovation and geopolitical defiance..

output.title: How Iran Built the Saegheh Fighter Jet Under Harsh Sanctions
output.description:
Despite international sanctions, Iran developed the Saegheh jet not only for defense but also to gain critical experience for future aircraft like Kowsar and Yasin. It represents Iranâ€™s industrial resilience and determination to achieve self-sufficiency in military aviation, aiming to eventually export it to allied nations.

output.script: how Iran built the SEI fighter jet under harsh sanctions The SEI jet fighter is Iran's first fully indigenous combat aircraft developed based on the American FE5 E Tiger 2 platform It was designed with the primary goal of reducing Iran's dependency on foreign spare parts Iranian engineers reverse engineered the F5 structure to analyze and replicate its components The Sai project was launched in the early 2000s as the starting point for the indigenous development of military aircraft The first prototype successfully took flight in 2006 The design process of the Sai began with major modifications to its vertical stabilizers While the original F5E had a single vertical tail the Sai was equipped with twin vertical stabilizers This design inspired by the American FA18 offered better stability and maneuverability especially at low altitudes The twintail configuration also enhanced the aircraft's agility and contributed to a more modern and stealthier visual profile The airframe of the Sai is constructed using locally produced alloys and composite materials resistant to pressure and stress Its engine is the J85G21 the same model used in the F5 Iran has managed to overhaul reproduce and even optimize this engine in certain versions Each engine provides around 5,000 pounds of thrust offering flight performance comparable to its American counterpart One of the most notable upgrades in the Sai is its indigenous digital avionic system It features multi-function displays MFDs a head-up display HUD and an internal navigation suite Communication systems have been upgraded for compatibility with other jets and ground control Additionally the aircraft is equipped with radar warning receivers and electronic countermeasure systems improving its survivability in combat zones In terms of weaponry the Saiy can carry 70 mm unguided rockets generalurpose freefall bombs and air-to-air missiles Among these is the AM9 Sidewinder or its Iranian variant The aircraft also supports short-range infraredg guided missiles The underbelly retains provisions for an internal cannon Iran has also worked on integrating precisiong guided munitions in newer versions The SA's lightweight structure and aerodynamic design allow it to perform high-speed maneuvers and quick turns making it suitable for close-range dog fights During domestic joint exercises it has demonstrated acceptable performance in interception and targeting roles It is also used in advanced pilot training missions However its operational range and fuel capacity remain limited To address the range limitation Iran developed an upgraded version known as SE 2 This variant includes an external fuel tank under the fuselage significantly extending its range The increased fuel volume allows the aircraft to participate in longer missions Additionally this model features a fully digitized avionic sweep Some reports also indicate improvements to the engine cooling system SEGI 2 is equipped with advanced positioning and inertial navigation systems These allow the aircraft to navigate combat routes without relying on external GPS sources This capability becomes crucial in electronic warfare environments enhancing its operational survivability Some Sega 2 models are fitted with touchscreen multi-function displays which greatly simplify battlefield management for the pilot To produce the SIGA Iran utilized the capabilities of domestic aerospace firms and academic institutions The Iran Aviation Industries Organization AI AIO and the Islamic Republic of Iran Air Force IIAF played key roles in the project Malik Ashtar University contributed to the aerodynamic design and advanced materials Currently the aircraft is assembled on domestic production lines Though not mass-produced it has entered service in limited numbers The SIG is primarily deployed for air defense advanced training and combat patrol missions Due to its low maintenance needs and operational costs it is ideal for training fighter pilots Iran has showcased this aircraft in multiple military exercises to demonstrate its deterrence capability Notably it has participated in the defenders of the Veilot sky drills where its performance was wellreceived by local experts In terms of reconnaissance certain Siege variants have been adapted for light Awax and imagery surveillance roles By equipping the aircraft with cameras and electrooptical sensors its capability for patrol and observation has increased Although it lacks long range radar systems it is effective in regional operations It has been frequently deployed along Iran's western and southern borders and has also been trained for anti- drone missions Official Iranian sources claim that the Siege is capable of engaging fourth generation enemy fighters It is considered superior to older F5s in terms of performance and systems Although it cannot compete with more advanced platforms like the F-16 or Sue35 its lightweight design and practical range make it a valuable complement to other air defense systems It also plays an important role in preparing pilots for heavier combat aircraft In terms of stealth the Sai features a slightly reduced radar cross-section RCS compared to the original F5 thanks to its twintail design and angular body shape While it does not qualify as a stealth fighter it is harder to detect than earlier models New paint schemes with radar absorbent coatings have also been tested on certain variants contributing to Iran's long-term ambition of developing stealth aircraft Economically the Siege is significantly cheaper to produce than imported fighter jets Its hourly flight cost is lower than that of many other aircraft maintenance spare parts and crew training are all conducted domestically This self-reliance enhances Iran's defense independence amid ongoing sanctions Some sources suggest that each SIGE costs about 25% of an F-16's price The SEI project gave Iran invaluable experience in reverse engineering This expertise later contributed to projects like the Kosar fighter and jet powered drones It also raised the level of aeronautical engineering knowledge across Iranian universities Engineers learned how to build complex systems with limited tools and resources An achievement that marks a turning point in the country's pursuit of military self-sufficiency Iran is seeking to export the SIE to allied countries Although sanctions have posed significant obstacles however the primary goal has been to gain experience for developing more advanced generations of aircraft The knowledge acquired through this project laid the foundation for the development of the Kosar Yasin and future designs Saigi is not merely a fighter jet It stands as a symbol of Iran's industrial independence and resilience Despite all limitations this aircraft has managed to defy doubts and demonstrate capability under pressure

output.title: When Muay Thai Legend Challenges a Master of MMAâ€¦ Then This Happened
output.description:
What happens when a Muay Thai legend walks straight into the clutches of one of the most dangerous men in MMA? What unfolded in this clash of titans left fans questioning everything they thought they knew about these warriors. Brace yourself: this fight took an unexpected turn that nobody saw coming.

ğŸ”” Subscribe now with all notifications on for more Muay Thai, MMA and Epic Fights

On March 26, 2022, the combat sports world saw something unforgettable. Two legends were about to collide at the #one X event in Singapore. This fight had a twist: round one would follow #muaythai rules, and round two would be under #mma rules. In one corner was Rodtang Jitmuangnon, a Muay Thai powerhouse with over 300 fights by the age of 24. Known for his
relentless aggression and his ability to take hits like no other, #rodtang had become a living legend, feared for his relentless pressure and devastating strikes. On the other side was Demetrious Johnson the 'Mighty Mouse, a former #ufc Flyweight Champion and one of the most adaptable fighters in MMA history. Johnson's speed, technique, and fight IQ made him a force to be reckoned with. But this time, he was stepping into Rodtangâ€™s territory: the brutal world of Muay Thai. What happens when a Muay ThaiÂ 
legend walks straight into theÂ Â  clutches of one of the most dangerous men in MMA? What unfolded in this clash of titans left fansÂ Â  questioning everything they thoughtÂ 
they knew about these warriors. Brace yourself: this fight took anÂ 
unexpected turn that nobody saw coming. Welcome to 'Fight LegendsÂ 
Unleashed,' where we takeÂ Â  you straight into the heart of the mostÂ 
jaw-dropping showdowns in combat sports. Today, weâ€™re talking about a fight thatÂ 
had everyone on the edge of their seats. Rodtang Jitmuangnon, also known as â€œTheÂ 
Iron Man,â€ is Muay Thaiâ€™s human wreckingÂ Â  ball, and went head-to-head withÂ 
'Mighty Mouse' Demetrious Johnson,Â Â  the MMA mastermind whoâ€™s beenÂ 
rewriting the rulebook for years. This clash had fans holding their breath,Â 
wondering whoâ€™d be the last man standing. Letâ€™s break down how thisÂ 
explosive battle played outÂ Â  and why itâ€™s still got the fight world buzzing. On March 26, 2022, the combat sportsÂ 
world saw something unforgettable. Two legends were about to collideÂ 
at the ONE X event in Singapore. This fight had a twist: roundÂ 
one would follow Muay Thai rules,Â Â  and round two would be under MMA rules. In one corner was Rodtang Jitmuangnon, a Muay ThaiÂ 
powerhouse with over 300 fights by the age of 24. Known for his relentless aggression andÂ 
his ability to take hits like no other,Â Â  Rodtang had become a living legend, feared forÂ 
his relentless pressure and devastating strikes. On the other side was DemetriousÂ 
'Mighty Mouse' Johnson, a formerÂ Â  UFC Flyweight Champion and one of theÂ 
most adaptable fighters in MMA history. Johnsonâ€™s speed, technique, and fightÂ 
IQ made him a force to be reckoned with. But this time, he was stepping into Rodtangâ€™sÂ 
territory: the brutal world of Muay Thai. The big question was clear: CouldÂ 
Johnson survive Rodtangâ€™s onslaught,Â Â  or would Rodtang be outsmartedÂ 
by Johnsonâ€™s MMA brilliance? As the bell rang for round one, theÂ 
energy in the arena was electric. Rodtang Jitmuangnon wasted no time,Â 
charging at Demetrious Johnson withÂ Â  the intensity that had made him a Muay Thai icon. This round was all about Muay Thai,Â 
and Rodtang was in his element. Right from the start, he unleashed a barrageÂ 
of powerful kicks, elbows, and punches,Â Â  pushing forward with the kind of aggressionÂ 
that had overwhelmed so many opponents before. Johnson, stepping into unfamiliarÂ 
territory with Muay Thai rules,Â Â  found himself struggling to keepÂ 
up with Rodtangâ€™s relentless pace. Rodtang was clearly in control,Â Â  dominating the round as he pressedÂ 
forward with brutal combinations. At times, Rodtang could be seen smilingÂ 
and even laughing, a clear sign of howÂ Â  comfortable he felt in his domain. For him, this round seemed almost effortless,Â Â  as if he were toying with theÂ 
challenge in front of him. Johnson, known for his calm underÂ 
pressure, tried to stay composed. He moved with precision, using hisÂ 
footwork to evade some of Rodtangâ€™sÂ Â  strikes, but it was clear that he was on theÂ 
defensive, trying to survive the onslaught. Every time Johnson attempted to find an opening,Â Â  Rodtang shut it down with a fierce strike,Â 
reminding everyone why heâ€™s feared in the ring. Johnsonâ€™s usual confidence wasÂ 
tested as he grappled with theÂ Â  challenge of Muay Thaiâ€™s raw power and pace. Despite his best efforts to counter,Â Â  Rodtangâ€™s relentless pressureÂ 
kept him from finding his rhythm. Rodtangâ€™s dominance was evident: heÂ 
controlled the distance, dictated theÂ Â  pace, and landed the heavier shots, allÂ 
while keeping Johnson on his back foot. The crowd roared with every crushing blow, sensingÂ 
that Rodtang was fully in charge of the round. As the seconds ticked away, it becameÂ 
clear that Johnsonâ€™s primary goal wasÂ Â  to make it through to the next round,Â 
where the rules would shift in his favor. The tension in the arena was palpable as theÂ 
first round came to a close, with Rodtang firmlyÂ Â  in control, his confidence on full display, andÂ 
Johnson left to regroup for what was coming next.  If youâ€™re into intense fight breakdowns like this,Â Â  hit that subscribe button and stayÂ 
tuned for more exciting content!  As the bell rang for round two, theÂ 
atmosphere in the arena shifted. With the rules now favoring MMA, this wasÂ 
Johnsonâ€™s moment. Rodtang, still ridingÂ Â  high from his dominance in the first round,Â 
charged forward again, but Johnson was ready. With lightning speed, JohnsonÂ 
secured a rear-mount clinch,Â Â  latching onto Rodtangâ€™s back as the MuayÂ 
Thai powerhouse tried to shake him off. Rodtang, in a desperate attempt to dump JohnsonÂ 
over his shoulder, made a move to the ground. But Johnson, always vigilant,Â 
used this moment to his advantage. As they hit the canvas, Johnson seamlesslyÂ 
transitioned into a full rear-naked choke,Â Â  locking in the submissionÂ 
hold with intense precision. Rodtang fought back with everything he had,Â Â  struggling against the choke,Â 
his iron will on full display. For nearly a full minute, he resisted,Â 
refusing to go down easily. The crowdÂ Â  watched in suspense as Rodtangâ€™s movementsÂ 
grew slower, his oxygen slipping away. Finally, despite his best efforts,Â 
Rodtang lost consciousness. The referee stepped in, and Demetrious 'MightyÂ 
Mouse' Johnson was declared the winner. The arena exploded with applauseÂ 
as Johnson made a victory lap. He had outlasted Rodtang andÂ 
showcased his unmatched versatility,Â Â  turning the tide of the fight in dramatic fashion. This fight was a thrilling reminder ofÂ 
the unpredictability that makes combatÂ Â  sports so captivating, especially in theÂ 
high-stakes arena of ONE Championship. When two legends step intoÂ 
the ring, anything can happen. For Rodtang, this bout put his incredibleÂ 
striking power on full display, but it alsoÂ Â  highlighted the challenges he faces whenÂ 
venturing beyond his usual battlefield. Fans are now left wondering: Is RodtangÂ 
willing to step into uncharted territory again,Â Â  or will he focus on dominating the Muay ThaiÂ 
scene, where his reign remains undisputed? As for Demetrious 'Mighty Mouse'Â 
Johnson, this victory stands asÂ Â  a defining moment in a career that hasÂ 
set the standard for greatness in MMA. Having recently announced hisÂ 
retirement on September 6, 2024,Â Â  Johnson leaves the sport as one of the mostÂ 
versatile and accomplished fighters of all time. His ability to adapt and conquer opponentsÂ 
will be remembered as a hallmark of his legacy. In the ever-evolving world of ONE Championship,Â Â  where the best from every disciplineÂ 
collide, Johnsonâ€™s victories,Â Â  including this one, will continue toÂ 
inspire fighters for generations to come. This clash between two titans from differentÂ 
realms will be remembered as a night thatÂ Â  perfectly captured what makes ONE Championship -Â 
and combat sports in general - so electrifying:Â Â  the surprises, the skill, and theÂ 
relentless heart of true champions. Thanks for tuning in! If you liked this breakdown, hit that like buttonÂ 
and subscribe for more exciting fight analysis. Got a matchup you want us to cover next? Drop your ideas in the comments. Until then, stay ready and stay sharp!

output.script: tariffs from the white House, leading to a reversal in stocks Monday afternoon from a big up session on Friday which is seems so long ago. Joining us now with her view on the current state of the markets, Gabriella Santos, J.P. Morgan Asset Management chief market strategist for Americas. It's a. It's the best of times. It's the worst of times I think. And that's your point. If there weren't some of these external things happening, the base case is still pretty solid in terms of earnings and margins and the economy and everything else. But you don't know at this point how all this is going to play out. >> I think that the first thing that we do have to appreciate in moments where there is a lot of change, is the actual underlying momentum coming into this moment. And we ended 2024 with real domestic final demand growing 3%. We had been surprised over and over with the resilience of the economy, especially the consumer. And we had most importantly, a broadening in earnings growth. With the magnificent seven growing earnings 15% in the fourth quarter, finally seeing margins start to improve again. So that's really, really important. This is a resilient economy with good momentum. That said, I think the markets are now trying to figure out exactly the decimal points for this year, which is a lot of function of a lot of crosscurrents in policy. And we do seem to be starting to see a cooling in the economy. But it's a cooling. It's not cool. So it's more just trying to figure out the contours around the edges. How does all this change in tariff and trade policy affect sentiment, affect CapEx, consumption margins, revenue growth? How does the change in government spending also affect confidence? Maybe employment? So how do all these different puzzle pieces fit together? >> I wish it was just decimal points and you're turning decimal points to the right. That's right. Of the to the right. >> Yes to the right of the period. >> To the right of the period. >> When it starts affecting according to the Atlanta Fed, it's actually affected numbers to the left of the decimal point and GDP. >> And that to us seems like a bit of a we don't want to overreact to what happened in two trading days. Is the Atlanta Fed GDP now went from 2% to -2.8%. So there are two separate artificial issues here masking that underlying change. The first related to the import surge that we seem to have had, we're going to get more trade data this Thursday. What seems to have happened is a big surge in imports of gold, which is the BA, does not include in its GDP calculation. So just a mechanical thing there. And then the second one is related to sentiment. There has been a big decline. For example yesterday ISM manufacturing. But that's soft data. We have to actually see what's really happening in the underlying hard data. That's why this Friday's jobs report will be so important. And I think it can be a relief for investors to see that. Our expectation is we're still creating over 150,000 jobs. So there is still a continuation of momentum. It's more of a cooling. It's not cool. And for us the underlying momentum is closer to 2%. >> If you are right. >> The administration could make the case that if its decimal points, this is when you'd want to make some of the moves for the long term to correct some of the imbalances that that they see, whether it's trade, whether it's the size of government, whether it's government spending, you might be you might be just feeding into the impulses of the administration to do it now instead of some other time. >> And I do think it's going to depend on exactly how much we see all at once. It is starting to. >> How long it. >> Lasts and how long it lasts. I do think there is somewhat of a consensus in the market right this second that maybe especially these 25% tariffs on Canada and Mexico are not persistent. We'll have to see the scope of the change, how long it lasts, and whether it's just these more recent developments that's affecting negatively the supply and the demand side of the economy, or whether we start to get some of the other policy aspects that are actually pro and boosting the supply side and the demand side of the economy and how those two interact. I think for the short term, while there is still uncertainty about this, what we saw in 2018 is a period of multiple contraction to try to factor in these different possible outcomes. And then eventually, if they are persistent, maybe start to factor that in into earnings estimates. So I would say just two quick implications here. The first is really that we had been talking about going into this year. Just taking a look at the portfolio drift that might have happened in portfolios. A lot more exposure to risk. I see you see bonds doing their job with yields moving lower. The AG moving higher 2.5%. So having some real growth diversifiers in there. And then the second is not turning too much to the cyclical trade quite yet. It's too early for that. It's usually out of a recession. So for us it's diversifying within the market but much more of a quality factor tilt. For now. >> We were going to have Howard Lutnick on the he does just bowl right. He always has an answer for everything and just, you know, headlong into these things. But is it fentanyl. Is it dairy in Canada. Do we want factories built here or there? I don't know what. I'm not sure exactly what the end game is. Is it renegotiating the Usmca and just not sure. We need to be clear on when we are able to take things off and what the you know, is it really fentanyl? I Gabriella, thanks. >> Are there concessions to closing. >> The loop. >> For

output.script:
Hello and welcome... Hello and welcome back toÂ 
Accounting Stuff. I'm James and today we'reÂ Â  talking financial statements. The income statement,Â 
the balance sheet and the cash flow statement. I'mÂ Â  going to try and explain all the basics in underÂ 
eight minutes which is going to be a challengeÂ Â  because we have a little puppy here who's uhÂ 
trying to bite my finger. So let's get started!Â Â  What are financial statements? FinancialÂ 
statements are reports that summarize theÂ Â  activities and financial performance of a business.Â 
They're prepared at the end of each accountingÂ Â  period and they're designed to give investors andÂ 
lenders a feel for a business's financial health.Â Â  The three main financial statements are the balanceÂ 
sheet, the income statement and the cash flowÂ Â  statement. Now I'll explain how each of theseÂ 
work with an example. Tea-licious is a family-runÂ Â  business that produces a popular blend of blackÂ 
tea. Their financial year has come to a close andÂ Â  they've finished putting together their financialÂ 
statements so let's look at them. We'll start withÂ Â  the balance sheet. What is a balance sheet? TheÂ 
balance sheet is a financial statement that givesÂ Â  us a snapshot of a business's assets, liabilitiesÂ 
and equity at a single point in time. The balanceÂ Â  sheet is also called the statement of financialÂ 
position and it looks like this. In the header weÂ Â  have the business's name followed by the name ofÂ 
the financial statement and directly below thatÂ Â  we have the point in time that we're looking at. AÂ 
snapshot of December 31st. On the left hand side ofÂ Â  the balance sheet we have a list of everything theÂ 
business owns - its assets - and on the right we haveÂ Â  everything the business owes its liabilities andÂ 
equity. Tea-licious owes liabilities to third partiesÂ Â  like its suppliers, its employees and the taxÂ 
office. But it also owes equity back to the ownersÂ Â  of the business. This includes their originalÂ 
capital contributions which is the cash the ownersÂ Â  injected into the business and retained earningsÂ 
which are the cumulative profits that the businessÂ Â  has held onto. If we collapse the balance sheetÂ 
down into its core components then we can seeÂ Â  that Tea-licious has total equity of 129.5 millionÂ 
dollars. What does this mean? Well if the businessÂ Â  were to suddenly sell off all of its assets andÂ 
pay off all of its debts then in theory, this isÂ Â  how much money the owners would get. At the bottomÂ 
of the balance sheet Tea-licious has total assetsÂ Â  of 169 million dollars and total liabilities andÂ 
equity of 169 million dollars. The stuff it owns isÂ Â  equal to the stuff it owes. So the balance sheetÂ 
is in balance. Which is fantastic news becauseÂ Â  a balance sheet always has to balance. Why? BecauseÂ 
it says so in the accounting equation. Assets shallÂ Â  always equal liabilities plus equity. Or the stuffÂ 
that a business owns is equal to the stuff thatÂ Â  a business owes. What is an income statement? AnÂ 
income statement is a financial statement thatÂ Â  summarizes a business's revenues and expensesÂ 
over a period of time. If the balance sheet isÂ Â  a snapshot of a point in time then the incomeÂ 
statement is more like a video or a boomerangÂ Â  covering a range of time. The income statementÂ 
looks like this. As you can see in the headerÂ Â  the income statement covers a period of time.Â 
The year ended December 31st. And in theÂ Â  body of the report we have a summary of revenueÂ 
earned and expenses incurred. If we collapse itÂ Â  then we find it the income statement is reallyÂ 
showing us three things. Firstly, Tea-licious madeÂ Â  255 million dollars in revenue. Which is their topÂ 
line income that it earned from selling productsÂ Â  during the year. Secondly, it incurred 248 millionÂ 
dollars in expenses. This includes the direct andÂ Â  indirect costs of running the business and finallyÂ 
when we subtract expenses from revenue we see thatÂ Â  Tea-licious generated seven million dollars in netÂ 
profit on the bottom line. Profitability is key toÂ Â  the income statement which is why it's also calledÂ 
the statement of profit and loss. It tells us howÂ Â  much profit the business earned over a period ofÂ 
time. But be careful here because profit doesn'tÂ Â  necessarily translate to cash flow. Which is whyÂ 
businesses also need a cash flow statement. WhatÂ Â  is a cash flow statement? A cash flow statementÂ 
is a financial statement that shows a business'sÂ Â  cash inflows and outflows over a period of time.Â 
Businesses need to make a cash flow statementÂ Â  if they are using accrual accounting. You seeÂ 
there are two methods of accounting. We haveÂ Â  the cash method and the accrual method. The cashÂ 
method of accounting is often used by smallerÂ Â  businesses it says that revenue is recognizedÂ 
when cash is received and expenses are recordedÂ Â  when cash is paid out. Under the cash method theÂ 
income statement and the cash flow statement areÂ Â  equivalent to one another. If cash comes in weÂ 
record revenue and if cash goes out we recordÂ Â  an expense. It's nice and simple but it has itsÂ 
limitations. What if Tea-licious makes a large saleÂ Â  but the customer doesn't pay the invoice until theÂ 
following accounting period. Their revenue could beÂ Â  understated in the period that they made the saleÂ 
and overstated in the following period when theyÂ Â  received the cash. There has to be a better way!Â 
And thankfully there is. The accrual method saysÂ Â  that we should recognize revenue as it's earnedÂ 
and record expenses as they are incurred. WhenÂ Â  the substance of the transaction takes place. ThisÂ 
means that cash inflows and outflows aren't equivalentÂ Â  to revenues and expenses. They need to be trackedÂ 
separately in the cash flow statement. A cash flowÂ Â  statement looks like this. In the header we haveÂ 
the period of time that it relates to, just likeÂ Â  we had in the income statement. And in the bodyÂ 
we have two main sections. At the bottom we haveÂ Â  the opening and closing cash balances for theÂ 
financial year. We get these numbers from theÂ Â  balance sheet Tea-licious started out with 11Â 
million dollars and finished up with 12 millionÂ Â  dollars. So overall that's a net increase in cashÂ 
of one million dollars. But how did this come about?Â Â  This is where the top section comes in. We work outÂ 
the cash flow from operating activities, investingÂ Â  activities and financing activities. Cash flowÂ 
from operating activities covers regular businessÂ Â  activities. How much cash Tea-licious broughtÂ 
in and spent whilst selling tea. Tea-licious isÂ Â  using the direct method so this section mirrors anÂ 
income statement prepared under the cash method ofÂ Â  accounting. Cash flow from investing activitiesÂ 
looks outside of the core operations of theÂ Â  business. These are the cash inflows and outflowsÂ 
from investments and buying or selling propertyÂ Â  and equipment. Cash flow from financing activitiesÂ 
is all about funding the business, either throughÂ Â  loans from banks or equity from the ownersÂ 
of the business. If we collapse this all downÂ Â  then the net cash flow on the top should match upÂ 
with the net cash flow on the bottom. It does hereÂ Â  which means the cash flow statement is reconciled.Â 
Let's do a quick recap. The balance sheet gives usÂ Â  a snapshot of a business's assets, liabilities andÂ 
equity at a single point in time. It shows us whatÂ Â  a business owns and what it owes. It also tells usÂ 
how much the business is worth to its owners. AndÂ Â  then we have the income statement which shows usÂ 
a business's revenues and expenses over a periodÂ Â  of time. When we take the difference we can see ifÂ 
it made a profit or a loss. The cash flow statementÂ Â  reveals a business's cash inflows and outflowsÂ 
over a period of time. These are reconciled backÂ Â  to the movement in cash in the balance sheet.Â 
I've made videos and cheat sheets coveringÂ Â  each of these financial statements. You can findÂ 
links to all of that down in the description.Â Â  And a big thanks to all my channel members youÂ 
know who you are and I appreciate your support.Â Â  Thank you from both of us. This is Winnie byÂ 
the way... and we'll see you in the next one!

the grocery store at the gas station for their rent for their child care for their health care and all of those things have gone up consider considerably over the last 3 years while inflation has come down it's not spiking any longer it's back basically where you would consider it normal prices haven't come down and getting back to those prices of three years ago it's going to be a really long road the typical family right now is paying about $1,200 more every month on the same goods and services as they were three years ago the FED has been fighting this fight through uh both interest rate increases and what we anticipate will tomorrow an interest rate cut um because they as far as the FED is concerned have sort of won that inflation fight at this point because inflation has normalized but still again prices are higher and that's going to be something for now president-elect Trump to try to deal with in his presidency well and I want to dig in a little deeper on that because we talk about inflation but that's not the same as high prices right inflation has sort of leveled out it's almost at that Target that the FED laid out you know at the 2% Target we're at 2 and a half% pry close right now prices are growing but when milk is eight bucks even once inflation levels out that just means that price isn't increasing that much anymore but that still means it's going to be eight a lot of the sort of fast food types of restaurants have recently begun to lower their prices and that's because you have seen the consumer change habits with prices as high as they've gotten but that doesn't exist yet at the grocery store where you see egg prices for example up 161% over the last 3 years people feel that and again like you said inflation is the rate of change but prices even though the rate of change has really dramatically slowed down from where it was spiking prices are not coming down and we still feel that every time you go to the grocery store that's for sure now when you spoke to voters about the economy being one of the critical issues in this election you said they were specifically concerned about about inflation and so given the context of everything we easy road ahead of course you have the Federal Reserve with its own monetary policy and it will do everything in its power to keep prices stable the types of policies we've heard uh from from Trump input: main idea: Make a dramatic explainer breaking down the signs of a looming recession under Trump's economic policies and how it's affecting the stock market..

output.title: How to balance paying debt vs. investing
output.description:
The simple math behind paying off debt versus investing.

This video is presented by Robinhood. Our sponsor has no editorial influence over how we report our stories, but their support makes videos like these possible.

When you get to a place financially where you can begin to start saving, rather than living paycheck to paycheck, a big question often comes up: â€Should I pay off my debt or invest in the stock market?â€ Thereâ€™s no simple answer, but thereâ€™s a simple rule of thumb that can help you decide what to do with this money to have the best financial outcome in the long run. 

The first place to look is the interest rate on your debt and see if itâ€™s below 7%, the rate of return you can conservatively expect from investing in an index fund, like the S&P 500. If your debt â€” like a mortgage or a student loan â€” falls below 7%, it is usually mathematically more beneficial to invest in the stock market while you pay down the debt by its minimum payments. The logic being: Youâ€™ll likely earn more interest by investing than your debt will accrue in that time. 

Higher interest rate debt, like credit card debt, should almost always be eliminated as soon as possible, since you are statistically unlikely to see a rate of return from investing past 7 to 10% annually. And of course, investing always comes with risk. So the most secure bet is always to work toward being debt-free.

Further reading: 

How to Prioritize Retirement Savings vs. Debt Payoff, Bill Fay
https://www.debt.org/retirement/prioritize-savings-vs-payoff/

Should you pay down debt or invest?, Fidelity
https://www.fidelity.com/learning-center/personal-finance/pay-down-debt-vs-invest

Debt Destroyer, a US government online tool to help make a plan to eliminate debt
https://finred.usalearning.gov/debt-destroyer-calculator/debt-destroyer-calculator.html

Note: The title of this video has been updated
Previous title: When it's okay to wait to pay off debt

output.script: [Music] let's say you're at a place financially where you're able to start saving rather than living paycheck to paycheck a situation that describes more than one in three American workers across many different income levels after covering your monthly expenses like groceries Health Care your rent or house payment you've got $200 left over what should you do with this money there's two places people usually look paying off their debt or investing in the stock market to watch the money grow and save for retirement so which one sets up for a better Financial outcome in the long run there's no simple answer but there is a rule of thumb that can help you start thinking about [Music] this the number that experts say tips this scale in either direction be it pay your debts or invest is seven that's a 7% interest rate the amount by which a debt or investment grows over time you'll sometimes see this Tipping Point number as 6% or 5% after factoring in considerations like how close a person is to retiring but since 7% is the low end of the growth you can expect from investing over time that's where the scale will balance out for the purposes of this video if your debt has a lower interest rate below 7% it's considered mathematically more beneficial to put that $200 toward investing in an index fund an investment fund that tracks the performance of a market index like the S&P 500 for example these are a hands-off way to invest your money that generally carry a lower risk than investing in individual stocks the S&P 5 500 going back decades grows at an average rate of about 7% when adjusted for inflation some years are much higher than that and some years are much lower but generally if your debt interest rate is below 7% you stand to earn more over time by investing rather than tackling the debt right away past 7% though the interest adding to what you owe outpaces any growth you could reasonably rely on through investing the way to think of it is just which one enhances your net worth from year to year because it is sort of a balance sheet issue what you own minus what you owe and I think 7% is a good guideline looking at the math really shows how this 7% rule of thumb Works let's say you have $10,000 in debt at a 5% interest rate that's about the average rate of federal student loans for undergraduates over the past 10 years and let's say this debt has a monthly minimum payment of $150 that you have to pay every month along with all your other necessary expenses there's a bunch of calculators online that can show you how long it will take to pay down this debt based on your monthly payments and how much total interest it will cost you in the end in our hypothetical scenario if you pay just the minimum payment without contributing anything extra it will take you about 6 and 1 12 years to pay off this debt and you will have acred around $1,700 in interest on top of the original $1,000 but if you put that extra $200 per month as an additional payment toward this debt it's gone in 2 and 1/2 years and your total interest is under $700 paying it off faster means you have $1,000 more in your pocket but let's go back to scenario one you pay your debts minimum payments and rack up $1,700 in interest over 6 and 1/2 years and during that time period you invest your $200 per month into the S&P 500 instead of paying down the debt sooner even at the more conservative 7% expected rate of return you end up earning around $4,000 in total interest so sure you've added $1,700 of interest to your debt but you earned $44,000 by investing that's $2,400 extra in your pocket instead of 1,000 from paying off your debt faster but now let's crank this debt interest rate up to 13% a typical interest rate to take out a subprime loan one given to someone with a below average credit score to buy a new car paying just the minimum payment it would take you almost 10 years to pay this off and you'd have racked up $7,800 in interest on top of the original debt but if you put in your extra $2 $ per month here this debt is gone in just under 3 years and you'll pay around $2,000 in interest so you come out ahead by $5,800 in interest saved by using your money to get this debt paid sooner so let's do the invest scenario for this one if you pay just the minimum payment on your debt and invest your $200 per month over those 10 years you can conservatively expect to earn around $10,000 in compound interest which sounds nice but when you subtract the $7,800 the debt grew in interest you end up with a net gain of just under $2,400 which is less than half as much as you would have ended up with if you had paid the debt down sooner so whichever side of this scale accumulates more interest has the higher rate of return that's where you generally want to put your money of course using seven as the Tipping Point on this scale is just a rule of thumb and life is much more complicated than a single math equation plus different kinds of debt carry dramatically different costs let's unpack that after a quick word from this video sponsor thanks Coleman while investing can feel overwhelming at times with Robin Hood gold you get contributions gold also grants you access to premium Marketplace inside from Morning Star offering unlimited in-depth stock research reports for those who are just starting or who are already investing experts you can try gold with a one-time free trial for the first 30 days by signing up at robinhood.com sgold Robin Hood has no editorial influence on our work but they do help make videos like this possible now back to the video the largest total debt in the US in dollar amounts is from mortgages these are long-term loans that generally have lower fixed interest rates usually below 7% % then there's student loans the next highest debt amount in dollars but also often with low interest rates especially at the undergraduate level one of the harder to manage sources of debt is credit card debt credit card interest rates have been turning above 20% for the last few years and can go even higher especially for people with lower credit scores the likelihood that even the most Savvy investor could consistently reach that level of return from the stock market is very very low when you have debt that is growing at over 20 % there's almost no reason not to eliminate that as soon as possible a federal law pass in 2009 actually required credit card companies to display on each statement how long it will take to pay off the debt and the additional interest incurred by going with the minimum payment and show you what you need to pay each month to eliminate the debt in 3 years plus what you'd save an interest by doing it there's one other important step a financial planner will tell you to take care of before deciding what to do with extra cash and that is to have an emergency fund set aside just in case the guidance you'll often get is for this fund to be at a minimum $1,000 to cover an unexpected expense ideally though this security blanket is bigger the classic advice is 3 to 6 months of must pay expenses that's the mortgage or the rent that's the groceries that's Health Care things like that the experts I talked to for this story emphasized that any investment in the stock market always comes with some risk and that could be a big factor for someone choosing between these two paths 7% rule or not I will just double down on there are no guarantees in the stock market you have so many more options and so much more flexibility if you're debt-free there's just a a benefit to being debt free that you really can't quantify so if you're someone who would rather avoid the risk of investing no matter how high or low your debts interest rate is well then you have your answer [Music]

output.title: Why Chinaâ€™s Economy Doesnâ€™t Want American Corn Anymore | WSJ U.S. vs. China
output.description:
The U.S. produces more corn than any other crop, with American farmers selling $5.3 billion of it to China last year. But China has spent years courting other producers as it is relying more on Brazil and other Latin American countries. China is also exploring ways to become self-sufficient long-term through embracing new technology and better farming education.

WSJ explains why growing its own grains has been such a struggle for China and how it has been trying to wean itself off of its reliance on U.S. corn production.

0:00 Chinaâ€™s corn demand
1:01 Chinaâ€™s struggles
2:57 International partnerships
5:59 Self-sufficiency

U.S. vs. China
This original video series explores the rivalry between the two superpowersâ€™ competing efforts to develop the technologies that are reshaping our world.

#China #Food #WSJ

output.script:
- [Narrator] China
imported over $5 billion of U.S. corn last year even though it's the world's
second largest producer of the crop. The world's top producer is the U.S. And most of the corn these
countries are producing isn't even eaten by people. About 75% of China's
corn and 40% of the U.S.' is used for animal feed. Livestock get fatter
when they're fed corn, and China's growing middle class is eating more and more meat. China now needs about
250 million metric tons of corn per year. So much corn that it has
to import millions of tons from other countries. And now China has begun
working to cut its reliance on foreign corn,
particularly from the U.S. - Any country that's trying
to maintain livestock, be it cows, pigs, what have
you, they need to have corn. - [Narrator] But China's farms
like far behind the U.S., which is a major concern
for its food security. Here's why growing its own grains has been such a struggle for China and how it's been trying to
wean itself off U.S. corn, which could leave a significant gap in America's export market. U.S. farmers are much more
successful at growing corn than their counterparts in China. The U.S. department of
agriculture estimates that China's corn fields yielded less than three
tons per acre last year versus nearly five in the U.S. - It's widely believed from
the folks that I talked to that the U.S. has the superior soil, the superior farming techniques. - [Narrator] The U.S. has
significantly more arable land than China, and the arable
land that China does have is decreasing due to urbanization. China's soil is also heavily polluted. A 2014 report found nearly 1/5
of the country's arable land was contaminated with heavy metals. China is currently conducting
a national soil survey to see the extent of the issue. A second key advantage for U.S. farmers is their growing practices. To try and grow more, Chinese farmers use massive
amounts of fertilizer, more than four times the global average. Many Chinese farmers are
using fertilizer inefficiently and polluting the larger
ecosystem in the process. A third issue for Chinese farmers, their seeds are about 20
years behind U.S. technology. Many in China are suspicious
of genetically modified crops, but the government has worked to overcome that skepticism. Even in its recent push to embrace genetically modified corn, China only allowed a tiny
fraction of its corn fields to be planted with
genetically modified seeds, according to reports. So China has turned to the U.S. for corn. While its banned domestic farmers from growing genetically modified corn due to public opposition, China has still imported
genetically modified corn to feed animals. But as tensions have escalated
between the two countries, China has put more effort into finding alternative trade
partners to get the resource, adding competition to the market. - They're in the process of setting up kind of their own trade network that can support their
population and their economy, and do so in a way where
they're free of U.S. influence, free of Western influence in general. - [Narrator] Namely, this
means turning to Brazil, which is right behind the U.S. and China when it comes to corn production. - For China, they're in
the process of seeking out the countries that can
handle their demand, and which is why Brazil is a key partner that they're developing a
stronger partnership with. It's because Brazil is able to grow as a corn-producing country, and they see that growth as supportive for their demand going forward. - [Narrator] For a long time, Brazil was known for having
a volatile corn supply, but the country's now
producing far more corn than ever before, increasing
how many acres are planted and growing a second crop of corn after farmers harvest soybeans. It hasn't had to do everything on its own. Foreign businesses have been investing in Brazil's agriculture for decades. Chinese companies have spent billions to get involved in the
growing Latin American market and everything from seeds to
processing and transportation. Things have shifted even further
since the war in Ukraine. For years, China was getting
lots of its corn there. Ukraine is one of the world's
largest corn producers, but its corn production
has fallen significantly in the past few years. The war has made it harder for farmers to get financing for corn
seeds and fertilizer, and some farmland has been unusable due to occupation or mines. So China has doubled down on
its relationship with Brazil. Last year, China signed an agreement to allow significantly more
corn imports from the country. The result, Brazil may surpass the U.S. in corn exports this year. - Brazil is receiving increased
market share of exports that used to be in the U.S.' domain. There's competitions for prices, who has the most competitive prices, and Brazil often wins that. - [Narrator] Because Brazil
still has lots of room to expand its corn growing acreage, it could soon surpass the
U.S. in corn production. - There's a lot of room to grow, and that's what they're doing. They're aggressively growing. - [Narrator] This could
pose significant competition for the U.S., especially in
light of other circumstances facing the country's corn market. The U.S. is currently
facing a trade dispute with its second biggest
corn customer, Mexico, which plans to ban
genetically modified corn by the end of 2023. The country says this is to preserve heirloom varieties of corn
that grow domestically, but it's a big deal since more
than 90% of U.S. grown corn is genetically modified. - Export markets are always a top concern. If China is no longer purchasing or exports in general are to drop off, then the price that
farmers are gonna receive at the grain elevators for their crop have the potential to sink. For farmers that are already operating on really thin margins,
that's very difficult. And a lot of times when
this kind of thing happens, there's some farmers that
simply cannot overcome that. - [Narrator] U.S. farmers could
potentially sell more corn to ethanol plants that
could use it to make fuel, but losing the export market could significantly lower prices. - They wouldn't be able to
cover the amount of volume that China and exports in general take up from the U.S. producers. They wouldn't be able to cover that just through ethanol alone. - [Narrator] Ultimately,
China aims to grow all the basic grains it needs, whether that's corn,
wheat, rice, or soybeans. But corn is just one crop where China's crop production falls short. The country also relies
on foreign soybeans. It imported over $16 billion
worth from the U.S. last year. Soybeans and corn often
grow on the same land, but corn is more productive. China's average soybean yield per acre is less than 1/3 that of
corn, and is about 40% less than the United States'
average soybean yield for the same plot. Some Chinese researchers
have been urging farmers to adopt new planting methods that could allow them to
grow both soy and corn, but they worry farmers prefer to just stick with what
they're already doing. Experts believe China
could grow self-sufficient in corn production by
the end of the decade. The recombination of
better planting practices, using cornbread to maximize growth, and improving the soil quality. But that would require
embracing new technology and farmer education. - They would have to
grow significantly more in order to be self-sufficient
the way that the U.S. is, and they would have a
long way to go to do that. - [Narrator] For the foreseeable future, China will probably need to keep importing large amounts of corn if
it wants to keep using it in animal feed, but soon, that may no longer
mean buying from the U.S. - China is in the position where they don't have
enough to feed their people, which is why they import from outside. And they've been reliant on us as the primary corn producer in the world even if they really don't
want to do business with us. That's why they're
building trade agreements that you can essentially
go around the U.S. The U.S. doesn't really
have an alternative to China in terms of the buying
power that they have. - [Narrator] Farmers
have seen what can happen when China stops buying
U.S. agricultural goods. When China sharply reduced orders for products like corn
and soybeans in 2018, farms hit record levels of debt despite the U.S. government
responding with billions in aid. If China stops buying us corn again and moves its business
to countries like Brazil, farmers would need to find a replacement. But having to replace a
$5 billion export market could be a major problem for farmers who are already
getting buy on thin margins. (gentle upbeat music)

isn't it to this strategy well yes and no so I mean you know the the the administration understands that you know Vietnam is a non-market economy country and the uh Communist Party of Vietnam basically controls the Vietnamese economy and and pulls levers to make Vietnam to manufacture in Vietnam cheaper to undermine US and other global interests so it Vietnam is not sort of uh viewed in a output.title: TRADER EXPLAINS: Investing Monthly vs. All at Once: The Winner Isâ€¦
output.description:
Dollar Cost Averaging vs Lump Sum Investing: Which is Better? 

In this video, I break down what dollar cost averaging really is, when it works (and doesnâ€™t), and whether it's actually the best way to invest your money in comparison to Lump Sum Investing. 

Youâ€™ll learn:
â€¢ The pros and cons of DCA vs. lump sum investing
â€¢ How much of your paycheck to invest monthly
â€¢ Whether you can "just buy the dips" instead of sticking to a schedule
â€¢ Real-world examples of DCA & Lump Sum in action


Don't forget to Subscribe for more no-BS investing advice.

  
#DollarCostAveraging #LumpSum #InvestingForBeginners #PersonalFinance #InvestingTips
output.tags: #PersonalFinance, what is dollar cost averaging, dollar cost average, dollar cost averaging, lump sum, dca vs lump sum, dca vs lump sum investing, dca vs lump, #LumpSumInvesting, investing, finance, personal finance tips, 401k, investing for beginners, dollar cost averaging explained, dollar cost averaging vs lump sum investing, dollar cost averaging strategy, dollar cost averaging stocks, lump sum vs dollar cost averaging, stock market, how to dollar cost average, seth moran
output.script: question for you is it smarter to invest a little bit at a time with dollar cost averaging or just dump all your money at once with a lump sum strategy because if you're sitting on cash or even just wondering what to do with your paycheck every month this one decision could cost you thousands of dollars over the long run the numbers emphatically say one way is clearly better than the other but I'm going to tell you why I prefer the complete opposite so stick around and we can go over both and you can decide which one is better for you so let's get into it first up dollar cost averaging what is it well it's simple you invest a fixed amount of money say $500 at regular intervals like every week or every month no matter what the Market's doing when the prices are low you're buying more stock cuz it's cheaper when the prices are high you're buying less stock because the price is actually now more expensive per share now over time that could lower your average cost per share from a vwap or volume weighted average price perspective particularly if the market isn't just going straight up now it's automatic it's consistent and it takes motion out of the equation so is it better than lumpsum investing which essentially is taking all your investable money whether that's 1K 100K or even over a millionar and investing it all at once right into the market now the answer may surprise me lump suum investing outperforms dollar cost averaging about 2third of the time according to a 2012 study done by Vanguard lumpsum investing outperforms dollar cost averaging about 66 to 70% of the time by an average of about 2 to 3% in total return over a 10-year period now that 2 to 3% might not sound huge but over 10 20 30 years it compounds significantly even after 10 years if you invested 100K in the same underlying assets the performance can be significant you can see the lump suum strategy here capturing all the gains because they were fully invested while the DCA strategy missed out on the gains by spreading out their risk and not being fully invested that 3% annual difference results in $57,000 after just a decade purely from compounding now you can visually see the difference in the blue shaded area of the chart that's because markets historically go up over time there is a long bias to the market the earlier you're in the longer your investment is able to compound now at dollar cost averaging you are leaving cash on the sidelines so it's not yielding anything other than the interest in your brokerage or your savings account so your investment is not able to achieve compound growth at its full potential but this is where it twists a bit dollar cost averaging isn't about maximizing every dollar it's about Building A system that helps you actually take action because let's be honest how many people stay on the sidelines scared to get in or waiting for the perfect entry price stricken with the case of analysis paralysis in this case dollar cost averaging wins because Behavior beats map so how much should you DCA every month well if you can swing it the professionals advise about 15 to 20% of your gross monthly income but the real answer is whatever you can afford what you cannot afford to do is stay uninvested and sitting on cash automated make it boring why because boring gets rich and if you're investing through a 401k or an IRA every month you're already dollar cost averaging you're winning despite see of red you've been swimming it in the past month stay calm carry on keep investing on a regular basis because that is the key so let's go over a couple examples example one this is one where dollar cost averaging works perfectly you invest $500 a month over 6 months now the market dips Midway through and then rebounds you bought more shares at the low and less at the High and when prices rise again your average cost is lower and your gains are higher see that's the perfect DCA setup now let's go to another example in this example dollar cost averaging will underperform lump sum so you take the same $500 a month but the market keeps on Rising each month you're buying fewer and fewer shares if You' invested a lump sum up front you'd have earned more so in this case both strategies are making money but lump sum is to clear winner now the big question I get asked all the time is do I have to stick to regular intervals or can I just buy on dips they technically dollar cost averaging is all about consistency but yes if you're not watching every tick of the market then I would tell you stick to the game plan inv that's the same amount every month eyes closed Left Foot Right Foot carry on that's it but if you're a stock jockey and you're always tuned in current events and you're trading consistently then no I would suggest a more hybrid approach and this is kind of more of the camp that I would fall in I call it tactical DCA so you invest a set amount each month and you keep a little cash on the side and when the market drops 5 to 10% or more you get in there and you buy the dip you get the discipline of dollar cost averaging and the upside of opportunistic buying so you don't just fall into the Trap of waiting around for the perfect dip That Never Comes that's called Market timing or being Dr Wall Street and it's where most people lose by missing out so is dollar cost averaging the smartest way to invest well for me it makes things mechanical and habitual with less emotion you don't have to worry about timing and if you're a new investor it's the perfect way to safely and comfortably get involved with investing again though it depends on you and if your nerves about volatility and you need structure then dollar cost averaging is your best friend now if you've got a lump sum of money that's sitting around and you've got the stomach for some ups and downs the statistical data is behind you and says go all in my view here is you have to know what the theme of the market is now if it's a bare Market or volatile market then dollar cost averaging is a better option because you're investing on a regular basis and you're catching those dips if the Market's on a bull run then lump suum investing is the best bet because it gets you money in the market quickly with momentum and then the power of comp finding interest can begin but whatever you do pick a plan and stick with it cuz that's how real wealth is built thanks for watching I'm stth Moran I spent 20 years on a street professionally trading a ton of stock and now I try and help everyday investors like you guys take the fear out of investing by answering the questions you want to know but you're not sure how or who to ask now if you like the vibe subscribe for similar type content distributed weekly and hit that like button it does help me build and grow so I greatly appreciate it and if you've tried DCA or you still sitting on Cas wondering if you should go all in or not drop a comment below and let me know what you're trying to do and don't be afraid to fire any other investment related questions you might have down there as well especially if there's something that you want me to do a deep dive on for a future video remember kindness is the rent we pay on Earth so do something nice for some see you in the next one [Music]

output.title: How do we create a better economy?
output.description:
Explore the model known as doughnut economics, which aims to meet the needs of people without overshooting Earth's ecological limits.

--

Can we call any economy â€œhealthyâ€ in the face of dwindling resources and growing inequality? What if we cut off our addiction to endless growth, and used a new compass for modern prosperity? One such compass is known as â€œdoughnut economics,â€ which aims to meet the needs of people without overshooting Earth's ecological limits. Explore how this model reframes our economic systems.

This video is based on interview excerpts from the TED Interview podcast. The episode is called â€œKate Raworth argues that rethinking economics can save our planetâ€
Listen to the full episode or read the transcript here: https://www.ted.com/talks/the_ted_interview_kate_raworth_argues_that_rethinking_economics_can_save_our_planet
