output.script: >> Welcome back to Squawk Box. From the state of the stock market to major companies rolling back Dei policies. There's so much going on in our next guest says concerns loom for business leaders because many fear losing access, influence and potentially attracting retribution. I want to talk about all of these things, to discuss everything that's going on in our economy, what it means to be a CEO today. Former Blackstone president CEO Tony James. Also, we should mention the chairman of retailer Costco, and we can get a pulse on what's going on with the state of the consumer as well. Good morning to you. Good morning Andrew okay. So I'm I'm just curious your sort of sense of confidence in today's economy relative to what we're seeing in the stock market. What is what's your sort of gut on what's happening here? >> I think the economy is weakening. It didn't. >> Have a lot. >> Of. >> Momentum, but it was okay. But it's definitely starting. >> To turn down. >> I think the consumer there's several warning signs. Confidence was down. Obviously the base. >> Of consumers. >> That are driving spending is narrowed to affluent defaults. Delinquencies are rising. Meme stocks are down. There's a lot of things to say. The consumer is starting to buckle a little bit. At the same time, I think the uncertainty coming out of Washington is causing businesses to slow down. What's my supply chain going to cost? I don't know, can I export? Are they going to be reciprocal duties? I don't know, should I. >> Build another plant? >> Let's wait and see. >> Okay. So just help me with this because there feels like there's a disconnect. We've had so many business leaders come on our air. I would say over the last 2 or 3 months and say, oh my goodness, we're going to become unshackled by regulations that are just going to disappear. We are excited about, you know, taxes, all sorts of things. Right? I mean, you've heard that over and over again. So explain that with the perspective that you're offering right now. >> Well. >> There's certainly been an. >> Ambulance about my Republican friends who are business leaders. I agree, one of the greatest errors of American history is going to unleash the deals business and so on and so forth. I don't see it happening. I mean. >> On the. >> Ground. I actually think we are slowing. >> And for all the. >> Reasons I mentioned, I think business leaders are very reluctant to stick their head up right now and start start complaining. >> Hey, Tony, just what we've heard over the last week from a lot of the retailers that have been reporting their earnings, is that they're cautious about this next year that's coming up. But the results they saw in December and even in January have been stronger than they had anticipated. The consumers have been doing better. What do you see? Maybe through Costco, maybe through other places, that makes you think that the consumer is actually already starting to turn down? >> I don't think I see it at Costco, honestly, but I'd say they generally target a. >> More affluent consumer. >> The average Costco consumer has about two times the national median average of wages, and those results are holding up. Are they exceeding expectations like you said, Becky? No. >> But they're. >> Holding Home Depot and Lowe's in the last two days, have both said that they've exceeded their own expectations on some of these things. And January was pretty strong for Walmart. >> January was butt. Walmart also blew a caution whistle on the future. >> Yeah. >> I'd say Costco is hanging in there, but that's not where we that's not where we where we see the slowdown. It's in confidence. Ironically, something like as simple as egg prices seem to have a lot of correlation with the economy and consumer attitudes. And obviously, you know where those are going. >> Well, that's we know why they're there. It's a total one off. But do you think that we were overregulated the economy in business during the Biden administration? You think only Republican business people are optimistic about a more friendly regulatory environment for business? You don't think there's anything to that? >> No. I totally agree with you. I think all business executives felt we were overregulated, honestly. And I think there's both Republicans and Democrats. There's a lot of good things that they like about the directions that President Trump is going, okay. However, there's also a lot of uncertainty, tariffs and a lot of variability. And it's very hard if you're a business to plan. Right now, we own a fertilizer company that's that sells a lot into Canada. We were going to build a new plant. Now we're holding off. We don't if there's duties on Canada and the reciprocal duties coming back, we don't know what that does to us. Similarly, a lot of our companies, the supply chains are completely up in the air. What's what's the cost of goods and how. >> That's all tariff related is where a lot of these. >> Related some of that we have we have plenty of health care companies that are looking at much lower regulatory approvals with Doge and everything. So if you had if you're a if you're a biotech company and you had one year's worth of runway in your cash, now maybe you have to slow things down, stretch it out. So you have two years. >> They already are assuming that cuts at the FDA are going to make. >> We have. >> To put advisory panels, or they. >> Have to assume that because running out of money is death. >> The cuts. Have there been cuts already at the FDA that would cause clinical trials to be delayed? >> Not I don't. >> Know, actually, but that's not really the concern. No one's going to count the cuts. It's the chaos down there. It's the it's the reduced. >> You see any positives to trying to rein in government waste? >> 100%. >> You do. >> Every one of the last fiv presidents. Both parties have said government is too big. I'll cut it back. And they failed. And I think this is a lot like Elon's approach to say, Tesla cut maybe over cut, cut radically. And then if you cut too much, you can add it back. And that's the only way you make significant cost. >> And so do you think he's right about that. And I ask because the other thing is he said, and I don't know whether voters listen to this or not. He explicitly said before the election that there was going to be pain. There was going to be now. He suggested it was a temporary pain because he thinks it on the other side. It's going to be better. But the question is whether, you know, we are going to, quote unquote, suffer for six months or a year and that there's, you know, a rainbow on the other side. >> Well, there's a lot of stuff thrown in here together. So let's just separate it out a little bit. There's certainly the business community is certainly, I think, 100% for less regulation. It's less government waste. Tariffs. If tariffs can have a very good effect, if they're used as a bargaining chip to get other deals, and if they're used to lower barriers from other countries, if it triggers a trade war, that's a different thing. So the tariffs is a little hard to know which way it goes. Is it beneficial? Is it not. However, all those things, if your business executive right now, you don't know the path of the future. So that causes you to hold back on things temporarily. So I threw the business in there. I think the consumer is suffering. Confidence is coming down, but business is not providing

output.title: Will smart glasses eventually replace smartphones? | BBC News
output.description:
Smart glasses are often praised for being the next step on from the smartphone.
  
Maybe weâ€™ll use them for calls and messages, and all sorts of information will flash up before our eyes, as sound is directed into our ears.  
 
This year, the Consumer Electronics Show floor in Las Vegas was awash with smart glasses. 
 
BBC Clickâ€™s Lara Lewington tested some of them out.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news

TIMESTAMPS

output.tags: planet fitness app, planet fitness app review, planet fitness app tutorial, planet fitness app how to use, planet fitness equipment scanner, planet fitness perks, planet fitness perk discounts, planet fitness black card, planet fitness black card guest, planet fitness check in, planet fitness how to check in, planet fitness app workout, planet fitness workouts, planet fitness workout app, planet fitness apple watch, barcode planet fitness app, how to scan planet fitness
output.script: want to learn more about the Planet Fitness app in today's video I'm going to explain all the different things you can do with it and show you how it works let's get started after you join Planet Fitness as a member you'll be prompted to download the app and create an account crowd meter something you might want to do before you head over to Planet Fitness is see how crowded the gym is on the home screen you'll see a crowd meter beneath your home location the crowd meter indicates how busy the gym is if you tap on it you'll get a more detailed view that shows you crowd history so you can get a sense of when the gym is busiest the thing is there aren't any values attached to these purple lines so you can only make an assessment based on how short or tall these lines are Club info in the same screen for crowd meter you'll see Club information so you can see the address phone number Club hours holiday hours and a list of all the amenities that specific gym has if you want to find another club's information tap the find a club button which brings you to a screen where you can enter your address City or zip code and see all the locations nearby checkin one of the most important features of the Planet Fitness app is that it can serve as a way to check into to the gym when you open the Planet Fitness app tap the check-in button which will open a QR code screen that you can use to scan in at the front desk perk discounts underneath benefits you'll see a button for perk discounts tap on that and you'll see all the different perks and discounts you can get as a Planet Fitness member there are featured perks you can swipe through as well as categories you can browse tapping on any of these categories will filter all the relevant perks in that category you you can tap on any perk you want to get more information on and learn how you can redeem the offer some of these perks are only available to Planet finest blackard members which is the Premier membership you can learn more about in the video in the top right and those perks are indicated by the purple PF blackard Banner blackard guest back at the home screen if you're a Planet Fitness blackard member you'll be able to bring guests to the gym by tapping the blackard guest button underneath benefits here you'll be able to add a new guest and unlock their Club passes by toggling the lock icon I explain more about this in the video in the top right refer a friend if you tap the show all across from benefits on the home screen you'll see a button to refer a friend here you'll learn more about the referral program that gets you a free month for every friend you refer with the ability to refer three friends a year tapping share this deal pre-populates a message you can send to your friend and if you want to see how many referrals and free months you've earned you can see that information by tapping the my referrals button virtual tour at the bottom of the home screen you'll see a virtual tour button that brings you to a playlist of short videos discussing different areas and pieces of equipment in the gym workouts on the home screen or by tapping on the workouts tab at the bottom you'll see guided workouts you can perform at Planet Fitness some of the workouts are follow along videos whereas others are written out for you to perform with demonstrations if you want to perform these workouts at the gym I recommend searching for an open space and Gathering the equipment you'll need here's me demonstrating a follow along video workout and here's me following a listed workout using a medicine ball underneath work workouts there are categories for abs and core full body upper body lower body mind and body and tutorials the mind and body category consists of educational segments on Concepts such as heart health and the benefits of sleep exercise tutorials in the workouts tab by tapping tutorials at the top or scrolling down to exercise tutorials you'll see a list of tutorials on how to use different machines and pieces of equipment tapping on an exercise shows a looped video of the exercise being performed as well as details about the exercise equipment scanner at the bottom of the workouts tab there's a button for scan and learn that opens your camera and prompts you to scan a QR code on any piece of equipment you want more information about however I tried using this feature and scanning machine's QR code prompted me to download the Life Fitness app which then prompted me to create an account and provide a whole lot of information only to ultimately not work every time I scanned the QR code it just brought me to the Life Fitness app and provided no information on the machine let me know in the comments if this is the experience you have with the equipment scanner if that's how it is for everyone I recommend just getting the name of the machine such as back extension and searching for it in the exercise tutorial section schedule a class if you're plan to Fitness host classes you'll be able to schedule them here on the app Fitness education Fitness education will show you a lot of the Mind and Body classes that consist of educational topics and more track your fitness journey near the bottom of the home screen or on the my journey tab at the bottom you'll be able to track your fitness journey tap the purple track activity button and you'll see tabs for gym activities and other activities which you can log in track tapping on my activities at the top will show you a breakdown of all of your activity by week month or year as well as all of your gym checkins you can also add information about what your personal motivation is so it's always there to refer to you can only choose one of these so you'll have to add what you think is the most important same for what your target is you can also update your Fitness profile which includes your weight height and experience level what you choose here influences the workouts that are shown to you in the home screen Fitness tracker you'll also be able to connect to Fitness tracker to the app but all I see is connecting to Apple Health which I suppose if you've connected other wearables to Apple Health you'll be able to sync those activities account info aside from all the workout related things you can do on the Planet Fitness app you can also access your account information by tapping on the profile icon on the top left of the home screen here you can view and update your personal details membership and billing information as well as access the features I described earlier there's also a web link to the Planet Fitness Store now if you want some more guidance on how to use the different machines of Planet Fitness watch this playlist on the top right thanks for watching

input: main idea: Produce a playful and educational kidsâ€™ video about launching a toy rocket ship to space, introducing basic space concepts in an imaginative adventure format..

output.title: Flying ride on kids rocket ship to launch satellite in space for eclipse. Educational | Kid Crew
output.description:
In this video we pretend to be an astronaut and head to space in our ride on kids rocket ship to prepare for the solar eclipse! We're putting down the power wheels for the day to fly high in our solar system. We also play with our Lego space toys inside! 

First, we arrive at the space shuttle launch pad and receive our mission. Launch a satellite to study space before the total solar eclipse. We open the rocket's canopy and buckle up. We raise the launch platform and grab the joysticks as the launch sequence initiates. 3 2 1 liftoff! The ride on rocket ship blasts into the sky and soon we are in space. This is way faster than any of our trucks. We open the cargo bay doors and deploy the satellite just in time for the eclipse. Then we head to Mars in our rocket ship to pick up some space garbage. We make a smooth landing and then collect the trash. We hop back in our rocket after walking on the martian surface and head back to earth. Its a successful mission! After cleaning up that mess, we head inside to play with our Lego space toy sets. First an out of control satellite collides with a space shuttle and then crashes on the moon. The space shuttle is OK, and calls mission control for help. A rocket is deployed and goes to the moon to collect the satellite with the help of a rover team. They find the wreckage and head back to earth. They splash down in the bath tub where a boat is ready to retrieve them.  In the educational segment we learn how a solar eclipse works with a moving diorama in the back yard. Remember, don't look at an eclipse without approved eclipse glasses. 

Come pretend play with us! Join us kids, toddlers, girls, and boys as we use our ride on toy trucks, toy tractors, and toy equipment to do construction, farming, and home improvement pretend play projects. While we play our games and drive our vehicles, we learn about engineering, science, STEM, and how things work in our educational segment. Thank you for watching Kid Crew! 

Please note, the appearance of U.S. Department of Defense (DoD) visual information does not imply or constitute DoD endorsement. 

Fire in cover and in video by imrulkayesng from Pngtree.com 

Richard Strauss, Also Sprach Zarathustra, by Kevin MacLeod is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported license

output.script: that's my goat right there i mean he's everybody's goat and it's not that Vulk being the greatest featherweight of all time was in question but man just add a massive capstone moment to his legacy if he retired tomorrow or loses that thing outright next time he fights there will still be that incredible win over Lopez last night to recapture the title after that devastating run that marked the demise of his initial title reign that is forever now it's MMA cannon and one of the best highlights of Alex's career i would put that equal to if not on a higher level than Randy Couture coming out of retirement to beat Tim Sylvia even though he was I believe 87 years old on the night i know that is a very bold statement but Randy had been defying age and odds most of his career and no offense to Tim Sylvia but it felt like oh the reasonQur was able to almost identically to Vulk show up a year after losing a title fight only to again capture gold in glorious fashion is because the heavyweight division was in shambles and Sylvia was at the top of it but I digress vulcganowski came into that fight last night at 36 years old he was the poster child for age catching up with you as a fighter in fact the two videos we've done recently about aging in the UFC have featured Vulk in the thumbnail it's such a cliche now but it's a cliche because it's largely true father Time is undefeated nobody has two primes except for George Foreman all that stuff and I'm not saying this is going to lay the groundwork for another long and prosperous title reign for Alexander the Great but who knows the guy is incredible and he certainly seemed ambitious in his hopes to go back to being a fighting champion so I suppose we shall see how long that can hold up but again this isn't about the future this is about last night to come in after the losses he'd faced backto back that short notice devastating headkick KO by Islam the second round knockout by Ilia to lose his featherweight title and then to have sat on those losses for over a year to have every single pundant and fan point out that at Vulk's age statistically it's incredibly unlikely he's ever going to hold gold again and then to carry all of that out there against an absolute animal in Diego Lopez just about as good a representative of the new guard as you could get and still put on the performance he did through five rounds despite getting knocked down despite getting some bad cuts despite getting some serious pressure from Lopez that was a hard fight and Vulk could have easily crumbled under the pressure under the weight of everything he brought into the cage but he still went out there and he fought like it was 2021 again that is the stuff of legends i couldn't be happier for Vulk even though it wasn't reclaiming his gold from Taporia it really was probably the next best thing but truly that fight wasn't about the opponent diego was an element of the story but that was Vulk versus Vulk vulk versus time and he beat everybody's ass last night and as for what's next I mean I guess we'll see air seemed pretty adamant that he'd be getting a title shot off that win over Patriceio Pitbull and maybe that is in the works personally I don't want to see that rematch just yet but the suggestion that Rogan had Lord Silva and El Pantara throwing down to see who fights Vulk next man sign me up for that one we can let Alex rest for a bit there's no rush right now in that division now as awesome as Vulk's win was a story that was absolutely worthy of the top of the video and its title and thumbnail we got to talk about Patty the BD and that is truly the first time I personally have ever felt that way i know oftentimes fans have strong reactions to how we at OnPoint feel about Pimpblelett however you think it is we feel about him but full disclosure he's never been for me personally one that I felt I needed to think of as a potential mainenter i just wasn't into it until last night it was truly the perfect win patty came out there with the typical swagger the intangible stuff that sells tickets but we've seen that plenty that was never in question it was whether or not he's an elite fighter and I think he earned the right to get a chance to prove that and as someone who has looked at Patty's previous wins and said "Well who were any of those early guys he fought?" The judges absolutely gifted him the Jared Gordon win tony Ferguson was in no place to be considered a test for anybody as much as I hate to say that and again with all due respect to King Green these were just not elite fights they weren't and so the non-believer in me going into this week already had caveats in my head and it's hard to say but Michael Chandler hasn't exactly had the best run in the UFC so if Patty narrowly defeated him or Chandler did something really overly aggressive and got himself caught I was fully ready to say well still not much of a test but that's not at all how I feel in fact I think given the trouble that Chandler has had at the top of the UFC if you're going to be a title contender that is exactly the kind of victory you should be having over Mike he kicked the [Â __Â ] out of him that was the best that Patty has ever looked in the octagon and now I'm fully intrigued to see him in a title eliminator against somebody in that top five the performance has finally caught up with the swagger and the annoying fans with the wigs and all that stuff if somebody like me who never really found much interest in him is excited for his next fight for the first time that fight is going to be huge and special especially if he can perform like that again we've seen this story play out a bunch of times and it's really simple if your hype was massive coming in like Patty's was there's got to be that moment that you prove your hype that you finally get skeptical fans on board and Pimpblelet just had that all right so Patty and Vulk were the two big narratives coming out of 314 but it wasn't the only thing that happened in a hot night in Miami so let's look at the numbers this thing produced and pass out some awards to wrap this thing up the UFC's fourth ever trip to Vice City saw 13 fights with six KO TKOs's two submissions five decisions for a total cage time of 2 hours 22 minutes 47 seconds it was almost all favorites 11 earned wins by the end of the evening with dogs defying the odds just two times a big time bet for you would have been choosing Lord Silva taking out Bryce Mitchell via submission in the second round because it was a plus 2800 outcome massive payout there when Dominic Reyes wins a fight it's by knockout at least that has been the trend going all the way back to 2019 dom's four victories in that time including the one last night and the three he's had backto back are all KO TKOs's that is five in a row for Lord Silva in the UFC with five finishes going back to his debut early last year what a [Â __Â ] nerd give that man our near future main event award that was Pit Bull's first decision loss in a three- round fight since 2010 the guy who beat him tonight Yaier Rodriguez was 17 years old at the time speaking of that's El Pantara's first victory in over 2 years also dude was jacked out of his mind no stat there just shredded like a Julianne salad that was the seventh straight win for Patty the Batty in the UFC and the biggest by a huge margin that gives Pimpblelet the second longest win streak in the lightweight division behind none other than champion Islam dude is one away from a title shot he called the crowd a bunch of mushrooms what a night for Liverpool michael Chandler is now officially two and five in the UFC his only victories Dan Hooker and Tony Ferguson and finally in our main event that was the biggest strike differential ever scored against Diego Lopez that was Alex's 10th title fight in a row going back to 2019 hard to fall off when you're at the very top and as they mentioned on the broadcast Vulk became the first fighter over 35 under 155 to ever win a world title earning him our get [Â __Â ] father time award my kids these days no respect and that is 314 all done and dusted i cannot thank Max Randall enough for his legendary run on these autopsies gets them done faster than should be humanly possible please show him all the love on his socials and go check out his fantastic YouTube channel a huge thank you to our channel members as well your support is what makes this kind of video so possible if you want to become a member hit the join button there's a single price tier and exclusive content like and subscribe because we do these after every single pay-per-view sound off in the comments everything you thought of last night's card and thank you so much for watching catch you again next time fight fans [Music]

output.script: oh my god Oh my gosh Oh my goodness Oh my gosh At approximately 3:17 this afternoon we began receiving multiple calls for a helicopter that crashed in the water These calls generated the response of many agencies as Deputy Mayor Dory stated including uh FDNY NYPD the Port Authority and our Jersey partners uh the police officers in Jersey as well and the Coast Guard Uh three adults and three children were on board a Bell 206 helicopter that had left from the downtown skyport just about 300 p.m The pilot and a family visiting from Spain with our preliminary information as at this time members of the FDNY and NYPD harbor units arrived at the scene and divers from both agencies entered the water At this time all six victims have been removed from the water and sadly all six victims have been pronounced deceased Again we're praying for the families and our gratitude uh to the rescuers and the courage that was displayed in their dedication NYPD units from aviation harbor scuba and patrol all responded with our first units arriving at the site within minutes Our NYPD divers entered the water along with rescue personnel from FDNY Port Authority and various New Jersey agencies According to the manifest aboard the helicopter were six people one pilot two adults and three children NYPD divers pulled four people from the crash site and FDNY divers recovered an additional two Immediate life-saving measures were undertaken on the vessels at the scene as well as the adjoining pier Four victims were pronounced dead on scene and two more were removed to local area hospitals where sadly both succumbed to their injuries Here is what we know about the flight and this is based on uh flight tracking software A Bell 206 helicopter flying for the tour company New York Helicopters took off from the downtown Manhattan Helport at 2:59 p.m The aircraft flew south before turning to fly north along the Manhattan shoreline up the Hudson River At 3:08 p.m the helicopter reached the George Washington Bridge and then turned again to fly south along the New Jersey Shoreline shoreline Shortly thereafter the aircraft lost control and hit the water just a few feet off the coast of Pier A Park in Hoboken The cause of the crash is currently under investigation

output.title: Story of Mission Chandrayaan-3 | India Creates History | Success of ISRO | Lunar Soft Landing
output.description:
Chandrayaan-3 is a follow-on mission to Chandrayaan-2 to demonstrate end-to-end capability in safe landing and roving on the lunar surface. It consists of Lander and Rover configuration. It will be launched by LVM3 from SDSC SHAR, Sriharikota. The propulsion module will carry the lander and rover configuration till 100 km lunar orbit. The propulsion module has Spectro-polarimetry of Habitable Planet Earth (SHAPE) payload to study the spectral and Polari metric measurements of Earth from the lunar orbit.
Chandrayaan-3 consists of an indigenous Lander module (LM), Propulsion module (PM) and a Rover with an objective of developing and demonstrating new technologies required for Inter planetary missions. The Lander will have the capability to soft land at a specified lunar site and deploy the Rover which will carry out in-situ chemical analysis of the lunar surface during the course of its mobility. The Lander and the Rover have scientific payloads to carry out experiments on the lunar surface.

output.script: go go go go go go [Music] yay yay finally isro's hard work paid off a great achievement for humankind that's a great question so in today's episode let us take you and our curious audience to the Dark Side of the Moon by narrating the story off of Mission chandrayaan 3 zoom in chandrayaan an incredible series of lunar Explorations by ISRO the Indian space research organization has brought us closer to the mysteries of the Moon the first mission chandrayaan 1 launched in 2008 was a breakthrough as it discovered water on the moon changing the way we perceive our Celestial neighbor however the real surprise was Yet to Come chandrayaan 2 launched in 2019 was designed with an Orbiter a Lander named Vikram and a small robot called pragyan unfortunately during its Landing attempt Vikram lost contact and couldn't reach the moon's surface as planned due to a small error K7 the then chairman of ISRO described this nerve-wracking process as the 15 minutes of Terror forest team setback was not only disheartening for the ISRO scientists but also a poignant moment for the entire nation yes ISRO didn't succumb to despair instead they embraced the challenge learn from their mistakes and immediately embarked on their next venture Chandra yarn 3 turn on the remarkable day of July 14 2023 the powerful LV M3 heavy lift rocket lifted off flawlessly from sriharikota space station in Andhra Pradesh carrying the Chandra young 3 spacecraft with the Vikram Lander and the pragyan Rover on board this spacecraft had a special mission of 41-day Journey To The Moon as projected on August 23 2023 at 604 PM India's Standard Time the Vikram Lander gently touched down to the moon's surface perfectly The Landing was so gentle so smooth that it felt like the moon itself was giving a warm hug to the spacecraft this kind of Landing is called a soft landing and chandrayaan 3 executed it flawlessly following this historic moment India joined an elite club of Space Explorers the United States the Soviet Union and China who had successfully sent robotic crafts to land on the moon but wait there's more to the story this Landing was different from the others why that's because chandrayantri landed on the moon's South polar region a spot that no one had ever touched before after the landing chandrayant III waited for the lunar dust to settle and then the pragyan Rover rolled out of the Lander and started taking a walk on the moon then pragyan studied the elements available on the South Pole of the Moon and confirmed the presence of sulfur oxygen aluminum calcium and more the detection of sulfur holds particular significance as it's a relatively uncommon element on the moon its occurrence in the lunar South polar region suggests the potential existence of water ice a critical factor for future lunar missions and potential human settlements the findings underscore the importance of lunar exploration in advancing our knowledge of the universe as the Quest for knowledge continues the global Community eagerly anticipates further Revelations from the Indian space research organization trivia time did you know the first discovery of water on the moon was made by the isros chandrayaan one mission 3 discovered a temperature drop from around 50 degrees Celsius on the moon's surface to -10 degrees Celsius just 80 millimeters below it sketching time today's sketch of the day goes to yotam and Opry hope you had fun today until next time it's me Dr binox zooming out [Music] what are you building Kitty [Music]

output.title: Eyeing China, Trump Unveils Sixth-Gen Stealth F-47 Fighter Jet | Vantage with Palki Sharma | N18G
output.description:
Eyeing China, Trump Unveils Sixth-Gen Stealth F-47 Fighter Jet | Vantage with Palki Sharma | N18G

US President Donald Trump unveiled a new sixth generation stealth fighter jet for the US Air Force this weekend. The aircraft, F-47, will be made by Boeing, which has won the contract for making a stealth fighter jet for the first time. Details about the F-47 are yet to be fully declared, however it is expected to cost more than $300 Million per unit. The F-47 is meant to replace the F-22 in the US Air Force. The announcement comes months after China flew two prototypes of sixth generation stealth fighters which are being called as J-36 and J-50. Will Boeing be able to recover from its dwindling reputation and deliver on these modern jets? Palki Sharma tells you.

output.title: Anatomy of an economic collapse | Yanis Varoufakis on the hypocrisy of the Global Financial Crisis
output.description:
Yanis Varoufakis analyses the 2008 Financial Crisis and the dark heart of our modern economic systems.

With the stock market crashing and a trade war well under way, could we be facing a situation similar to the 2008 Financial Crisis?

With a free trial, you can watch the full debate NOW at https://iai.tv/video/economic-fact-and-economic-fantasy?utm_source=YouTube&utm_medium=description

Although there has been a recent fall, central banks are widely seen to have failed to control inflation. At times running up to six times target, the banks blamed the Ukraine war, but critics point to the rapid rise in inflation before war broke out, and amongst other factors often find quantitative easing at fault. Moreover, some claim there is a more fundamental problem that there is no overall coherent economic theory in the first place. Bank models failed to predict the 2008 crash or the more recent cost of living crisis. In 2015, the European Central Bank claimed that neither monetarist nor Keynesian economics provided solutions to the financial crisis, leading some to question if any economic theory had the answers.

Should we conclude that central bank failures to predict, let alone avoid, economic crises are evidence of a deep underlying flaw in their understanding? Or were banks just negligent in their failure to respond to evidence of rising inflation? Do we need a radical new economic theory or should we conclude that the economy is not predictable, forecasting a mugs game, and the options for government policy wider than commonly supposed?

#economics  #financialcrisis  #YanisVaroufakis

Join Yanis Varoufakis, former finance minister of Greece, John Redwood Conservative MP, and Vicky Pryce, chief economics adviser to the Centre of Economics and Business Research. Hosted by the BBC's Roger Hearing.

The Institute of Art and Ideas features videos and articles from cutting edge thinkers discussing the ideas that are shaping the world, from metaphysics to string theory, technology to democracy, aesthetics to genetics. Subscribe today! https://iai.tv/subscribe?utm_source=YouTube&utm_medium=description&utm_campaign=https://iai.tv/video/economic-fact-and-economic-fantasy

output.script: I recently just got a Twitter account and I know what you're saying I've missed the hype train it has been going downhill since the Takeover by Elon Musk I know there's Alternatives like blue sky like Macedon that are becoming super popular but I wanted a place where I can you know get more software engineering news like upto-date live news and Twitter is still the biggest platform for this kind of information besides like YouTube and on Twitter there's a feature called communities which is similar to Facebook groups if you ever remember those and communities are essentially groups of people focused on one topic so I joined some that are about software engineering some about C programming some about Java they have strict rules on what tweets you can make and not make inside of those communities but essentially they're focused on just like this one topic and I kept all of mine towards software engineering and my entire feed was software Engineers but one Trend I noticed going crazy was Vibe coding and if you don't know what that is don't worry I'm going to explain it to you but to do that let me show you one of the most popular things I saw on my feed looking at this PL game you might be wondering is this a new game created by a Indie Dev trying his feet in the water trying to create a new project trying to learn or is it a new student maybe someone on the younger side trying to become a Game Dev themselves but not exactly this is a project made by a prolific Vibe coder made in a matter of hours for the sole reason of making a profit when starting up the game you're instantly presented with an option to purchase an F16 for this game for $29.99 that's more than some games cost some full Triple G A games on sale so this brings me back to the main question what is Vibe coding it's the process of using AI to generate a project as quickly as possible with the least amount of effort on your end to then quickly turn it around and make a profit and I know some Vibe coders actually do this to solve their own problems and not push a profit however there's a large vocal group that that's their only goal like this Vibe coder flexing on all of us peasants from first class while making a project using Claude turns out it was a calorie tracking app that he was going to charge $19 a month for until he was called out for it and then was going to charge $49 until quot un quote the beta ends and that previously mentioned rudimentary airplane game it generates around $67,000 a month majority of which is from advertising as you can see from the blimps and other objects around in the game and I'm not saying there's anything wrong with trying to make a product Market it and then try to make a profit even if it's with AI the problem is with Vibe coding and Vibe coders they don't maintain their projects and I fear that they might not be able to maintain their projects fly Peter is nearly unplayable I run a 3070 and I experience bug after bug crash after crash basic game mechanics that would probably take 5 minutes of research and probably 5 minutes of implementations like collisions don't work my assumption is that the game got too out of hand and the AI is no longer able to fix these bugs and since this game was Vibe coded and only made through AI prompts he most likely doesn't understand the codebase well enough to fix this and he's also not an experienced Game Dev to understand how to resolve these bugs quickly and that is completely fine I am not a Game Dev either and I would love to make a video game but I don't think Vibe coding is the process to make any long-term project you will no longer be able to maintain your own code you aren't learning anything new and your product is going to suffer in the end the success of fly Peter other Vibe coding projects came out like this tank game and it's riddled with even more bugs and even more problems funny enough an experienced game developer noticed that every time a tank shoots it grabs the audio file from the server every single time instead of caching it on local and initially to someone without experience it might not sound that bad but with a little bit of research and a little bit of work and learning you'd realize that is a very inefficient method and you should instead cash the sound on the machine the continue continue on none of these projects are open source we can't even take a look at how they're implemented there's very little open source contribution made by these projects instead it really is a goal of only monetizing I actually tried asking for a GitHub repo from one of these projects and I got ghosted um it wasn't from specifically fly Peter or any of the projects I showed here but there has been no GitHub repo no links that I can find to see what the quality of the source code actually is and that also brings up the question of security for these Vibe coded SAS apps we can't take a look at the source code we don't know if the developers of these Vibe coded apps actually know best security practices and I think that's my main gripe with Vibe coding it's because code is seen as a nuisance as an obstacle to overcome to push a product and make as much money as possible there isn't any passion or love for the code or the implementation of the product and that's not every Vibe coder I'm sure that the majority actually want to learn from this code but a lot of that is overshadowed by trying to churn out as many products as quick as possible and ironically one of the most successful Vibe coded projects I found was a course on how to code and maybe I'm just too obsessed with code and computers and I'm jealous of all of the profits that these people people are able to make but I disagree with the vibe coding mentality of disregarding the code and the process and trying to just optimize and push out products as quick as possible but that's ironic coming from me since I'm A vibe video maker though if you like this video and before I get flexed on by thousands of vibe coders making tens of thousands of dollars more than me please like And subscribe and thanks for watching

output.title: What the Apollo 11 Site Looks Like Today
output.description:
Get Exclusive NordVPN Deal Here: https://nordvpn.com/neovpn

Follow neo on social media:
Twitter: twitter.com/NeoExplains
Facebook: facebook.com/NeoExplains

Watch this video on Nebula:
https://nebula.tv/videos/neo-what-does-the-moon-landing-site-look-like-today

In this video, we will look at what the astronauts of Apollo 11 left behind. With the first people to step foot on the moon, NASA apollo 11 astronauts Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin having left the site, they also left behind different experiments including a seismometer, the laser lunar retroflector and commemorative items such as soviet medals and an apollo 1 mission patch. In this space video I am revisiting a significant historical site, Tranquility Base, that noone has has visited since.
output.tags: moon, nasa, space, neil armstrong, first step on the moon, lunar, scifi, sci-fi, tranquility, base, experiments, 3d animation, explaining, educational, us flag, lunar module, eagle, rocket, apollo 11
output.script:
NASA Radio:"Eagle (this is) Houston, looking good" After 21h and 36m on the surface of the Moon it was time for the first people to walk here, NeilÂ Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin to start heading home NASA Radio: "nine, eight, seven, six, five, abort stage, engine arm ascent, proceed" In this video we will look at what theÂ 
astronauts left behind on what is oneÂ Â  of the most significant historicalÂ 
sites that no one has visited sinceÂ Â  During the astronauts takeoff Buzz Aldrin observedÂ 
the site from a window noticing that the engine'sÂ  spearing exhaust was whirling up Moon dust andÂ 
caused the American flag to tip over fallingÂ Â  to the ground. A special mounting mechanism hadÂ 
been designed for the flag as with no wind on theÂ Â  moon it had to be held upright by a horizontalÂ 
crossbar. The flag itself however made of nylonÂ Â  is not a custom-made product but was orderedÂ 
through the standard government supply catalog In addition to the flag, other commemorativeÂ 
items that serve no scientific purpose wereÂ Â  left on the moon. Attached on the ladder ofÂ 
The Descent stage there is a metal plaqueÂ Â  featuring the signatures of the Apollo 11Â 
crew and then U.S president Richard Nixon The astronauts also placed a number of small objectsÂ 
with symbolic meaning on the surface.Â  These items were stored in a shoulder pocket on Buzz aldrin'sÂ 
spacesuit and he almost forgot to leave them on theÂ Â  moon and was reminded to do so by ArmstrongÂ 
while he was already on the ladder to re-enterÂ Â the lunar module. From there Aldrin dropped theÂ 
objects onto the lunar surface. Part of it was an Apollo 1 Mission patch to honor the astronautsÂ 
that had died in a tragic accident two and a halfÂ Â  years prior. Their cabin had caught fire during aÂ 
launch rehearsal killing all three crew membersÂ Â  The astronauts also left two commemorative medalsÂ 
to honor the Soviet cosmonauts Yuri GagarinÂ Â  and Vladimir komarov: two space PioneersÂ 
that died in different tragic accidentsÂ Â  Even amidst the Cold War the aim wasÂ 
to express mutual respect for thoseÂ Â  who risked their lives for the explorationÂ 
of space. Another object that was placed toÂ Â  express the spirit of internationalÂ 
cooperation is a small silicon diskÂ Â  Tt contains Goodwill messages from the leadersÂ 
of 73 countries around the world. In addition itÂ Â  features the names of Congress members responsibleÂ 
for NASA legislation as well as names of NASA senior staff. The astronauts also left a goldÂ 
Olive Branch as a symbol of Global Peace. Besides these purely symbolic objectsÂ 
we can find instruments that we used forÂ Â  experiments such as this seismometerÂ 
that can measure ground vibrationsÂ Â  The device, powered by solar panels,Â 
records data on the strength, durationÂ Â  and approximate direction of seismicÂ 
events and transmits this data to EarthÂ Â  Unfortunately just three weeks after the moonÂ 
landing the device stopped sending data backÂ Â  presumably because it overheated in the middayÂ 
Sun. The temperature fluctuations between dayÂ Â  and night are much more extreme than on Earth.Â 
This is because the sun's heat is not absorbedÂ Â  by an atmosphere, which could distributeÂ 
it and retain it during the night Further we find another experiment, the lunarÂ 
laser retro reflector, it acts as a special kindÂ Â  of mirror reflecting incoming light in exactlyÂ 
the same direction from which the beam originatesÂ Â  This means scientists on Earth can directÂ 
a laser beam towards this device which willÂ Â  reflect the light back to Earth. Since theÂ 
speed of light is known, this instrument canÂ Â  be used to measure the exact distance betweenÂ 
the Earth and the moon. And it is the mission'sÂ Â  only experiment that still works to this day.
Other experiments that the astronauts carriedÂ Â  out can only be recognized by the tracesÂ 
they left behind. The astronauts took rockÂ samples and drilled into the ground measuring theÂ 
resistance. They also hung up a special sheet forÂ Â  the duration of their stay in order to measureÂ 
the solar wind outside of Earth's magnetosphereÂ Â  Because the astronauts had to bring this sailÂ 
back to Earth, only the pole remains on the moonÂ Â  Close to the Lander we find an area that isÂ 
cluttered with objects. This is the trash weÂ left behind. A number of rock samples were broughtÂ 
back to Earth and in order to be able to take asÂ Â  much as possible of those the astronauts tossedÂ 
away equipment that had already served its purposeÂ Â  Also the black and white camera which hadÂ 
transmitted both the first steps on the moon, and the raising of the flag to a worldwideÂ 
audience stayed behind on the moon In addition to commemorative items, scientificÂ 
experiments, and tossed away equipment, the astronauts left one other thing behind: theirÂ 
footprints, which are often used as a metaphorÂ Â  for the achievement that this journey represents.
The paths that the astronauts took are clearlyÂ Â  visible in the moondust and they reveal one pathÂ 
that was taken far away from the landing siteÂ Â  Towards the end of the extra vehicularÂ 
activity Neil Armstrong took the chanceÂ Â  and went on an unplanned trip toÂ 
the little West crater. After the astronauts left, the site's conditionÂ 
is expected to only change slow, not so much inÂ Â  periods of weeks or months but decades centuriesÂ 
and even greater intervals. And so today more thanÂ Â  53 years after Apollo 11 left, it can be assumedÂ 
that solar radiation has visually changed the siteÂ Â  Without a significant atmosphere to protectÂ 
the moon, the intense ultraviolet radiation ofÂ Â  sunlight will have an impact on the materialsÂ 
used in the mission. It is widely assumed thatÂ Â  the colors of the U.S flag have fadedÂ 
over the years. In addition the materialsÂ Â  were exposed to the extreme temperatureÂ 
fluctuations alternating between 14 daysÂ Â  of 100 degrees celsius heat and then 14 daysÂ 
in the dark at negative 150 degrees celsiusÂ Â  And so it's likely that the nylon flag isÂ 
also tattered and disintegrated as otherÂ Â  materials will have suffered and will be coveredÂ 
in dust. Ultimately however these are assumptionsÂ Â  to the best of our knowledge, what's left is aÂ 
truly fascinating historical site that unlikeÂ Â  archaeological sites on Earth is superblyÂ 
preserved but yet hardly studyable. If you find find yourself far away fromÂ 
home you might notice that your favorite TVÂ Â  shows are not available. That is because theyÂ 
are region locked. Luckily this can simply beÂ Â  avoided by using my sponsor NordVPN, as theirÂ 
service lets you choose from dozens of locationsÂ Â  currently limited to planet Earth. This meansÂ 
you can access sites and streaming content thatÂ Â  is not available in your own country, therebyÂ 
expanding what you get from your subscriptionsÂ Â  And I have also found that it fixes a ton ofÂ 
issues common when browsing while travelingÂ Â  like those websites that automatically defaultÂ 
to the local language and currency, or poorlyÂ Â  implemented login security the results in youÂ 
constantly having to re-authenticate that it'sÂ Â  actually you browsing. NordVPN has been usefulÂ 
for me in tons of different ways and the bestÂ Â  part is that you can try it with no risk.Â 
Nordvpn has a 30-day money-back guaranteeÂ Â  so go ahead and try it for yourself byÂ 
getting an additional four months for freeÂ Â  at nordvpn.com/neovpn or click the link onÂ 
the screen. Thank you so much for watching!

output.title: Hear what a top economist thinks Trump's tariffs will do to the US economy
output.description: President Donald Trump announced a 25 percent tariff on all imported US cars that will go into effect April 3. Trump believes these tariffs will boost US manufacturing, but economist Mark Zandi predicts the tariffs will result in higher prices and less US jobs.  #CNN #News
output.tags: latest news, Happening Now, Trump Tariffs, President Donald Trump, Trump Administration, Canada Tariffs, Mexico Tariffs, Inflation, US Economy, Canadian Prime Minister, Canadian Government, Canada US Relations, Dairy Tariff, Lumber Tariff, Mark Carney, Canada Liberal Party, Toronto, Melanie Joly, Auto Tariffs, Kate Bolduan, CNN News Central, Mark Zandi, Becky Anderson, Connect the World, Allison Stewart, CNNB, CNN Business
output.script: How about this for a warning from one auto industry expert? The price of new cars in the U.S. will skyrocket in coming weeks, and maybe even sooner than you think. After President Trump announced 25% tariffs are coming on all cars and car parts shipped to the U.S., there's probably not a vehicle on the market today that wouldn't be affected in some form or fashion by tariffs. Leaders of some of America's biggest trading partners, also known as some of America's closest allies, are pushing back hard overnight. About this try on another warning for size from the Premier of Ontario, Doug Ford, that 65 billion of tariffs that we have on the table that we can launch towards the U.S., we have to run through every tariff and minimize the pain for Canadians. Maximize the pain for Americans. And I feel terrible for the Americans. But it's one person, as President Trump, that's creating this chaos. Joining us right now is Mark Zandi, the chief economist for Moody's Analytics. It's good to see you, Mark. Thank you for coming in. 25% tariffs coming for cars and basically all cars since it also applies to car parts. What is this going to mean. What's your analysis on what people need to be preparing for. Well Kate it means higher prices and it means fewer jobs. I mean, on the higher price side, you know, a lot of moving parts here, a lot of uncertainty. But, I think if, the if the tariffs are imposed as articulated and stay in place by this time next year, the typical car price will be somewhere between 5000 and $10,000 more. so, you know, right now, the average car, car price is 50 K, so that means you're going to be paying 55 K to 60 K as a result of the tariffs. And then I do expect that it's going to cost jobs. you know, you'll see retaliation just toward the Canadian Canadians talk about this. Other countries will respond no doubt. And that means, where U.S. manufacturers are going to have trouble selling what they produce to those countries, you know, cost jobs, and you don't really need to go too far back to see this. If you go back to President Trump's first term and look at, what happened with manufacturing activity, jobs and prices, the tariffs, resulted in the kind of damage that I'm talking about. So and here we're talking about much higher tariffs. So I, I buckle in I think this means higher prices and fewer jobs because and that was what I was going to ask you next. Because Donald Trump, the president says that this is being done to protect American manufacturers, to save American workers. The UAW president, Jon Faine, applauded the decision, saying it's a step in the direction to end the free trade disaster, is how he put it. What are the chances this does not negatively affect American consumers? Now I just don't see it. I really don't, you know, take a if you just put yourself in the position of a CEO of a major global manufacturer and you're looking at this and you're thinking, should I build a vehicle factory in the United States? And by the way, Kate, to build a factory takes years, as you know, he can't build for next month, next quarter. This is something that takes two, 3 or 4 years, and then you're building it to last for years after that and maybe even decades. And what's the tariff going to be tomorrow? What's the tariff going to be six months from now? What's the tariff going to be a year from now? What's the tariff going to be five years from now? because all this is done under executive orders, not in the legislation. This is in which a change in the stroke of a pen. So that's the you know, who's going to say, I'm not going to invest, I'm just going to sit on my hands. So I just don't see it. I'm confused by it. help me be un less confused about also now the following, if you look at it all together, I mean, you said a couple of weeks ago the risk of recession is uncomfortably high because of how markets are reacting to tariffs. And in part, we learned this week, consumer confidence slid to its lowest level since January 2021. Add it all up. What is the economic outlook looking like since the new administration came in? Well highly uncertain. You know, I've been a professional economist for 35 years, and there's a few other times in that 35 years where the uncertainty is as thick as it is today. I mean, you know, maybe 911, the global financial crisis, the pandemic. I mean, it's incredibly uncertain in that kind of world. people freeze at first, and then they start pulling back and cutting back in the you can see it in the surveys. You mentioned the consumer sentiment survey, the Conference Board survey. That's a really good leading indicator of recession. Now it's not screaming recession yet I don't see, you know, red flares going off yet. But it's moving in the wrong direction. And I do think it prices if we do see these kinds of tariffs go into place and prices do rise to the extent that seems likely. I think it's a lot of pressure on, consumer psychology, on business sentiment, on what the Federal Reserve Board decides to do or not do. And all those things mean recession risks are on the rise. Mark, thank you so much for jumping on this morning. Appreciate it. There is some real concern still about what President Trump will do ahead of what he is calling Liberation Day, and that is April the 2nd, when these next levies are set to go into place. And analysts are warning us car buyers to prepare for some serious sticker shock. The president announcing 25% tariffs on imported vehicles and auto parts. It is a move that will significantly raise the cost of producing all cars sold there, even those built in American factories. The white House claims the levies are needed to strengthen America's manufacturing industry because of unfair trade practices and US national security concerns. All this at stake affect, of course, Saint Paul the Third, a day of deliberation day after tariffs hit a wide variety of other goods produced by America's trading partners. Right. CNN's Dana Stuart, following this story for us. Good to have you here. Analysts warning consumers to brace themselves, at least in the US, for price increases set to come fast. Just how fast and by how much? We're looking at a considerable price increase for U.S. consumers. And this could take really only a few weeks. It depends on stock levels for car manufacturers. This is one of the most interconnected sort of global sectors in the world. The Trump administration, of course, is very aware of this, but it's interesting to consider that, yes, this will impact U.S. branded U.S. made cars. You're looking at stock prices here for General Motors, Stellantis, which makes Jeep Ford GM down more than 8% today. And that's because they are very reliant on car parts from around the world, particularly Canada and Mexico. So we are going to see a big increase in prices. And in fact, some analysts today putting that at thousands of dollars a car. I think the Anderson Economic Group said that for vehicles built in the U.S., the cost between a 3500 and $12,000 a car, this is a huge cost increase. This, of course, feeds into inflation. This is not what President Trump wants. It will impact international carmakers as well, but it will even punish those that have factories in the United States like Volkswagen or BMW, because they too rely on car parts from elsewhere. And Becky, of course, it takes many, many years to shift that. So even as we see a car manufacturer like the South Korean one last week, Hyundai investing or committing to invest a lot of money in a steel manufacturing facility, it will take years for that to come on board. And in the meantime, who is getting hit? Not just economies around the world, but U.S. consumers. Yeah. What's been the reaction to President Trump's escalating global trade war? We've got a lot of reaction, Becky. You won't be surprised to hear that. Plenty of stock market reaction in Asia, Europe and of course announcing the US car stocks down really across the board. More so for those that are more impacted. And we actually can show you the countries that will be most impacted by this. Mexico, Japan, Canada, South Korea all up there. And we are now getting responses from pretty much all of them. Mexico's president due to speak soon Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney called it a direct attack on Canada. The EU Commission president. Interesting kind of said the EU will continue to seek negotiated solutions. They have actually delayed half of their retaliatory tariffs from a few weeks ago. They're hoping clearly to have some sort of negotiation. Germany's trade minister, though much stronger, Becky, unsurprising given Germany is such a bigger automaker. What counts now is to have a firm response to these tariffs from the EU. It needs to be clear that we will not take this lying down. And of course, President Trump really doesn't like retaliation. So what are we going to see? Is it gonna be negotiation or escalation?

input: main idea: Make a cautionary finance video analyzing warnings from ex-financiers about an impending downturn similar to the 2008 crash, with comparisons and data-driven insights..

output.title: Ex-financier warns economic downturn akin to Great Depression could be beginning | The Business
output.description:
Ex-financier and global market analysis Satyajit Das explains why Donald Trump's attempts to remake the US financial system could result in an economic downturn comparable to the 1930s Great Depression. Satyajit Das says the complete disconnect between cash, earnings and valuations in conjunction with Trump's desire to reorder the global economic system could see an unravelling which would rival the worst economic downturn in US history, as well as the history of the industrialised world. He says a loss of investor confidence and a crash of the US dollar are possible as a result of the Trump Administration's attempts to try to devalue the world's reserve currency.
#ABCBusiness

output.script: i think GFC was fundamentally different because it was a problem in the financial sector mainly in the US subprime market This is a combination of economic problems and things which are flowing through into financial problems And to be honest we haven't seen a reordering of the global economic system on this scale since the 1930s And that was the smooth holy tariffs which certainly didn't cause the Great Depression but were contributors to that And also on the other side on the financial side the excesses that have built up over the last 20 years are far greater than I've ever seen before And I think the critical thing there is there's a complete disconnect between cash and earnings and valuations So the difference between valuations and everything else has become stretched So I don't know how bad it would could be but all I know looking at history is it could be very bad And so what you are saying is that an economic downturn comparable to the great depression of the 1930s is not inconceivable Certainly it's not inconceivable And I think the caution I have is this is like going to a football match and the national anthems haven't finished playing and we're trying to judge how the game ends And it's almost impossible to do that Unlike the banking crisis of 2008 and the share market crash of 1929 the catalyst for this latest crisis has been the US president himself Is it within his power to undo the damage he's already done well the best thing I could say is what leenencia once said which is it's difficult to make an aquarium from fish soup So basically he has tried to undo the entire economic system as it's existed for 40 or 50 years and I think the loss of trust in the US loss of trust in the basic way the US has operated is very very critical to understand and I would not be surprised if it's very difficult to go back from there and the other interesting issue is that one of the questions I have is the intellectual caliber of the people involved Mark Twain once said that he didn't know about the people who ruling who were ruling us that whether they were very smart people putting us on or they were imbecile who really meant it and we are still trying to work that out Well what do you make of what Donald Trump and the White House is trying to achieve the stated aims whether it could work well I think you have to go to Shakespeare which is if there's be madness there is method in it because the there's a plan here and the plan is to try to address a wide range of US grievances which range from the loss of manufacturing jobs It looks at things like basically national security There is things like the budget deficit the trade deficit the overvalued dollar and the role the US dollar plays in the financial system globally as a reserve currency He's trying to address all of that and tariffs is just one part of that program and probably the one that's most overlooked is what is known loosely as the Mirin plan This is a way to try to address the US budget deficit trade deficit and also US debt And that would involve believe it or not taking US government bonds or a certain portion of them and forcibly converting that into 100red-year or perpetual bonds with low coupons Alternatively they could charge user fees for US treasuries And those types of measures including capital controls are a complete reversal of what we have seen over the last 40 or 50 years of globalization So this is part of a plan and the problem is we really don't know how many bits of it are going to get actually implemented when they'll be implemented because what we've seen is the whole process is entirely erratic You know people embrace the idea of creative destruction All I'm seeing now is destruction without any creativity And so do you think it could work or do you think we're going to see a flight of capital away from the United States or something else well I think if they start to play with the dollar which they are to some extent already they've tried to devalue the dollar I think once you start to play with that the loss of confidence will mean essentially that overseas holders of US assets will start to sell And at the margin that makes it very difficult for the US in several layers The first is the dollar will crash which will actually make the tariff problem worse because in the 2016 time when he put tariffs on the appreciation in the US dollar actually offset part of the cost of the tariffs and that'll be the reverse Now the second thing is if there is a loss of confidence in US treasuries interest rates around the world will move up holders of US treasuries overseas like the Chinese the Japanese and also other East Asian and also the pro states will start to sell pushing up interest rates And because US treasuries play such a big part in setting interest rates around the world it will completely destabilize the international financial system It's all very well for somebody to say I'm going to change things but you got to have a very clear idea of what the endgame is and how you get there without disrupting anything Unfortunately I don't see that plan currently A lot of analysts argue that Australia is well placed to weather these shifts What is your view australia is better placed than most We're not terribly dependent on the US in terms of trade but it's the secondary effects because of our reliance on China which is obviously involved in a cage fight with the United States for dominance And the second thing is if the global economy itself slows we'll be affected That's the first thing We have a bit of ammunition in terms of that our debt positions are not as bad as other people's But there's a fundamental dilemma which nobody wants to talk about which is a geopolitical one because economically we're completely dependent on China because it accounts for somewhere between 35 and 50% of our actual exports on the other side our cultural political geostrategic links are to the United States particularly for security And I think Joe BLK Peterson once said that you know you can't run along a barb wire fence with a foot on either side And we've done that for a long period of time and we're going to have to choose I think we need to understand what Henry Kissinger once put forward which is that it was dangerous to be America's enemy but to be America's friend was fatal and we are now caught in that dilemma and unfortunately I don't see any real attempt to address that dichotomy Is that going to be one of the most pressing issues for the next federal government to address whatever its composition i don't think it matters who's in government I think we are going to have to deal with these issues and I think fundamentally we need to have a couple of principles which I don't see being talked about The first is we have to do what Lord Palmerston once says that countries don't have permanent friends they have permanent interests and we have to reconcile our interests The second thing is we have to be extremely pragmatic about how we go about this And the last element to this which is probably the most dangerous is that we need to actually be able to manage these things dynamically over time in an environment which is extremely volatile Short bitas thank you for joining the program It's my pleasure

input: main idea: Make a short documentary about Gennady Korotkevichâ€™s legendary career in competitive programming, tracing his achievements and what sets him apart in the coding world..

output.title: Gennady Korotkevich Biography: The GOAT of Coding | Tourist Road to 4000 Elo
output.description:
Meet Gennady Korotkevich (tourist), the GOAT of competitive programming. From winning his first gold medal at age 11 to becoming the first programmer to break 4000 Elo on Codeforces, tourist's journey is nothing short of legendary.

In this video, we dive deep into the story of a shy Belarusian prodigy who mastered algorithms, data structures, Python, JavaScript, and C++ to rewrite the rules of competitive programming. With 8 Google Code Jam championships, 6 consecutive IOI gold medals, and 3 Facebook Hacker Cup victories, his solutions showcase advanced software development techniques from machine learning to web development.

But beyond the trophies lies a fascinating story of dedication, genius, and relentless pursuit of perfection. How did a young boy from Gomel become the greatest competitive programmer of all time? What drives him to maintain this unprecedented dominance in coding interviews, hackathons, and programming challenges? Find out in this deep dive into the life of tourist, a must-watch for anyone interested in coding bootcamps, software engineering, or full stack development.

#GennadyKorotkevich #TouristCoder #Codeforces #CompetitiveProgramming #CodeforcesLegend
#GoogleCodeJam #ICPCChampion #ProgrammingGenius #CodeChef7Star
#ProgrammingMotivation #Elo4000 #CodingLegend #TopCoder #ProgrammingJourney #HackerCupChampion #coding #codinglife #codingchallenge

output.script: what if I told you that the most dominant competitive programmer in history started his journey at just 6 years old yeah we're talking about a guy known as tourist who's won every single major competition and turned down Millions from Tech Giants just to pursue his love of computer science so how exactly did a kid from Belarus become the Undisputed goat of competitive programming well let's hold on a second to understand genned katovich we need to take it back to September 25th 1994 when a child was born in the city of gol bellarus to two programming professors who had no idea their son would rewrite history ged's parents Vladimir and leoda katovich were programmers at the Francis skarina homeo State University's mathematics Department little did they know their son would become the greatest competitive programmer in history at just 6 years old young Gennady showed an unusual fascination with his parents work this wasn't the typical childhood curiosity there was something different about the way he approached problems the way his mind worked his father recognizing this spark designed a special children's game to introduce him to programming Concepts but nobody could have predicted how quickly this spark would ignite into a roaring Flame by age 8 gennady's Talent caught the attention of Mel delinsky one of belarus's most respected computer science teachers delinsky recalls a remarkable moment as a second grader at a national competition he he solved a problem about a body immersed in water without even knowing about Archimedes principle of buoyancy this was the first sign that they were dealing with an extraordinary mind the competitive programming world first stood up and took notice when at the unprecedented age of 11 genned qualified for the 2006 International Olympiad in informatics this wasn't just breaking the record it was shattering it most competitors were high school seniors genady was barely in Middle school he didn't just participate he won silver in his first attempt a feat that would have been the crowning achievement of most programmers careers for Gennady it was just the beginning What followed was a display of dominance never before seen in competitive programming from 2007 to 2012 Gennady won six consecutive gold medals at the II to put this in perspective most programmers dream of winning just one medal in their entire career gened won Gold six times in a row often finishing first overall he wasn't just winning he was revolutionizing how problems were solved approaching challenges with a creativity and efficiency that left even the judges in awe at the 2009 II in plav div a 14-year-old genedy showed remarkable humility that would become his trademark I try various strategies and one of them is the right one he said I am no genius I am simply good at it this modesty combined with his extraordinary Talent only added to his Legend unlike many who might let success consume their lives genned maintained balance spending no more than 3 to 4 hours daily at the computer making time for football and table tennis in 2012 gennady's Journey took him to Russia's prestigious itmo University this move marked the beginning of a new chapter in his already illustrious career in 2013 he led itmo to victory in the international Collegiate programming contest World Finals defeating Powerhouse teams from Shanghai jao Tong University and the University of Tokyo this Victory showcased not just his individual Brilliance but his ability to excel in team environments but it was in individual competitions where genned truly rewrote the history books his dominance at Google code Jam is the stuff of Legend eight consecutive championships from 2014 to 2022 think about that for a moment for eight years the best programmers from around the world gathered to compete and eight times they all went home second place to genedy add to this three Facebook hacker cup victories and you begin to understand the breadth of his dominance on coding platforms gennady's achievements border on the mythical on code forces he became the first and only person to break the 4,000 ELO barrier a rating so high that a new category had to be created just for him fittingly named tourist after his handle this achievement stands as a testament to his unparalleled skill with over 2,600 problems solved he's not just setting records he's creating benchmarks that might never be matched his dominance extends across every major competitive programming platform he holds the highest possible rating on COD Chef as a sevenstar coder he tops the rankings on top coder atcoder and hacker rank this isn't just succcess this is complete and total dominance of an entire field despite his unprecedented success ged's choices reveal a character as remarkable as his talent when Tech giants like Google and Yandex Came Calling with lucrative job offers he declined choosing instead to pursue his PhD at itmo University in a world where technical Talent often follows the highest bidder genned chose to follow his passion for computer science and research in August 2024 genned achieved what many thought impossible breaking the 4,000 ELO barrier on code forces this Milestone required the creation of a new rating category as the previous highest category legendary grandmas only went up to 3,000 the new tourist category with its distinctive red first letter and black remainder stands as a testament to his unparalleled achievements his consistency is perhaps his most remarkable trait even now he maintains a strict practice schedule solving complex algorithmic problems daily while pursuing his PhD at itmo University While others burned out ged's methodical approach limiting practice to 3 to 4 hours daily and maintaining outside interests has kept him at the top for over a decade the numbers tell the story over 2600 problems solved on code forces alone eight consecutive Google code Jam victories from 2014 to 2022 the first and only person to break the 4,000 ELO barrier a feat that forced code forces to create an entirely new ranking category his handled tourist now represents more than a username it's become the highest possible achievement in competitive programming his influence extends far beyond the rankings through his teaching at itmo University and his competition strategies he's revolutionized how problems are approached young programmers study his Solutions like grandmas chess games learning from his elegant approaches to seemingly impossible challenges despite offers from Tech Giants worth millions he chose to stay in Academia focusing on advancing computer science rather than corporate success Jed's Legacy isn't just about the records he's broken or the competitions he's won it's about proving that with the right approach dedication and strategic thinking you can achieve what others consider impossible from that curious 6-year-old in bellarus to becoming the Undisputed master of competitive programming his journey shows that true greatness comes from consistent Excellence not just fleeting moments of Brilliance the legend of tourist continues to grow at an age when many retire from competitive programming genned katovich keeps pushing boundaries solving problems in ways that leave even veteran programmers in awe he hasn't just dominated the field he's redefined what's possible in competitive programming setting standards that may stand for generations to come

seal continued his education at bua Park High School sigal's first job was as a dishwasher at a restaurant called The Wagon Wheel noticing his quick movements a Japanese shodokan karate expert who was
