and the title of Shihan in iido this Japanese term is used in various martial arts to honor senior martial arts practitioners furthermore seagull became the first Foreigner in Japan to successfully run an iido Dojo iido is a Japanese martial art developed in the early 20th century by moriba iido focuses on harmonizing with an opponent's energy rather than directly opposing it iido techniques involve circular movements that redirect the opponent's Force using their momentum against them iido practitioners typically avoid direct confrontation preferring to guide attacks into controlled movements the techniques in iido emphasize efficiency using minimal physical strength by applying joint locks throws and precise strikes combat in ieto often involves manipulating the attacker's joints such as the wrist elbow or shoulder to immobilize or off-balance them to defend themselves practitioners often deflect attacks by blending with the incoming for force and redirecting it through circular movements this technique focuses on disrupting the opponent's balance making them vulnerable to being subdued iido techniques can also be adapted to various combat situations making them versatile for different types of opponents in arenas overall the philosophy of iiko with its emphasis on blending circular movements and minimal force distinguishes it as a martial art focused on Harmony and effective self-defense on the other hand there stands Brock Lesnar with his background in Greco Roman wrestling Brock Lesnar's WWE debut was Unforgettable for WWE fans know who it is but what's he doing out here he's he's just he's destroying his initial appearance involved him entering the ring and demolishing other wrestlers in His official WWE debut match against Jeff Hardy Lesnar not only defeated Hardy but also knocked him out WWE matches ending in a knockout are extremely rare but Brock Lesnar managed to KO Jeff Hardy which significantly boosted his Fame after leaving WWE and njpw Lesnar sought other Pursuits that kept him within the realm of Sports and professional fighting he eventually succeeded in joining MMA and secured a contract with UFC during Lesnar is the new UFC Brock Lesnar also of similar weight few seemed able to match his combination of muscle mass and speed his fighting style can be summarized as ground and pound which means he moved quickly to take down his opponent he typically moved to the side to gain control and then began attacking with punches and elbows while ensuring he kept his opponent pinned beneath up against big TR try to finish it he wasn't the toughest MMA fighter and his weaknesses were likely his stamina and his standup fighting abilities however his Superior wrestling skills and brutal fighting style enabled him to defeat several tough opponents potentially including someone as skilled as Steven Sagal although Sagal has extensive martial arts training and has trained prominent Fighters Lesnar's competitive experience in wrestling and MMA gives him an edge Lesnar's track record of winning championships and his real world fighting experience score him higher compared to Steven Seagal whose combat experience is output.script:
This is how I learned to code in Python, Javascript
and C++ by spending only a few weeks on each of them. But, learning a new language was not always
as easy as this. When I learnt my first programming language
which was Java, I spent months watching online tutorials and following along. But when I joined Amazon, I delivered a project
in Python within the first 2 weeks. I had never written a single line of code
in Python before working on this project. Later when I joined Google, I used the same
approach to quickly pick up C++ and be useful to my team. And I have done this over and over again to
learn other languages like JavaScript, Go and Dart. But, how am I able to do all this? Did I take some magic pill that made me a
Python wiz overnight? Truth be told, itâ€™s actually very simple. For thousands of years, great civilizations
and powerful leaders have tried to uncover the secrets of learning a new programming
language. To find the answer, we have to go all the
way back to 1945. World War 2 has just ended and after winning
the war, the British want to spread English throughout the world. As you might already know, English is not
exactly a very easy language to learn as a non-native speaker. So, they created this simplified version of
English called Basic English. Basic English had only 850 words. For comparison, there are around 170,000 total
words in English. In addition to fewer words, Basic English
also had simplified grammar rules, with a focus on basic sentence structures. To popularize the language, the British used
state owned radio called British Broadcasting Corporation or BBC to create a show named
â€œEnglish by Radio ''. This show taught Basic English vocabulary and pronunciation to non-native
speakers and was a huge success. But how could just 850 words and a few basic
grammar constructs help people learn English? And can we use the same principles to learn
a new programming language? To answer that, we need to know a few things
about how the languages exactly work. Imagine a circle that contains the top 10%
most popular words among the 170,000 total words in English. This circle would contain words like I, me,
you, eat, drink etc. Then we have another circle around it that
contains the next 20% most popular words. This would contain words like overpaid and
programmer which makes sense. And we can keep making these circles until
we cover all 170,000 words. In case you are curious, the outermost circle
contains words like nincompoop and teetotaler. For simplicity, letâ€™s combine the innermost
two circles together and the rest of the circles together. Now imagine that you start reading one of
the best novels of our times called â€œFifty Shades of Greyâ€ which has a total of 150,000
words. What youâ€™ll find is that roughly 80% of
these 150,000 words in the book lie in the inner circle and the rest of the 20% words
come from the outer circle. For those who donâ€™t know, this is also known
as Pareto principle. Pareto principle states that 20% of your effort
results in 80% of your outcomes. And this powerful principle is the main idea
behind the BASIC English as well as the secret to learning a new programming language really
fast. I applied the same principle to learn French
and now, â€œJe peux parler en franÃ§ais mais mon accent est marrantâ€. â€œLearning a new spoken language is one thing
but learning a language that a computer understands is totally differentâ€, you might say. Well, letâ€™s try to test this hypothesis. Letâ€™s build the same circles for the vocabulary
of programming languages. What would be the top 10% most popular concepts
here? I believe it would include different data
types like int, float, strings or Array etc. Maybe â€œif elseâ€ blocks and for loops would
also be part of this circle. Maybe writing functions and classes would
also be here. If you move outside to the next circle, you
might have concepts like polymorphism and inheritance etc. And you can keep drawing these circles until
you reach the outermost circle that might have I donâ€™t know, maybe iterators or generators. Now if you pick all the Github repos in the
language of your choice, you will find that 80% of the code would be coming from the inner
20% circle. And following what we learnt from the BASIC
English example, we will focus on this 20% circle first. But as we do this, we need to be careful about
2 things. Number one, this 20% circle though fairly
similar might vary a little bit across different languages. For example, in Java, you might have an Arraylist
and you will call it just List in Python. Or in Javascript, you might have async/await
which might be very different in other languages. The point is, this top 20% circle might change
depending on the language you pick. So, you would want to do your own research
on the top concepts for the language of your choice. Number two, when you are trying to learn these
concepts, you need to change your method of learning. If you were trying to learn a new spoken language,
letâ€™s French for example. No matter how many movies or TV series you
watch in French, you will not be able to speak French unless you actually try to talk in
French. In the same way, no matter how many lectures
or video tutorials you watch in Javascript, you will not be able to code in Javascript
unless you actually try to code in Javascript. In a video tutorial, you will usually get
the code that already works and if you copy it, sure enough, it will work for you as well. But, programming is the art of breaking and
fixing things. Thatâ€™s why I recommend interactive learning
instead of casual learning. For example, if you want to learn Python,
you can go to learnpython.org and do exercises, break things and fix them as you learn new
concepts. Similarly, for Javascript, you can use W3
schools. I am sure you can find this kind of platform
in other languages as well. Now that you know what to learn and how to
learn it, there are 2 problems left for us to solve. How to remember what we are learning and How
to learn the rest of 80% concepts in the circle. To solve the first problem, we need to first
understand the Ebbinghaus Forgetting curve. Herman Ebbinghaus was a German psychologist
who is well known for his work on memory and learning. He conducted experiments where he would give
himself some nonsense words to remember and then test himself at various intervals to
see how many of these words he could remember. What he found became the backbone of how we
teach kids in the modern school system. What you are seeing is the famous Ebbinghaus
Forgetting curve. This graph is a classical exponential decay
graph. What this means is that right after we learn
something new, we start forgetting it very quickly. But this rate of forgetting slows down over
time and in the end, we only retain a small fraction of what we learnt. But what if I tell you that there is a way
to retain more of what we learnt. Ebbinghaus also studied the impact of revision
on our retention. What he found was that if you review the concepts
again, you can increase the number of words you remember in the end. And if you repeat this multiple times, your
retention can keep increasing. And this is called Spaced Repetition, which
many of you might have already heard about. This is the reason why if you try to learn
a new language using an app like Duolingo, they keep repeating the same words again and
again in the exercises. But how do we apply the spaced repetition
to learning a new programming language? The answer to this question is also the answer
to the second problem that we still need to solve. So, letâ€™s quickly cover the second problem
and then we will talk about the solution. The other pending problem we have is that
we have still not figured out how to learn the remaining 80% of concepts. For this, we need to take a breadth first
approach to our learning. What this means is that instead of taking
some random long deep path from the inner circle to the outside boundary, we just keep
enlarging our inner circle. In other words, we slowly keep increasing
the breadth of our knowledge. The biggest advantage of doing this is that
we are only learning new things that are close to what we already know and this makes learning
them very easy. But how exactly do we do this? To remember more of what we have learnt so
far and to learn the remaining 80% concepts, all we need to do is build projects. But not just any projects, we need projects
with increasing difficulty. I will tell you which exact projects to build
in a moment. But, building projects helps you in 2 ways. Number one, as you build projects, you will
encounter the top 20% concepts again and again. And this will help you achieve spaced repetition. Number two, as you build projects, you will
need to learn some new concepts on the go. If you choose your projects carefully and
slowly increase the difficulty, you can constantly expand your inner circle to become the same
size as the outer circle. One thing that you should be aware of though
is that you will never be able to learn 100% of what there is to learn. But look at you. You donâ€™t know everything about the language
that you speak and you are doing just fine. So, donâ€™t obsess over learning everything. As I mentioned, choosing the right projects
is extremely important. Doing this will not only help you learn faster,
it will provide you with a portfolio of projects that you can write on your resume to impress
the hiring managers. If you want to know about the 5 projects that
I recommend to all beginners, you can watch this video. My name is Sahil and I will see you in the
next one.

output.title: Iran Rejects Egyptâ€™s Sukhoi SU-35 Fighter Jets | Algeria Took Them!
output.description:
Why Did Iran Reject Egyptâ€™s Sukhoi SU-35 Flanker Fighter Jets? | Algeria Buys Egyptâ€™s SU-35 Fighters

What happened to Egyptâ€™s advanced Su-35 Super Flanker fighter jets? Why did Iran reject these powerful jets that were ready for delivery? And how did Algeria suddenly become the new operator of this elite fleet?

Using satellite imagery, and leaked production data, we reveal what really happened to the 30 Su-35s originally built for Egypt.

In this in-depth video, we uncover the full story behind the Su-35 Algeria deal, the missed opportunity by Iran, and the behind-the-scenes factors including U.S. pressure, CAATSA sanctions, and the Russia-Ukraine war's impact on jet production. From Egyptâ€™s canceled Su-35 deal to Algeria's surprise acquisition, this is the full breakdown youâ€™ve been waiting for.

Learn how this unexpected move might reshape the power balance in North Africa and the Middle East, and what it really means for the Iranian Air Force and Russian military exports.

output.script: latest news on the Pharaoh's fighter jets in Africa the newest user of the Sukcoy Su35 Super Flanker has been identified iran rejects Super Flankers that were ready for delivery [Music] hello everyone and welcome back to our channel today's video focuses on breaking news about the newest official user of Russian Sukcoy fighter jets jets that were at times expected to be delivered to Iran but have now ended up in another country according to evidence the Pharaoh's super flankers which were originally meant for Egypt have ended up in the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria in this video we'll get familiar with the unfortunate fate of Egypt's Sukcoy SU35s and in contrast Algeria's ambition but the most important question is why didn't Iran go after this windfall wouldn't purchasing fighter jets that had been ready for years have been more logical especially under the current sensitive regional conditions or has Iran's plan for modernizing its airfleet changed altogether or perhaps there's another reason behind the scenes in other words a tangled web surrounding the SU35 mystery in Iran satellite images and videos posted online suggest that Algeria has suddenly emerged as a leading operator of the Su35 these jets have unexpectedly taken to the skies over the African continent since about a month ago with minimal media coverage but the main question here was how these jets suddenly appeared in Algeria in such a short time the answer lies with another African country the Arab Republic of Egypt a transcontinental nation with direct connections between Asia and Africa and of course the keyholder of the strategic Suez Canal in March 2019 reports emerged stating that Egypt intended to purchase over 24 Su35 fighter jets from Russia under a deal valued at approximately 2 to3 billion this agreement had been finalized in late 2018 and it was expected that deliveries would begin in 2020 or 2021 on the other hand the US Secretary of State at the time warned that if Egypt proceeded with the purchase sanctions would be imposed on the Egyptian government under the Katza law countering America's adversaries through sanctions act despite these statements Russia began producing the Su35s for Egypt in 2020 and the first five fighter jets were completed and flown that same year by 2021 a total of 17 jets had been manufactured for Egypt and it's likely that shortly afterward this number increased to between 22 and 30 however Arab newspapers suddenly reported that three countries Egypt Algeria and Indonesia had suspended their military contracts with Russia including deals for new fighter jets meanwhile the United States had approved the sale of a version of the F-15E fighter jet to the Egyptian Air Force with the Egyptian generals stepping back the Pharaoh's super flankers which were ready to fly over the deserts remained under snow and ice in the far east of Moscow at the Kamsumulsk on Amore aircraft plant one of the largest aviation industry complexes in the Russian Federation egypt's custom options and sometimes weaker equipment didn't appeal to the Russian Air Force or Navy so the best solution was to find another buyer and what better country than Iran at least from the perspective of the media and even Iranian sources Egypt's SU35s were an ideal option for Iran's exhausted air force at least 30 fighter jets that with the deepening of cooperation between the two countries over the past 5 years even before the October 7th operation and the True Promise operations could have been operational in the country there was hope for this even up until recent months but now suddenly these fighter jets have gone to Algeria satellite images show that the Sukcoy Su35s present in Russia have received the Roundell of the Algerian Air Force and have been loaded via Antonov 124 transport aircraft at the Kamolskamore facility and unloaded at the elbowagi air base the discussion of Algeria receiving Su35s jets has been circulating for years in 2016 reports were published stating that Algeria's military had tested this jet a Russian newspaper named Commerce later claimed in 2019 that Algeria had signed a contract for 14 SU35 fighter jets alongside other jets like the Sukoy SU34 and Sukoy Su57 although neither Russia nor Algeria ever officially confirmed it on the other hand with Algeria announcing a contract for the purchase of the Su57 Iran remained the only potential customer for this Egyptian squadron and it was never expected that the Super Flanker would return to Africa again but the story is a bit more complicated according to a photo published a few years ago during a visit by the Russian Minister of Defense to the United Aircraft Corporation facilities the Su35 production schedule becomes somewhat clear based on the chart visible on the monitor screen a total of 30 SU35 Superflanker jets were produced in two batches 22 and eight aircraft respectively in 2020 and 2021 which were most likely Egypt's order however there's also an unknown customer involved a country scheduled to receive 12 jets in 2022 14 in 2023 and 8 in 2024 whose name is still undisclosed so if we assume that this unknown customer was Iran it can be guessed that the fighter jet purchase agreement was signed almost simultaneously with Egypt's and repurchasing Egypt's customordered jets wouldn't have made sense but now in 2025 contrary to the promised production of jets for Iran starting from 2022 there's still no sign of them two factors likely played a role in this first the war in Ukraine which has occupied the capacities of Russian factories and along with European sanctions slowed down production second the pressure from the United States on Iran Russia relations but even if we say the unknown customer wasn't Iran then why weren't Egypt's Sukcoy SU35s purchased perhaps the strongest argument is that the downgrade of Egypt's customized fighter jets failed to win approval from the Iranian Air Force and Iran demanded a special version instead a topic that could be extensively discussed currently reports indicate that Algeria has purchased 14 of the 28 initially manufactured aircraft for Egypt however the exact role of the SU35 in Algeria's air force remains unclear it's not known whether these aircraft will expand Algeria's fleet or replace older units algeria's air force with its current fleet of Sukcoy Su30 MKAs and older MiG 29s has long relied on Soviet and Russian hardware the retirement of MIG 25 interceptors in 2022 created a significant gap for the country which was supposed to be filled by the purchase of 14 Su57s however by 2024 Russia had only about 12 Su57s in service full-scale production of the aircraft faced delays due to sanctions supply chain disruptions caused by the Ukraine war and technical challenges such as the unfinished Iselia 30 engine pushing back the export version's delivery therefore contrary to earlier expectations Algeria agreed to the immediate purchase of Egypt's SU35s in order to overcome geopolitical challenges regarding the Arab Sahara with Morocco however there are still a number of Egyptian super flankers with unnamed ownership and it remains to be seen whether they too will go to Algeria or meet a different fate from secret contracts to delayed deliveries the Su35 story just keeps unfolding if this kind of deep analysis excites you give us a like and drop a comment subscribe and share if you want more global military breakdowns like this thanks for being here see you in the next one

output.script: last week something Monumental happened a day that marked the end of one type of economy and the start of another it is something that is slowly changing the world economy but behind closed doors and it's something that large financial institutions don't want you to know about so what is this thing well let's step back to the 1980s big hair cocaine Michael Douglas yelling greed is good back then institutions trading huge amounts of stock needed a way to do it quietly so in 1986 a company called instanet created something called the first dark pool of money so just to quickly explain what really dark poool money is it goes something like this dark pools are private hidden stock markets where big players Banks hedge funds billionaires and many others in the elite club trade huge amounts of stock without the public ever seeing it it's like wall Street's VIP section where the Real Deals actually happen and US regular people are stuck outside like losers at the club not that that's ever happened to me it was like an underground poker game but for stocks no lights no cameras just trades happening in total secrecy at first it was a niche thing Banks and hedge funds used it to swap stocks like they were exchanging bags of cash in a parking garage but then the government stepped in in 1998 the US Securities and Exchange committee Mission or the SEC introduced regulation ATS which is alternative trading systems this was supposed to give investors more options to trade outside of traditional exchanges but as always Wall Street found a way to turn this into a money printing loophole by the early 2000s more dark pools of secret trades popped up and big Banks realized wait if we control dark pools we can control who gets the best prices without anyone knowing dark pools were supposed to be a way for big investors to trade large amounts of stock without screwing up prices because if a hedge fund needs 5 million shares of I don't know apple on the New York Stock Exchange or the NASDAQ the second people see that order Panic sets in and prices tank and well that's bad for the seller so they said let's just do these big trades you know in secret and that's how dark pools were born no price impact no public record just billionaire handshakes behind a velvet curtain but in 2005 comes regulation nms which stands for National Market System which was a well-meaning but completely naive SEC rule it was supposed to make sure investors got the best price available no matter where a trade happened and it sounds great right well it wasn't instead Banks realized they don't have to use public exchanges at all they can match trades in secret as long as the price is close to the public public one and they can do all of this in dark pools away from watchful eyes now between 2005 in 2012 dark poool trading exploded from 3% to 40% of all stock trades and by 20125 in fact by last week the Monumental day the majority of all trades is now dark pool but now as of 2025 in fact as of last week more than half of all trades on the stock market are dark poool money trades meaning that half of stock trading is now invisible to millions of people that trade on the stock market it's not happening on the New York Stock Exchange not the NASDAQ it's happening in private Market owned by Wall Street itself so now that the billionaires and the dark pools officially run the majority of the investing world let's break down what this actually means for us peasants when you check a stock price you think oh this is what people are paying for it nope that's just what the little guys are paying for it the real price now is set in dark pools where billionares and hedge funds make their deals in secret imagine if Amazon had a second private website where only rich people got special discounts and you weren't allowed to see it that's what dark pools are doing for stocks so if now more than half of all trades are off exchange how do you know if the price you're paying for it is fair well you don't and it probably isn't fair because B investors get first dibs on price movements in fact your trades that you might make on something like Robin Hood they go through market makers like Citadel who profit off of your trade you never directly invest into the stock market ever even if you make trades through your bank there's always some third party that's in the way and so if all of this sounds bad to you well it kind of is and has been in 2014 Barclays ran a dark pool called LX which they marketed as safe investment for highfrequency Traders except oops they were secretly letting hfts Feast on everyone else's trades when New York's attorney general found out Barclays got hit with $70 million in fines but fun fact they made way more money than that from the scheme so naturally they just kept doing it a little bit before that on May 6th 2010 the Dow Jones plummeted nearly 1,000 points in just a few minutes and one of the best examples of dark poool trading actually came during the GameStop frenzy of 2021 where actually 80% of gme or GameStop trades were happening off Exchange in dark pools retail investors were wondering why isn't the stock moving higher when everyone is buying it well that was because most of the trades were being internalized in dark pools and market makers like Citadel they weren't letting the orders move the price on public exchanges but these are just a few examples of how dark pools are directly affecting some of the trades that you make but now I want to ponder how bad could this all get I mean dark pools were just a small fraction of the stock market just 40 years ago and now they are the majority of Trades so let's set up the worst case scenario what if dark pools keep growing until they completely take over the market we're already at 50% of Trades happening in secret and some Wall Street insiders think by 2030 it could be 80% if that happens stock exchanges will become just the place where small investors trade while big money operates in its own private system the stock price you see will just be completely fabricated the trades you place are priced in after all of the billionaires and all of the financial institutions already have made their decisions and all of a sudden it's not just average everyday investors that are left out of the market it's millionaires or even multi-millionaires they're getting left out now too in this scenario and this is not just conspiracy talk because it's already happening so anyways in this first scenario where 80% of trading is dark the stock market just becomes a theme park for retail investors in Wall Street bets the actual market and the real money it moves in private and we'll never see it but another potential path and scenario is the liquidity death spiral so what happens when so much trading happens in dark pools that the public markets can't even set real prices anymore so right now dark pool's piggyback off of stock exchanges they match trades based on public prices but if too much trading moves to the dark side well then public stock prices become unreliable so in this scenario large gigantic price swings become pretty realistic because there aren't those big public orders to stabilize prices instead of a stock having a down day of 1 or 2% all of a sudden the average down or update could be 5 or 10% or more in this scenario Market crashes would also be worse flash crashes would happen all of the time just like they did in 2010 for one day except they would happen many times per year all of a sudden the highfrequency Traders and the algorithm Traders well they now have to deal with the giant price fluctuations and their algorithms well that they might not do too well in uh in this kind of scenario either meanwhile a lot of those you know midlevel hundred million institutions well they would struggle during this as well and they could go under and all of their money would go to the large financial institutions that would buy them out but now another thing that could hopefully happen is well the SEC grows a spine but this is pretty unlikely you see the SEC has been talking about dark pool money for years but they haven't done anything they could require big institutions to execute a certain amount of their trades publicly preventing them from permanently hiding in dark pools Europe already does this by the way the EU caps dark trading at 8% per stock the us could do the same but Wall Street lobbyists would fight it harder than a toddler fights at bedtime so what should you take from all this well when you see a stock price it's probably fake now and it's going to get more fake into the future the large hundred billion dollar or trillion dollar institutions well they get to make a lot more money now so that's great good for them they will make all of this money in private we won't see any of it if a large group of Traders trade through apps now as we know it doesn't really matter big market makers control everything now and the stock market is becoming more and more of a fake game where billionaires play in private and Retail invest ERS trade into a rigged system but what do you think of all this what do you think about dark poool money where do you see it going and do you think that this is a major problem in the United States and in the world right now let me know in the comments down below see you

#gym #gymworkout #workoutplan #symmetrical

Full Week Workout Plan
---------------------------------------------
Monday          -     Chest
Tuesday.         -     Back
Wednesday    -     Arms (Bicep / Tricep)
Thursday        -     Abs & Forearm
Friday.             -     Shoulder
Saturday         -     Legs
Sunday            -     Rest

MONDAY  - CHEST WORKOUT
----------------------------------------
1) FLAT BENCH PRESS
2) INCLINE BARBELL BENCH PRESS
3) PEC DECK FLY MACHINE
4) HIGH CABLE CHEST FLY
5) INCLINE DUMBBELL FLY


TUESDAY - BACK WORKOUT
----------------------------------------------------
1) WIDE GRIP LAT PULL DOWN
2) CLOSE GRIP LAT PULL DOWN (UNDER HAND GRIP)
3) CABLE ROW
4) BARBELL BENT OVER ROW
5) HYPEREXTENSION


WEDNESDAY - ARMS WORKOUT
( BICEP / TRICEP )
--------------------------------------------------------
1) BICEP CURLS
2) INCLINE BICEP CURL (45 DIGREE)
3) HAMMER CURL
4) STRAIGHT BAR TRICEP PUSH DOWN
5) SEATED DUMBBELL TRICEP EXTENSION
6) CLOSE GRIP BENCH PRESS


THURSDAY - ABS AND FOREARM
----------------------------------------------------------------
1) CRUNCHES
2) VERTICAL LEG RAISES
3) ALTERNATE HEEL TOUCHES
4) PLANK
5) BARBELL REVERSE WRIST CURL
6) BARBELL WRIST CURL


FRIDAY - SHOULDER WORKOUT ( DELTOID ) 
----------------------------------------------------------------------
1) SEATED DUMBBELL SHOULDER PRESS
2) SHOULDER LATERAL RAISE
3) FRONT RAISES
4) SEATED REVERSE FLY ON MACHINE
5) SHRUGS


SATURDAY - LEGS WORKOUT
------------------------------------------------------
1) SMITH MACHINE SQUAT
2) LEG PRESS
3) LEG EXTENSION
4) LYING LEG CURLS
5) STANDING CALF RAISES


SUNDAY - REST

output.title: Financial Literacy for Kids | Learn the basics of finance and budgeting
output.description:
Sometimes it's hard to distinguish whether something is a necessity or we just want that thing. Financial Literacy for Kids provides the basics about needs versus wants, budgeting, credit versus debit, and more. The points are easy to follow and understand. By the end, students will receive a good foundation of these points of financial literacy.

A need is something that is necessary to survival. Food, water, and shelter are needs because we need those things to survive. Wants include much more, from toys and books to phones and cars. While it can be difficult to tell the difference sometimes, these definitions will help you find the answer. 

The video also reviews the concepts of saving versus borrowing. Saving money is something we do so that we can eventually buy something we want, like a new bike. This can take time. If you want something more immediately, you can borrow money. Borrowing money, however, means that you have to pay back the money you borrowed over time. And sometimes you have to pay interest.

Budgeting is a very helpful tool to help control or manage our finances. A budget designates a certain amount of money to go toward certain things. For instance, perhaps you budget $50 for food for a week. If you spend more money on food than you budgeted for that week, you may have to save money somewhere else to ensure you don't spend more money than you have and go into debt.

We hope you and your student(s) enjoyed learning about these important skills! If you want even more information, head over to our website and download one of our many free lesson plans, full of activities, worksheets, and more! 

https://learnbright.org/lessons/math/introduction-to-financial-literacy/

What you will learn in Financial Literacy for Kids:
0:00 Introduction
0:37 Needs versus wants
1:13 Making a budget
1:52 Saving versus borrowing
2:56 Savings and checking accounts
3:39 Credit versus debit
4:40 Review of the facts

output.script: foreign [Music] for kids have you ever seen something in a store you really wanted to buy maybe someone even told you save your money and you can buy it someday how do you earn money to buy things you want or need today we are going to define and explain certain words and phrases that will help you become more financially literate let's grab our friend Frankie Finance to help us along the way needs and wants a need is something you must have to survive like food water clothing and shelter a want on the other hand is something that would be fun to have but you can live without you know like a skateboard video game or favorite toy knowing the difference between needs and wants can help you be more responsible with your money making a budget a budget is a plan for managing your money it is based on your estimation of income the money you earn or receive as a gift plus your expenses meaning the money you spend one of the main reasons to create a budget is to help you live within your means in other words a budget can keep you from spending money you don't have and avoid going into debt a debt is a money you borrow from someone else that must be repaid saving versus borrowing as you can probably guess saving is when you set money aside for the future and do not spend it right away like if you are saving up for a special toy or activity you might have a piggy bank at home where you put money that you are saving or you might even have a savings account at a bank have you ever heard of a loan before a loan is a money you borrow from someone borrowing money means that you are expected to pay it back most often a loan is given for a specific reason like to help purchase something big like a house or a car quite often you will have to pay interest on the loan this means the bank expects you to pay the full amount back plus an extra charge for borrowing the money in the first place this extra is called interest and is a percent of the borrowed amount a savings account is a place where you put money that you intend on saving for a while and guess what you can actually earn a little extra money while your money is in the bank for real this is also called interest but instead of giving money back to the bank for a loan it is a little extra money that you earn while your money sits in the bank a checking account is another kind of bank account that you can use to pay bills either by check or buy a special card called a debit card checking accounts do not earn interest credit versus debit a credit card is a small hard plastic card that is issued by a credit card company or other financial institution they are basically a type of loan because using a credit card means you are borrowing money from the company who issued the card here's how it works the credit card company loans you money and you pay it back according to a schedule this is usually one payment per month with interest on the unpaid amount on the other hand debit cards are linked directly to your bank account which means you use your debit card to pay for things with money you already have in either your savings or checking account want to learn more we have more videos that go into more detail about each of these skills for now let's review what we learned today true or false checking and savings accounts are basically the same exact thing boss savings accounts are for money that you are planning to save for a while and earn you interest checking accounts are used to pay for bills and other immediate needs and wants that do not earn interest fill in the blank a blank is a plan for managing your money budget what is the difference between a need and a want a need is something you must have to survive a want is something that would be fun to have but you can live without fantastic job Financial friends learning financial literacy is important as you create good money habits for the future what is it one thing you can work on to become more financially literate hope you had fun learning with us visit us at learnbrite.org for thousands of free resources and TurnKey solutions for teachers and homeschoolers foreign

output.script: what if a Shaolin monk came face to face with a giant fighter who would emerge victorious in such a battle get ready because you're about to witness a showdown unlike anything you've ever [Music] [Music] seen who would have thought that a Shon monk named Yong would dare to challenge a giant fighter like Cho hongman when you look closer Cho Hong man doesn't seem like a fair match for Yong how could he be this giant fighter stands at a towering 7'2 in and weighs an incredible 351 lb in comparison The Shaolin monk Yong is just 5'9 in tall and weighs 176 lb mathematically speaking it seems almost almost impossible for Yong to win against Choy Hong man even so Yong appears confident in his abilities especially given that this Shaolin monk is trained in several martial arts including kickboxing and wooo went out for a second but he just writes and says give me your best shot and he has plenty of them still he comes Yong also has an impressive track record in martial arts having competed in several tournaments across multiple weight classes super welterweight welterweight and super middleweight not to mention the numerous Awards Yong has achieved throughout his martial arts career he's claimed titles such as wuin Fun World Champion in 2013 wck World Champion in 2015 S1 super middleweight Muay Thai world champion in 20 2014 wuin Fang World Champion in 2014 and cik World Champion in 2012 with this wealth of experience it's clear that Yong feels confident enough to challenge a giant fighter unbelievable you would not believe that if somebody told you however let's not underestimate Cho Hong man it's not just his massive physique that will pose a challenge for Yong in the ring it's also his extensive experience in various championships throughout his career his track record shows why Choy Hong man is recognized as a South Korean kickboxer a mixed martial artist and a former scum wrestler on top of that several accolades mark his success in the ring underscoring why this giant fighter should not be overlooked from winning the prestigious K1 World Grand Prix kickboxing event in Soul in 2005 to reaching the semi-finals in the dream super Hulk tournament in 2009 Choy hongman has proven himself time and again so with each Fighter's background who will emerge Victorious will it be the Shaolin monk or the giant fighter let's watch A Match that will keep you on the edge of your seat as the 9-minute match begins Choy hongman immediately unleashes his full strength and skill to attack Yong leaving the Shaolin monk on the defensive with no room for counterattacks however yong's determination to win isn't shaken by this assault in fact it seems to fuel his Spirit making him even more eager to strike back one crucial move for Yong though is to keep a safe distance if choong man manages to get a hold of him it could spell disaster for yong's career and life yet it appears that Yong has trained diligently and devised a smart strategy to defeat the giant fighter moments later Yong successfully lands several punches directly on Cho Hong man's face but yong's attack only seems to fuel the giant Fighter's rage Cho Hong man responds by increasing his pressure closing in on the Shaolin monk relentlessly but with the Fearless mindset of a Shaolin monk ye long continues to fight back despite the challenge of targeting Choy Hong man's head the tension in the room mounts as the two fighters exchange blows and not a single spectator wants to leave their seat the energy is electric as the crowd watches this intense Showdown occasionally Yong ramps up the pressure by combining punches with kicks scoring points for his efforts unfortunately though many of the Shaolin Monks attacks don't seem to phase his opponent in fact each strike from Yong only appears to add to choong man's pressure on him could it be that the Shaolin monk is on the verge of defeat even so yong's Spirit remains unbroken The Shaolin monk stays determined in his limited but persistent attacks a tactic to fend off Choy Hong man's powerful blows any of which could potentially knock ye long out in an [Music] instant Yong even manages to land a few strikes to the giant Fighters Temple a feat considering the height difference between them finally a spinning kick from Yong hits his opponent causing Cho Hong man such pain that the referee has to pause the match Choy hongman is clearly in pain clutching his sensitive area did yong's kick really land in a vital area let's watch the replay together you can see how yong's kick connects with his opponent's body and it appears that his foot did not actually strike Choy Hong man vital area do you think the same the referee continues attempting to help Choy hongman get back into the fight but it's not so simple the giant fighter seems to be in serious pain on the edge of the Ring the referee asks Choy Hong man again if he's able to continue the [Music] fight however still reeling from the impact of yong's kick Choy Hong man decides not to go on as a result Yong emerges as the winner this match was undoubtedly full of surprises leaving the audience in awe yong's Victory came from a single decisive strike to Choy hongman a fight that everyone thought the giant fighter had a chance to win [Music] [Music] [Music] spee for

output.title: Is the U.S. really heading for a recession? | About That
output.description:
The U.S. stock market lost $4 trillion in market value in only weeks, dropping from record highs in the days following Donald Trump's election. About That producer Lauren Bird explains how the uncertainty triggered by Trump's trade war is sounding alarm bells about the state of the economy.

output.script: when President Donald Trump won the election in November the market skyrocketed all right stock markets surge on the news of Mr Trump's Victory 1,500 points for the Dow today the Dow actually hit a new record high the overwhelming sentiment from investors was that this Administration would be good for business good for the economy it's what Trump campaigned on inflation will be in full Retreat our economy will be roaring back now not even two months into his presidency the talk of a possible American recession seems to be everywhere the RW recession wasn't even in the vocabulary a few weeks ago and Trump didn't rule out the possibility of a recession in a recent interview are you expecting a recession this year um I hate to predict things like that there is a period of transition because what we're doing is very big that makes it sound like he's willing to trade a potential recession for the values and the goals that he has for the United States so how did the world's largest economy go from booming to stoking fears of a recession in just a few weeks let's start with the one place everyone is watching like a hawk if you want a real time indication of where things are at with the economy one place you can look is the stock market it is the right now the one thing that is signaling sort of a red light in terms of recession now we should make it clear the US is not in a recession and most experts aren't suggesting one is imminent either but that red light we just heard about it's a huge shift and it may not be surprising if you've been paying attention to the stock market which has cratered in the last few weeks wiping out all those gains from Trump's election and more breaking news from Wall Street right now the markets just closed clocking in their worst day of the year today was the worst day for the NASDAQ since 2022 take a look at the major indexes over the past month the S&P 500 lost almost 10% of its value the Dow Jones down nearly 9% the NASDAQ down about 133% more than 4 trillion dollar of market value has been lost in under a month technically the bull market that ostensibly began back in late October of 2022 that bull market is over this is the biggest bout of Market volatility in years and a lot of people uh you know not wanting to check their 401ks their retirement accounts of course because of this huge dip and a lot of it has to do with how investors are feeling about where the economy could be headed the stock market is not the economy but it does indicate people's moods about and prospects for companies because the stock market is forward-looking in the sense that people are expecting stock returns dividends those sorts of things I do think the stock market is a bit of a self-filling prophecy for the economy and that if people see the stock market down it overall lowers confidence and you can understand understand where that low confidence is coming from just think about the Whiplash we've seen over the last month president Trump announced sweeping tariffs president Trump's tariffs against Canada will now be put on hold Donald Trump's tariffs are in effect be clear for the 50% is that going to go into effect on Canada or not which one the 50% tariffs I'll let you know about it the chaos has been hard to keep up with and all of that uncertainty is making it tough for investors to know where to put their money leading to those huge sell-offs every time Trump announces tariffs if he thinks it's good for the American economy and good for American Business you should expect stocks to spike instead they creat it so he keeps announcing it and then backing off and announcing it and then backing off most recently markets have been like I don't know what the hell is going on I don't know how anyone can make any decisions and all of that uncertainty is showing in another place gold it's often considered an investment Safe Haven and turbulent Economic Times and its price has increased 11% since the start of the year so I think this sort of shock and awe campaign is definitely digging into the um into the psyche of Americans and uh you know naturally one can expect that people might go towards the safe havens there's some pretty unprecedented policies being pouted and that um has everybody uncertain and I think uncertainty is the big factor here and you can imagine Trump's comments about being in a period of transition doesn't temper those fears or that uncertainty he's even gone so so far is to say he's not actually concerned about it when it comes to decision- making some of these exemptions that have been announced and some of these temporary delays have you been influence in those decisions because of the market reaction no nothing to do with the market I'm not even looking at the market I do think that the Trump administration's thinking is that the stock market's going to go through a little bit of a blip and eventually investment will flow into the us as they plan with these tariffs and it'll be gangbusters again I think uh other folks are wondering if this is going to just be a deeper and deeper and that the stock market will sort of take the economy down with it and the fear now for economists is that the uncertainty that's rocking the stock market will trickle down through the rest of the economy it makes investors businesses consumers all verely nervous economists track a lot of indicators to get a sense of the economy things like jobs numbers GDP inflation retail sales and consumer sentiment a lot of that data lags a month or two behind so it's hard to say say exactly where the economy is right now but there are a couple of warning signs starting to show they're more yellow flags than red flags for the US economy but they are out there and they're part of the discussion take consumer sentiment which basically measures how people feel about the economy and their own financial situation the University of Michigan's tracker shows sentiment fell in January after Rising for five straight months and his report from last month said people's long-term expectations when it came to inflation exhibited sub substantial uncertainty especially concerning policy changes under the new presidential Administration we just keep going back to this word um uncertainty I think consumers are starting to wonder how these tariffs will play out it's part of an everyday discussion they're very much aware that import prices could increase what we are seeing actually is that households are not only unhappy about the General State of things in Washington they are starting to worry about their own economic situations and a fallen consumer sentiment could be a uniquely big problem for the us because consumption plays a huge role in the American economy 70% of its GDP comes from consumer spending that's high so people going out and buying cars food clothes it matters consumer sentiment is actually really important in thinking about the near future of the economy because if consumers are worried about their situations then they tend to pull back on spending and it doesn't take long for that to affect businesses it may already be happening the Delta Airlines warn it expects profits to be lower than previously indicated because of a Slowdown in both business and consumer spending and travel coals and Dick Sporting Goods adding to the flood of companies raising concerns about the US consumer and it's not just the big corporations the national Federation of Independent Business tracks small business optimism in February its uncertainty index Rose to 104 the second highest recorded reading and it showed only 15% of businesses after adjusting for normal seasonal changes plan to create new jobs in the next 3 months businesses are reacting to this uncertainty with what they usually do is namely become very conservative about their spending and their investing habits if you were a CEO right now and you had major investment projects in front of you you might just think to yourself I might just wait it out for a few months and see where all this lands and that's where the problems start to feed each other if businesses pull back on investing that could mean fewer new jobs maybe even job losses which may mean consumers don't feel safe to spend now if CEOs do this and families do this and we all do this then spending plummets and if that's the case that's the first step that causes a recession now again the US is not there that's the good news but as we've said how people feel about this really matters recessions can be self-fulfilling prophecies and according to the analysts we spoke to the uncertainty around all of this doesn't seem to be going anywhere anytime soon [Music]

output.title: Finally: US Revealed Its F-47 6th Generation Strike/Fighter Jet!
output.description:
In this video, I cover the latest military news on ngad, f47, f47 fighter jet, and the role of donald trump in future air force projects. The f47 fighter could replace f22 and f 22 raptor as the leading fighter jet in the us military.

We look into boeing f-47, lockheed martinâ€™s position, and what trump and donald j trump have said. Is the ngad fighter truly the face of 6th generation fighter jets and next generation air dominance?

Also touching on u.s. air force, pentagon strategies, and comparing f-22, f-15, f-35 performance. From top gun to real-world military aviation â€” tech and technology are changing everything for the united states.
output.tags: ngad, f47, f47 fighter jet, donald trump, f47 fighter, f22, f 22 raptor, fighter jet, f22 raptor, lockheed martin, air force, us military, boeing f-47, boeing, trump, us air force, ngad fighter, 6th generation fighter jets, f-47, donald j trump, top gun, next generation air dominance, u.s. air force, pentagon, fighter jets, f-22, f-15, f-35, united states, technology, military aviation, tech, military news
output.script: meet the F-47 Ngad named in honor of Donald Trump on March 21st 2025 President Donald Trump dropped yet another information bomb by announcing that Boeing had won the contract to develop the sixth generation F-47 fighter jet this news instantly sparked widespread debate as the competition for the contract involved major defense industry players including Loheed Martin the traditional manufacturer of American fighter aircraft what makes the F-47 so important for the US Air Force what are its key features in this video we'll break down the technical characteristics and strategic implications of the new combat aircraft that could potentially reshape the balance of air power in the 21st century the F-47 is being developed under the next generation air dominance program or NGAD for short an ambitious US Air Force initiative aimed at creating a sixthg generation fighter jet capable of securing total air superiority in the high-tech conflicts of the future the ENGAD program is expected to replace the current fleet of F-22 Raptors which despite their power are becoming outdated in light of emerging threats from China and Russia before diving into the F-47 itself it's worth unpacking the intrigue behind the aircraft particularly the choice of Boeing as the developer considering the company's troubled reputation in recent years this might seem like a surprising decision however it appears to be the only realistic option at this point northre Grumman declined to participate in the ENGAD program opting instead to focus its efforts on the B-21 Raider stealth bomber loheed Martin another potential contender is committed for decades ahead to the production servicing and upgrading of the F-35 Lightning 2 multi-roll fighters in addition Loheed Martin's already involved in a separate program to develop a sixth generation carrierbased fighter for the US Navy that naval project is distinct from ENGAD as the Pentagon learned its lesson after the F-35 a joint project for both the Air Force and Navy proved to be far from ideal meanwhile Boeing which is already scaling back production of legacy models like the F-15 F-16 and FA18 has significant unused industrial and technological capacity the company simply too vital to the US defense sector to be left without contracts which would risk the loss of critical expertise moreover the recent scandals surrounding Boeing have led to massive internal reforms the new management is clamped down on the so-called efficient management practices putting real manufacturing back at the center of operations as for the F-47 itself solid information is still limited to key concepts this will be a heavyweight air superiority fighter positioned as a next generation replacement for the aging F-22 Raptor the primary design focus is long range capability essential for operations in the Indo-Pacific region clearly signaling where US strategic priorities are headed in the 2030s the aircraft is expected to feature low observability and a large payload capacity interestingly extreme maneuverability no longer appears to be a top priority seems the Pentagon has doubled down on the F-35's design philosophy where the aircraft might fly more like a penguin than an eagle but remains stealthy and deadly at long range in fact the F-47's main role likely won't be engaging in dog fights but rather serving as a sensor hub coordinating the actions of forward operating drones guiding surfaceto-air missiles and directing air-to-air missile strikes the aircraft is expected to be capable of sustained supersonic cruising at speeds up to Mach 2 and to reach an altitude comparable to or exceeding that of the F-22 a major focus of the program is adaptability meaning the F-47 must be easy to upgrade over time as battlefield requirements evolve both in terms of onboard equipment and software the F-47 will be powered by two next generation engines developed under the next generation adaptive propulsion program or NGAP created specifically for the ENGAD aircraft in August 2022 the US Air Force awarded framework contracts worth $975 million each to five leading American aerospace companies to design and test prototype NGAP engines these companies include GE Aerospace a division of General Electric Pratt and Whitney in partnership with Rathon Technologies Boeing Lockheed Martin and Northrup Grumman the last three are serving more as integrators than engine developers and the final engine choice is expected to be between two adaptive three stream concepts the XA 102 from GE Aerospace and the XA 103 from Prattton Whitney in early 2025 the Air Force expanded the contracts with GE Aerospace and Prattton Whitney to $3.5 billion each to support continued development and testing of their respective endgap engines interestingly the Chinese sixth generation fighter prototype known as the Changdu J36 reportedly uses three WS10C engines with afterburners this suggests that China has yet to achieve the required thrust levels in both dry and after burning modes and is compensating by installing three engines an arrangement that brings many obvious drawbacks in terms of appearance our only reference points are a few official composite images revealed in the Oval Office during Trump's announcement of Boeing's victory these show a fighter with a large cockpit canopy and a sharply swept wing with a pronounced dihedral angle it remains unclear whether the aircraft has vertical stabilizers but it likely does not as seen with China's Changdu J36 vertical stabilizers greatly compromise stealth and the F-47 is expected to be even less visible on radar than the already stealthy F-22 and F-35 true removing vertical stabilizers makes it more difficult to achieve aerodynamic stability and maneuverability but China's apparently managed it and the United States after all is the only country to have mass-produced tailless stealth bombers namely the B2 and B-21 the total cost of the ENGAD program is estimated at 20 billion the plan is to produce a fleet of 200 aircraft with the maximum unit cost including R&D reaching up to $300 million however the F-47 is projected to be cheaper to operate than the F-22 due to maturing technologies and a significant reduction in maintenance hours according to US Air Force Chief of Staff General David Alvin F-47 prototypes will take to the skies during the current Trump administration meaning before early 2029 it's also been revealed that since 2020 competing ENGAD teams have already built and flown several experimental demonstrator aircraft logging hundreds of flight hours during testing notably the Pentagon's vision of a sixth generation fighter appears to closely mirror that of China when China showcased three different sixth generation prototypes at the end of 2024 it sent shock waves through the US Air Force and was a major factor in reviving the ENGAD program which was on the verge of cancellation for the first time in decades American technological superiority and military aviation was seriously called into question trump's announcement appears aimed at restoring confidence in the US defense industry following the reputational blow caused by China's display of progress that may be why the president stated that the F-47 prototype had been undergoing secret testing for nearly 5 years unofficial sources claimed that experimental sixth generation aircraft have been flying since 2020 at classified locations including Edwards Air Force Base and the infamous Area 51 long associated with cuttingedge stealth technology and finally a small conspiracy theory why the F-47 designation originally the final contractor selection for this aircraft was scheduled for 2024 however between May and July 2024 President Joe Biden's administration effectively paused the program to re-evaluate its design concepts the ENGAD program was only restarted in late December 2024 likely influenced by the reelection of President Trump who had consistently supported the project during his first term in fact the ENGAD program saw some of its most important developments in 2018 and 2020 ultimately it was Trump who approved Boeing's proposal as the winner of the competition and here's the fun part trump is the 47th president of the United States put two and two together and the F-47 designation starts to look more symbolic than random there is however a more official explanation the F-47 name may be a nod to the legendary P47 Thunderbolt of World War II a heavy fighter that was one of the most powerful and effective aircraft of its time known for its ruggedness firepower and long range it played a key role in Europe especially against German forces and laid the foundation for the modern concept of the multi-roll heavy fighter so which version do you prefer could the F-47 eventually be named the Thunderbolt 3 don't forget the A-10 Thunderbolt 2 ground attack aircraft is already a living legend we hope that one day the F-47 earns that same iconic status and it certainly has all the ingredients to do so what do you think will the F-47 become a legend in its own right and more importantly will it outperform China's sixth generation Changdu J36 proving once again that the United States remains the global leader in military aviation especially in the realm of fighter aircraft share your thoughts in the comments thanks for watching and we'd appreciate it if you give us a like and subscribe to the channel see you in the next video [Music]

output.script: joining us. >> Yes, ma'am. >> Sounds like he just called the market bottom. >> Well, tech. Stocks posting their worst day in more than five years. The Nasdaq. Closing 6% lower today. Joining us now Dan Ives, Wedbush Securities global head of technology research. Dan, it looked pretty ugly. Out there today. You're usually bullish on the potential for technology. But this picture is complicated not just by the dollar impact of the. >> Tariffs. >> But by what happens to brand America around the globe where even this software has to be sold now. >> Yeah. I mean, look. It's a it's. >> Essentially an economic Armageddon. >> You know, if. >> These tariffs stay in place. And the reality is talking in front of a microphone in. >> The 202. >> Area code is a lot different than the reality of moving the supply chain. And I think it speaks to our point that when you look at China. Exposed names from. Nvidia to Apple to any of the semi names, I mean, this this is as. Nervous as I've seen investors going back to, you know, Covid March 2020. >> So what. >> Do investors need to listen for on these earnings calls? What are the fundamental numbers to watch perhaps when it comes to margins getting squeezed. To understand what the real dynamics are going to be throughout the rest of 25, and where you can continue to get a valuation premium. >> So I think. >> There's three things. >> I think. >> You have to look at one. >> I mean, Navarro talked on negotiations. >> You have. >> To assume that these tariffs don't hold in their current form. If they hold in their current form that then essentially you have 15 to 20% demand destruction across the board in terms of cost that are actually going to have to come through. And then to that point, I don't think a lot of companies even give guidance on their one Q conference calls given, you know, what we've seen in terms of the head scratching tariffs? The thing that you really have to focus on in terms like what demand destruction looks like in terms of when it comes to AI revolution, data center, build out inventory. And then of course, you start looking at consumer focus names like Apple. In terms of what that means for iPhones. The reality. >> Is. >> If you want if you want an iPhone made in the US and you want that for $3,500, we should make in the US, if you want it for $1,000, you keep it in China. So I think that's these are all the issues that investors are trying to sort of game out. >> So in light of that, I'll just use Apple as an example. There's just this automatic assumption that any kind of price increase tied to 54% tariffs on goods imported that have been made in China, iPhones perhaps included in that is going to be pushed out to consumers. Is that is that actually going to be the case, especially if you look at an Apple that has pretty robust margins and maybe is going to absorb some of that cost? >> Yeah. Mark. >> If it was. >> A smaller tariff, that's something maybe that they can absorb. But these are numbers I mean that that are I view as absurd. And I think many of you across tech. So there's only whoever's going to pay it. It's the consumer. And that's the reality. You get to buy tariffs all you want. Consumers are going to pay it on iPhones. They're going to pay it on electronics. They're going to pay it across the board. And that's really what you're seeing in terms of self I think right now tech stocks you can name like Apple essentially baking in numbers cuts 1,215%. And you. And margin erosion that could be more. So our view in terms of how we're navigating this very similar financial crisis is COVID 2020 is that you have to look on the other side, assuming some sort of normalized earnings into 25 and even 2026. And those are the names, whether it's Microsoft, Apple and some others, that's how you navigate some, you know, looking at the scenarios in terms of how these play out. >> That's interesting because we did get exemptions on semiconductors in the midst of these tariff announcements. But the other area, another area of the market that was very defensive today and held up relatively well were defense contractors themselves. Now, I realize, not necessarily the case for the palantir of the world, but in general, when you're talking about some of these types of companies that are exposed to government revenues that maybe are a little more domestically focused in terms of the stocks they've built out, is that a place to be investing right now? >> Yeah, I mean, I think Palantir and others. But if you look at Lockheed and some of the primary. Yeah, no doubt those are the ones that held up. I think a lot better in terms of defensive. But I think devil's in the details because the reality is when you look at the implementations, you look what comes from foreign perspective. You're talking 40, 50%. A lot of these imitations from a hardware perspective and others. So that's why our view is like what? And to your point, John, is like what are the second third derivatives? What's the ripple effect. What the demand destruction is. I think investors if you look here, these stocks are baking in recession into these stocks. If you think it's anything better and you're basically saying some sort of game of high stakes poker and there will be negotiation, then, you know, these are the names that you ultimately buy

output.script: is coding dead in 2025 [Music] well maybe but not in the way that you think we are not far from a world I think we'll be there in 3 to 6 months where AI is writing 90% of the code and then in 12 months we may be in a world where AI is writing essentially all of the code programming is vital but it's just different now so we're going to break up this video into five parts and explain exactly why coding as we know it is dead in 2025 but why programming is not you you you probably recall over the course of the last 10 years 15 years um almost everybody who sits on a stage like this would tell you it is vital that your children learn computer science everybody should learn how to program and in fact it's almost exactly the opposite it is our job to create computing technology such that nobody has to program and that the programming language is human everybody in the world is now a programmer a portion of this video has been sponsored by HubSpot okay so let's first take a step back when you first started to code you probably ended up choosing a highle language like Python Java or JavaScript and then maybe even a framework like React or Spring Boot but what you probably never had to do on the job was code in binary or physically work with a bunch of servers and cables in the little room in the back of your office those were the OG software and hardware engineers and kind of like how every generation before says you never had to work as hard as our generation it's somewhat true okay no we didn't have to painfully write things in binary or assembly but we still have to work harder in other ways we now have so much more information at our disposal that technology changes extremely quickly you always have to think on your feet and there's never any job security likewise coding in these highle languages is kind of like the boomers of the past you no longer have to spend hours on Stack Overflow to try to find the answer in fact you shouldn't because the next developer that comes along is just going to default to using Copilot and they'll be a lot faster and a lot more productive than you understanding this first is extremely important in understanding how to get past the death of coding as we know it today we're talking about vibe coding which is from a Andre Karpathy post that went viral recently there's a new kind of coding I call vibe coding where you fully give in to the vibes embrace exponentials and forget that the code even exists so this is a clip from YC's main channel they're talking about the newly coined term vibe coding and I've heard many different terms for this like the AI assisted developer the noode software engineer you name it vibe coding as the video suggests is just coding off of good vibes essentially not really coding but leaning very heavily on AI to code for you but the truth is people always find a way to market software engineering as something easy to do but if it was easy then everyone would be doing it the problem is there are a lot of software engineers but there are not a lot of decent software engineers and the no code approach doesn't mean no coding it just means less thinking about code a lot less for example if I wanted to build out functionality to hit an API that gave me basketball player stats for the past 5 years in the NBA and then use that data to come up with March Madness picks I would probably spend hours trying to build and deploy said API cleaning the data manually adding processing and ranking logic and then displaying the info on the web page but as a Vibe coder defaulting to AI generated code is a lot faster but here's the thing you still need to understand what to do with the code you can't just throw it into the void and hope that it works you still have to understand what code is needed you need tests that have good coverage using optimal data structures and algorithms utilizing solid principles and understanding the dynamics of system design i'm not saying that it hasn't become easier but the skills required are just shifting okay so leading on this whole no code approach I did mention that coding was dead but programming was not and by programming I just mean building off of intricate software systems this can include manually coding things but it doesn't have to i actually had a recent video where I talked about building AI agents without any code at all the cool thing about AI agents are that they're not just LLMs that summarize things for you they actually take action in that video I go through a demo of Operator by OpenAI where it opens up a browser on the cloud browses the web for grocery items to make apple pie and then orders the groceries for me and I set up an AI agent on my own within 5 minutes as well you can actually check that video out here this technologies limit is endless you can use AI agents to automate entire workflows for you without having to do any code this is the future of programming it's evolved into maintaining and designing overarching systems in a clean way this type of programming can get complicated so if you want a free resource to learn more I'd highly recommend checking out HubSpot's free AI agent playbook this playbook goes over a breakdown of things like what AI agents are and how they work how to get started with AI agents and even some common pitfalls to watch out for it also gives you a foundational understanding of the difference between an AI agent and any old AI chatbot for example as shown here AI agents won't just summarize information for you it'll actually do the thing here the guide shows that if you wanted to find your top performing blog posts and draft social media updates for them the AI agent would connect to an analytics API analyze top posts draft social media posts and even schedule the posts for you my favorite section is actually setting up an AI agent yourself as important as the theory is behind it it won't matter if you don't know how to create an AI agent yourself this guide sets up a framework to follow so you can start creating these agents on your own it even goes into detail about low precision versus high precision task frameworks and the common pitfalls that you should definitely avoid at the very end it even reflects on the relationship between AI and humans this 40-page guide is filled with golden nuggets and it's completely free i've linked the HubSpot guide in the description below so you definitely want to check it out okay now back to the video so in the same video clip that I showed you earlier Jensen talked about domain level expertise being on the rise the countries the people that understand how to solve a domain problem in digital biology or in education of young people or in manufacturing or in farming those people who understand domain expertise now can utilize technology that is readily available to you you now have a computer that will do what you tell it to do but what exactly does that mean in the context of software engineering he means having a deep specialized knowledge in a particular field and that's beyond just the technical skills required for coding now it's not just knowing how to code but also understanding context at a high level and knowing how to effectively apply AI within a new domain for example with healthcare this looks like an engineer that understands medical terminology workflows patient privacy laws and how doctors actually make decisions this gives us the ability to focus our problem solving on using the code rather than creating the code in the best possible way of course which by the way still means having an understanding of the code and the theory and how everything works problem solving has always been the foundation for software engineering so this part hasn't actually changed but if you treat it like a technology change then it'll be a lot easier to adapt to this AI revolution then learning new domains won't be hard either in fact it'll feel more creative as you get to explore the AI architecture side of systems and the domain that you're using these systems for do you remember working on a bug or a coding assignment and you just couldn't get one of the tests to run you had to spend hours looking things up on Stack Overflow or Googling random examples that could maybe be applied to your work this was honestly the most frustrating part of the process for me you may know most of the coding fundamentals but there's always something that you don't know and so you end up relying too much on either the gold or the garbage of the internet because let's be honest both exist now I'm not saying that AI can't give you garbage code it definitely can and I've seen it happen a lot but the cool thing is you don't have to put in the effort to manually search for things so even if it gives you gold or garbage you'll have to sift through that but it'll just be a lot faster and if you don't get what you want it'll at least try to modify things or give you a template to jump off of the old way of coding is definitely dead but there is a new way to program the environment around you and it just takes a new type of software engineer to do these things and the sooner you adapt to these changes the easier it'll be to level up your skills it's a marathon at the end of the day so don't get disheartened if you don't understand things or it doesn't come quickly for you just keep trying and pushing along and you'll eventually get
