of the country the aircraft was developed and built by Sichuan Tangen technology ctd and is equipped with two engines and designed for cargo Transportation it features ease of loading and unloading reliability safety and a high level of automation this unmanned aircraft is the largest in its class in China with a payload capacity of up to 2 metric tons its development aims to meet the growing demand for unmanned cargo transport particularly in remote or hard-to-reach areas the successful testing of this aircraft highlights China's significant advancements in unmanned aviation technology and its ambition to secure a leading position in this sector recently the new til Trader aw609 from the Italian company Leonardo made its first takeoff in landing on an aircraft carrier demonstrating the unique combination of aircraft speed and helicopter maneuverability this important event has opened new prospects for the use of the aw609 in military operations including Transportation search and rescue missions and support for Special Operations the aw609 is the world's first certified commercial tilt rotor capable of taking off and Landing vertically like a helicopter while achieving speeds of up to 500 kmph and a flight range of over 1,300 km like an airplane its unique design allows it to perform tasks in the most challenging conditions from maritime operations to missions in remote areas it can carry up to nine passengers or be equipped for specialized missions such as medical evacuation and Border Patrol Boeing Phantom Works has developed the high-tech unmanned aerial vehicle Boeing Phantom ey which is capable of operating at altitudes of up to 19,826 [Music] has a wingspan of 46 M and is powered by two internal combustion engines with a volume of 2.3 l specially Engineers from Kawasaki have developed the Next Generation cargo drone named K racer X2 capable of carrying up to 200 kg of cargo over a distance of more than 100 km this unmanned helicopter was created to address challenges in remote regions such as the mountainous areas of Japan where traditional Transportation methods are limited due to a shrinking Workforce and difficult terrain the new drone is equipped with a main rotor that has a diameter of 7 m and runs on high octane gasoline it has a flight range of 100 km with a working time of more than 1 hour at sea level it can lift up to Mountain huts and emergency zones during testing the ker X2 successfully completed trials at the Fukushima robot test field in recent years the United States has been actively developing and testing new supersonic passenger aircraft aiming to set new standards for Speed and efficiency in aviation for instance the startup hermus which was founded by former employees of SpaceX blue origin and generation orbit is developing a supersonic aircraft called quarter horse this aircraft is designed to reach speeds of up to 6,125 kmph five times the speed of sound in 2021 the United States Air Force allocated $60 million for flight testing of this reusable aircraft which could become the fastest in history additionally NASA in collaboration with Lockheed Martin has unveiled the experimental quiet supersonic aircraft x59 qu SST this plane is designed to fly at speeds 1.4 times the speed of sound approximately 1,480 kmph the main goal of the project is to develop technology that significantly reduces the sonic boom when breaking the sound barrier potentially Paving the way for the resumption of commercial supersonic flights over land these projects underscore the United shape and an engine located on the upper part of the fuselage at an altitude of 16.8 km the x59 can reach speeds of up to 1,488 kmph its innovative aerodynamics and noise reduction technology are output.script: Ukrainian su27 and mig29 fighter jets strike Russian fortifications Ammo Depot and Personnel using GBU 62 bombs Ukrainian Aviation is becoming increasingly active striking Russian ground targets with greater frequency and Effectiveness as Russian air defenses weaken along the front Ukrainian fighter jets and attack aircraft are operating with more freedom launching Precision strikes on enemy positions Supply Depot and armored columns the use of long range Western Munitions such as jdam ER bombs and Storm Shadow missiles has allowed Ukraine to hit high value targets deep Behind Enemy Lines additionally Ukraine's improved suppression of Russian air defenses has reduced risks to Pilots enabling more aggressive sorties this growing aerial dominance is Shifting the battlefield Dynamics putting Russian Ground Forces under constant pressure Russians took a direct hit from a Ukrainian drone on their bukka near aiva donet region the back is blown off one of them yells describing the destruction of their zmobile foree fore Ukrainian fighters of the 30th mechanized Brigade repelled a Russian mechanized assault in the soladar area of donet region halting the enemy's Advance the fighting in the soladar area of donet region has been Fierce and ongoing with both Russian and Ukrainian forces vying for control of this strategically important location soladar known for its extensive salt mines and proximity to other key cities like bakut has seen intense Urban combat Russian forces initially made advances pushing toward the town but Ukrainian troops utilizing well-coordinated defense strategies and terrain advantages have managed to slow down and repel many of the attacks the area has become a brutal Battleground with trench warfare artillery duels and Close Quarters engagements both sides are suffering heavy casualties as the terrain is difficult and fighting often involves Street to- Street combat leaving little room for maneuvering for Ukraine Ukraine holding soladar is crucial to maintaining control over the surrounding regions and preventing a Russian foothold in the area meanwhile Russian forces are determined to seize it as part of their broader objective to encircle Ukrainian positions in the denet region as the conflict drags on solidar remains a symbol of the brutal grinding war in eastern Ukraine with no clear Victor yet in sight the ongoing battle for soladar reflects the larger struggle in donet where both sides are engaged in a war of attrition in an attempt to protect their equipment from Ukrainian drone attacks Russians are upgrading their anti-drone Grill technology as the Thin netting proved ineffective so they decided to Shield the turret with steel cables in the luhansk direction Ukrainian forces from the 54th 81st and 10th brigades repelled 11 Russian assaults destroying two ATVs 10 light armored vehicles two buggies 31 motorcycles and eliminating 20 infantry soldiers in total Russia lost 109 person during these attacks the fighting in luhansk has been intense and brutal with Russian forces suffering significant losses as they struggle to advance in the region Ukrainian Defenders have managed to hold key positions using well fortified defensive lines Superior artillery and coordinated counterattacks to inflict heavy casualties on the Russian military Russian forces despite their numerical superiority have faced persistent resistance and logistical challenges particularly in the dense ter rain and urban areas Ukrainian forces have also made effective use of advanced drone technology and precision guided Munitions targeting Russian supply lines command centers and armored vehicles further crippling the enemy's ability to sustain operations the ongoing attrition is taking a toll on Russian morale with reports of low troop morale and logistical breakdowns in several instances Russian units have been forced to retreat after failed offensives leaving behind significant amounts of equipment the losses are compounded by a lack of proper reinforcements and coordination between different branches of the Russian military Ukrainian intelligence and reconnaissance have also played a key role in identifying and targeting vulnerable Russian positions leading to a number of successful ambushes as a result Russian forces have been unable to achieve their objectives in luhansk despite months of trying to capture the region the failure to breach Ukrainian defenses and the mounting losses are forcing Russia to reconsider its strategies especially as the region becomes increasingly fortified by Ukrainian forces residents of Russia's belgrod oblast feel satisfaction when Ukrainian drones Target Moscow where life remains unaffected by the war Ukraine's Military Intelligence reported citing an intercepted conversation on March 30th in an intercepted recording released by Ukraine's Military Intelligence a woman complains about losing sleep due to drone attacks and expresses approval of on Moscow saying they might prompt action she adds that while people in her oblast suffer Moscow continues dancing and singing the woman also laments an attack on kesn Yuga in belgorod and warns of worsening conditions if no action is taken on March 11th Russia faced a record drone assault including strikes on Moscow and its suburbs which mayor Serge soan called the largest attack yet Russia's defense Ministry claimed to have intercepted or shot down 337 drones including 91 over Moscow oblast Ukraine plans to request changes to a new draft agreement with the United States on Mineral Resources particularly asking for more American Investments according to a source familiar with the discussions a draft of the agreement reviewed by output.script: stocks mutual funds index funds ETFs what do all these things mean and which one should I be buying sit back and relax and let me do the heavy lifting I'm going to break down what these different terms mean and which ones are more advantageous for which reasons if you're ready to become a smarter investor then smash the like button and let's get started for more videos on investing or personal finance or even paying for college please subscribe to the channel so let's start at the beginning with what even the stock market is it's basically just a marketplace where you can buy individual small portions of companies that exist in the real world you're not just buying pieces of paper or electronic data that doesn't mean anything you're actually purchasing a partial ownership of a company that is existing in the real world doing business every day the people that run these companies have decided to split the company up into these tiny slivers of stock called shares when you go and buy a share you are purchasing one of these tiny slivers of ownership of the company which makes you part owner owner of a company that's pretty cool right but if you're going to be part owner of a company then you probably want to know a little bit about the companies right you want to make sure that it's worth you owning part of that company you want to make sure that they're going to do well that they're going to be successful there's a lot of data that goes into determining that which one should you dive in on and which one should you stay away from that could ultimately fail this is where individual stocks come in you can buy just one stock of one company and avoid every other company because you really believe in this one company however the danger of buying just one company stock is that if that company has a downturn or doesn't do well or ultimately fails and goes bankrupt then you've just lost all of your investments in one foul swoop has anybody heard of Enron so while there is potential to see very large gains if your one company does well there's also the possibility that you could lose it all so it's a highrisk potentially High reward opportunity but there are ways to invest in the stock market that minimize that risk dramatically now I'm not a financial adviser I just have throw that out there in the disclaimer here but for your typical beginner in investing in stocks I do not recommend going with individual stocks I recommend going with funds specifically index funds but we'll get there so you definitely want to stay watching till the end so breaking down what a fund is in terms of a mutual fund think about it like buying flowers if you buy one flower you've bought one stock but if that one flow dies you have nothing however if you buy a whole bouquet of flowers you not only have one stock you have a whole bunch of stocks that are all part of the bouquet when you're buying into a mutual fund you're usually buying into a whole collection of stocks that have been bundled into one price and you pay $10 for the whole bundle instead of you know $2 for that flower $7 for this flower 20 bucks for this flower $2 for that flow it's just one price and it gets you all the flowers another way I've heard it described is like honeybees again if you buy one b and that b dies well then you put all this money towards your 1B but now he's dead you've lost it all but if you buy a whole Colony a whole beeh hiive now if any one you know one two three a whole bunch of the bees don't do well they've got all these other bees making up for it so you're still getting your honey even though some of those bees haven't made it but if you only bought one it's a lot riskier if that one bee does really well hey cool but if that bee dies you're in trouble so I would say instead of buying individual flowers and bees buy the bouquet buy The Beehive buy the mutual fund but there's a specific type of mutual fund that I recom recommend coming up the time that I don't recommend now they're not all bad some of them are good but personally for beginners getting started I would stay away from actively managed funds the reason is because they have higher fees usually around 1% now a 1% fee doesn't sound like a lot but if you look at it over the course of long-term investment strategy it can be a huge difference if you were to invest $100 over the course of 35 years $100 a month for 35 years you would end up at an 8% % rate of return around $26,000 a little bit more than that if that rate was consistent over that full time if you had to pay a mutual fund manager 1% of that then your returns actually are more like 7% instead of 8% because that extra percent is actually being paid out each year to the fund manager so now after those same 35 years have elapsed instead of having $26,000 in your account you only have about $165,000 in your account that 1% annual fee cost you almost $40,000 and $40,000 compared to the potential 206,000 that's almost 20% lost so while you're looking at 1% thinking that's not very much but over the course of 35 years that turned into over 20% loss that you're paying somebody else to manage your money for you so over the long haul it can really kill your growth potential which brings us to index funds and why I think they're a good way to go for beginners an index fund can do the same thing as an actively man managed fund except it simply mirrors a portion of the market or in the case that I recommend the entire market and then you can benefit from that same fund analogy where if some companies do poorly but others do well you're still going to grow over time but their fees are exponentially lower in fact if you look at VT Sachs which is vanguard's total market index fund their fee is 0.04% so instead of 1% or more to an actively managed fund manager you're paying 0.0 4% so if we use our previous example if you taking $100 a month for 35 years and that ends up going at an 8% interest rate or growth rate you end up with about $26,000 at the end of that well if you're removing 0.04% as a fee that you pay annually then your returns over those same 35 years is actually about $25,000 so instead of losing 40 Grand to a mutual fund manager you've lost one maybe $2,000 over that same period of time to pay for an index fund so so your growth potential is about the same as far as your total return but the amount you lose in fees to an index fund is way less way less I would always do it this way so for me that's the huge selling point of index funds over mutual funds that are actively managed now there are different kinds of index funds as well you can have index funds that are just indexed towards a specific industry so I again recommend something like an index that follows the S&P 500 or even broader than that like a VT sack VT sax vtsax is just the ticker symbol for this mutual fund that Vanguard offers that mirrors the total market and another reason to go with index funds is because Warren Buffett bet hedge fund managers that the S&P 500 would actually outperform their Investments over 10 years and he got people to accept his bet of a million dollars to try to beat the market and over 10 years the S&P 500 Index outperformed the hedge fund managers now there were years where the hedge fund managers did better but over the course of the Long Haul the full 10 years they couldn't beat the market consistently over time that's what managers try to say they say we'll pick things that are going to beat the market hey any given day month or year they might and that's what they're going to point to to say well this is how we've done it for this year and that year and and so we're super successful but over the course of your retirement like preparing for 10 20 30 years no fund manager is going to consistently beat the market over a 30-year period period at least a very very small portion of them will and the odds that you've picked the one that will are very low so it's better to just stick with Index Fund investing for the long term and that's a more secure way to guarantee growth over the long-term Investments and who am I to argue with Warren Buffett right and then there are ETFs these are called exchang traded funds ETFs are like index funds with a few key differences ETFs can be bought and sold throughout the day so as you have probably Seen On TV throughout the day a stock market price can go up or down so with an ETF you can buy the price at this second you can look online at a on a broker which offers ETFs and you can say I want the pricee now and then you buy it at that price an index fund is bought and sold at the price that is set at the end of the trading day so you can't buy in the middle of the day at a specific price point that you want right this second it doesn't work like that but for long-term investors thinking 20 or 30 years the specific and minimal differences between being able to pick the price uh at you know 2 in the afternoon as opposed to the end of the day it's going to have a minimal effect over the course of your Investments so it's it's kind of just a preference thing and the other key difference is the minimum investment required to get started so with an index fund remember we talked about VT saxs the minimum requirement to invest in VT saxs is $3,000 however the ETF version of VT saxs you can invest for the price of a single share and there are also Brokers like Robin Hood that allow you to purchase fraction shares so if a if a single stock share was $100 but you didn't have $100 you only had $20 then with Robin Hood you could invest just $20 and buy one fifth of one share and so you can buy fractional shares so you don't even have to have the price of a full share and you definitely don't have to have the $3,000 minimum investment to invest straight into an index fund like BT saxs so either way index funds and ETFs are a great way for beginners to get started in the market with an investment that is already Diversified and are already has low fees so if you have any further questions about stocks mutual funds index funds or ETFs go ahead and throw that in the comments and smash that like buttton

output.description:
Douglas Holtz-Eakin, Former Congressional Budget Office Director, Charlotte Howard, Executive Editor at The Economist and Tim Miller, former RNC Spokesperson join Nicolle Wallace on Deadline White House with to discuss the continued plummet of the stock market, and how long the business community many of whom supported Donald Trumpâ€™s re-election, will tolerate his policies which have single handedly hurt the economy.Â Â

output.title: How I Retired Early With $3 Million At 36 In San Diego | Fired Up
output.description:
Jeremy Schneider, 41, lives in San Diego and achieved FIRE â€” financial independence, retire early â€” at 36. In 2015, he sold his Internet company RentLinx for just over $5 million. In 2017, he retired from corporate work with about $3 million. Schneider traveled and played video games in that first year of early retirement. Then in 2019, he started Personal Finance Club, which teaches people learn to save and invest money. Since launching, the company has made nearly $1 million in sales. 

Subscribe to CNBC Make It.:Â http://cnb.cx/2kxl2rf

output.script:
I think FIRE is the concept that
retirement is not an age. A lot of us go through the world
thinking that when we turn 65, something magical is going to happen and you get
to retire. And that's not true because if you don't
have any money, you can't stop working when you're 65. And the flip side of
that, you don't need to wait until you're 65 either. If you have enough
money, you can retire at 55 or 45 or 36 like I did. And so it's just kind of
turning this whole idea of traditional retirement age on its head. My name is Jeremy Schneider. I'm 41 years old. I live in San Diego
and I reached financial independence at 36. I grew up in southeast Michigan, outside
of Detroit. My parents were kind of middle class. I went to college at the University of
Michigan. I studied computer science. I was in college from 1998 to 2002 when
the dotcom boom was happening, and I would see these young people just
a few years older than me who were making millions with tech startups. And it inspired me to start young. And then as I was graduating from
Michigan, I turned down a job offer from Microsoft to start my own Internet
company. But I recorded my bank account the
moment the wire came through. I clicked
refresh and it jumped from $100,000 or so to over $2 million, which was pretty
surreal. And it was very abstract. I don't really know how much money that
was. The day after the company sold, I was
suddenly in integration mode with this very nice company that just gave me
millions of dollars. It was an especially busy time and so I
couldn't just like ditch and head to Fiji. I just saw that as like a finish
line that when I sold the company and made millions, I would just like be on
this beach. I was talking to the CEO of the company
that bought our company and I told him that vision. I was like, "All right,
I'm going to be on the beach." And he asked me, "What are you going to
do when you get back?" And what he meant was, you can't spend
your life on a beach, you know? I mean, you could, but that's kind of a
crappy life. So I guess it dawned on me that I
couldn't just, like, spend the rest of my days sipping Mai Tais on the beach
because that would be really boring. I worked for the company that bought us
for two years, and then in April of 2017, I quit my job and officially was
retired or financially independent at the age of 36. And that was the year when I played
video games and traveled for a year. That first year of being unemployed or
retired or whatever you want to call it. It was just kind of like every day was
the weekend. I would always get asked like, "What do
you do all day if you're not at work?" And my answer would be like, "What do
you do on Saturdays?" It's amazing how quickly your time fills
up with meeting with friends or working out or working on projects or playing
games or traveling. And so I kept really busy and it was
really fun at first. But as the year dragged on, I found that
there's something missing in my life. There actually was a moment where I had
an epiphany where a year after I retired and played video games for a year, I
was on a vacation in Mexico and for a week I wasn't playing this game
Starcraft II, which I had become very addicted to. And I realized what a
massive waste of time that was and how I basically just gave away a year of my
life to play this game. And so I decided that I didn't want to
do that anymore. And so I came back and before I played
another game, I uninstalled it cold turkey from my computer and haven't
played it ever since. Get it out of there. At the time, it
wasn't very calculated that I needed exactly $3 million. It was more of just a sense of over the
course of two years, the growth of my investments were outpacing my actual
W-2 income. Now, with the benefit of knowing about
the FIRE movement much more in depth, I know about the 4% rule, which says you
can live on about 4% of your investment portfolio. 4% of $3 million is
$120,000, which was like twice as much as I'd ever spent in a year. And so I think that I was easily FIRE at
$3 million. My net worth is about $4.4 million. $1.1 million is the value of my home you
see behind me. I was a lifelong renter until I was 38
years old. I was actually living in my friend's
garage, which was converted to an apartment. I have a traditional IRA
with about $50,000 and a new 401(k) with my new company that's got about
$15,000. The other $3 million or so is all in a
taxable account just because it didn't fit in the tax advantaged accounts. I think my biggest expense is probably travel right now. I'm just going on vacation. Restaurants, I think I spend about $800
a month. I don't have a mortgage. My home that
you see behind me is 100% paid for. I actually applied for a mortgage and
was denied because I didn't have a job. And so I just wrote a check and paid
cash. I don't buy things if I don't think I
need them. So, for example, if I look over to my
left, I see the keyboard on my computer, which I use every single day, which is
from college. And so people walk into my house and
they see this like 1998 era keyboard and think it's ridiculous, but it's a great
keyboard and it works fine. And so why would I spend more money if I
don't need to? I live alone, don't have any roommates
or a wife just yet. Welcome to my home. I live here in sunny San Diego in this
two-bedroom condo. Come on, I'll show you around. This is my living room where I watch
CNBC Make It. This is my office. I sit here. I make Instagram posts,
TikTok reels. The kitchens over here. When I bought this house for $712,000,
everything was different. There was a gigantic wall that came
right down here. I knocked down the wall, remodeled the
kitchen from this big built-in table. It was about $100,000 in total for the
remodel. Guest bathroom. I actually did the tile work in that
bathroom myself. One of the few parts of the remodel. This is the master bedroom that includes
the peak view of Mission Bay in sunny San Diego way over there in the corner. Over here is the master bathroom. When I bought the place, this was all
pink with a tub. And I put in a total new shower. Tile. One of these fancy lighted mirrors so I
can look at myself every morning. Do my daily affirmations. And that is the house tour. I'm going to bed. I started an Instagram account where my
plan was to share daily personal finance and money tips. Every single day I would get the exact
same question, which is like, "How do I get started investing? What's a Roth IRA? What's an index fund? What investment do I buy?" And then after a year and a half, it was
mid 2020 and I was kind of bored during the pandemic. And I essentially started
a company by mistake by launching a paid product. I wanted to create just a
video course that walked through it that kind of was like a brain dump from my
brain to everyone who was asking these questions. So I decided to sell the
video course for $79. And the first week of launching this
course, we made like $110,000. And so I was like, "Oh, it took me four
years on my first company to make $110,000. So this might actually be a real
business." I do a 25% profit share. So 25% of our profit is split among the
employees based on seniority. I have a friend, and about 10 years ago
we started a website called What's That
Charge? Which helps you identify mysterious
charges on your credit card statement. My buddy and I own it 50/50. And so it's been live for 10 years. I think we're going to make like $7,000
this month. I think that I've found peace with where
I'm at in life financially. I don't feel like I need more to be
happy. And so I'm not really chasing any big
financial goals. I'm still not totally immune to ideas of
like a bigger place or a vacation home or something like that. So that might
be nice if the company does well or my investments continue to grow. If I didn't have income from my current
job, I can live forever on my investments. I'm living way below the
safe withdrawal rate from my portfolio short of some sort of economic
apocalypse in the future, which no one can predict. But I can live forever on
my investments.

output.script: I get asked all the time in stream you know if I were to start over again and have to relearn all the stuff that I know what would I do today to learn about the lowest level for those of you that don't know my name is l level learning my day job I'm a security researcher but on the internet I teach people how to code in languages like C and teach them how computers work through languages like assembly and others if you're new here welcome to the channel hit that sub button and let's learn how to be lowl together so how would I get from zero to lowlevel as fast as possible thought this question really hard and I came up with the following three answers three things that I would do today to get good at the low level starting with number one code in a lowlevel language this probably goes without saying but if you know how to code right now maybe you know how to code in python or Ruby or God forbid JavaScript I would say take that knowledge of programming and go and learn a language that gives you raw unfettered access to the memory of your process space and the language I recommend for that is the c programming language I know there's a lot of talk and I talk about this a lot on my YouTube channel if C is the appropriate language for the future when it comes to systems programming I think that rust eventually will take over for C we're not talking about that today in this video I want to talk about why C is the best language to learn with also we're not going to get into the holy war of whether or not C is a high or low-level language for the purposes of this video C is a low-level language discussed in the comments learning to code effectively in C forces you to learn effective memory management it forces you to learn how to write code that is bulletproof because if you don't the code will just inherently be unsafe there are lots of things you have to do in C to not leak memory to not give your code access to hackers and to not have the crash the code just crash whenever it runs the number one project I tell people to write when they're trying to learn to code maybe they know the language but don't have a project to go after is to write an HTTP server and I know that sounds fairly Advanced for somebody who may be new to a language but it will teach you not only the ins and outs of the HTTP RFC but a lot of really important things about programming for example when you're writing the HTTP parser you have to not only write the code that adheres to the RFC but then you also have to think of your code defensively you're going to be inprocessing and reading code from literally anybody on the internet you have to treat your code as if it's being attacked you have to code defensively writing an HTTP server will allow you to get really familiar with how to read the documentation of a language you're not just going to know the networking stack off the top of your head you have to learn how to read Man pages read documentation and read how return values work in the language of your choosing I think learning C teaches you how computers work at a fairly high level so go and take your programming knowledge and learn a language like C as step one step two go learn an assembly variant I'm not saying you have to be some wizard who can just look at an assembly blob and tell you exactly what's going on as fast as possible I am saying that knowing an assembly variant and knowing how the CPU works at the instruction level gives you a really really good understanding of how your code is going to behave and also if you can look at a blob of c and figure out basically how it's going to happen under the hood in the CPU architecture it gives you a superpower in choosing what code you make and deciding how to design your code so that it performs better the best way you can learn assembly right now is by taking this snippet of C code and I'll put it in the description below and go and compile that in if you can object dump this piece of code go to the main function in reverse engineer how it works you will learn the basic 101 of that CPU architecture and that will give you a significant advantage on how things work and number three once you've learned how to code in a low-l language once you've begin to understand when you write that low-l code what architecture code gets spit out by the compiler and generally how the architecture works I recommend learning the basics of reverse engineering now this pays off in a number of ways one maybe your job is just a malware reverse engineer maybe you're a Bug Hunter looking for bugs and taking binaries apart or maybe you're just somebody who is looking at code and you can't figure out why it doesn't work learning the basics of reverse engineering will teach you fundamentally not only how things work but how things are engineered and what the final output of the compiler will be also when you do reverse engineering challenges typically they're all based around a specific thing that you should know or like a specific fact like maybe it has to do with the Trap flag in the Intel CPU or maybe it has to do with the global offset table all of these challenges teach you a little thing that you can kind of put into your toolbox of knowledge that over time you'll just begin to H have a holistic picture of how binaries are how binaries are constructed in the Linux operating system for example and I highly recommend going to crack. one this is not sponsored this is not an ad it's just a website that I like where there are people who write reverse engineering challenges and you can download them run them on your computer run them in a VM because you have no idea if the code is malicious or not um but I think these challenges are really cool and an easy and fast way to learn the skills of reverse engineering and ultimately one of the lowest level techniques and then finally actually number four secret bonus um I think that another way to get really good at low level stuff is to pick up a board to learn to write C on that board so this for example is an stm32 it's an arm-based board this is the stm32 F7 nucleo if you can learn C if you then learn an assembly architecture if you can then get that code to run on a specific architecture of microcontroller so again be it like an STM maybe an Arduino or risk v-b Bo an esp32 something like that it will give you the ability to read a data sheet to understand how to interpret that data sheet and how to crossport your code to a board that can run somewhere else as Computing gets more advanced as computers get older and older and they get more technologically Superior as time goes on I feel like we lose touch with how CPUs work at a basic level I can literally take out my iPhone and access any information that I need to in the world and the whole Magic of what's going on we literally tricked rocks into thinking I think it's kind of lost on us so part of what I made this YouTube channel to do is to teach people and remind people that you know computers work and to make sure that we have a cohort of people moving on into the future that once the gray beards of the world lest tals of the world that built these systems move on and possibly pass away you know we have the second generation of low-l Architects that that know how CPUs work so if you think that's cool or you enjoyed this video or you want to be a part of that cohort hit that sub button really appreciate it and uh yeah we'll see you guys on the next video you can go check out this other video that I made about an interview question that I got asked it was really cool and it taught me actually a lot about how CPUs work you can go find that out right there see you guys

output.title: How Far Can The Voyager 1 Travel?
output.description: How far can the Voyager 1 even travel? Since its launch on September 5, 1977, the voyager 1 has ventured beyond our solar system, and is providing unprecedented views of the outer planets and interstellar space. From capturing the intricate details of Jupiter's storms and Saturn's rings to the iconic "Pale Blue Dot" image that portrays Earth's fragile beauty, Voyager 1 has significantly expanded our understanding of the universe. Even at a staggering distance of 176 astronomical units from the Sun, it continues to communicate with Earth through the Deep Space Network.
output.tags: Voyager 1, space exploration, NASA, interstellar travel, solar system, outer planets, Jupiter, Saturn, cosmic rays, Deep Space Network, Golden Record, astronomy, spacecraft, heliosphere, Pale Blue Dot, space science, astronomical units, space mission, interstellar medium, cosmic journey
output.script:
On September 5th, 2027, the voyager 1 will haveÂ 
been officially traveling in space for 50 years. At this date, given its current speed of aroundÂ 
38,000 mph, it is expected to be 176 astronomicalÂ Â  units or about 24 light hours away from theÂ 
sun. However if it travels at this speed,Â Â  it would take 300 years to reach theÂ 
inner boundary of the Oort Cloud,Â Â  and 40,000 years before it reaches another star. Nevertheless, over the next billion years,Â 
where will it travel? And what will it see? But before answering that, lets take a step back. The primary mission of Voyager 1,Â 
along with its twin, Voyager 2,Â Â  was to explore the outer planets of the solarÂ 
system. Voyager 1 was specifically tasked withÂ Â  conducting close-up studies of Jupiter and Saturn,Â 
their moons, and their magnetic environments.Â  Its trajectory was designed to take it pastÂ 
Jupiter in March 1979, and Saturn in NovemberÂ Â  1980. Interestingly, when it approached Jupiter,Â 
the spacecraft's cameras captured intricate cloudÂ Â  patterns, massive storms, and the planet'sÂ 
faint ring system. One of the mission's mostÂ Â  iconic images is the detailed view of the GreatÂ 
Red Spot, which is a gigantic storm larger thanÂ Â  Earth. Voyager 1 also turned its attention toÂ 
Jupiter's moons. It discovered that Io is theÂ Â  most volcanically active body in the solar system,Â 
showing erupting volcanoes and vast lava flows. In addition, its images of EuropaÂ 
revealed a smooth, icy surface,Â Â  hinting at the possibility of a subsurface oceanÂ 
beneath the moon's icy crust. A year later,Â Â  the voyager 1 reached Saturn. The spacecraft'sÂ 
images showcased the intricate structure ofÂ Â  Saturn's rings, revealing countlessÂ 
ringlets and gaps within the rings,Â Â  including the previously unseen F ring.Â 
Like with Jupiters moons, voyager 1 providedÂ Â  detailed views of Saturns moons. But perhapsÂ 
the most significant discovery was the thick,Â Â  orange atmosphere of Titan, Saturn'sÂ 
largest moon. The dense atmosphere,Â Â  rich in nitrogen and hydrocarbons, suggestedÂ 
the presence of complex organic molecules. Almost a decade later in 1990, the voyager 1Â 
started on the extended phase of its journey,Â Â  known as the Voyager Interstellar Mission,Â 
which was aimed to explore the outermostÂ Â  edge of the Sun's domain, known as theÂ 
heliosphere, and to venture beyond intoÂ Â  the interstellar medium. This was also whereÂ 
the famous pale blue dot picture was taken. 8 years after this, it passed the pioneer 10,Â 
officially making it the furthest man-made object. (Voyager 1 surpassed Pioneer 10 to become theÂ 
most distant human-made object from the Sun onÂ Â  February 17, 1998. At that time, VoyagerÂ 
1 was about 69.4 astronomical units (AU)Â Â  from the Sun. An astronomical unit is theÂ 
average distance from the Earth to the Sun,Â Â  approximately 93 million miles (150 millionÂ 
kilometers), so Voyager 1 was about 6.4Â Â  billion miles (10.3 billion kilometers) fromÂ 
the Sun when it achieved this milestone) - And almost 15 years later on August 25th 2012, itÂ 
crossed the heliopause and entered interstellarÂ Â  space, providing the first direct measurements ofÂ 
cosmic rays, magnetic fields, and the density ofÂ Â  interstellar medium, offering interesting insightsÂ 
into the nature of the space between the stars. The Voyager 1 maintains its communication withÂ 
Earth through a High Gain Antenna, which is aboutÂ Â  3.7 meters in diameter. This antenna focusesÂ 
the radio waves, allowing the spacecraft toÂ Â  send and receive signals over the vast distancesÂ 
of space. It specifically communicates with theÂ Â  Deep Space Network, which is a collection ofÂ 
large radio antennas located in California,Â Â  Spain, and Australia. This placement, with eachÂ 
station positioned roughly 120 degrees apart inÂ Â  longitude around the globe, ensures that asÂ 
the Earth rotates, at least one facility isÂ Â  always in a position to maintain a line of sightÂ 
with any spacecraft, allowing for continuousÂ Â  communication. These large dishes are capableÂ 
of communicating with spacecrafts billions ofÂ Â  miles away which is how they can communicate withÂ 
the voyager space probes. The signals travel atÂ Â  the speed of light and can take around 20Â 
hours to reach Earth. This is because theÂ Â  Voyager 1 uses the high-gain antennas to directÂ 
a narrow beam of radio waves towards Earth, andÂ Â  since radio waves are a form of electromagneticÂ 
radiation, they travel at the speed of light. The spacecraft's ability to communicateÂ 
and operate is fueled by radioisotopeÂ Â  thermoelectric generators. These generatorsÂ 
harness electricity from the heat releasedÂ Â  by the decay of plutonium-238, poweringÂ 
Voyager 1's instruments, onboard computers,Â Â  and radio transmitters. The RTGs, with a half-lifeÂ 
of about 87.7 years, experience a power declineÂ Â  of roughly four watts annually. It is anticipatedÂ 
that by 2025, Voyager 1 will lack sufficient powerÂ Â  for any scientific instrument operation. BeyondÂ 
this point, although Voyager 1 will continue itsÂ Â  silent journey through space, we will no longerÂ 
receive new data or signals from the spacecraft. But in any case, the Voyager 1 carries a GoldenÂ 
Record, which is a 12-inch gold-plated copperÂ Â  disk containing sounds and images selectedÂ 
to portray the diversity of life and cultureÂ Â  on Earth. It's a time capsule intended for anyÂ 
extraterrestrial life form or future humans whoÂ Â  might find it. The record includes greetings in 55Â 
languages, music from various cultures and eras,Â Â  natural sounds of Earth, and a selection ofÂ 
images showing life and the human condition. So how far can the voyager 1 even travel? Realistically, based on its trajectoryÂ 
and the vastness of space, the voyagerÂ Â  1 is far more likely to experience structuralÂ 
degradation over time due to factors such asÂ Â  micro meteoroid impacts, cosmicÂ 
radiation, and thermal cycling,Â Â  than to be significantly affected byÂ 
the gravitational influence of a star orÂ Â  planet. Therefore it's possible that Voyager 1'sÂ 
structure could remain recognizable for hundredsÂ Â  of millions to a few billion years, barringÂ 
any catastrophic collisions with large objects. By this time, it will have traveled aroundÂ 
a quintillion miles, which is only aboutÂ Â  1.7% of the Milky Wayâ€™s diameter, butÂ 
it wouldâ€™ve have seen numerous stars. Given its current trajectory towards theÂ 
constellation Ophiuchus, during its lifetime,Â Â  the voyager 1 could potentially passÂ 
by the constellations Hercules, Lyra,Â Â  Cygnus, Draco, and Camelopardalis. TheÂ 
number of stars in these constellationsÂ Â  could range from a thousand to tens of thousands. Its worth noting, that over billions of years, theÂ 
spacecraft's trajectory will be influenced by manyÂ Â  factors, including gravitational encounters suchÂ 
as those from molecular clouds, passing stars,Â Â  or even the tidal forces from the MilkyÂ 
Way itself. As the Milky Way rotates,Â Â  its gravitational forces and thoseÂ 
of nearby galaxies and interstellarÂ Â  objects will subtly alter Voyager 1'sÂ 
course. These changes, though smallÂ Â  over short time scales, can accumulateÂ 
to significant deviations over eons. Furthermore, over such vast timescales, the starsÂ 
themselves will have moved significantly fromÂ Â  their current positions, and the constellationsÂ 
as we know them, will have altered or ceased toÂ Â  exist in their present forms based on newÂ 
stars forming and old ones dying, ensuringÂ Â  that the galaxy of the distant future will beÂ 
significantly different from the one we see today. Given these uncertainties, predicting VoyagerÂ 
1's exact journey becomes an exercise inÂ Â  probabilities rather than certainties. ItsÂ 
interaction with the interstellar medium,Â Â  including potential encounters with dust, gas,Â 
and other particles, will also play a role inÂ Â  its long-term trajectory and condition. TheÂ 
spacecraft may also pass through regions ofÂ Â  varying densities in the galaxy, from theÂ 
relatively sparse outer halo to potentiallyÂ Â  denser regions nearer the galactic core,Â 
each with its own gravitational nuances. However, Voyager 1's journey continuesÂ 
to embody the spirit of exploration andÂ Â  discovery that defines human curiosityÂ 
as it travels the uncharted territoriesÂ Â  of scientific knowledge andÂ 
understanding of the universe.

output.title: Female Pilot of US Air Force F-16 Fighter Jet Takes Off Insane at Full Speed
output.description:
Female Pilot of US Air Force F-16 Fighter Jet Takes Off Insane at Full Speed 

Amid the roar of jet engines, a female pilot from the United States Air Force (USAF) expertly maneuvers her F-16 Fighting Falcon with calm precision and outstanding skill. In a recent combat mission in the Middle East, this pilot played a crucial role in a precision bombing operation against enemy targets. 

The presence of female pilots in combat operations is no longer unusual in the US Air Force. Yet every time they step into action, they prove that their capabilities are equal to those of their male counterparts. This mission served as a platform for a female aviator to demonstrate her ability under immense pressure and responsibility.

#f16 #f16fighter #f16fighterjet #femalepilot #usairforce #fullspeed

output.script: [Music] amid the roar of jet engines a female pilot from the United States Air Force USAF expertly maneuvers her F-16 Fighting Falcon with calm precision and outstanding skill in a recent combat mission in the Middle East this pilot played a crucial role in a precision bombing operation against enemy targets the presence of female pilots in combat operations is no longer unusual in the US Air Force yet every time they step into action they prove that their capabilities are equal to those of their male counterparts this mission served as a platform for a female aviator to demonstrate her ability under immense pressure and responsibility her F-16 was fully armed carrying advanced munitions such as GBU12 Paveway 2 laserg guided bombs and JDAM joint direct attack munition smart bombs the mission was part of a coordinated air strike campaign to destroy hidden enemy weapons facilities in a remote desert region before takeoff the pilot and her ground crew underwent a detailed briefing she reviewed target maps strike scenarios and weather conditions that could affect the flight full concentration and quick decision-making were critical in this highstakes mission with clearance from the control tower her F-16 roared off from a forward deployed air base in the Middle East within minutes she reached operational altitude and began maneuvering toward the target zone using the aircraft's advanced radar and navigation systems she scanned for target coordinates communicating with escort and reconnaissance aircraft over radio she received real-time updates on enemy positions and terrain just moments before bomb release she executed evasive maneuvers to dodge potential surfaceto-air threats she then stabilized the aircraft locked onto the target using a laser targeting pod and released two precisiong guided bombs seconds felt like minutes in the air but in no time a powerful explosion erupted on the ground the target was successfully destroyed and a plume of black smoke rose high into the sky the mission wasn't over yet she continued circling the area to monitor for possible counterattacks and coordinated with other aircraft still engaged in operations overhead in a post mission interview the pilot emphasized that rigorous training and strong team support were key to success "i'm just one small part of a big team we all work together to accomplish the mission accurately and safely," she said her journey as a combat pilot began years ago when she entered the USAF flight training program though initially doubted due to lingering stereotypes about female pilots she proved that discipline mental toughness and technical skill are what truly matter in the cockpit of the F-16 there is no distinction between male and female performance is measured by quick decision-m situational awareness and the ability to control the aircraft in extreme conditions and in this mission she delivered flawlessly her squadron commander praised her courage and precision describing the operation as one of the cleanest and most effective air strikes in recent months back at the base she was greeted with applause and warm embraces from her fellow airmen not only did she return safely but she also secured a critical victory for the mission this operation stood as a powerful symbol of the growing role of women in modern military forces from pilots to technicians women are increasingly recognized and respected within the US military structure in every training and mission female pilots like her often feel they have to work twice as hard to earn recognition but she never complains i chose this path and I will walk it with all my heart she affirmed with an ever growing flight log she has become a role model for aspiring female aviators she also takes part in mentoring programs to help guide new cadets at the Air Force Academy her success in precision bombing demonstrates how advanced technology like targeting systems and smart munitions reach their full potential when operated by highly skilled pilots the involvement of female pilots in strategic air operations has broadened the US military's vision of building an inclusive and high-performance force they're not just supporting elements they are frontline warriors in modern combat looking ahead she is committed to continuously sharpening her skills she believes that every mission carries a profound responsibility that must be approached with professionalism and integrity and for many she now stands as an inspiring figure who proves the sky is not the limit but the beginning of limitless possibilities her achievements have not gone unnoticed beyond the air base military leaders and policymakers have cited her performance as an example of the evolving role of women in combat and the importance of diversity in leadership and frontline roles her story has even begun to circulate among defense circles as a case study in operational excellence and gender integration in interviews with her fellow squadron members many expressed admiration for her calm demeanor under fire and sharp tactical thinking "she doesn't flinch," "Even when we're flying into high threat zones," said one of her wingmen "that kind of confidence inspires the rest of us to stay sharp when not flying missions." She dedicates time to training simulations and mission planning she also advocates for better outreach to young women interested in military aviation often speaking at recruitment events and high schools to encourage the next generation of pilots her experience also contributes to refining operational doctrine after each mission she participates in debriefs where pilots discuss what went right what went wrong and how to improve her insights often drawn from the unique perspective she brings have helped shape more agile and adaptive air strike strategies as her career advances she hopes to one day lead a combat squadron "i want to pay it forward," she said "i was given an opportunity to fly and fight for my country and now I want to make sure others get that same chance no matter their background or gender [Music]

output.tags: Spacedock, space dock, spacedock, f-47, jet, jet fighter, fighter jet, fighter, aircraft, us, america, plane, sci-fi, tech, technology, f-302, ace combat, drones, drone fighters, loyal wingman, remote, control, lore, history, analysis, review, breakdown, summary, retrospective, specifications, news, update, reveal, sixth generation, sixth gen fighter, boeing, stealth, canards, best, scene, worst, good, bad
output.script: [Music] hello everybody and welcome back to Space Talk i'm Hujana and today we're looking at Boeing's newly revealed F47 6th gen fighter jet because I thought it would be fun to speculate about some neat near future sci-fi tech it might have i won't be going over every sci-fi plane tech though because it's unlikely to have stuff like the magic thought control from Firefox but it may just be equipped with lasers like lots of things in Ace Combat have had for many years now jet engines do produce a tremendous amount of power that could be tapped to run a laser weapon though most likely one just for defensive purposes it would be there to shoot down incoming missiles and such like the one the Medusa has in nuclear option the question is whether that's actually practical considering you need optics and a way to point a thing like a turret or something which wouldn't be particularly stealthy maybe something with a very small arc of fire peeking through a window but eh a better fit would be a phased array laser which would be flat yet still able to point its beam all over the place but those things are tech kind of far off having since you need nano scale optics and such i talked more about phased array lasers in this video here if you're interested the other route with lasers is to go full ace combat and have it be a forward-fixed weapon like the gun that fighters carry but such a laser would have to be ludicrously powerful for that to do anything in the brief moments it would actually be pointed at a target it's just easier to have an actual gun for that job so the F-47 is probably just going to have one of those rather than a laser but it would be technically possible to include the latter i guess it could have a microwave weapon based on its main radar but would it be used for more than just electronic warfare stuff i don't know its main weapon is going to be longrange missiles and such fired from an integrated stealthy weapon bay though probably not one like the jets in the movie Stealth use with the crazy revolver selector thing it looks really cool and is actually similar to something many bombers have but real integrated weapons bays on stealth fighters work a bit differently payloads are solidly mounted inside and the bays work by opening pushing out a missile and closing as fast as they possibly can this limits the amount of time the unsty interior of the bay is exposed for which is kind of important for a craft that's not meant to be seen another one of the ideas I've seen around is that the F-47 may use aerero elastic control but what is this we've all seen how wings bend up when they create lift but there are other ways and directions for wings and control surfaces to move and bend under these forces things like induced vibration reduction of control or even reversal of a control surface can happen and these are all kind of bad so aircraft are built to limit or prevent these things from happening just like how aerodynamic instability can be harnessed to actually improve aircraft maneuverability with the aid of computer controls aerero elastic twist can also be used in this manner the X53 demonstrator actually tested this in the early 2000s installing a lighter more flexible wing and split leading edge flaps onto a pre-production FA18 a computer used the control services to deliberately twist that more flexible wing to turn what were previously negative impacts into positive ones getting more roll control out of a more lightweight component win-win i'm not sure if this tech ended up being applied to any current production craft but it is apparently applicable to lots of kinds of aircraft like the lambda wing seen in stealth bombers and some UAVs so it's possible it's used but we just don't know about it interesting tech by itself but the real sci-fi stuff comes by combining it with the related concept of the adaptive compliant wing which is basically flexible control services like these flex foil morphing wings these are intended to eliminate all the little gaps and seams that can increase drag and reduce efficiency but to my eye it seems like that smooth shaping would fit very nicely onto a stealth plane and the makers of the movie Stealth apparently agreed since look bendy control services on the Eddie Ukav that the movie actually refers to as being aerero elastic the question is would these bendy services be a real thing on a new jet the B-21 Raider is designed to be super stealthy but as we can see from its test flights its control services are the same tech as always based on the Raider it would make sense that the F-47 would likely just have normal control services too but look at its cannards there's no seam between them and the fuselage what if they bend and curve instead we know the flex foil tech is many years old so could have been integrated with stealth coatings and the like by now but on the other hand this is an artist's impression that could be just low detail and new tech like this is expensive something the F47 is supposedly trying to avoid the next big tech thing the F-47 is actually quite likely to have is the ability to work in concert with armed drone fighters the technical term for this is manned unmanned teaming or collaborative combat aircraft but you may have heard it go by the term loyal wingman referring to the idea that a plane flown by a person would always have backup from its robotic followers one way to think of them is in terms of being a detached extension of the lead aircraft carrying more sensors and weapons for it to deploy as needed think back to the thing about limiting how long weapons bays are open for a stealthcraft and imagine how much more useful it would be to have the weapons bay on a different plane entirely you can see why everyone is trying to make these things work and sci-fi is chock full of all sorts of similar things be they drones or full AI i want to highlight the ones seen in the movie Stealth and the Ace Combat franchise the first is pretty much all about this idea though the AI Eddie with his super extra high-tech jet is more intended to eventually replace the flesh and blood pilot he's teamed up with the movie also has some musings about if drones are suitable for this role and if it's worth having pilots still present to make moral choices even if they're in harm's way but it's kind of muddled in with a weird plot about the AI gaining sentience from a lightning bolt like it's Johnny 5 and consequently turning into an edgy teen with airto ground missiles and yes there's also the discussion about drones and AI in real life but that's beyond the scope of this video ace Combat has its own take on it ai planes have been a staple of the franchise since the second installment but Seven went allin with drones and AI being a huge part of the story and gameplay there's the annoyingly agile little drones you fight throughout the game but also the big super duper flying drone carriers are themselves also remotely operated drone craft in the later levels there's also normal jets with AI replacement pilots that very much play the part of the loyal wingman backing up flesh and blood pilots though they are not quite as capable as them that does not apply to the two end bosses of the game though the two AI ravens Huggin and Munan who are both smart capable opponents and they're dangerous because they just carry on with their programmed orders despite them not being relevant anymore what else might the F-47 have well one trend in some upcoming jets like the Chinese one seen flying around last December seems to be going for a tailless design forgoing the vertical empanage to make the plane nice and flat improves stealth and range though maybe at the cost of some agility but look at this thing the X36 from the late '90s this was a subscale prototype specifically designed to see if a craft that was both tailless and agile could work and it worked well thanks to its cannards and oh look the F47 has those too i find it interesting that to my knowledge at least there's actually not all that many tailless fictional fighters there's a few around here and there like the ones we've very conveniently mentioned already in this video but they're definitely rare compared to how futuristic they feel i don't know just an interesting observation that's sure to change if these sixth generation jets end up being tailless i hope you enjoyed this look at some of the techs out there that might be included on the F47 some are certainly a lot more likely than others but it's also interesting to see how fiction may or may not have used some of them already and to think about how future creations will be inspired by this new jet you can support Space Talk by joining our Patreon where you can get our frigate and space fighter design reference books alternatively you can support us directly through YouTube by becoming a channel member thanks to our supporters and thank you for watching [Music] [Applause] [Music]

output.script:
From the day I wrote my first Hello World program,Â 
it took me 2 years to land a job at Amazon andÂ Â  another 2 years to get into Google. Thatâ€™s becauseÂ 
I did all this with no Computer Science degree orÂ Â  bootcamp. I made countless mistakes along theÂ 
way which made my path to become a SoftwareÂ Â  Engineer longer than it should have been.Â 
I watched countless Youtube tutorials, paidÂ Â  for numerous Udemy courses and spent hundreds ofÂ 
hours learning things that didnâ€™t add any value.Â Â  If I could go back in time and undoÂ 
all the things that donâ€™t work,Â Â  I would be in the exact same situation asÂ 
today within 6 months of starting programming.Â Â  Thatâ€™s exactly why I made this video. Today,Â 
I'll remove all the useless fluff and giveÂ Â  you the fastest path to go from a beginner toÂ 
a full-time Software Engineer.  Before I begin, there are 3 major mistakes thatÂ 
can slow down your progress to become a full-timeÂ Â  Software Engineer. I will also share these 3Â 
mistakes along the way. So, stay tuned for that. As a new programmer, the first decision youÂ 
need to make is â€œWhich programming language toÂ Â  learn?â€. To answer that question, letâ€™s talk about whatÂ 
a beginner wants from a programming language.Â Â  Number 1, The language should be easy andÂ 
intuitive to write. It should not requireÂ Â  learning very complex syntax. It should beÂ 
as close as possible to writing in English.Â Â  Next, The programming language should be versatileÂ 
and have many applications. As a beginner,Â Â  you donâ€™t want to learn a new language for everyÂ 
new project you want to build. In other words,Â Â  the language should have great returnsÂ 
for the time you invest on learning it.Â Â  Lastly, the programming language should beÂ 
fast to write. You shouldnâ€™t have to waste timeÂ Â  spelling out the declaration of a new variable orÂ 
simple iteration through a list. In other words,Â Â  it should be concise and get the job done inÂ 
minimum lines of code. As some of you might haveÂ Â  already guessed it, Python is the language thatÂ 
solves all these problems. Itâ€™s almostÂ Â  as easy as writing in English. It has so manyÂ 
different applications like Web development, DataÂ Â  Science and Automation. Python is extremely fastÂ to write when compared with other popular languages.  That's because it requires less lines of code for theÂ Â same amount of code. As an example, here is the same codeÂ 
written in Java vs Python. For me personally, I startedÂ Â  out with learning Java. I used to do all my codingÂ 
interviews in Java. Recently, I switched to usingÂ Â  Python and it improved my interview performanceÂ 
by at least 2 times because itâ€™s so fast to write.Â Â  Having said that, Java and other popularÂ 
languages have their own advantages and you willÂ Â  have to learn another language at some pointÂ 
in your career. ButÂ Â  I do believe that Python would beÂ 
the best language to start with. Now that we know we should learn Python, letâ€™sÂ 
talk about how to do it. And this is where mostÂ Â  new programmers make the first major mistake thatÂ 
slows them down. The mistake most beginners makeÂ Â  is that they learn by watching others code. LetÂ 
me explain this by telling you how most peopleÂ Â  learn programming. Most newbies would go to aÂ 
course provider like Udemy and look up for PythonÂ Â  courses. Then they pick one of these 20+ hoursÂ 
courses thinking that these courses are long andÂ Â  detailed and hence good for them. And then theyÂ 
never end up finishing the course. Thatâ€™s becauseÂ Â  20 hours of content is not the same as 20 hoursÂ 
of great content. Some people will go to YoutubeÂ Â  and watch someone else code without ever writingÂ 
any code themselves. And watching these tutorialsÂ Â  gives them a false sense of progress. Thatâ€™sÂ 
because coding in your head is very differentÂ Â  from actually writing down the code and debuggingÂ 
the errors. So, what is the right way to do it?Â Â  The answer is very simple, you should Learn byÂ 
Coding. For this, you can go to this free websiteÂ Â  called learnpython.org. On this website, justÂ 
focus on the basic lessons for Python and donâ€™tÂ Â  worry about Data Science tutorials or any AdvancedÂ 
tutorials. That's because even if youÂ Â  learn advanced concepts right now, you would notÂ 
be able to remember them until you have actuallyÂ Â  applied them on a real world problem. You canÂ 
always come back to learn the advanced concepts inÂ Â  the future when you need them for your projects.Â 
If you look at a lesson, each lesson first explains a basic conceptÂ Â  and then asks you to apply those concepts to aÂ 
problem. Feel free to play with the sample code.Â Â  Think about other problems you can solve withÂ 
concepts you just learnt and try to solve themÂ Â  in the exercise portion. Once youâ€™re done with theÂ 
basics, youâ€™re good to move on to the next steps. In the spirit of learning by coding, we would doÂ 
some projects in Python next. In the beginning,Â Â  itâ€™s very hard to do something on your own.Â 
So, weâ€™ll take the help of experts. So,Â Â  go to Youtube and look up this video called â€œ12Â 
beginner Python projectsâ€ by freecodecamp.org,Â Â  which by the way is a greatÂ 
channel to follow. In this video,Â Â  they build 12 beginner Python projects fromÂ 
scratch. These projects include building Madlibs,Â Â  Tic Tac toe, Minesweeper etc. and all of themÂ 
are very interesting. They walk you throughÂ Â  the implementation of all these projects stepÂ 
by step making it very easy to follow. But,Â Â  before you start watching this tutorial, thereÂ 
are 2 things you should know. One, You shouldÂ Â  not watch this tutorial casually. Follow along ifÂ 
you really want to learn programming and become aÂ Â  Software Engineer. To follow along, you wouldÂ 
need something called Integrated DevelopmentÂ Â  Environment or IDE to build these projects. IDEÂ 
in simplest terms is an application where you canÂ Â  write and run your code. There are several popularÂ 
IDEs for Python. This tutorial uses VS code. So,Â Â  you might want to download VS code and set itÂ 
up for Python before starting on this tutorial. Once you have completed this tutorial, youÂ 
are ready to work on your own projects.Â Â  Working on building your own projects willÂ 
help you in multiple ways. Number one,Â Â  it will introduce you to how Software EngineersÂ 
work in the real world. You will write code thatÂ Â  will fail and youâ€™ll debug it and repeat itÂ 
over and over again. This is exactly whatÂ Â  a day in the life of a Software Engineer looksÂ 
like. Number two, you will build a portfolioÂ Â  of projects by doing this. You can host yourÂ 
code on Github and put the link in your resume.Â Â  This will help you attract recruiters and getÂ 
your resume shortlisted. Lastly, building yourÂ Â  own projects will give you confidence that youÂ 
are ready to tackle new challenges as a SoftwareÂ Â  Engineer. But, what kind of projects should you work on?  You can think of any projects that youÂ 
find interesting but here are some examples IÂ found. You can build a Web crawler, or an Alarm clock, or maybe an app that gives you Wikipedia article of the day.  Some example projects thatÂ Â  I built were a Spam filter, an AlgorithmicÂ 
Trading engine and an e-commerce website. Now you have a great resume and you areÂ 
confident about your programming skills.Â Â  Letâ€™s start applying for Software EngineerÂ 
positions. Wait a second. This is actually the secondÂ Â  major mistake new programmers make.  You see, inÂ an ideal world, having good programming skills and a great resume is all you should need toÂ Â  become a Software Engineer. But unfortunately forÂ us, tech companies like to play games withÂ Â  us in the interviews. They ask you specific kindsÂ 
of programming questions in the interviews. If youÂ Â  donâ€™t prepare for these questions, you might notÂ 
get the expected results. So,Â Â  letâ€™s see how to prepare for interviews. All theÂ 
interviews are based on this one course that isÂ Â  taught to all Computer Science graduates. ThisÂ 
course is called Data Structures and Algorithms.Â Â  Fortunately for us, Google has created this courseÂ 
and made it available for free on Udacity. And theÂ Â  best part is that this course is taught inÂ 
Python. In this four week course, youâ€™ll learnÂ Â  about different algorithms related to searchingÂ 
and sorting. Youâ€™ll learn about data structuresÂ Â  like maps, trees and graphs. Donâ€™t worry if youÂ 
donâ€™t know any of these terms right now. I amÂ Â  sure that by the end of this course, youâ€™ll beÂ 
a pro. For that just keep 2 things in mind . One,Â Â  be regular and finish this course. As I mentionedÂ 
earlier, most people start courses and neverÂ Â  finish them. So, make sure you take small stepsÂ 
everyday and make regular progress. Two,Â Â  make sure you complete all the exercises they giveÂ 
in this course. As I have already said many times,Â Â  the only way to learn coding is by doing. So,Â 
implement the algorithms by yourself if you canÂ Â  and finish all the assignments. Trust me whenÂ 
I say this. When it comes to interviewing forÂ Â  entry level jobs, this course is the onlyÂ 
difference between you and someone who droppedÂ Â  more than a hundred thousand dollars on a computerÂ 
science degree. So, if you finish this course,Â Â  youâ€™ll be pretty much on par with someoneÂ 
who has a CS degree when you interview. After completing this course on Data StructuresÂ 
and Algorithms, you have all the foundationalÂ Â  knowledge you need to tackle the interviews. InÂ 
order to sharpen your interview skills further,Â Â  you need to practice some questions that have beenÂ 
asked by tech companies in the past. For that,Â Â  you should use a website called Leetcode. OnÂ 
leetcode, you will get interview style questions.Â Â  You can write your code and test your solutionÂ 
right there on the website. Leetcode is great forÂ Â  beginners because all the questions are taggedÂ 
easy, medium or hard based on difficulty level.Â Â  If you buy a premium subscription of the website,Â 
you can also filter the questions by the techÂ Â  company that asked them in the past interviews.
You should start with easy questions and keepÂ Â  working on them until you can solve them inÂ 
45 minutes. Once that happens, you can moveÂ Â  on to medium questions.When you start solvingÂ 
mediums in 45 minutes, you can start applyingÂ Â  for Software Engineering jobs. If you are lucky,Â 
you will get the job right away. For most people,Â Â  it will be a process full of disappointmentÂ 
and rejections. And this is where theyÂ Â  make the third and the biggest mistake of all,Â 
They quit. The main reason people give up earlyÂ Â  is because they overthink and complicate theÂ 
interview process. After every rejection,Â Â  they replay the interview over and over in theirÂ 
head to figure out why they failed and take everyÂ Â  rejection personally. To avoid this, stay insideÂ 
your circle of control and try to influence theÂ Â  outcome of your interviews but never get tangledÂ 
in the things you canâ€™t control. In other words,Â Â  do your best to crack the interviews but try toÂ 
be detached from the outcome of the interviews. IfÂ Â  you want to learn about how I became a SoftwareÂ 
Engineer without a Computer Science degree,Â Â  watch this video at the top. If youÂ 
want to see my 5 year coding journey in 5 minutes,Â Â  you can watch this other video.Â 
I will see you in the next one.
