output.script:
We've seen the shift in the soft data.
The last time we spoke, you raised the issue, I believe, Lazarus, to the
question with that soft data bleed into the hard data.
Do you sense a inevitability now that we are beginning to see that if looking at
high frequency data? So over the last several weeks, we have
seen and I know some of these indicators are a bit special, but we've seen the
number of people who are going to movie theaters, number of people going to
Broadway shows. If you look at the TSA data for how many
people fly in airplanes, even if you look at how many people are visiting the
Statue of Liberty here in New York City, all of that has actually started to
weaken. And now we get another soft data point
here and with the Michigan sentiment for consumers.
So overall, it is still a little bit too early.
But given that we have this wait and see situation, both for consumers and for
corporates, it does make sense that the soft data should eventually begins to
spill over to at least some weakening in the hot data.
One feature of this cycle I think a lot of people underestimated you, not
included, is the resilience of this economy.
What is our capacity to absorb shocks now?
Is that been reduced? Well, that's a very important question
because that depends on the nature of the sharks.
And we're facing two sharks at the moment, namely those which is laying off
government workers. Estimates suggest that that will be
around 300,000 workers that might be losing their jobs.
Remember that for every federal worker, there are two contractors, according to
Brookings. So Brookings studies show that in total,
true employment in the federal government is roughly around 19 million
people. So if you now think about total number
of households, that's 130 million. And someone in a federal worker, a
contractor lives together with someone in the private sector, you get that as
much as ten, 15% of all households in some way or another is being impacted
from a sentiment perspective by those alone.
And tariffs, of course, also in particular, that impacts anyone who's
associated with trade with Canada and Mexico.
And you have that that is also a particular, of course, across the border
to the north and to the south, playing a significant role in a number of states.
So the bottom line is it's not only tariffs and trade war, it's also the
combination of the risk that government workers and contractors potentially lose
their jobs that are the main reasons why this soft data is weakening the way it
is. And it's not only consumers of data is
also corporate. If you look at the CapEx planning from
the regional events, Dallas Fed, Philadelphia Fit, New York Fed, that's
showing that businesses in those districts are saying we're beginning to
cut backs, Cap explains. Likewise, NFIB also roundtable surveys.
CapEx planning is also moving lower. So both consumer confidence, when we
lower corporate confidence moving lower, it is a precursor for a slowdown coming
in the hot data. There's an argument being made that if
what was propping up the United States economy was government spending, it
wasn't that strong to begin with. And this is actually somewhat of a
withdrawal from a sugar high, from an incredible amount of fiscal spend in the
direct aftermath of the pandemic. Do you buy that?
There is some truth to that detox argument in the sense that if you look
at hiring in non-farm payrolls over the last two years, 25% of jobs created in
2023 and 24 were government jobs. The previous year, it was like five,
10%, much, much less. So a very significant part of jobs in
the last two years have been coming from the government sector.
So it is true that job growth has been slowing in the private sector, even
going in to these shocks that we're looking at at the moment heading into
2025. You are pretty clear that you think that
the inflationary shock was going to be maintained and that it was going to
create a real problem for the Fed to actually offer a response to that kind
of weakness in the economy. Do you continue to see that even though
the shocks that we're seeing right now to policy might have a bigger
ramification on growth than you had previously expected?
Well, the real challenge is that going into tariffs, we had that inflation,
unfortunately was still too high at around 3%.
And most calculations suggest that you will add roughly half a percentage point
to capacity as a result of tariffs. So it makes a huge difference where you
start. If you start with inflation at three and
you add half a percent. Of course, the risk is that you will
have too much upside and we're way above the Fed's target.
Whereas if inflation had started at one and a half, which is where we were in
2016 and you add half a percent, then inflation would move up towards the
Fed's target. So the problem was really that the
starting point for inflation when these policies came along was that it was
unfortunately well above the Fed's target.
So the risk is in this situation that you have inflation moving higher and
growth slowing down, which of course is a definition of a stagflation era shock.
We were talking to Mohamed El-Erian earlier this week, and he made the point
that given these dual shocks, the Fed should probably allow inflation to run a
little bit hotter for a longer period of time and address the growth issues and
cut rates at least once this year. Do you agree that that's more prudent at
a time where there are these stagflation area forces starting to loom?
Absolutely, because the Fed has the dual mandate.
On the one side, if growth is slowing, is saying the Fed should be cutting, if
inflation is going up, is saying the Fed to be hiking, I think the Fed will look
at if growth stops as low and if we're where the next several weeks begin to
see that unemployment begins to go up. Let's not forget that non-farm payroll
is always done in the week of the 12th means this week.
So this is the week when they do the survey for the.
And if we do believe that this week was somewhat intense on the policy front,
then there is, of course, a change that nonfarm payrolls for March could be on
the weaker side. And if that's the case, then in the next
seven weeks in particular, going into April and with the April 2nd deadline
also from Trump with a reciprocal as tariffs, we come to the conclusion that
the risk is that we might begin to see growth slowed down.
And the Fed will say, well, as long as inflation expectations are anchored,
yes, actual inflation may be higher, but if inflationary pressures are anchored,
they will be focusing on growth slowing down and therefore the risks are that
markets will be pricing in more cuts at the time.
And by the way, it looks like from stock markets that they are almost saying,
well, the Fed should be cutting many more times, whereas rates markets are
saying, no, no, we only need two more cuts.
So there's almost an inconsistency between the messaging from stocks that
are now in correction territory and rates markets saying, no, no, we only
need two more cuts in the news conference on March 19th next Wednesday
as Chairman Powell addressed those issues.
What are you looking for? So I'm looking very much for how much
he's focusing on this off data slowing down.
He did do that at the US MPF last Friday here in New York City where he was in
his prepared remarks saying everything is generally okay.
But when he was sitting down with Anurag Kashyap and ask questions, he was more
saying, Hey, something is going on that has some downside risks that we maybe
should be putting more weight on. So I do think that he will begin to talk
about, well, there's softness in the soft data, but maybe we're also worried
about softness in the hot data. We have seen this incremental shift from
the November meeting into December. We don't assume, we don't guess, we
don't speculate. Then in December, there was some
assumption, some guessing, some speculation.
And then I agree with you, the recent address we had from Chairman Powell,
there was another subtle shift just started to tackle policy issues head on
in a way he hadn't done in the previous few months.
And on some level, he kind of has to because there is a sort of scenario
analysis that has to come from the Fed for them to even be relevant about how
they're measuring some of these aspects. And that's probably why the statement of
economic projections, which could be a dart board but is sort of a messaging
tool about how they're going to potentially respond to what is
transpiring and policy and how is transpiring in data, even if it doesn't
necessarily come to full pass. The difference now, I guess, is we're
actually getting the policy. They don't have to speculate about it
anymore. But that policy comes with a lot of
volatility. And so and they've got to manage
interest rates through the cycle. Maybe Chairman Powell steps down in the
next couple of years. I imagine he will.
I don't know for sure, but I think we all think he will.
I want to understand from that perspective, you sit there and you
acknowledge the risk right now, but also you've got to think about tax cuts, the
potential for looser regulation further down the road.
How do you manage through the cycle with that in mind?
Well, that's why this debate about is it policy dependent, is it data dependent,
becomes really, really important because, of course, the policy that's in
place suggests that, well, so far the two things that we have seen from the
beginning is those which is putting the unemployment rate up and also
terrorists, which is pushing inflation up.
So if that's the case, they need to deal with that shock as the first thing, even
as you say, if there are other policies coming on deregulation and lower taxes
and potentially also more energy production.

output.script: has been quite a roller coaster for the global markets you know this is after US President Donald Trump announced and then paused his tariffs while implementing even more on uh China now there were some of the biggest falls and rises on the share markets in decades with Australian stocks at the mercy of international uncertainty the chief executive of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry Handra Mckela says Australian businesses will be affected uh obviously uh it has been a tumultuous uh week we've seen the volatility uh on global financial uh markets i think the big issue for Australian industry and for Australian exporters uh now is not so much the 10% tariff that's been applied on Australian exports to the United States but it's the prospect of a protracted uh trade confrontation between the United States and China uh obviously um you know the China is Australia's biggest trading partner that's not going to change anytime soon the United States is very important uh if those two economies uh are at each other's throats then it has major implications which can knock on uh to the Australian economy and tell us about those implications the real world implications for mom and dad well look I think it's going to you know um potentially flow um through throughout industry and throughout the economy um China is our major market of course uh it's very important in terms of a range of our commodities uh exports and also a major source of supplies into Australia so look if we see um you know uh growth um slowing in the United States and in China then that will have uh reverberations uh you know through into our economy to the exports that we sell uh you know whether it will have an impact on global inflation or not certainly in the US uh and in China one would have to expect that those higher prices that they will pay will have an impact uh uh whether that flows through into the rest of the world remains to be seen andrew one of the things that President Trump has said here is he wants uh industry manufacturing back in the US now we can't send the cows over there but is there any danger that Australian businesses or Australianbased businesses might move some of their operations to America well I think uh that's something that's uh got to be assessed over the longer term and I think it will be on a a range of different factors we have a significant level of investment uh in the United States uh but one thing that I think uh everyone should bear in mind here it's uh I think very unlikely um you know to borrow a phrase from others that uh any country uh can tax its way to prosperity um and effectively that's what you know raising tariffs is it's raising taxes uh we've seen it in the past uh that attempts you know to uh you know bring manufacturing back by raising tariffs uh there are very few examples where this has succeeded so I think that is uh unlikely um you know the risk is that in fact what it will do is thwart investment the one thing I would say though uh is there are other policies that the Trump administration may pursue so for example it is on their agenda to cut things like company tax uh again so in the future you know if they try to make their economy more competitive more attractive to investment through things like that then you know maybe that will have an impact andrew is there much more the Australian government could have done or should do uh to help Australian businesses in this situation well I think uh up to this point uh what we've seen the Australian government doing uh really is as much as could be expected and and in terms of the outcome that's been achieved so to be on the lowest rung at 10% uh in that uh announcement on the 2nd of April um you know honestly I think that represented the fact that we have uh a very deep uh economic and trading relationship uh with the United States we are trusted partners we are trusted allies uh the government uh working with business I think put uh every representation uh that it could uh in that process uh obviously where we go from here um if tariffs remain on that sort of baseline 10% for everybody else I think there is a good argument that we should be pressing that the United States uh restores zero tariffs to Australian uh exports into the uh into the US um we've been a reliable trading partner we have a free trade agree agreement um that's uh the rate that we're applying uh to US imports into Australia uh so we would expect that that would be what should apply uh in the near future again going back to the United States we're in the middle of an election campaign labour has said they'd like the minimum wage to be increased more than the rate of inflation uh if that went ahead what effect would that have well look what we've put forward is uh a submission which says that the uh minimum wage should go up by 2 and a half% um we should also remember that of course superanuation the superanuation guarantee will go up again by another half a percent from 1 July so we think that's a fair uh reasonable and responsible uh increase in minimum wages it would maintain the real value of minimum wages at the level that they currently are uh we don't think there's a case uh to go uh well beyond that we've seen the ACTU the unions pushing a claim for 4.5% uh honestly we think that makes it very hard particularly for smaller and medium-sized businesses in the Australian economy uh you know I think 2 and a half% is fair there are some sectors you know uh restaurants cafes hospitality retail they're real really still struggling um and uh certainly uh that would put a lot of pressure on some of those businesses

output.script: [Music] good morning everyone welcome to another relaxing coding Vlog today I decided to cycle downtown because I haven't been here in a long while and I wanted to see what's up and even though we still have some snow in the streets I really feel good about cycling today I'm continuing my work on the book and while in the previous Vlog I made that little check boox to Mark a page as completed this time around I'll be working on the back end part to save this information in the database and complete this entire feature but you may be wondering why am I digging through my backpack to find a pencil well yesterday I broke this little thing ofama jig on my rice fish loose and now I have to use a pen to unzip my jacket I just can't be bothered to fix these things and I can't be bothered even more to go and buy a new jacket just for this so for those of you who don't know I've been working on a book about software engineering and it has 101 different software engineering concept that I feel like were the most important and most useful for me in my engineering career but a lot of articles are also free so I put a link in the description if you'd like to check it out but in this video I want to give you a behind thesc scenes look on how it works while working on a feature request from a user in today's world you could almost describe this project as under engineered my goal is to show you that even with the simplest of tools you can make something that works and that users like so in the previous video I described how the front end is just a little bit of CSS and vanilla JavaScript and on the back end this entire thing is just a few little expressjs Services that's it and a static landing page so when it comes to hosting you can see I'm using a railway and the reason is I really like the pricing model where they charge you for actually used CPU memory and dis rather than how much you provisioned and that makes it possible to run a lot of different microservices where each one uses a little bit of resource here and there so up until this point the book service itself was actually completely stateless because I didn't need to keep track of any user information but now that I'm working on tracking the progress users as they go through the pages the first task was to connect a database and because I was using mongodb in another project I just decided to yank the whole configuration code from there but then I ran into my first question when naming collections in mongod DB should you use camel case or snake case for some reason snake case felt just a little bit off given that everything in my JavaScript codebase was cam case and after thinking about it for a while I decided to skip the whole conundrum and just rename my collection to use a single word but I'm curious what do you guys do after this I was making pretty solid progress and everything was going fine except that my scone has mysteriously vanished and as a bit of a spoiler this isn't the first mystery that unfolded today but at this point I was still unaware that it was going to happen so I just kept on going and continued implementing the progress end point both to update the progress of the user but also to get it later now there is no need to sugarcoat it the code you're looking at here has some massive glaring holes and numerous potential issues so I'm curious if you guys can see them but some time ago we had a discussion on my Discord server whether it's better to try and write your code perfect the first time around or if it's better to write any kind of version in the beginning and then improve it later and right now I was definitely trying the latter so I wasn't feeling insecure or anxious about the glaring security issues that I was introducing not nearly as anxious as I felt about what happened next when the second mysterious event started unfolding you see for no reason whatsoever my trackpad stopped working completely I mean I was able to move the mouse but I wasn't able to click and so I started panicking a little bit because I thought that the development version of one menu which I had running decided to somehow hijack my mouse and hold it for a ransom and straight up I just stopped one menu alt together but some of you with a Keen Eye might notice that I used activity monitor to try and see what's going on even though one menu has a pretty well functioning system monitoring feature but somehow in the moment it just didn't feel right to use one menu to stop itself it kind of felt a little bit morally wrong so I tried using activity monitor but it had such horrible keyboard support that I ended up using the terminal in the end but one menu wasn't at fault and the Mystery continued so I decided to try a different approach I remembered I had a mouse lying around in my bag so I thought maybe turning it on and off would fix the issue and here's a funny thing that I did you know one of output.title: Exercise Tutorial: Cable Machine Hip Abductions
output.description:
In standing attach a cable to the farthest ankle. Keep the back straight and the knees slightly bent and the abdominals contracted. You can hold on to the machine to maintain your balance. Raise the leg outward (abduction) as far as you can without letting the foot or the pelvis turn outward.  Return to the starting position and repeat.

output.script: in this exercise tutorial I'm going to be taking you through how to do the single leg hip abduction exercise on a cable machine now maybe you've been doing resistance bands and you're looking to ditch those and start doing weighted exercise this is a fantastic option for you you'll notice here I'm holding an ankle attachment so this fastens around my ankle I just want to show you standing first how this one works so I'm going to feed one side through I'll then of course make sure my ankle was nice and tight and then I can Loop it back and it's all velcroed in I've then of course got this part here which fastens into the carabina and what I would always do with clients is I would actually set this up first before fastening them into the carabin you'll notice here I'm on the second to lowest setting for some clients they'll be on the lowest setting for taller clients they might be one or two up and what I'm going to do is always attach this to the furthest leg away from the machine so let's say for example facing the camera here it would be my left leg working and I'd have to face away to have my right leg doing the abduction so I'm going to fasten this up I've already got the weight selected if you're not sure about weights just make sure you pick the lightest one and then get your form and technique and go from there now that this is all set up for me I'm all ready to go and now I'm fastened into the carabina so what I'm going to do here is I'm just going to take a step away from the machine notice my stance so I've got my left leg here a little bit further forwards than my right leg so I don't hit into it in each repetition a lot of people also cheat in this they'll have their arm resting against the the actual cable machine which is fine but then they'll start to do this keep that arm bolt straight don't bend the elbow as you bring the leg away from the body and back in so that's away from the body and back in second sheet is people start pointing the toe out so make sure that your toes are always pointing directly forwards they're not coming away that's going to take tension off your glute medius muscle and to keep it on we can simply tense the quadricep lock the knee out so the legs completely straight and then keep those toes facing the way that you're facing as well so make sure they don't start going this way what you'll also notice is on your standing leg you'll actually get activation of that side as well so if you've got a weaker side i' always start off with that first then do your stronger side no matter what side that you do first that's going to be pref fatigued because it's going to be stabilizing you so by the time you get onto doing the next side it will naturally find it harder so always start off with your weaker side doing the abductions first then you can switch over of course once you're done you're going to pop the ankle attachment around the other leg and repeat exactly the same process tensing your core arm nice and straight you've got one leg in front of the other and it simply is bringing that cable away from the body making sure that your feet are always pointing in the direction that you're facing that's how to do the single leg hip abduction exercise on a cable machine and you repeat that for your desired amount of sets and repetitions

output.script: anyone who does not drive a Ferrari is a lazy idiot whenever I charter a jet for a flight I always ask the Steuart S do you take weekends do you stop working at five great stop complaining that you aren't making i recently talked to a Wall Street Journal reporter about how young men are investing in things like stocks crypto and more recently politics and because of that I was able to make it into the article i mean that's me but shout out to Financial Failure he was the main focus on this article and he was the one that even hooked me up on getting the interview his channel covers more cryptoreated topics and it'll be linked down in the description but this overall experience actually raises really important questions like why are young men today more tempted or I would consider more desperate than previous generations to make financial bets let's start with the obvious in 2025 the conversation about making money has never seemed more urgent unlike previous generations new form of investors aren't playing it safe they're not primarily value investors they're only focused on maximizing returns and this is simply because everyone feels like they need to because they're living in a harsh economy see 70% of Gen Z and millennials are living paycheck to paycheck student loan debt has reached a total of $1.7 trillion while home prices have nearly doubled in the past two decades but real wages haven't grown i mean they're nearly stagnant so now more than ever people truly have that get rich or die trying they're trying to take bigger swings and the main focus because of this is that they're currently living in hardship and they want to escape it the real conversation needs to be had of what truly is the working class it's simply paycheck to paycheck only working just to survive and most people don't want to live in that situation because many people are trying to break out of that slow and steady income because they're not getting the results that they were promised trying to risk it all is probably the only way that people see results that previous generations were nearly guaranteed to get i mean just think back a few generations ago sitcoms were really average of just a single parent income household while living in middle suburbia so asking why people are willing to take such a large bet well it's simply a reaction to the current living conditions they're in let's be real wall Street Bets was simply a reaction to Wall Street excluding average people who wanted to invest their money and crypto is simply a financial response to the '08 crisis which locked out many Americans and only helped out the traditional wealthy and betting on sports politics or current events is simply just that desire to turn frustration into potential profits all these movements and reactions are simply a response to someone being systematically ignored and while obviously these come with risk I feel like people aren't looking out for the main thing that they actually come with which is hope in a community a recent example was literally Wall Street Bets users rallying with GameStop i mean most people hated GameStop but this wasn't just to make money it was actually to stick it to the hedge funds who were taking advantage of people for so long because it's very clear and googable that the top hedge fund CEOs are able to buy homes that are up to $200 million that's a clear form of rebellion against the system that has been depriving average people for so long now obviously this intent can come with a form of greed but it comes out of survival and even while stating most of this information I feel like people are missing the elephant in the room which people are broke and the reason why articles like this sort of focus on it is that because young men are feeling this the hardest so they're willing to risk more i mean you could find so many studies that talk about how young men aged under 30 have the highest rate of unemployment or underemployment amongst all age groups and a scary stat is that an average 25-year-old working today is making less than his father did at the same age if you adjust for everything like inflation but it's not just wages it's the overall cost of living for instance the medium rent for most places in a high cost of living area is well over $2,000 to $3,000 for most places and that just comes with like a studio apartment the average home price for a starter home is well over $400,000 and don't even get me started on the price of gas because the transportation cost must be factored in if you want to go anywhere a gallon of gas used to cost anywhere from $2 to $3 but now can stretch as far as 56 $7 meanwhile everyone's simply telling everyone to work harder but if you understand the concept of pull yourself up by your bootstrap it's just a sort of disingenuous term because if you ever tried it you're pulling yourself up which is even harder forced to do because today people are literally watching pensions disappear union efforts get crushed i mean even college degrees are sort of losing value everyone has them so what's left for most people risk and this comes with the form of illusion through most platforms see first in this case we need to talk about investing which is the first gateway drug directly after co we saw retail investors trade up to $600 billion through ETFs and this was primarily on accounts like Robin Hood well nothing is inherently wrong with the platform it's slowly enabling a new form of investing which is yolo investing which if you're familiar with Wall Street Bets subreddit then you know what I'm talking about and if you literally go back to the heights of GameStop you saw Robin Hood have 3 million new users in one month on one hand you were able to see people invest in options and turn $100 into $5,000 so the appeal for something like this is completely obvious it's easy to use it has an instant order execution and there's zero commissions and on top of this it was likely number one in the app store so people didn't have to go anywhere but the less had conversation but was just as common as how people were losing money it's like everyone overnight became a day trader but if you know any stats most day traders lose money and unfortunately with the meme stock rallies retail investors were the last one holding when the stock went to zero but still that dream of getting money fast is what keeps people around and just as fast as people will go to investing people will turn to crypto see for many crypto isn't just an asset it's more of a lifestyle and while yes there are plenty of projects that have great devs that have technical understanding that are hoping on the project I would say most users in the space are only in it for the money see while on one hand you have things like Bitcoin and Ethereum you have meme coins on the opposite while you could always argue that one of these random coins has a potential it just comes with a gambling frenzy the crypto market at its peak neared $3 trillion dogecoin surged 15,000% in one year but the problem with this is that most crypto traders lost money most retail investors were the one left holding the bag with the rug pulls and the pump and dumps apps like Coinbase and Binance made it very easy to invest and spaces like Twitter and Reddit made it very cool to have a community but now a new memecoin literally launches by the hour with Tik Tok users pushing tokens that literally vanish overnight because for many crypto is literally just a digital scratchoff ticket and this is what leads me into what I think is probably the worst form of investing which is gambling this is literally the gamified version of well everything you can bet on sports politics and anything in between sports books DraftKings FanDuels all of these have become household names all of these have simply turned your phone into a casino or worse you can go to like Stake or Kick and see 24/7 betting on sports slots dice and I mean everything in between life events and you can bet on things like the presidential election federal decisions celebrity outcomes sport outcomes and you can do all of this from your Robin Hood app and let's call it like it is the reason why it exists and the reason why it's growing is because it makes a lot of money just the sports betting market alone hit 11 billion in revenue in 2023 and it's likely only going to increase but the gambling addiction amongst men under 30 has increased nearly 60% in the last 5 years and if you go to most content creators you can follow a rabbit hole of XQC's Aiden Ross all gambling and while I don't want to simply put the blame of gambling on content creators it's at least brought it to the mainstream gambling used to be limited to certain sections certain states but it seems like it's going to be mainstream relatively soon because of how much money it makes that's why it's no longer just casino gambling now it's sports gambling next it's going to be live events gambling all of this invokes emotion you're going to be tied to betting on your team your identity your beliefs you're just scratching that itch because it's very clear we have the data gambling addiction is very bad but with the stats we also have on increasing population doing it it's only going to get worse and with all of that it only makes it harder to stop but I completely understand why people are doing it remember this is simply a response to the question why the overall solution is simply financial freedom but it's going to come in the form of messy decisions and whether it be stocks crypto or gambling this gives you a tribe and hope but the way out is going to be messy no matter the situation because you're up against a multi-trillion dollar machine people are up against multiple systems that are designed to take their time their attention their money literally leaving them with nothing this system thrives on you having hope to get out because at the end of it you're only going to be addicted confused and broke but at the end of this you have to understand the real play out of this it's going to be get educated and understand that you're even up against that multiple trillion dollar machine you have to focus on building real skills you have to understand delayed gratification because you understand instant gratification gets you nowhere that slow and steady progress only works if you have a tangible skill that helps you get out because the truth is that this get-richquick scheme is built on your loss we have to have an open conversation of trying not to be the product and hopefully be the exception now I'm going to have a link to the article down in the description but understand that these articles simply bring up the problem and I just wanted to bring up the

output.description:
Trump Tariffs: Worst Crash for US Stock Markets Since the Pandemic | Vantage with Palki Sharma | N18G

US President Donald Trump's new tariff regime has rattled global markets, wiping out trillions in investor wealth. Indices across the US, UK, Europe, Japan and India have plunged. Trump says the US economy is â€œsickâ€ and tariffs are the cure, but global agencies warn of deepening recession risks. The International Monetary Fund, World Trade Organization and major banks like JPMorgan have all raised alarm. As retaliatory tariffs emerge and uncertainty grows, markets are in turmoil. Investors are bracing for long-term fallout. The trade war Trump initiated may have no winnersâ€”only losses, and mounting global economic pain.

output.script: you are going to be so proud of your country You're going to be so proud of your president We're going to turn it around and we're going to start winning again We're going to win so much We're going to win at every level We're going to win so much You may even get tired of winning And you'll say "Please please It's too much winning We can't take it anymore Mr president it's too much And I'll say "No it isn't We have to keep winning We have to win more We're going to win more We're going to win so much." Donald Trump loves winning You just heard him say that His tariff plan was built on that promise Trump wants to win global trade by waging a trade war But today there are no winners Trump's trade war is making everyone lose and the stock market is the biggest loser of all The selloff has been brutal Just look at the numbers America's Dow Jones the S&P 500 the NASDAQ UK's Footsie 100 Germany's DAX Japan's Nikai and India's Nifty Every major index is in the red It is a stock market armageddon and it was induced by the Trump tariffs Now look at the losses in one day American investors alone have lost some $2.4 trillion in one day $2.4 trillion This is the biggest one-day wipeout since 20120 And that was the year the pandemic struck So basically for the markets the tariffs are proving to be as deadly as the Wuhan virus And India has not been spared Investors here lost some 9.5 lakh crore rupees today That's over $110 billion All thanks to a trade war that no one asked for Trump says he's not surprised by any of this He was expecting the markets to crash First we'd love to get your reaction sir to what's going on in the financial markets today Well I mean it's to be expected where uh this is a patient that was very sick who was a sick patient and went through an operation on liberation day and it's going to be uh it's going to be a booming country a very booming country It's going to be amazing Actually Trump says the US economy is sick and tariffs are the cure But as things stand the cure is hurting more than the disease He's right on one point though The sell-off is not surprising at all Investors are jumping ship They're dumping stocks because their investments no longer reflect the new reality We are in a global trade war and like all wars it is chaotic Donald Trump has not set any deadlines He looks prepared to drag this out What we have is we have a set of tariffs based on uh what they've been charging that's reciprocal and those uh tariffs have come in and many every country's called us That's the beauty of what we do Uh we put ourselves in the driver's seat Some trade US trade partners are already hitting back They have imposed retaliatory tariffs on the US Others are mulling their options We'll tell you more about this in just a bit For the moment let's look at the US president He has targeted 60 countries and trading blocks Not everyone will be able to strike a deal with him and get out of this So if you're an investor this is a tricky time to make bets Be very careful No one knows how this trade war will shape up There is significant risk both in the short and the long term Global agencies are sounding an alarm Like the International Monetary Fund or the IMF its head Cristina Georgie Evva has issued a warning She says Trump's tariffs threaten the global economy Georgie Eva has appealed to the US that the IMF does not want a protracted war They want America to end these trade tensions and reduce the uncertainty And remember the US is the IMF's largest shareholder So this statement is quite significant It is a rare criticism of the United States But the IMF's concerns are valid A global recession cannot be ruled out this year Look at what JP Morgan is saying It is the biggest American bank It has raised the odds of a global recession to 60% 60 Earlier that figure was 40% So Trump's tariff announcement has caused a 20% bump The World Trade Organization or WTO is alarmed too It has projected a 1% fall in global trade Now this is a contraction of 1% And the WTSTO says that it is deeply concerned because tariffs would lead to a chain reaction Although Washington is downplaying it the US Vice President JD Vance says this is and I'm quoting "This is just one bad day for the markets." Although he did warn about long-term pain you don't fix that stuff overnight We know people are struggling We're fighting as quickly as we can to fix what was left to us but it's not going to happen immediately So how would this play out tariffs will make imported goods expensive This will reduce the demand for goods which in turn will impact factories the ones that make these goods The factories will be forced to cut supplies This will disrupt supply chains and the job market The high entry barriers will force companies to rethink their strategy They will have to consider the cost of tariffs They will have to relocate to avoid them And none of this will happen overnight But if the tariffs stay it will happen Hence the long-term pain This is Donald Trump's gift to the world Greeting you with aloha and namaste No I I I love India Presence uh occupation of a territory by another country pertains to India What we saw in Kashmir how do you see Trump's America yes the current administration behaves differently from the previous administration Are you saying that there are foreign powers who are trying to bring down the current government in Syria exactly Iran maybe Russia actually Prime Minister Modi committed to South you know corporations for not over 50% Is Ukraine prepared to pay the price for that peace no compromises at the cost of territorial integrity and sovereignity Thank you very much for having me I'll clear up

2 years of C++ I started my journey all the way here at the bottom of the food chain I knew zero C++ never touched it and never planned to the plans changed because I applied to University and turns out I now have to learn it make a game make another game and thenn low-level programming wait let's slow down a little I started by attending lectures that taught me C++ let's just say this was really boring and I was not getting anywhere with it so I decided to go home and practice what was taught in those lectures it was really simple things at first like outputting text to the console or checking for input but I was actually doing it I was technically programming in C++ I did this for a few months but it got to a point where I wasn't going anywhere I already knew the ins and outs of writing texts or trying different algorithms thankfully in time came a new semester where I would now have to make a game with C++ now my small brain at the time didn't comprehend how this would work you see I thought you needed game engines to make games but turns out there is other Solutions like Frameworks and so I started using this thing called sdl which basically allows me to turn this console project into a window that now can check for input have Graphics audio and more at the end of the semester I had created a simple Pac-Man clone but I learned a new things like how to make a text level editor how to save high scores create different AIS path finding Etc at this point I was pretty confident with C++ but that was all about to come crashing down with the next year of University projects yeah you read that correctly I needed to now create my own graphical application for those who don't know what that is I have to first create a window that write 100 lines of code to Rend of a single Square scrap that we now need a cube which means another 300 lines of code Fu then we need to create our own Shader what even our shaders how do I make shaders I don't know then we needed to do ah so um I did in fact complete the engine eventually I made a video about it for those interested by the way but here are some screenshots and videos of it working but guess what my professors are clinically insane and now I have to do all of this again but this time instead of just Graphics I have to add physics to it okay so like again I did eventually do this and I guess let's make this video slightly educational here is a list of features I implemented most importantly I was happy with this thing here anyways this was actually a massive step forwards in me learning C++ since now I was no longer just using the bass console project instead I was using things like direct X openg goo Etc if you yourself want to be doing these kinds of things then today's sponsor brilliant is the answer now hang on give me just one minute of your time brilliant is essentially just a platform that you can access for your browser you go on it and learn but not just by sitting there and listening to boring talks instead you are actually physically doing things which in my opinion is the best way to learn it has lessons from maths data analysis computer science of course programming and much more all of the content on brilliant is also crafted by people who know what they are doing because there is Teachers researchers and professionals from MIT cowtech Juke Microsoft Google and more learning a little every day is one of the most important things you can do and Brilliant helps you do that with fun lessons you can do whenever you have the time and they don't have massive time commitments the platform has a ton of different content from getting familiar with python learning essential coding elements from Loops variables to nesting and conditionals brilliant has it all so if you've ever had the slightest urge to learn programming maths or anything of the sort today is the day to try everything brilliant has to offer for free for a full 30 days visit brilliant.org ziger or click the first link in the description you'll also get a 20% off of an annual premium membership and now let's continue okay this is where the era of engines 2.0 came being perfectly honest those engines were kind of I mean look at them so to avoid any embarrassment I decided to try and make them again plus I was kind of forced to do another Graphics engine by my clinically insane lecturers love you really starting with the graphics engine this time I used something called openg GL to make it which at the time I'm not going to lie I hated I actually love it now but I guess we all grow as people the engine not only ran better but also kind of focused more on shaders I created things like a Fresno glow kind of a metal Shader a mission Shader even this noise Shader oh saying the word Shader so many times doesn't make it sound real anymore anyways Video available on that too now I also recreated my physics engine because honestly that one was the worst one I don't know how to explain it but this new version was just better the entire structure was much nicer I cleaned up a bunch of my C calulations particularly with the collisions so now I could have a bunch of collider objects working almost flawlessly and I added a couple new features here and there I'm currently also working on another physics engine this one is the 3.0 version so video on that soon maybe so after completing those two engines it was getting kind of boring so I decided to make well an engine again but trust this one's different drum roll please a voxal engine yeah that was kind of underwhelming so this engine was like a combination of the graphics engine base mixed in with voxos at this point I didn't know anything about voxal engines or how to make them but it ended up being a lot of fun painful but fun I am most proud of this project because it's just awesome more notably you can place and Destroy blocks structures Etc it's all procedurally generated and it has its own custom render distance system and also although it generates blocks from like y 100 to0 it only renders the top layer so that your PC isn't fighting for its life of course if you break a block it will render the ones below but it essentially only renders what you can see I also made a video on it here at this point I applied to a bunch of internships and kept practicing my C++ after some companies go back to me I attempted and completed some of their programming tests and honestly these tests taught me a lot since with some of them I didn't even know where to start I doesn't mean I run errands or hand out coffees I do actually program stuff the difference is that my load is much smaller of a non- intern plus I have less responsibilities I was in the gameplay sector so my primary jobs were programming actual gameplay stuff that the players see in the game but without breaking any ndas I did also do other things that weren't necessarily gameplay stuff about half of my time there was spent working on the legend of Monkey Island toale I'm not sure how much of that I can say but it was super fun I got to create a new weapon and some other cool stuff I'd of the video if you did enjoy it please leave a like And subscribe and again if you guys want to learn something new then check out Brilliance with the link below bye

to psychologically optimal and the psychologicalÂ Â  comfort of knowing you have a small emergencyÂ

expense this will cover most small emergencies andÂ Â  you can look into adding to this after you doÂ 
the next step first and that is paying off yourÂ Â  high interest debt the majority of adults are inÂ

like and one of the biggest problems with debtÂ Â  is that it restricts your monthly income if youÂ

you can save and the amount of everything elseÂ Â  that you can do instead if you focus on payingÂ 
off debt that is a tax-free risk-free guaranteedÂ Â  rate of return if you have credit card debt thatÂ

printer support the interest that you'll no longerÂ Â  be paying the very first High interest that youÂ

is high interest now I would Define High interestÂ Â  debt as anything above eight percent interest someÂ 
people say six percent others say 10 the reason IÂ Â  chose eight percent is because historically whenÂ 
investing in the stock market you can expect toÂ Â  earn about 10 annually and when you adjustÂ 
this for inflation it's around eight percentÂ Â  so to me anything above what you could earn inÂ 
the stock market is going to be high interestÂ Â  debt but what about mortgages or other smallerÂ 
loans usually the interest on that isn't as highÂ Â  as credit card debt or overdraft fees so you canÂ 
continue making the minimum payments on those andÂ Â  to The Next Step instead but before we get intoÂ 
it I want to let you know that I'm doing a freeÂ Â  five-day money program it's going to be five daysÂ 
of videos where we cover a different topic everyÂ Â  day from asking for a pay rise money believesÂ 
saving investing and it's completely free theÂ Â  launch date will be confirmed in the next fewÂ 
weeks I'm really excited for this so if youÂ Â  want to know when it launches then sign up usingÂ 
the link below with that aside number three onÂ Â  my list of order is what you will hear a lot ofÂ 
personal finance people talking about doing a stepÂ Â  one as it's free money how could you be saying noÂ 
to free money but the reason why I don't think itÂ Â  makes sense to put this as number one is becauseÂ 
it's something that you will benefit from in 20 30Â Â  40 years from now and that doesn't matter if youÂ 
can't get your finances today in a good place toÂ Â  start with so once you have steps one to two doneÂ 
then you want to take the match that your employerÂ Â  is offering you for your retirement fund this isÂ 
called different things in different countriesÂ Â  in the UK it's the pension contribution and theÂ 
US you would have heard it as the 401K and whatÂ Â  this means is for every pound or dollar thatÂ 
you contribute your employer will also matchÂ Â  that contribution put that towards your pensionÂ 
so say you're earning a hundred thousand and youÂ Â  contribute 4 000 of that towards your workplaceÂ 
attention your employer matches everything youÂ Â  put in so you're basically making 100 returnÂ 
on your investment straight away remember thisÂ Â  is different from the full amount that you canÂ 
contribute all you care about here is contributingÂ Â  whatever you need to get the full match becauseÂ 
otherwise you're just leaving free money on theÂ Â  table and unfortunately for these retirementÂ 
matches that employers provide as a benefitÂ Â  you can't claim it retrospectively so you can'tÂ 
claim it now for previous years so you're goingÂ Â  to repeat this one every single year you neverÂ 
want to miss out on this free money step numberÂ Â  four have an additional fund imagine the kind ofÂ 
freedom and stability you'd have if you had threeÂ Â  to six months of your living expenses in yourÂ 
bank account at all times knowing that if anythingÂ Â  happened you lost your job your business didn'tÂ 
work out then you would have something to fallÂ Â  back onto and that will all be taken care of thisÂ 
is when you want to have enough money available soÂ Â  that if anything happens you can bail yourself outÂ 
and not rely on credit card debt to get you out ofÂ Â  your situation so you want to work out what is theÂ 
absolute minimum you need to survive on so yourÂ Â  fixed expenses your variable expenses your totalÂ 
expenses for the month and then multi apply thatÂ Â  number by three to six months if you're employedÂ 
or nine to twelve months if you're self-employedÂ Â  this number is your emergency fund and it'sÂ 
different to your safety net that we spokeÂ Â  about in the first point this is for the largerÂ 
Financial shocks that we just mentioned that haveÂ Â  longer term implications now once you've done thatÂ 
this is where it gets fun because you've completedÂ Â  the groundwork for a truly free financial futureÂ 
now you get to invest and meet some of your otherÂ Â  Financial priorities so the next step is to investÂ

one of the most tax efficient places you can beÂ Â  putting your money in to make it grow most otherÂ 
Investments buy some sort of tax when you buyÂ Â  a share and make money from it you usually haveÂ 
to pay capital gains tax however when you investÂ Â  through a tax advantaged account such as an Isa ifÂ 
you're in the UK or a Roth IRA if you're in the USÂ Â  you Shield your profits from the tax man so youÂ 
want to take advantage of these accounts up untilÂ Â  the maximum if you can then we have a payoff lowÂ 
interest debt this includes for example studentÂ Â  loans in some cases and sometimes car loans from aÂ 
financial standpoint this debt may not be hurtingÂ Â  you as as much so you can choose whether you wantÂ

step is being used to help you make more moneyÂ Â  if it's not helping you do that then you shouldÂ 
be paying it off so if you're using that moneyÂ Â  to invest rather than to pay it back then itÂ 
may make sense but if you are not paying offÂ Â  your debt because you rather have more moneyÂ

consider debt as a normal way of life it can veryÂ Â  quickly Cascade into a mindset of justificationÂ 
and using it to fund an elevated lifestyle withÂ Â  low interest debt is something you want to avoidÂ 
you want to get into the habit of paying off asÂ Â  much bad debt as you can from your life then weÂ 
have paying off your mortgage this is the lastÂ Â  thing on the list and I would highlight that it isÂ 
completely optional and it really really dependsÂ Â  on your financial situation there are so manyÂ 
variables that you have to take into account howÂ Â  much Equity do you have left when does your fixedÂ

output.description:
President Trump has announced that Boeing will build the next generation of fighter jets for the US Air Force. The new sixth-generation fighter aircraft will be called the F-47, named after Donald Trump, the 47th president of the United States.  

This concept art shows what the new jet might look like. The real thing is expected to carry advanced stealth, AI â€“ and drone technology. Boeing defeated a rival bid from Lockheed Martin, which produces the F-35 fighter jet. The announcement is welcome news for Boeing, whose reputation has taken a hit after a series of crashes and mechanical failures.

output.script: Jasmine Crockett just issued a brutal takedown of the conspiracy theorist RFK Jr. who is leading the Health and Human Services agency as Donald Trump's Secretary of HHS. Now, stick around to the end of the video to watch Marjorie Taylor Green get triggered by Crockett's comments. I now recognize Miss Crockett from Texas for five minutes. Thank you so much, Madam Chair. Are we tired of winning yet? We are hugely winning. We have the best of the best. Right. Wrong. That was sarcasm if you didn't catch it. Um the fact is we should never have partisan politics playing a role when we're talking about something such as science. But unfortunately in today's times, Democrats believe in scientists and experts and data and Republicans instead believe in conspiracy theorist. And right now, that is who we have leading one of the most important agencies in this country is a conspiracy theorist, not someone who has an actual resume to get the job done. So, why would anyone trust the Republicans on anything, let alone matters of public health and safety? It has taken Texas largest measles outbreak in 30 years with more than 500 confirmed cases and the death of two children for the Secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services to say what we already knew. The most effective way to prevent the spread of measles is the MMR vaccine. This is the same guy who chaired the antivax nonprofit Children's Health Defense. Just last month, during an interview with Fox News, he suggested that somehow being infected with measles could provide protection against cancer and heart disease. The Republicans are implementing the most dangerous public health agenda in modern American history, and people are literally dying as a result. This administration doesn't believe in science. They're firing thousands of scientists and public health officials who keep our food and medicine safe. Slashing funding for scientific agencies that help cities and states respond to public health emergencies, limiting public access to research and data that contradicts their misinformation. They're using financial threats to manipulate which studies the government will sponsor, and blocking researchers from diversifying clinical trials. This reckless and chaotic approach will make it more difficult for the FDA to achieve its mission of protecting the public health of Americans. But there are two issues that I want to address before my time expires. Staffing at FDA has long been a challenge. The Government Accountability Office has identified several challenges at FDA as high-risk issues. One of the bigger issues the GAO has identified as FDA's extensive workload. Last Congress, the Senate held a hearing on the sale of unauthorized and illegal vaping products and ecigarettes. During the hearing, Dr. Brian King, director of FDA's Center for Tobacco Products, testified that the volume of pre-market tobacco product applications is overwhelming. So FDA is instead prioritizing its enforcement responsibilities when it comes to ecigarettes products. But just last week, Trump not only fired the director of FDA's tobacco center, he closed two entire offices responsible for drafting new tobacco regulations and setting policies. Dr. Kesler in its 2025 high-risk report, GAO stated that quote, "Stable senior FDA and center leadership remains of vital importance to the agency. How will this vacuum of leadership impact the public health and safety of Americans?" It will put Americans at risk. But you, Congresswoman, you raised a very, very important point. I'm the only pediatrician on this panel today. And your constituents, please, the most important thing is what you said. If you want to prevent measles, please have your children vaccinated against that very dangerous disease. Thank you so much for that, Doc. And I only got 56 seconds and I don't know if I'm going to go through my last question because you just I'm looking to Greg to see if he gonna make me do it. Listen, I I'm I'mma go off instead. Um, sorry. I appreciate the fact that you are an expert in this and here's the reality. Um, the Republicans and definitely MAGA loves to troll me in so many ways. Um, and the reality is that I trust and believe experts. I don't believe that I know everything. I believe that I was elected by my constituents to make sure that I could keep them safe in all ways. Making sure that they are not going to be victimized if they have, say, family members that are serving abroad because of Signal Gate because of that incompetence. Making sure that they have access to vaccines if they need it. Making sure that they can actually provide for their family because we have real economists that are the general lady's time is whether or not we are inad tariff war. Gentle lady's time is expired. I now recognize Mr. Fallon from Texas for 5 minutes. Of course, I had to leave Marjorie Taylor Green banging her gavvel there, using the only little power she has to try to get back at Jasmine Crockett, who made point after point about how Republicans love the conspiracy theories, love the conspiracy theorists like Marjgerie Taylor Green, and refuse to listen to science and facts and data. like Democrats do. Now, talking about RFK Jr., uh it's really important to remember that the guy made numerous comments about how vaccines are unsafe in the years leading up to his presidential bid and then used that bid to try to land a position as the Secretary of Health and Human Services for either Kamla and Donald Trump. He approached both campaigns and Kamla told him that he can go kick rocks, but not Donald Trump. Donald Trump instead chose him to be the secretary of HHS. And now, because RFK Jr. doesn't want an outbreak of measles on his hands. He's now saying that the measles vaccine is the best way to prevent your child from getting measles. And now people who listen to him talk about how vaccines might cause autism and how they're unsafe. Well, now he's singing a different tune because RFK Jr. will blow whatever way the wealth winds take him. He's very vorious. He only cares about power and money. And that's the real issue here. It's not so much that he's a conspiracy theorist. It's that he's the cabinet secretary of health and human services and can make decisions based on the money. And if you don't know anything about health and human services, there's a lot of money when it comes to the American health care system. So, Jasmine Crocky here pointing all of this out is fantastic, but she also started to uncover the defunding of public health organizations that Donald Trump is conducting from the White House. And so we see things like, you know, we're focused on things like RFK Jr. being the conspiracy theorist and Donald Trump's tariffs and the defunding of federal government programs uh at the hands of people like Elon Musk and Doge and Donald Trump. But what Jasmine Crockett is doing here is so important because there's so many layers to uh the the impacts of what this defunding means. for the federal government. And so while what's on the surface is deeply troubling, what's underneath it is also very scary and and that should really alarm a lot of us and and wake a lot of us up to the problems that we're going to need to fix once Donald Trump and Republicans are out of power. Let me know what your thoughts are on Jasmine Crockett's comments in the comments down below. And be sure to subscribe to Reflect Politics so that you get my future videos delivered straight to you. Thanks for watching. My name is Brendan Plank. Hope to see you in the next video.

output.description:
Janet Henry, Global Chief Economist at HSBC weighs in on the economic impact of Donald Trumps tariff policy as China says its open top talks if the US president and his team show the country more respect. The fate of the global economy and financial markets hinges in large part on whether the US and China can find a way to avoid a protracted trade war. Trump has hit China with tariffs of 145% on most goods since taking office, prompting Beijing to retaliate and threatening to wipe out most trade between the world's biggest economies.Â 

Janet Henry spoke to Bloomberg Radio's Stephen Carroll and Valerie Tytel as Bloomberg Economics calculated that US importers have borne almost 100% of the tariffs , with little offset from their counterparts across the border, through March. Tariff costs have been passed on to US importers at the border, and profit margins for US firms appear set to take a hit.

output.script:
Tariffs are bad for growth and the
uncertainty is very, very bad for growth.
And we now have a higher cost of capital because equities are lower and bond
yields are higher than they were. So that will weigh on investment
spending and and on decision making. This is going to be a weaker period for
for hiring. So certainly we are looking for the
unemployment rate to rise. And and we think that that will also
mean especially with higher inflation from from tariff prices, the real
incomes will be squeezed. So it's not just investment spending
that will be weaker, but with employment, weaker consumer spending
growth will be weaker as well. So, yes, the these tariffs are going to
take a significant toll on growth. We're not going to see anything like the
kind of growth rate, even if we're not forecasting a deep recession.
Do you see the impact as being more time limiting?
What are the kind of long term parts of that that could actually drag sort of as
we think further into the future? Well, I think that's that's the key
question in all of this. How long does this last?
You know, this isn't a kind of one off adjustment in tariffs if it was 10% on
everyone indefinitely, because that's how we're going to raise revenues.
And it all happens in April. Then a year later, it drops out and you
haven't got this ongoing uncertainty. But the stop start nature and the fear
that on a daily basis you wake up in the morning and not wondering whether which
sectors are going to have 25% tariffs, which countries tariffs are going to be
at 100%. That's where the damage is caused.
And we know that there is a broader point to this.
The intention of the US President is to relocate manufacturing to the US, but
manufacturing only accounts for less than 10% of U.S.
employment. Is the damage that would be caused on
the other 90% of employment from that much weaker spending.
But also, he really does want to significantly reduce the relationship
between the U.S. and China, and that's where there will
be knock on impacts within the rest of the world.
And I think it is it is longer term, you know, certainly for the next two years
ahead of the midterm elections and there will be significant shifts in global
trading relationships, reconfigurations. And look what's already happened in
terms of triggering more policy stimulus in China and in Europe.
And that's not going into reverse. Now, you know, the European rearmament
and I guess the realization in Europe that they need to do more to support
domestic demand in their own economies. This is medium term.
It's not just something that's going to be resolved in a few weeks or indeed 90
days. Janet, on relocating trade or perhaps
rebalancing the economy. I'm having a hard time getting my head
wrapped around what are the effects of a narrowing trade deficit if if Trump gets
gets that, if that's what he's after? I mean, we're still confused if that's
really what he wants. But let's say the trade deficit does
narrow. Does that necessarily entail there'll be
less investment, you know, via capital account inflows into the U.S.
And does that worry you or is that off the mark?
Well, he's not going to balance the budget.
The trade deficit. Balancing the trade deficit would take a
multi-year recession, which is actually what happened in the 1930s when tariffs
were at this level. But I think there is an inconsistency of
what he's trying to deliver. You cannot have a much narrower trade
deficit and have lower bond yields and have a weaker dollar.
That is an possible shouldn't have a have a government deficit of 8% of GDP.
Right. That something has to break there.
Absolutely. He will have to decide, you know, what
are his major priorities. And also, as much as countries are
queuing up apparently to say that they will invest more in the U.S.
and we've had announcements from Japan and Taiwan, actually, if you are
investing now and remember, a lot of countries have been investing in the
U.S. for the last three years, helped by the
Inflation Reduction Act and the CHIPS Act.
But now if you're building plant in the U.S., you're paying tariffs on a lot of
the building materials and other areas that you are doing.
So he is making the costs of producing in the U.S.
more expensive and therefore making a lot of U.S.
industry a lot less competitive in global markets.
It's all about the domestic market. And you're right, there will be less
financial flows into the U.S., particularly if there are
other viable investment opportunities. If the U.S.
now is the budget deficit, the current account deficit, then there'll be less
foreign savings to be reinvested into U.S.
Treasuries. Where does that money go, I suppose, is
the next question. If if we're seeing this move away from
the U.S., is Europe attractive enough for that?
Will the Chinese stimulus measures help to drive kind of greater growth from
there? Where do you see that rebalancing
benefiting? Well, if the U.S.
does succeed in narrowing its external balances, then that means the the
external surpluses elsewhere in the world.
So they're kind of excess. Savings that used to all go into the
U.S. Actually, they'll be they'll be less of
it. Also, in Europe, there will be more
demands on those European savings. And I think this is what we'll even hear
from the ECB today is about the role of fiscal.
We know that at the moment inflation's going to be lower, that we are going to
see, you know, perhaps diversion of trade flows.
We're seeing the stronger euro, we're seeing the lower oil price on the
inflation side. But over the medium term now, and
particularly as we go into 2026, you are going to see a lot of these savings
going into European investments. And a lot of it will be whether it's the
German infrastructure spending, the European rearmament.
And there's still a lot of credibility in U.S.
institutions in terms of perhaps not the same yields that you got out of the
U.S., but you don't have the same growth outperformance in the U.S..
Uncertainty. And and, you know, I guess conviction
that the U.S. dollar is going to be persistently
strong. Now, the euro's actually a bit stronger.

output.script: so this guy is going to launch himself into space in a homemade rocket to prove to everyone that the Earth is flat now his name is Mad Mike and Mad Mike has always been a risk taker he used to race motorbikes as a young teen and he eventually became a pro motorcycle racer for a while but all that thrill seeking that's just not enough for Mad Mike he wants more he wants to become the world's greatest Daredevil but unfortunately right now he can't because he's just a working man in fact he's a limo driver in Las Vegas but then one day in 2002 he gets an idea why not break a world record and he decides to take his limousine that he uses for work and drive it up a ramp and jump it as far as it will go and basically create a world record for how far he can jump a limo and he does at the local Speedway he sets it all up and he jumps his limousine a whole ass 103 ft and he sets a Guinness World Record and about a year later he tries again to break his own world record by jumping a new limo 125 ft this time though unfortunately the limo crashes to the ground early and poor Mad Mike gets no world record this time but that doesn't matter to him he still holds his original record so basically he got what he wanted and people now know him as a daredevil and he's happy with that until he here's the thing about Mad Mike jumping limos is great but it's still not enough of a thrill for him and if he's going to be the world's greatest Daredevil he needs to go bigger and that is when he gets another idea he wants to build a homemade rocket and fly higher than anyone has ever flown before in a homemade rocket here's the problem with this idea though other than the fact that it's reallying dangerous the problem with this idea is that he doesn't exactly know how to build a homemade rocket and he's never built something like like this before so he eventually teams up with another guy who does build amateur Rockets this guy Waldo and together Mike and Waldo they're going to build this thing and they're going to do it on a budget cuz you know they're kind of broke and so they design a cheap version of a rocket one that runs on water more specifically it runs on Steam because steam is cheap to make while actual Rocket Fuel is not and so they work on this rocket and they build it out of a bunch of scrap parts and eventually in 2014 boom they finish it and Mad Mike calls it the X2 Sky limo and it's just a little guy I mean here's a picture of Mike standing next to it and here it is on its ramp and so now it's finally time to launch it and one day on some land out in Arizona they actually do Mad Mike he gets all ready and he gets in it and they countdown and boom it takes off and this homemade rocket flies around 1,370 Ft before Mike pulls his parachute to end the flight and then one of the parachutes doesn't end up opening and then pow the rocket Falls and lands pretty hard and Mad Mike ends up getting injured and for the next two weeks he has to move around with a walker but you know he eventually recovers regardless he got what he wanted he successfully launched himself in a homemade rocket and he's content now uh actually no he's not quite the opposite at this point Mad Mike's desire to be the world's greatest Daredevil gets even worse which means not only does he want to go up again but he wants to go higher which means he and Waldo will have to build a new rocket here's the problem with that though they're out of funds now I mean even though they're making Rockets out of spare parts I mean these things still cost money to build and so Mike gets yet another idea why not launch a fundraiser and so he does he makes a Kickstarter to raise money like I'm going to launch myself over 2,000 ft in the air in a homemade rocket please donate but unfortunately of the $150,000 he was hoping to raise he only raises a whopping $310 so that failed but oh Mike he's never out of ideas and he certainly isn't going to give up now so then he decides to do something kind of brilliant he starts pandering to Flat earthers saying that he's one of them and he like really plays into this bit like he starts talking about it publicly I believe the world is a different shape than what we were taught in those programming centers which is called public school system and so he starts telling the Flat Earth Community all this stuff that he wants to launch a homemade rocket into space or nearly into space so that once he's up there he can observe and take pictures and see that the Earth is not a sphere but that it's actually flat and this will prove that the flat earthers have been right about the shape of the world this whole time and because he's going to do that that they should help him raise money for this project to First do a smaller launch and that eventually at some point he'll do a much bigger launch all the way into space I mean he's totally bullshitting them but it doesn't matter flat earthers believe him who would have thought flat earthers would be so gullible anyway so the flat earthers believe him and they set up a GoFundMe for him and through that he raises about $8,500 which isn't a ton but it is enough to help him build his next rocket and so he and Waldo they build a new rocket and here's a picture of of it and you can see that it says Flat Earth on the side then in 2018 they go launch again Mike gets in it and they go ahead and boom it takes off and this launch is also successful and you can see it reaches 1,875 ft and you can see the little parachutes coming out and he eventually gets to the ground safely now just to be clear this launch wasn't supposed to reach space this was supposed to be a smaller launch first to raise awareness for a much bigger ger space launch later but whatever Mike fleeced the Flat Earth community and he beat his previous launch height by 500 feet and that's pretty damn good oh but it's not good for Mike not good enough he still wants to be the world's greatest Daredevil and so he has to go again and now at this point there have got to be people around him saying like Mike you don't have to do this I mean you've launched yourself more than once bro you have proven yourself you're a daredevil every one knows it but Mike he's still determined not only that after this last launch he's suddenly getting all kinds of media attention from this like he's doing interviews on TV a film crew from the Science channel has started following him around documenting his work for a TV series called homemade astronauts he even gets featured on an episode of Tosh.0 and Tosh the host comedian doesn't actually believe that Mike thinks the Earth is flat and he kind of calls him out on it and I believe it is flat I believe you don't believe that and you just want a free trip to space anyway so Mike and Waldo put another rocket together and this is actually their best looking one yet and if you zoom into the photo it looks like he actually got some sponsors to pay for this one so that's cool well however he did it finally the big day comes and this is going to be his greatest launch yet and the Science Channel crew is there filming for the TV show and about 50 other people show up to watch and document the whole thing so mad Mike he gets prepared and you can see him here climbing into the rocket and he straps in and they ready the launch they countdown and boom mike and the rocket blasts off into the air however something goes horribly wrong if you slow down the footage you can see that during the blast off the rocket slightly hits the ladder that Mike had used to climb into it which then snags one of the parachutes and this snag rips off this parachute and knocks the rocket off course and we don't have proof of what happened inside the rocket but it's theorized that this sudden jerk to the side knocks Mike unconscious which means that inside he's unable to pull any of the other Reserve parachutes and because of that Mad Mike and his rocket fall crashing to the ground and of course he doesn't make it 64-year-old mad mik Hugh was known as a homemade astronaut on a self- financed mission to space But as mola langi reports he died living out his dream

output.title: The First and Only Photos From Venus - What Did We See? (4K)
output.description:
Only four spacecraft have ever returned photographs from the surface of  Venus. Our neighbouring planet doesnâ€™t make it easy, below the clouds blistering heat and crushing pressures quickly destroy most landers. But, in 1975 and 1982, 4 of the Soviet Unionâ€™s Venera probes captured our only photos of Venusâ€™ surface. The Venera landers scanned the surface back and forth to create panoramic images of their surroundings. They revealed yellow skies and cracked, desolate landscapes that were both alien and familiar, views of a world that may have once been like Earth before experiencing catastrophic climate change. Here are the only photos we have of the surface of Venus. 

Remember to like and subscribe for much more to come! Thanks for watching! V 

I'm on PATREON! You can help support my channel and gain added perks! Join the community and become a V101 member or Patron today - 

https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC_MTPqgFSm_8WUWaCHIfUgQ/join

https://www.patreon.com/V101Scienceâ€‹
