#V101Science
output.tags: Venus, Surface photos of Venus, What does Venus look like, what does the surface of venus look like, Venera 14, Venera 13, Soviet space program, NASA, space, landing probe, Documentary, Venusian, spacecraft, Scorched planet, Have we seen the surface of Venus?
output.script: [Music] on march 5th 1982 the soviet union's venera 14 lander successfully touched down on the surface of our hellish neighbor venus in total it worked for just 57 minutes before succumbing to the harsh environment but in that short time it managed to capture a color panoramic photo of its scorched surroundings more than four decades later and this photo is still one of the best we have from the surface of venus venera was a series of space probes launched by the soviet union in the 1960s 70s and 80s on a mission to study the planet's bizarre environment but it also was a program aimed at returning the first ever close-up photos from the surface of another planet over the course of the program 13 probes successfully reached venus and transmitted data about our neighbor eight landed successfully on the surface and four managed to capture incredible photographs the reason it is so difficult to land on venus is that below that thick toxic cloud cover that is perpetually shrouding the planet the surface experiences extreme temperatures and pressures in fact venus is the hottest planet in the solar system even though mercury is closer to the sun here the temperatures reach about 475 degrees celsius which is about 900 degrees fahrenheit to put that into some kind of perspective that's more than seven times hotter than the highest ever recorded air temperature on earth hot enough to melt lead but that's just the temperature at the surface of venus all that thick cloud creates a crushing air pressure more than 90 times that of earth's here the atmosphere would be similar to the pressures found more than 914 meters or 3000 feet below the ocean along with the extreme heat this environment would easily destroy most spacecraft attempting to explore venus's horrifying landscape however the venera landers were designed to withstand these intense conditions for just about long enough to collect data and send us the first ever glimpse of the venusian surface but how exactly do you take a photograph in such a hellish environment what was clear based on previous data is that if the camera were placed outside of the protective shell then the enormous pressure and temperature would destroy it therefore engineers placed a telephoto meter inside the lander through a special porthole light from the surface bounced through a periscope which then directed it to the camera that was protected inside venera 9 which launched on june 8 1975 was the first mission to attempt to take photos of the venusian surface using this technology though the probe successfully landed unfortunately only one of the lens caps of the two cameras separated what was planned as a 360 degree panoramic photo around the lander became a 180 degree photograph but we did get our first ever look at this scorched landscape the white object at the bottom of the photo is part of the lander and the distortion is caused by the old venera imaging system angular and partly weathered rocks can be seen dominating the landscape many partly buried in soil and the mysterious horizon is visible in the upper left and right corners following venera 9's footsteps venera 10 reached to the surface on october 25th 1975. again unfortunately only one of the lens caps separated properly returning a 180 degree panoramic photo before going silent after about 65 minutes or so the lighting was similar to that on earth on an overcast summer day during the photograph according to scientists the objects at the bottom are parts of the spacecraft and the ground seems to be covered in flat slabs of rock similar to volcanic areas found here on earth in december 1978 venera 11 and venera 12 landed on venus collecting even more data for over an hour but also attempting to capture the first ever color images unfortunately in both cases the lens cap issue struck again on these two missions both lens caps on the cameras failed to separate so while the landers returned valuable data neither was able to take any photographs after this disappointing lens cap malfunction engineers made a series of changes to the design of venera 13 and venera 14 which as it stands are the only probes that have ever transmitted colour photos of the shrouded venusian landscape venera 13 landed on venus on march 1 1982. once on the surface the lens caps successfully ejected and the cameras began taking a panoramic photo around the lander the probe survived for 127 minutes before going silent which was enough time to capture in color what appears to be a bizarre landscape dominated by flat dark layered rocks and fine grain-like soil material filling the gaps the lens cap can be seen sitting in front of the lander and distant rolling ridges are visible in the corner of the photos just four days later on march 5th 1982 venera 14 successfully landed in a different region of venus and like its twin the lens cap also successfully ejected allowing us to see even more of this hellish terrain this time however the ground seems far more fractured with very little of the grain like soiled material seen in 13's images once again you can see the ejected lens cap and in the distance the hazy horizon each of these incredible photos gave us a tiny glimpse into a world covered in cloud so thick that its surface was a mystery up until the first lander arrived they revealed to us a yellow sky above a cracked desolate landscape that is both alien and familiar they found that venus is so harsh that no earth creature could ever survive there yet this world may have once been earth-like before it experienced catastrophic climate change it has been decades since we got a fresh look at what's below the clouds of our scorched neighbor but that might be about to change because this golden hot vision of hell is about to get a few more visitors one of the most exciting is nasa's da vinci plus mission which will study the origin evolution and present state of venus from near the top of the clouds all the way to the ground the mission has a planned launch date sometime in 2029 so we will have to wait a bit longer yet but during a flyby the davinci spacecraft will release a descent probe that will be carrying a camera allowing us to see venus like never before on its hour-long descent the probe will take thousands of measurements and capture close-up images of the surface as soon as it emerges from below the thick clouds the probe is not required to survive the landing however but if it does it could provide up to an additional 17 minutes of invaluable science unfortunately the da vinci plus descent probe does not have a panoramic camera meaning that the old photos from the venera landers may still be the best close-ups we have of our hellish neighbor for many years yet a testament to the brilliant engineering that went into these ground-breaking probes all those years ago i hope you enjoyed this video if you did tap the like button subscribe and turn on your notification bell so that you never miss an upload if you want to find out more about future missions to venus then check out this video where i take a closer look at the da vinci plus mission plus other exciting up-and-coming missions to venus thank you all so much for watching and i'll see you all next time

Planet Fitness Rower Machine Tutorial // Want to learn how to use the rowing machine at Planet Fitness? In this video, I explain the technique to use the rower, two types of workouts you can perform, machine settings and more.

TIMESTAMPS

output.tags: planet fitness row machine, planet fitness rower machine, planet fitness rowing machine cardio, planet fitness row, planet fitness rowing machine tutorial, planet fitness rower, planet fitness rowing machine settings, planet fitness hydro rowing machine, rowing machine workout, rowing machine technique, rowing machine, rowing machine benefits, rowing, rowing workout, planet fitness, planet fitness workout, planet fitness cardio, cardio workout, planet fitness rowing machine
output.script: want to learn more about the rowing machine at Planet Fitness in this video I'm going to talk about the rower's design explain how to perform basic rowing techniques as well as share some rowing workouts you can perform let's get started rowing is an excellent full body cardio workout that any Fitness level from beginner to advance can enjoy and if you're a beginner looking for cardio workouts I have a sixe cardio Kickstart program that includes 30 workouts for the treadmill rower elliptical bike and stair climber to build your confidence as well as endurance and you can get 10% off with the discount code cardio check it out in my description anyways there are many different types of rowers such as an air rower and a hydro rower but for the most part rowing machines are designed very similarly they typically have footrests a handle a movable seat that Glides along a rail a monitor and a way to adjust the resistance level the foot rests have an adjustable plate called a foot stretcher foot stretchers are designed to secure your feet with foot straps when you row before you start rowing the foot stretcher should be adjusted so that the widest part of your foot is covered by the strap once your feet are in pull the straps to ensure your feet are secure and locked in place and when you're done with the rower just loosen the straps to get your feet out the rower handle is where you'll grip to perform the rowing motion make sure to hold it with a firm but relaxed grip the seat is what allows you to Glide smoothly along the rail so make sure you're sitting comfortably the monitor displays workout metrics such as time meters traveled Strokes per minute time it takes to travel 500 M calories and Watts the higher Strokes per minute the higher the Watts and the less time it takes to travel 500 M all indicate an intense Row in which you're working hard and exerting a lot of effort and the lower your Strokes per minute the lower watts and the more time it takes to travel 500 M indicates an easier effort depending on the type of rower you're using there should be a dial or adjustment of some sort that allows you to change the resistance level with a higher resistance the harder and faster you row can lead to more distance travel per stroke however if you're just starting out I recommend using a low to Middle resistance level so you can focus on your rowing technique the basic rowing technique can be broken down into four phases the catch the Drive the finish and the recovery with the catch you want to sit at the front end of the rail close to the monitor with your knees bent shins vertical and arms extended making sure your core is engaged from here we'll enter the next phase which is the drive in this phase you'll push off with your legs and as your legs straighten Lean Back slightly and pull the handles towards your chest remember here that your leg is generating most of the power not your arms after your legs are fully extended you're in the Finish phase in which your back is slightly leaning and the handle is close to your lower chest and elbows out into the sides of your body finally we enter the recovery phase which will have you extending your arms back out hinging forward at the hips and bending your knees to return to the catch position preparing you for your next stroke and then repeat this process for the duration of your workout in this demonstration I've shown you how to perform a mid row where you pull the handle towards your lower chest which activates the midback and lats there's also a high row which targets your upper back and rear deltoids more here you're going to pull the handles towards your upper upper chest or collar bone area keeping your elbows high and out to the sides and squeezing your shoulder blades at the top a low row will activate more of your middle back and lats the drive here involves pulling the handle towards your abs and elbows close to your body at the top of this movement you're going to squeeze your back muscles another type of row is the reverse grip row which targets your biceps and upper back with this type of row you're going to hold the handle with an underhand grip keeping your elbows close to your body and squeezing your back and biceps at the top of the movement two common types of workouts on a rowing machine are steady state in and interval workouts in a steady state workout you're rowing at a consistent moderate intensity for a prolong period of time the goal is to maintain a steady pace and heart rate throughout the session an example of this workout could be rowing at a moderate pace for 30 minutes keeping your stroke rate and speed steady in an interval workout you're alternating between periods of high-intensity rowing and low intensity or a rest period the aim is to push the body to work at maximum effort during the high intensity intervals and recover during low intensity phases an example of this is rowing hard for 1 minute followed by 2 minutes of easy rowing or complete rest repeated for 20 minutes and if you're a beginner looking for more cardio workouts to follow check out the sixe program I mentioned earlier in my description so you going to give the row a try let me know in the comments below and check out my other Planet Fitness videos in the link on the left thanks for watching

working on it because I had to make some interesting choices and trade-offs to make it work the way it does full disclaimer this feature is a paid feature of my app but I left some codes like this one throughout the video that you can use to claim your free copy so make sure to pay attention and catch them when they appear you see you got to stay alert otherwise this video doesn't have any sponsored Parts also one more thing I want to address because some people in the comments call me out on this all the time you see the reason I feel myself in coffee shops working is not because I want to sell you this lifestyle or whatnot I have nothing to gain from that I sure am not sponsored by Porsche but what's the reason then the truth is much more pedestrian I no longer have a home studio nor a desk setup for that matter it's my baby daughter's room now and I'm just a guy and this the coffee shop and occasional street photography I do is my little creative escap Cape something I do to find inspiration and if I can also find and capture a memorable moment from my city to share with you guys then even better okay now that we have that settled the next obvious question is why make a system monitoring feature for my app when Mac OS already has a perfectly working activity monitor I think that mostly depends on your definition of perfectly activity monitor is highly revered in the small Circles of people who find satisfaction in pointless waiting but even if we turn a blind eye to this short delay I wouldn't describe the user experience as anything more than whelming so to help with the narrative progression of this video the question I should ask you is obviously how can we do better than this but a question I want to ask is why is Swift such a garbage language and why are Apple Engineers who made it still allowed near a computer and to risk spoiling the rest of the video both questions will be answered the challenge with making a system monitoring app of any sort is that capturing a snapshot of system usage cannot exactly be described as free within most reasonable definitions of free I typically have a few safari windows open a code editor and maybe notes or notion and I easily see over 600 processes running at any time that's about 590 processes more than I would like to see and certainly enough to call cause all sorts of performance problems I would most definitely like to skip Al together so after looking at what these 600 processes really are it turns out most are system level drivers controllers data collectors and key loggers you know just the usual but there's just not much you can do about it so I decided to cut a corner here and only record and display the ones that take up any notable system resources at all the way I determine this is by taking the top 10 system processes by CPU usage then separately by memory and network and I take the union of those three sets which results in about 20 something processes even worth recording the rest of the processes are regular apps and they're numerous helpers but here's a question do you believe chat GPT has a sense of humor listen to this when I started work on this feature I asked GPT to write me some code to generate fake system usage data every second so I can iterate on the UI and it did that it added most commonly found apps to some list and randomized the numbers fair enough but it was a little bit too random the usage wasn't very realistic so I asked it to make it more believable and in made a few adjustments most notably it made Chrome use all the ram gave me a little bit of a haha so with the rest of the processes I decided to group them under their logical parent and show the aggregate usage next to each process because saying that cursor uses 100 megab of RAM is just recreational gaslighting on a typical day it's much closer to 100 kg of RAM and so I ended up with these neatly organized groups of processes that I collect over time and from which I draw the chart above with the darker color being the system usage and the lighter being users's own usage the chart allows you to select any previous snapshot and investigate past sources of mild to moderate frustration caused by excessive and unjustified usage of your CPU memory and Network and you can dive deeper and look at any process in isolation to monitor how it's trending which it with intuitive or productive to achieve great comedic effect I started working with swift some three years ago and in the first 2.97 years I remained convinced that skill issues were the main it is simple and intuitive in many of the same ways that Swift UI wasn't I quite like SW but not for the reason that most people do definitely not the clever compiler architecture or the benchmarking a trick question it's funny how if I were on an interview I would be expected to give a comprehensive well-rounded emotionally moving intelligently composed answer that evokes the feelings of longing declaratively configured in Json of course but I failed to Envision I'd have to make Json T in complete in the process to make it work so after about 5 days of mucking about with this I finally resigned because it felt a little bit like inventing a new language to describe a thing you haven't seen yet so this first dashboard is cod entirely bespoke with some very light abstractions like this bar chart component and this data loading Helper and I also made this communication bridge between Swift and web kind of reusable for future features but since I don't have a manager to impress with code complexity I will be rolling out this simpler version in the next couple days gradually to all users so make sure to download one menu and check it out and thanks for watching don't

models but nobody's talking about it instead every eyeball in the tech world right now is hypnotized by open ai's brand new GPT 40 image generator which has transformed the internet into a gbi anime cartoon nightmare this is exactly the AI dystopia that Senpai Miyazaki creator of the GBL Animation Studio tried to warn us about years ago when he said quote I am utterly disgusted if you really want to make creepy stuff you can go ahead and do it I would never wish to incorporate this technology into my work at all I strongly feel that this is an insult to life itself that was years ago but now this nightmare is in full effect if you make the mistake of going on Twitter today you'll find that all your favorite memes have been ruined by GPT 40 in today's video we'll take a closer look at open ai's latest toy along with a few other awesome tools that just put us one step closer to the singularity it is March 28th 2025 and you're watching the code report when I read the newspaper that GPT 40 added an image generator my expectations were extremely low especially after the disappointments of Sora and GPT 4.5 low expect however open AI just went out and totally redeemed Itself by shipping some actual fire this tool has allowed me to throw graphic design software like canva in the garbage because now I can create infographics and marketing material with near perfect text rendering it even produced an almost Good comic strip for me and it can even handle transparency like players unlike most other image generators but everybody's talking about its ability to transform images into specific art styles that's pretty cool but the significant thing here is that it gives us the ability to render our AI girlfriends in ways that were previously Impossible by maintaining character continuity like now I can upgrade her with new poses new outfits or even add her to photos of those lonely family dinners that's impressive but how does it work this is closed AI we're talking about so there's no paper or code to look at but apparently they use an auto regressive approach instead of diffusion a diffusion algorithm in models like stable diffusion and mid Journey generate an entire image all at once but GPT 4 takes a different approach generating the image pixel by pixel from left to right top to bottom it almost doesn't even look artificial but it actually contains a controversial Watermark provided by the Coalition for Content Providence and authenticity in fact if you take this image and upload it to the ctpa tool you can see it was generated by open AI along with a history of any modifications to it a camera manufacturers and software developers like Adobe are implementing this into their soft Ware with the goal of tracking every change that happens to a digital asset like an image and that of course is to keep you safe from misinformation at the expense of your privacy and freedom and platforms like YouTube and steam are now requiring people to disclose that they use AI Assets in their work and that brings up a big philosophical question that was first posed by someone with an anime profile picture on the internet with slops razor you ask can you tell it's AI generated by looking at it if the answer is no then it's indistinguishable from Human work thus no disclosure is needed but if you answer yes then it's visibly slop and again no AI disclosure is needed c2p is just deep State bloatware but I digress if you're poor the other thing you need to know about is Gemini 2.5 Pro this new state-of-the-art model from Google actually slaps not only is it arguably just as good for programming as Claude 3.7 with a bigger context window but it's also better than reasoning models like open ai3 and you can actually use it for free slaps Alibaba released quen 2.5 Omni which can see here talk and write thanks to its new thinker talker architecture then 10cent released T1 to compete with deep seek and bite dance the company behind source Chinese model and generate more code than they could ever possibly need and that means real programmers are going to have a lot of code to fix and refactor and an awesome tool that can help you output.title: China Overtakes US with Two New 6th Generation Stealth Fighter Jets | From The Frontline
output.description:
China Overtakes US with Two New 6th Generation Stealth Fighter Jets | From The Frontline

On the 26thÂ of December, 2024, as the Western World was recovering from Christmas Day celebrations, China was on a mission to overtake the West. China unveiled two new stealth fighter jets and its largest amphibious assault ship named Sichuan, which is even capable of deploying fighter jets. The two stealth fighter jets are believed to be sixth generation aircraft and have some extremely unique features including three engines, tailless bodies and diamond shaped structures. This comes as China continues to make J-10, J-11, J-16 and J-20 jets in large numbers. The new sixth generation fighter jets have not been named yet but are being made in Chengdu and Shenyang. Hereâ€™s what we know about them so far.

output.script: [Music] on the 26th of December 2024 the West Was recovering from Christmas celebrations meanwhile China was sharpening the tip of its sword because for China the 26th of December is mong's birthday a day to honor the country's founding father so Beijing went all out it unveiled a line of war machines that left social media and Military Watchers [Music] stunned First China unveiled its largest ever amphibious assault ship then came the breaking news videos of two UFO like stealth fighter jets flooded the internet it appears to be the maiden flight of two new sixth generation stealth fighter [Music] [Music] aircraft that was the flight of a Chinese stealth fighter flying ahead of its j20 wingman the video is believed to be from an Airfield that's operated by the changdu aircraft Industry Group it's one of the two major corporations that makes military aircraft for China the changu based manufacturer is responsible for making two of China's major fighter jets there's the fourth generation J10 vigorous dragon and the fifth generation j20 Mighty Dragon stealth fighter but this time changu has revealed a new aircraft it's being called the j36 because the aircraft that was spotted had the numbers 36011 painted on it it's reportedly the world's first sixth generation fighter jet while details about the new fighter remain classified a breakdown of the videos and photos reveals some intriguing details the most striking feature is that the new aircraft has a large diamondlike delta wing and a completely tailless configuration a tailless aircraft has a smaller radar signature enhancing its stealth capabilities it also has less drag improving supersonic cruise but it affects overall stability and maneuverability the j36 appears much larger than the j20 which means it can perform long range operations while carrying a bigger payload and the aircraft's most unusual feature is its triple air intake Arrangement there's an air intake on top of the Jet and twin intakes on either side of the fuselage in the belly of the body this means the aircraft could have three engines there's currently no fighter jet in the world that has three engines considering the new Chinese Jet's large size the third engine may be necessary for operations at high altitudes and longrange high-speed flights but the j36 wasn't the only aircraft that made headlines because 2,500 km away Beijing had another war machine up its sleeve while the j36 was conducting initial flight tests in the central Chinese city of changdu another possible sixth generation aircraft took flight in Northeast China in the city of Shenyang home of China's second major aircraft maker the Shenyang aircraft Corporation Shenyang makes aircraft like the j11 and j16 which are copies of Russia's suo 30 and 27 Jets Shenyang also makes China's second stealth jet the j35a which was recently revealed at the jwai air show in November videos and photos revealed that the Shenyang aircraft Corporation has also reportedly unveiled a sixth generation fighter jet the second Sixth Gen jet was seen flying with a j16 as its wingman while the changu design has a Delta Wing the one seen flying over Shenyang has a swept Wing like configuration it's conventionally known as a Lambda Wing the aircraft can be seen with just two engines and is almost the same size as the j16 it was flying next to however like the changdu this jet also has a tailless configuration the aircraft has an angular and diamondlike shape which could allow the jet to have low observability China has now unveiled two prototypes for its sixth generation fighter it's the first country in the world to do so the United States France Germany and the UK only have such designs on paper however Beijing has been deliberate with these unveilings because Shan ping is going for Maximum Impact military experts believe that whoever gets the sixth generation fighter first will dominate the airspace battle these are more advanced than the fifth generation jets in terms of stealth super Cruise dog fighting abilities Beyond visual range operations cyber and Space Warfare capabilities and advanced Weaponry including energy weapons like lasers there's no clear timeline for China's intentions however Beijing reportedly plans to induct its two six generation aircraft variants into full service by 2032 while the two jets are still away from combat roles China commissioned an amphibious assault ship on Ma's birthday as well it's named the Sichuan the ship is capable of launching fighter jets it's equipped with an electromagnetic catapult with a displacement of 40,000 tons the ship can carry fighter jets helicopters and amphibious assault equipment like tanks armored vehicles and hundreds of troops adding to China's Island attack capabilities it's a message Beijing wants to send across the Taiwan straight we Chinese on both sides of the Taiwan straight belong to one and the same family no one can ever sever the bond of kinship between us no one can ever stop the reunification of the motherland a trend of the times Taiwan Independence is a dead end and the US arming Taiwan to seek Independence will only backfire and lead to self-destruction the relevant us bills China related Provisions are filled with cold war Zer some thinking and ideological bias ignoring facts hyping the China threat and advocating US military support for Taiwan to increase US military spending and maintain the US hegemony endangering Regional peace and stability [Music] it was widely known that China was developing sixth generation fighter jets however the pace at which the two Jets were revealed has caught the West off guard but the latest Pentagon report suggests that the Chinese Air Force is still far behind the US Air Force in terms of numbers quality experience and combat capability meanwhile China's internal problems continue to mount a sweeping anti-corruption campaign has seen the forced removal of two of China's last three defense ministers at least nine high-ranking generals have been fired in the last 18 months xiin ping is committed to decorr opting his forces and projecting China as a worldclass military with the pre-planned reveal of the new Jets China has closed the Gap with its Western [Music] rivals for [Music]

output.description: Welcome to SportEye! In this thrilling video, we bring you an epic showdown between an Aikido Master and a Pro MMA Fighter. Witness the incredible skills and techniques of Aikido as the master takes on a professional MMA fighter in a battle you won't forget. This clash of martial arts disciplines showcases the power, precision, and philosophy of Aikido against the raw strength and versatility of MMA. Watch till the end to see unexpected moves and the ultimate test of martial arts mastery! Donâ€™t miss out â€“ like, comment, and subscribe to SportEye for more exciting martial arts content. Hit the notification bell to stay updated! #AikidoVsMMA #SportEye #MartialArtsShowdown

[Music] fighter some techniques in iido are known to be very painful however in MMA fights Fighters hands are wrapped and taped despite this Fighters like Anderson Silva have trained in iido and have tried to incorporate its techniques into fights within the [Music] Octagon the following fighter also demonstrated that gloves are not an obstacle to performing iido locking techniques he managed to make his opponent Fall using a perfectly executed wrist lock technique not just once this iido practitioner was able to make his opponent fall repeatedly and dominate the fight with his lethal iido techniques but once there [Music] was this is an example of how iido can be effectively used in an MMA fight iido itself is a Japanese martial art developed in the early 20th century by Mor WBA aido focuses on harmonizing with the opponent's energy rather than confronting it [Music] directly iido techniques involve circular movements that redirect the opponent's Force using their momentum against them iido practitioners usually avoid direct confrontation preferring to panel attacks into controlled [Music] movements come on man please put the gun away iido techniques emphasize efficiency utilizing minimal physical strength by applying joint locks throws and precise Stripes combat in Aikido often involves manipulating the attacker's joints such as the wrists elbows or shoulders to incapacitate or unbalance bance them to defend practitioners frequently deflect attacks by blending with incoming force and redirecting it through circular movements this technique focuses on disrupting the opponent's balance making them vulnerable to being [Music] subdued overall all aikido's philosophy of blending circular movements and minimal Force sets it apart as a martial art centered on Harmony and effective [Music] self-defense iido techniques can also be adapted to various fighting situations making them versatile for different types of opponents and arenas for instance in a match between a one-handed iido master and a professional MMA fighter the iido master managed to challenge the MMA fighter significantly even with just one hand the Aikido master was able to hold his own when they engaged in a clinch he even managed to take the MMA fighter to the ground not stopping there the Aikido Master continue to dominate even during ground combat y next there was an arrogant IO practitioner who claimed that his martial art was Superior to Brazilian jiu-jitsu he then challenged an MMA fighter with a BJJ background to a match however what happened in the arena was completely opposite to his big talk throughout the fight he only tried to evade the power powerful attacks of the MMA fighter and never once launched an attack the MMA fighter taught him a valuable lesson with a hard slam to the floor that left him in significant [Music] pain continuing with the story of an MMA fighter with a BJJ background versus an iido practitioner this time the MMA fighter had a larger and more muscular physique [Music] they were engaged in a clinch position for a long time before the MMA fighter finally managed to take down the iido master with his immense [Music] strength however this did not have a significant impact on the iido master while under pressure in the ground fight he executed a neck lock that forced the MMA fighter to [Music] submit let's move to an outdoor Arena where two overweight Fighters are competing the iido fighter wearing white pants was much older than the MMA fighter this was evident in their fight where the MMA fighter dominated with his powerful punches the MMA fighter took only 30 seconds to win the fight by forcing the iido master to the ground lastly there was a Japanese iido fighter facing an intimidating looking MMA fighter wait however the MMA fighter's intimidating appearance did not match his fighting abilities from the start of the match the MMA fighter was pressured to the edge of the Ring he could not break free from the tight hold of the iido master eventually he was thrown onto the canvas and they engaged in ground combat the iido practitioner did not give him any chance the MMA fighter ultimately submitted after being unable to withstand the extremely painful Aikido [Music] lck iido practitioners and enthusiasts around the world owe a great deal of gratitude and respect to Steven seagull as he is one of the individuals who popularized this Japanese martial art [Music] seagull's first job was as a dishwasher at a restaurant called The Wagon Wheel noticing his quick movements a Japanese Shotokan karate expert who was the cook at the restaurant decided to give him basic karate training this marked the beginning of seagull's long martial arts journey in 1964 he began studying Aikido under the guidance of Harry Koshi ishisaka each and in his late teens seagull moved to Japan with his father who was visiting the country for military reasons and they decided to stay there permanently not long after seagull earned a 7th degree black belt and the title of Shihan in iido this Japanese term is used in various martial arts to honor senior martial arts practitioners subsequently seagull became the first Foreigner in Japan to successfully run an iido dojo [Applause]

output.script: today we're diving into a question I guarantee every new investor has asked themselves at some point should I invest in an ETF or should I pick individual stocks first and trust me this question isn't as simple as some people on YouTube or other platforms make it sound whether you're starting with $100 $10,000 or more this decision can shape the way you build your wealth for the long run by the end of this video hopefully you'll know some of the pros cons and risks of both ETFs and individual stocks and be able to make a more educated decision to see which one suits your personal investing goals better overall we'll start with stocks let's begin with what exactly is a stock a stock represents ownership in a specific company when you buy a share you own a small piece of that company if the business performs well the stock price potentially rises and you benefit from the capital growth you might also get dividends which are small payouts from the company's profits for example if you had invested in Amazon 10 years ago your money would have multiplied many times over but if you picked a struggling company like Kodak or Blockbusters you might have lost everything so stocks are high risk and highreward investments why do people love stocks they do have huge potential for growth especially if you choose the right companies early some companies pay consistent dividends creating a passive income and you might feel a personal connection to the business you believe in what are the downsides stocks are exposed to company specific risks one earnings miss a bad CEO decision or a global event can crash a stock price emotional decisions often lead people to sell at the worst possible moments so that's a bit more about stocks now we can hopefully understand ETFs an ETF stands for an exchangeraded fund think of an ETF like a giant basket of stocks instead of buying one individual company you buy into an fund that holds dozens or even thousands of companies for example an ETF in my portfolio is VGS which gives you access to over 1,500 global companies including the likes of Apple Microsoft Johnson and Johnson and so on you can also get country specific ones such as VO which is another one I hold which tracks the S&P 500 or even VAS which tracks the top 300 Australian companies so why do beginners love ETFs they offer instant diversification much lower risks compared to picking individual stocks and less emotional stress you don't have to worry about every piece of news affecting your entire portfolio etfs also have downsides you potentially won't be getting rich overnight etfs usually track the market's steady growth you might also pay small management fees have a look into this to make sure the ETF you're investing in is worth it for you if you like the idea of being hands-on and actively selecting companies ETFs for some investors can feel a bit boring we can also look at the risk verse reward the real world comparison so let's say you have $10,000 to invest today scenario A you put it all into one stock such as a popular one like Amazon or Tesla if the stock soarses 30% your 10,000 turns into 13,000 in just a few months awesome but if the stock crashes 30% your 10,000 turns into 7,000 and you feel every bit of that loss scenario B is you put the 10,000 into an ETF here the risk is spread across hundreds or thousands of companies if one or two underperform it might barely dent your portfolio and historically markets tend to recover over time so some of the key takeaways are if you're earlier investing journey reducing emotional stress and risk with an ETF can potentially help you stay invested long enough to succeed chasing individual stock winners can be exciting but this requires a thick skin and lots of research there's also an emotional side to investing one thing not often talked about enough is the emotional roller coaster that comes with investing in the stock market when you invest in an individual stock the ups and downs can be intense a stock you believe in could drop 20% in a single week even if the business is still strong and that can make an experienced investor second guess themselves etfs tend to smooth out this ride because you're automatically diversified even during big events like co the inflation scares recently and tech pullbacks etfs usually recover more predictably than compared to individual stocks and that matters because the real secret to building wealth isn't timing the market as you've probably heard it's time in the market so next is my real world approach i'll be honest I used both strategies when I first started I was picking individual stocks such as Apple my first ever investment but I did also diversify like I mentioned into VO and now my portfolio equates to ETFs around sitting at around 70% of the total portfolio value but I still hold individual stocks which I quite enjoy because it gives me the broad market tracking diversification and I still get the joy of picking stocks that I'm aligned with and I believe in long-term overall it's taught me the approach of staying tough and investing during times we're down such as 2022 when I taught myself some really good lessons of going through when my stock portfolio was down over 20% and continuously investing which allowed for the growth in 23 and 24 it's important to learn these lessons especially if you're going to be investing long-term in the stock market so what is the answer if you're just starting out you can potentially look at focusing on ETFs first and building stable foundations and growing from there or if you want more control you can pick individual stocks that you believe in but make sure you do your research on both the ETF you want to invest in and the individual stock both will allow you to gain experience in the market and hopefully some confidence and learn some good long-term lessons the most important thing many people say is to start the longer you wait potentially the harder it is to catch up and I'd love to hear from you if you are an ETF investor a stock picker or if you like a mix of both feel free to leave your thoughts in the comments and if you found this video helpful please give it a thumbs up and share how your stock portfolio is doing i also share weekly updates on mine on this channel which you can feel free to check out thank you

The UKâ€™s new government will inherit an historic economic challenge as a result of Brexit, the pandemic, Russiaâ€™s war on Ukraine and the debt burden exacerbated by all three. Inflation is just one obstacle facing the Labour Party under Leader Keir Starmer, the Conservatives under Prime Minister Rishi Sunak or whomever the country chooses. While raising taxes or increasing debt are unlikely options, there is a potential solution to Britain's economic crisis: increasing productivity and efficiency.

output.script:
Britain's economy is under incredible
strain. More than you may realize. Austerity through two successive,
extraordinarily expensive and damaging crises, has left the UK
with an enormous debt burden. Compared to our friends here or here, or in fact, in any major advanced economy, national debt in the UK has ballooned
the most since Covid. But it's not just borrowing
that's an issue. Look at tax revenue
as a percentage of GDP. Basically,
the share of the country's output that the government takes to pay for what
the public needs. It's almost as high as when what
the public most needed were bomb shelters. And in an election year,
that's a massive problem for whoever's tasked with writing a new spending plan. We can't raise taxes,
can't really let debt go much higher. And yet, public services
are crying out for more money. Britain has appointed
as many prime ministers in the last five years as Taylor Swift's released
re-recorded studio albums. Four, to be precise. So the question is, can a new UK
government fix the problem its predecessors couldnâ€™t? The next government is inheriting
an incredibly difficult legacy. The burden of taxes on the economy
at a 70 year high. Public services are creaking at the seams. Record waiting lists
in the National Health Service. Parts of the justice system
have had nearly a halving of the number of courts
that are operating. You get the picture,
and it's not a pretty one. Some of this is down to government
spending during the pandemic, which is bigger than any G7 economy
as a share of GDP, bar the US. We are providing 280 billion pounds to get our country through coronavirus. But here's the thing. Most of that money was borrowed from creditors
when interest rates were down around here, at historic lows, and repayments
were expected to be relatively manageable. And they might have been. But then... The Russian assault has begun. The largest invasion of a neighboring
country in Europe since World War II. The invasion triggered an energy crisis,
as Europe's access to vital Russian oil and gas was choked by sanctions
and trade restrictions. UK households will pay almost triple the price to heat their homes
this winter compared with a year ago. We're in the middle
of a national emergency. People are really scared and families
don't know if they could warm their homes this winter. The cost of living began to soar
and the UK was once again the second most generous
with financial support, behind only Italy. Overall, 400 billion pounds
or so in additional spending, all of which went into debt, and
all of which gave us the biggest increase in debt as a share of our
economy, of any G7 economy. The twin impacts of the pandemic
and the energy crisis pushed our inflation rate to new highs,
and forced central banks to ramp up
the interest rate in an effort to halt it. And if you're lucky enough to own
your own home, you may remember that time your mortgage payments went up by hundreds
of pounds a month, seemingly overnight. Well, this is why. But for the UK government,
it wasn't repayments for a lovely house, but for hundreds of billions
of pounds of national debt. The combination of those two events
has increased how much it costs to pay for our debt,
from about 40 billion pounds a year to about 100 billion pounds a year. That 60 billion pound increase in spending
just on debt interest is equivalent
to the entire defense budget. As a result,
we have tens of billions of pounds less to spend on anything else,
from health to police to defense. But the extra borrowing on those crises
didn't come with faster growth. In fact, the UK economy has
barely expanded past pre-pandemic levels. You can see here only Germany
has grown less than the UK in that time, as it was so dependent on cheap
Russian gas that it faced an existential crisis
when the taps were turned off. Germany is also spending
a far lower proportion of its GDP on servicing its debt, though. So the challenge to the new government is
how do you pay off a huge pile of debt without raising taxes or borrowing
or squeezing public services even harder? Well, one of the best ways to grow
an economy is to make a nation more productive. What happens with improving productivity
is that for the same amount of work, you get more out of it. It doesn't mean what many people think it
means, which is just that you have to work harder. If you are working
in an old fashioned newspaper and you move to a tech company,
the tech company is more profitable, has greater margins,
and you could work less hard. But your contribution
in terms of productivity to the economy could be greater because you effectively
are working smarter. In the wake of Brexit and Covid,
the UK is in a unique position here. We did inherit a situation where output
per head productivity in the economy had already been weakening quite dramatically after the global
financial crisis in 2008,2009. Which you can see here, altering a trend that had been in motion since the 1970s. You then have the impact of Brexit,
which had a particularly sharp effect on investment, which we saw feed
almost immediately into growth and again pulling down our overall efficiency,
our output per head. And then Covid has added
this extra legacy. Which means we need our heads
to be working even smarter. But for the time being, we need bodies too
in the workforce. And here we have another problem. Across the major advanced economies,
every country saw an increase in the proportion of people finding jobs and going into the workforce
or trying to after the pandemic. But look at the UK, we lost workers. More people fell into long term sickness
and people just dropped out. There's a million people, in a sense,
missing from the labor force, many of them claiming disability benefit
or sitting on NHS waiting lists. One of the drivers of growth
over the last decade or two prior to the pandemic had been the increase
in the participation rate. So the proportion of people able
to work actually doing so. By going into reverse, that has caused
a very particular British problem. Participation has not come back
since the lockdowns. That represents
a lot of missing productive capacity. This is all monumental pressure for the
next government to withstand and relieve. They need to get the population
able to work doing so and in a more productive capacity. Then there's wiggle room
to deal with high interest rates and bring down national debt, freeing up
tax revenue to bolster public services and support the people unable
to work in the first place. Everyone agrees
this is an enormous challenge, but if it's one the new government can
pull off, the potential gains are massive.

output.script: is coding dead in 2025 [Music] well maybe but not in the way that you think we are not far from a world I think we'll be there in 3 to 6 months where AI is writing 90% of the code and then in 12 months we may be in a world where AI is writing essentially all of the code programming is vital but it's just different now so we're going to break up this video into five parts and explain exactly why coding as we know it is dead in 2025 but why programming is not you you you probably recall over the course of the last 10 years 15 years um almost everybody who sits on a stage like this would tell you it is vital that your children learn computer science everybody should learn how to program and in fact it's almost exactly the opposite it is our job to create computing technology such that nobody has to program and that the programming language is human everybody in the world is now a programmer a portion of this video has been sponsored by HubSpot okay so let's first take a step back when you first started to code you probably ended up choosing a highle language like Python Java or JavaScript and then maybe even a framework like React or Spring Boot but what you probably never had to do on the job was code in binary or physically work with a bunch of servers and cables in the little room in the back of your office those were the OG software and hardware engineers and kind of like how every generation before says you never had to work as hard as our generation it's somewhat true okay no we didn't have to painfully write things in binary or assembly but we still have to work harder in other ways we now have so much more information at our disposal that technology changes extremely quickly you always have to think on your feet and there's never any job security likewise coding in these highle languages is kind of like the boomers of the past you no longer have to spend hours on Stack Overflow to try to find the answer in fact you shouldn't because the next developer that comes along is just going to default to using Copilot and they'll be a lot faster and a lot more productive than you understanding this first is extremely important in understanding how to get past the death of coding as we know it today we're talking about vibe coding which is from a Andre Karpathy post that went viral recently there's a new kind of coding I call vibe coding where you fully give in to the vibes embrace exponentials and forget that the code even exists so this is a clip from YC's main channel they're talking about the newly coined term vibe coding and I've heard many different terms for this like the AI assisted developer the noode software engineer you name it vibe coding as the video suggests is just coding off of good vibes essentially not really coding but leaning very heavily on AI to code for you but the truth is people always find a way to market software engineering as something easy to do but if it was easy then everyone would be doing it the problem is there are a lot of software engineers but there are not a lot of decent software engineers and the no code approach doesn't mean no coding it just means less thinking about code a lot less for example if I wanted to build out functionality to hit an API that gave me basketball player stats for the past 5 years in the NBA and then use that data to come up with March Madness picks I would probably spend hours trying to build and deploy said API cleaning the data manually adding processing and ranking logic and then displaying the info on the web page but as a Vibe coder defaulting to AI generated code is a lot faster but here's the thing you still need to understand what to do with the code you can't just throw it into the void and hope that it works you still have to understand what code is needed you need tests that have good coverage using optimal data structures and algorithms utilizing solid principles and understanding the dynamics of system design i'm not saying that it hasn't become easier but the skills required are just shifting okay so leading on this whole no code approach I did mention that coding was dead but programming was not and by programming I just mean building off of intricate software systems this can include manually coding things but it doesn't have to i actually had a recent video where I talked about building AI agents without any code at all the cool thing about AI agents are that they're not just LLMs that summarize things for you they actually take action in that video I go through a demo of Operator by OpenAI where it opens up a browser on the cloud browses the web for grocery items to make apple pie and then orders the groceries for me and I set up an AI agent on my own within 5 minutes as well you can actually check that video out here this technologies limit is endless you can use AI agents to automate entire workflows for you without having to do any code this is the future of programming it's evolved into maintaining and designing overarching systems in a clean way this type of programming can get complicated so if you want a free resource to learn more I'd highly recommend checking out HubSpot's free AI agent playbook this playbook goes over a breakdown of things like what AI agents are and how they work how to get started with AI agents and even some common pitfalls to watch out for it also gives you a foundational understanding of the difference between an AI agent and any old AI chatbot for example as shown here AI agents won't just summarize information for you it'll actually do the thing here the guide shows that if you wanted to find your top performing blog posts and draft social media updates for them the AI agent would connect to an analytics API analyze top posts draft social media posts and even schedule the posts for you my favorite section is actually setting up an AI agent yourself as important as the theory is behind it it won't matter if you don't know how to create an AI agent yourself this guide sets up a framework to follow so you can start creating these agents on your own it even goes into detail about low precision versus high precision task frameworks and the common pitfalls that you should definitely avoid at the very end it even reflects on the relationship between AI and humans this 40-page guide is filled with golden nuggets and it's completely free i've linked the HubSpot guide in the description below so you definitely want to check it out okay now back to the video so in the same video clip that I showed you earlier Jensen talked about domain level expertise being on the rise the countries the people that understand how to solve a domain problem in digital biology or in education of young people or in manufacturing or in farming those people who understand domain expertise now can utilize technology that is readily available to you you now have a computer that will do what you tell it to do but what exactly does that mean in the context of software engineering he means having a deep specialized knowledge in a particular field and that's beyond just the technical skills required for coding now it's not just knowing how to code but also understanding context at a high level and knowing how to effectively apply AI within a new domain for example with healthcare this looks like an engineer that understands medical terminology workflows patient privacy laws and how doctors actually make decisions this gives us the ability to focus our problem solving on using the code rather than creating the code in the best possible way of course which by the way still means having an understanding of the code and the theory and how everything works problem solving has always been the foundation for software engineering so this part hasn't actually changed but if you treat it like a technology change then it'll be a lot easier to adapt to this AI revolution then learning new domains won't be hard either in fact it'll feel more creative as you get to explore the AI architecture side of systems and the domain that you're using these systems for do you remember working on a bug or a coding assignment and you just couldn't get one of the tests to run you had to spend hours looking things up on Stack Overflow or Googling random examples that could maybe be applied to your work this was honestly the most frustrating part of the process for me you may know most of the coding fundamentals but there's always something that you don't know and so you end up relying too much on either the gold or the garbage of the internet because let's be honest both exist now I'm not saying that AI can't give you garbage code it definitely can and I've seen it happen a lot but the cool thing is you don't have to put in the effort to manually search for things so even if it gives you gold or garbage you'll have to sift through that but it'll just be a lot faster and if you don't get what you want it'll at least try to modify things or give you a template to jump off of the old way of coding is definitely dead but there is a new way to program the environment around you and it just takes a new type of software engineer to do these things and the sooner you adapt to these changes the easier it'll be to level up your skills it's a marathon at the end of the out first and then once you get used to it you're gonna find the weight that works best for you i've got my dumbbell i'm gonna go ahead and get a pad as well it's not required but it makes it feel a little while to get used to this part and that is you're going to use your monkey abilities a little bit and you're going to be using your feet to act as hands you're going to clamp the dumbbell the hamstring curl machine that you might find at your local commercial gym with that one you're going to have the constant tension due to the cable but with the dumbbell as you get into that vertical Iran
Iran has officially received its first batch of Su-35 fighter jets from Russia, marking a major milestone in its air force modernization. With a total of 60 Su-35s expected by 2025, Iran Gets First Sukhoi SU-35 Fighter Jets from Russia, 60 to Arrive by End of 2025 acquisition significantly enhances Iranâ€™s aerial combat capabilities and shifts the regional balance of power.

ğŸ”¹ Why the Su-35?

Super maneuverability for air superiority

Advanced radar systems tracking multiple targets

Long-range operational capabilities

Seamless integration with Iranâ€™s defense infrastructure

ğŸ”¹ Strategic and Geopolitical Impact
This deal strengthens Iran-Russia military ties, with local assembly and technology transfer paving the way for future domestic fighter production. Iran is also acquiring Yak-130 trainer jets to prepare pilots for high-performance operations.

ğŸ”¹ Technical Advantages of the Su-35

Speed & Range: Mach 2.25 (1,550 mph) with a 1,000+ mile combat range

Super cruise: Sustained supersonic flight without afterburners

Electronic Warfare (EW): Khibiny ECM disrupts enemy radar

Weaponry: 12 hardpoints for R-77 missiles, KH-31 anti-ship missiles & KAB-500 guided bombs

ğŸ”¥ Whatâ€™s Next?
Iran may be eyeing future acquisitions like the Su-57 Felon or Su-75 Checkmate to further enhance its air force. Will the Su-35 deal reshape military power in the Middle East?

output.script: the evolution of Iran's air force for decades Iran's air force has relied on outdated fighter jets including the F-14 Tomcat and MiG 29 many of which date back to the pre979 era following the Islamic Revolution international sanctions severely restricted Iran's ability to acquire modern Western aircraft such as the F-16 or F-35 leaving it at a technological disadvantage meanwhile regional adversaries like Israel Saudi Arabia and the UAE expanded their air capabilities with F-35s Euro fighters and Rafaels to bridge this capability gap Iran sought an alternative solution ultimately securing the Sue35 a powerful and cost-effective fighter jet that significantly enhances its air combat readiness strategic and geopolitical impact and Russia have gradually strengthened their military ties culminating in the Sue 35 deal as part of a broader defense partnership pilot training to prepare its pilots for advanced fighter operations Iran acquired Yak 130 trainer jets enabling a smooth transition to high performance aircraft technology transfer as part of the agreement Iran began assembling Sue 35s locally gaining critical expertise in fighter jet production and maintenance future access to advanced fighters this collaboration could serve as a stepping stone for Iran to acquire next generation aircraft like the Sue 57 or Sue75 Checkmate by integrating local assembly and technology transfer this landmark deal enhances Iran's military self-sufficiency while cementing its strategic defense alliance with Russia positioning both nations as key players against Western influence iran's SU35 acquisition a gamecher in Middle Eastern air power after months of speculation and intense negotiations Iran has finally begun receiving its long anticipated most advanced 4th.5 generation SU35 fighter jets from Russia this is far more than just another military deal it is a strategic turning point that has the potential to reshape the balance of power in the Middle East with the arrival of these advanced aircraft Iran is entering a new era of aerial warfare implications for the region with an expected delivery of 60 SUE35s by 2025 this is the largest fighter jet acquisition in Iran's modern history however Iran is not merely importing these jets it is also assembling some locally which signals potential ambitions for domestic fighter production why the Sue35 iran's choice of the Sue35 stems from its cuttingedge capabilities including super maneuverability for aerial superiority advanced radar systems that can track multiple targets longrange operational capabilities over the Persian Gulf and beyond seamless integration with Iran's existing defense infrastructure technical advantages of the Sue35 the Sue35 Flanker E is one of the most advanced fighter jets in the world significantly boosting Iran's air force with its cuttingedge capabilities engines and maneuverability saturn AL41 F1s engines with thrust vectoring allow for extreme aerial maneuvers and superior agility speed and range maximum speed of MAC 2.2550 25 1,550 mph with a combat range of over 1,000 mi super cruise capability maintains supersonic flight without afterburners improving fuel efficiency and reducing thermal signature radar system passive electronically scanned array pesa radar detects targets up to 400 km away and tracks 30 targets simultaneously infrared search and track IRST enables passive target tracking allowing engagement of stealth aircraft without radar electronic warfare EW systems Kibini ECM suite disrupts enemy radar and missile guidance systems weaponry and hardpoints 12 hard points carry up to eight tons of munitions including R77 beyond visual range missiles for air superiority KH31 anti-ship missiles for naval strikes KAB500 guided bombs for precision ground attacks with this formidable combination of speed maneuverability advanced sensors and lethal firepower the Sue35 transforms Iran's aerial combat capabilities giving it a modern and competitive edge in the region impact on regional military dynamics iran's Sue35 acquisition could challenge the air superiority of Israel the United States and Persian Gulf states extended operational range allows Iran to project power over the Persian Gulf straight of Hormuz and even parts of the Eastern Mediterranean stronger air defense capabilities could improve Iran's ability to intercept enemy aircraft before they reach Iranian airspace enhanced deterrence makes any military intervention against Iran riskier for adversaries electronic warfare potential could disrupt surveillance and reconnaissance operations from rival nations iran's future fighter jet ambitions while the Sue35 is a major leap forward analysts suggest Iran may be eyeing fifth generation stealth fighters in the near future recently reports surfaced of a Russian Sue 57 felon stealth fighter making an unannounced stop in Iran speculation suggests Iranian officials inspected the aircraft as a potential future acquisition a more feasible option might be the Sue75 Checkmate a lighter single engine stealth fighter currently in development by Russia if Iran secures a deal for the Sue75 it could significantly enhance its stealth capabilities while reducing foreign dependency other reports suggest Iran may also be considering Chinese options such as the Chungdu J10C to further diversify its air force long-term strategic vision iran's sue35 deal with Russia is about more than just immediate air power it is a long-term investment in domestic aviation capabilities reports confirm that at least six sue 35s are currently being assembled in Iran under the supervision of Russian technicians a significant step in technology transfer pilot training iran has acquired 12 Yak 130 advanced jet trainers to prepare pilots for high performance fighter operations local assembly enables Iranian engineers to gain critical experience reducing dependency on foreign suppliers and strengthening self-sufficiency in military aviation potential for future collaboration iran's growing defense cooperation with Russia could lead to further technological advancements including potential involvement in the Sue75 checkmate program final thoughts iran's acquisition of the Sue35 Flanker E is more than just an upgrade to its air force it marks a strategic shift that could reshape military competition in the Middle East with 60 SUE35s set to arrive by 2025 Iran is rapidly modernizing its air power to counter regional threats and assert itself as a key player in aerial warfare beyond merely receiving fighter jets Iran is developing domestic expertise positioning itself for future indigenous aircraft production this deal also deepens Iran's military partnership with Russia potentially paving the way for next generation acquisitions like the Sue 57 or Sue75 as the Middle East's aerial warfare landscape evolves the Sue35's role in Iran's air force will be closely monitored by global military analysts and regional adversaries alike

output.script: what makes a great fighter jet is it stealth speed Advanced Weaponry or is it coste Effectiveness and versatility in the world of modern military Aviation two Jets stand out for very different reasons the ja 39 gpin Sweden's agile and cost efficient Warrior and the F35 lightning 2 America's stealthy and technologically dominant Powerhouse one is a 4.5 generation fighter designed for high maneuverability rapid turnaround and affordability the other is a fifth generation stealth aircraft built to dominate the skies with Advanced sensors and electronic warfare both have strengths both have weaknesses but which one truly excels where it matters most today we put them head-to-head to determine which fighter jetpack the bigger punch for Modern Warfare but before getting to the main discussion let's take a look at the overview of the both [Music] Fighters the Jazz 39 gpin is a testament to efficient and versatile fighter design developed by Saab in the late 20th century it was designed to replace Sweden's aging Fleet while prioritizing multi-roll capabilities cost Effectiveness and Rapid deployment its lightweight Canard delta wing configuration enhances maneuverability making it highly agile in air combat this adaptability allows it to perform air-to-air combat ground attack and reconnaissance missions making it a true multi-roll [Music] aircraft the latest variant the gpin EF brings Cutting Edge avionics a more powerful engine and an advanced electronic warfare Suite keeping it competitive in modern air combat a key upcoming upgrade is Sweden's plan to arm the gpin with the Taurus KD 350 cruise missile a long-range Precision strike weapon with a range exceeding 500 km once integrated by 2028 this will significantly boost the green 's ability to neutralize fortified enemy targets from standoff distances but how does it compare to the F35 the F35 lightning 2 represents a major leap in stealth and multi-roll fighter technology developed Under The Joint Strike Fighter program it was designed to provide a common platform for various branches of the US Military and Allied Nations one of its most defining features is its stealth technology which allows it to evade radar detection and penetrate heavily defended airspace undetected Beyond stealth the F35 boasts Advanced avionics including Sensor Fusion and network Centric Warfare capabilities giving Pilots unmatched situational awareness and the ability to share real-time Battlefield data with other assets the fighter comes in three primary variants each tailored for different operational needs the f-35a designed for conventional takeoff and Landing the f-35b capable of short takeoff and vertical Landing for use on amphibious assault ships and the f-35c optimized for carrier-based operations with a larger wingspan and reinforced landing gear now let's compare them [Music] head-to-head when it comes to speed the gpin holds the edge with a top speed of Mach 2 making it faster and more agile than the F-35 which maxes out at Ma 1.6 its lightweight Canard delta wing design enhances maneuverability making it an excellent choice for dog fighting the F35 while slower takes a different approach it leverages stealth and Sensor Fusion to dominate Beyond visual range engagements allowing it to strike before being detected but speed isn't everything range and Firepower matter too the F-35 outperforms the gpin in endurance boasting a combat range of 2,200 km compared to the gin's 1,500 km it also carries a heavier payload up to 18,000 lb of weapons surpassing the gpin 13,000 lb however Sweden is leveling the playing field by integrating the Taurus KD 350 cruise missile a Precision strike weapon with a range of over 500 km by 2028 this upgrade will significantly enhance the gin's long-range strike capabilities of course a modern fighter jet is nothing without stealth and that's where the F35 truly excels its low radar cross-section and internal weapons Bays make it nearly invisible to enemy detection the gpin on the other hand lacks stealth shaping but it compensates with a powerful electronic warfare Suite using gallium nitrite technology it can jam enemy Radars disrupt missile guidance and electronically evade detection while the F-35 relies on stealth to survive the GP encounters with electronic warfare making it highly effective in contested airspace when it comes to operational flexibility the gpin is built for maximum versatility it can take off and land on short or improvised runways including highways and remote air strips giving it a major advantage in decentralized operations its rugged design and quick turnaround time enable High sorty rates making it an ideal choice for nations with limited infrastructure the F-35 in contrast requ Ires well-maintained air bases to perform at its best its maintenance intensive nature and longer servicing times can limit the number of missions it can fly in a given period cost is another key factor the gpin E is significantly more affordable with a unit cost of around $85 million the f-35a while more advanced comes at a higher price around 100 million per unit this Stark difference makes the gpin a more budget friendly option for Nations looking to balance performance with affordability in terms of combat capabilities the gpen E integrates the meteor missile offering Superior air-to-air combat performance along with a gallium nitride based electronic warfare Suite that enhances survivability in high threat environments Sweden is also preparing to equip the gpin with the Taurus KD 350 missile by 2028 adding long-range Precision strike capabilities that will significantly boost its lethality the F35 on the other hand excels in networked Warfare it features Cutting Edge radar systems Sensor Fusion and Advanced Data sharing capabilities allowing it to coordinate seamlessly with Allied Forces and maintain a dominant situational awareness over the battlefield on the global stage the F-35 has been widely adopted with over 1,000 units delivered across 17 countries making it the most widely used fifth generation Fighter the gpin though not as extensively exported is operated by Sweden Brazil Thailand and Hungary and remains a strong Contender for Air Forces prioritizing affordability adaptability and multi-roll Effectiveness so which fighter do you think is better that's all for today thanks for watching [Music]

output.title: How Trump's tariffs could impact the global economy
output.description:
United States President Donald Trump's new global tariffs are â€œconsiderably more dramatic, considerably more consequentialâ€ than anything he suggested during his campaign, Edward Alden, senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations, tells CNA's Asia First, adding that the move is "really a declaration of economic war on the whole world". The universal baseline levy is 10 per cent. Additional reciprocal tariffs will apply to trading partners that the US deems it has significant deficits with.
