output.script: and for further insights on what repercussions we can expect from Trump's latest terrorist let's speak now with uh Edward Elden a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations hi Edward on balance can I start by asking you this is this what you were anticipating a sliding scale with much higher tariffs for America's so-called worst offenders and and coming down to that flat 10% base tax for everyone else no this is considerably more dramatic considerably more consequential than anything Donald Trump suggested during the election campaign and even larger I think than some of us were anticipating over the last couple of weeks i mean if we look honestly at this it's really a declaration of economic war on the whole world and I don't think any of us expected anything uh quite that dramatic so Edward how do you think success or failure of these far-reaching tariffs will be measured by the Trump administration and just how effective do you think these reciprocal tariffs will be in achieving his goals well I mean I think you have to take him at face value when he explains what his goals are he wants to raise substantial revenue for the US Treasury his trade White House trade adviser Peter Navaro has said the US government anticipates $600 billion a year in tariff revenue he would like to cut other taxes needs the revenue to do that he suggested that the revenue will be sufficient to reduce the US national debt uh perhaps even he made references to the income tax being established in 1913 he even seemed to suggest we could go back to the good old days before the income tax so everything that he said on the podium in the Rose Garden today suggest that these tariffs are not a negotiating tactic uh he intends for them to be in place for some significant period of time and to raise massive revenue for the US government and to force companies if they wish to sell in the US market to set up their businesses in the United States so this is a complete repudiation of the the world of global supply chains that has been built up over the last half century under US leadership edward we know that Trump has not spared airlines 24% for Japan and 26% on all imports from India he's calling these numbers kind and half of what these countries are supposedly charging the United States but they will no doubt be shocking to Tokyo and New Delhi i'm wondering if uh these Asian countries are going to take kindly first of all to to what they're facing and also of course I guess how damaging is it going to be for Asian countries which are high on the tariff chart i mean I you know I have to think extremely damaging you look at at Vietnam correct me if I get the number wrong here but I think it was a 46% tariff imposed on Vietnam vietnam as you know well has been a major beneficiary of the relocation of production from China again a a policy that the US pursued the US put pressure on companies to move out of China many of those companies have uh set up facilities in other parts of Southeast Asia yet none of these countries was spared from high tariffs so I think we have to imagine it's going to be extremely damaging for the economies in your region in terms of their response it's a very hard one i mean they can retaliate but of course retaliatory tariffs hurt your own people they raise prices they hurt your importers uh in the executive order the president has made it clear he may increase the duties if countries uh retaliate i think what we're going to be seeing is a sort of scrambling for a collective response i don't think uh any any country is really you know with the possible exception of the EU collectively is really capable of hitting back on a level that will materially affect the United States and perhaps get Trump to change direction and and for most Americans I guess the key question would be will this make their lives more expensive how much economic strain can American consumers and industry bear from these farreaching tariffs and what's the timeline for when they will start feeling that impact i mean I think you know pretty quickly as you've noted these tariffs are going to be fully uh in place by the middle of next week there'll be some grace period for shipments on the water but but I think you know in in highprofile uh items cars being a very obvious one the prices are going to go up they're going to go up uh quickly and I think Americans are going to feel that uh by all accounts one of the reasons Donald Trump was elected was the high inflation in the early years of the Biden administration americans want to see that brought under control so I I think you're going to see a pretty significant push back i think it's going to come pretty quickly the Republicans who as you know are so loyal to the president are still engaged in wishful thinking we have the chairman of the powerful ways and means committee still praising this as a negotiating tactic to get other countries to lower tariffs as Trump did in his first term but I don't think that's what we're looking at we're looking at something fundamentally different at Donald Trump trying to remake the American economy as a protected economy rather than an open economy that is a radical radical transformation that I don't think his supporters really get yet but they will figure it out okay uh Edward we'll have to end the conversation here for now thank you very much for talking to us edwood Elden is senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations

I've been wanting to create a game without an engine for some time now. Specifically the Java programming language because it has been used to create some of my favorite games like Runescape and Minecraft. If you're wondering "How to Make a Game in Java?" or better yet "How Easy is Java to Use" then you were on the same page as me. Hence why this video exists.

#Gamedev #Programming #java

output.script: Java has always fascinated me not only is it the most delicious sounding programming language I've ever heard but some of my favorite childhood games like RuneScape and Minecraft were made using it it was created to let programmers write once and run everywhere meaning Java code automatically works on other operating systems without having to recompile which is truly a beautiful thing and ever since it's release in 1995 it has remained one of the most popular programming languages needless to say I've been anxious for a long time to try it out and see what I can do with it now I must confess when I was 12 before I even made video games I went to my local library and picked up this book called programming video games for the Evil Genius a pretty cheesy name for a book that was just about learning Java of course after skim reading a chapter or two and trying to copy the code I quickly became frustrated and completely gave up so fast forwarding almost 15 years later I think it's time for me to redeem myself and see if I can actually make a game from scratch using Java not scratch I mean Java you get you get what I'm saying so starting off on my Java Quest I did something that I haven't done in a while and that was actually taking a little Java course on my phone and by take a course I mean I just kind of did a couple levels to get a feel for what the syntax was like and honestly if you're a beginner or new to programming languages uh I feel like this is just like a good thing to do it just kind of gives you a general idea before you just start jumping into it anywh who after I was done getting familiar with the basics I downloaded Eclipse which is an IDE and just in case you don't know what that is it's basically just software that you use to code in but this one's specifically for Java and I seem to remember using an IDE called net beans as a kid but Eclipse seems a lot more popular now so I just figured I would go with the crowd after that I set off to create a simple hello world program which was pretty straightforward basically you just create a package and I named it Maine and then you create a class and I also called it main I know it's confusing just trust me on it after that I slapped in the classic system out print line hello world and there you go your first Java program I did it so after getting my feet wet I knew I was ready to start working on my real project instead of CR a little mini game like I normally do for these kinds of videos I want to do something I've been dreaming about for a while now and that's making an RPG and I'm not talking about rocket launchers here I mean like an old grindy RPG that you would play on the NES games like Dragon Quest and Earthbound Beginnings I don't know why but I find these games simplistic art style super strange characters and repetitive combat to be so Charming they always feel so empty yet so full of character at the same time so now we know what direction the game's going to take it's time for us to do something basic and that's just draw a window and no I'm not talking about getting out a box of crayons and drawing a house with a window I'm talking about that frame that you see on your desktop when you play a game luckily for us Java has its own built-in container class called jframe meaning our game can be built purely with Vanilla Java so I set up jframe and made some of the parameters any who after doing all that I was able to successfully draw a window and as you can tell I was very excited next I created two new classes entity and player I'm planning on making NPCs later on so creating an entity class allows me just to reuse that code for the player and NPC for example like drawing their Sprites or checking for collisions and speaking of Sprites I was able to load and draw the Sticky's image make a move around the screen so yay I should also point out that I found this wonderful tutorial series by rynow and it was beyond helpful he does a really good job explaining how all this works so if you want to know more about the nitty-gritty details and all the code definitely check it out next I want to dive into creating a tile map system this is something that has always been intimidating for me for some reason it turns out to be super easy essentially all you have to do is create a text file full of numbers the numbers represent different types of tiles like zero is water and like one is grass and two is sand then all you need to do is load the data into an array and then slap it into a for Loop boom you got yourself a tile map and that's great and all but how do you make a camera system so that the player like can move around a larger tile ma area well the trick is instead of moving the player you move the tile set after that I made an if statement to see what tiles were on screen that way I could save performance by only rendering what the player could see and last I created collisions so you couldn't just like walk on the water so there you go now as you can tell the artwork is looking a little rough around the edges and since 50% of RPGs is just artwork I felt like we probably should update this now my original idea was to create a vector art style inspired by Byron be's Pokemon world map illustrations I've been a big fan of his work for a while and thought an RPG could look Super Fresh in this style though I quickly realized that higher resolution Vector artwork wasn't going to scale well down into pixels so this led me to kind of just create this same style but using pixel art instead I thought the results of this were kind of cool but I personally felt like this missed that quirky charm that I wanted to emulate in my favorite NES RPGs so after a slightly iterative process and the use of the NES color palette I ended up with this my animal inspired RPG so with that done I got to work replacing and adding in all the new tiles and artwork I also found that pixel edit the pixel art software I use has a feature that lets you export tiles out as a text file essentially turning my art software into my level editor which was pretty sweet after this I felt like the sound aspect of the game needed to be addressed so I jumped into lab tur I generated a couple of different sounds and then added them to the game I especially love this door sound when you enter a house it just It's oddly satisfying for music I made it myself using beatbox which I haven't used before I was surprised how easy it was to pick up but uh my song's a little clunky so let me know what you think after that I created a pausing State system so you can eventually look at your inventory and view your stats and I also Drew this text onto the screen so that text is actually a font I also know that world maps are a pretty big deal in these types of RPGs so I jumped back into pixel edit and made this kind of smaller world map just as a test run to see how I liked it this also means I had to create a room transition system so you could go from towns to the Overworld right now there's only one town but I think it's it's pretty cool it's start starting to feel like an RPG at this point I knew it was probably time to add NPCs I mean they're such a critical part using that entity system I mentioned earlier was super easy and made adding these NPCs take no time at all and then I add a dialogue system so I could have Bears say weird things like this and with that we have a basic RPG structure we're still missing combat which is the most crucial part of the game but I want to save that for a future video because this was a project I just really enjoyed working on I can't explain it but making a game without a game engine is super satisfying it's difficult and frustrating especially when you know you could do it 10 times faster using something else but it's also really rewarding cuz you know that you made it yourself I have a lot of plans what I could do with this RPG in the future even just as a passion project please let me know if you like to see more of it if not I'll probably just continue to work on it on my own time overall I really enjoy Java I think this has probably been my favorite language I've used so far in this series I highly highly recommend you check out RN's tutorial series on Java it's unbelievably helpful it explains everything that I covered in this video pretty much and even if you're just mildly interested check it out also if you're wanting to learn how to code yourself and you don't know how to get started check out a word from today's sponsor brilliant okay you might know this by now but brilliant is where you learn by doing with thousands of interactive lessons in math data analysis programming and of course AI now one thing I really like about it is brilliant helps build your critical thinking skills through problem solving not memorization so while you're building real knowledge on specific topics you're also becoming a better thinker brilliant is a learning platform designed to be uniquely effective each lesson is filled with Hands-On problem solving that can let you play with Concepts a method proven to be six times more effective than just watching boring lecture videos plus all the content on brilliant is crafted by an award-winning team of teachers researchers professionals from MIT Caltech Duke Microsoft and learning a little every day is one of the most important things you can do for both your personal and professional growth brilliant helps you build real knowledge in minutes a day with fun lessons you can do whenever you have time it's basically the opposite of mindlessly scrolling which is a beautiful thing now if you want to start programming brilliant has a growing number of programming courses that are a great way to start building foundational programming skills and learn real world applications get familiar with python and start building programs on day one with a drag and drop editor learn essential coding elements things that everyone should know like loops and variables and most importantly develop your mind to actually think like a programmer to try everything brilliant has to offer for free for a full 30 days visit brilliant.org goodus or click the link in the description you'll also get uh 20% off annual premium subscription so check it out also I just want to give my website a shout out gus. fun check it out it's got some information on there latest videos and a picture of me wow let me know if there's any other coding challenges you want me to tackle in the future and I'll see you next time

output.title: Is Russia's war economy on the brink of collapse? | About That
output.description:
The Russian central bank is forecast to raise its benchmark interest rate to 23 per cent this month, with military spending consuming a third of Russia's overall budget. Andrew Chang explains how Russian President Vladimir Putin's war machine is causing inflation to skyrocket and what that means for civilians.

THE RUSSIAN CENTRAL BANK IS  DESPERATELY TRYING TO TAMP DOWN  INFLATION, BUT THE MORE WE  LOOKED INTO THE STORY, WE  REALIZED IT'S NOT JUST ABOUT  INFLATION, IT'S ABOUT A SUPER  HEATED WAR ECONOMY AT RISK OF  GOING SUPER NOVA IN THE WORST  WAY POSSIBLE.  INTEREST RATES IN RUSSIA ARE  HIGH RIGHT NOW BECAUSE INFLATION IS HIGH.  ALMOST 9% LAST MONTH.  IT'S BEEN IN THAT RANGE FOR  ABOUT A YEAR NOW BUT FOOD  STAPLES HAVE BEEN ESPECIALLY  EXPENSIVE, BREAD UP 12% THE LAST YEAR, APPLES UP 14%, MILK UP  15%, CABBAGE UP 26%, BUTTER UP  30%, ONIONS UP 33%, AND POTATOES UP 74%.  [SPEAKING ALTERNATE LANGUAGE].  >> Andrew: GROCERY STORES HAVE  SEEN A SPIKE IN THEFTS.  GO AHEAD AND GOOGLE RUSSIA  BUTTER THEFT.  SOME KEEP THEIR STOCK BEHIND  LOCK AND KEY.  RUSSIA CENTRAL BANK HAS DONE  WHAT CENTRAL BANKS HAVE DONE  AROUND THE WORLD TO REIGN IN  INFLATION.  >> RAISED INTEREST RATES.  >> TO 20%.  >> TO 21%.  >> Andrew: BUT THERE IS A STEEP  PRICE OF MAKING THE COST OF  BORROWING THAT HIGH.  FOR SOME RUSSIANS, IT WILL MAKE  THE OPTION OF HOME OWNERSHIP  IMPOSSIBLE.  CORPORATE BANKRUPTCIES IN RUSSIA HAS JUMPED 20% THIS YEAR AND  INTEREST RATES ARE SQUARELY TO  BLAME.  >> THERE ARE FIRMS THAT RELIED  ON BORROWING FROM THE BANK.  THEN YOUR LOAN REPAYMENT SOARS.  >> Andrew: MORE THAN 200 MALLS  FACED BANKRUPTCY BECAUSE OF THE  HIGH COST OF FINANCING.  EVEN THE COMPANIES WHO ARE  STAYING AFLOAT HAVE TO MAKE SOME TOUGH CHOICES.  TAKE RUSSIAN RAILWAYS.  STATE OWNED, THE BIGGEST  OPERATOR IN THE COUNTRY,  PASSENGER AND FREIGHT, AND  ACCORDING TO A LEADING BUSINESS  DAILY IN RUSSIA, THE LOANS HAVE  BECOME TOO EXPENSIVE.  DESPITE FIGURING THAT THEY NEED  TO SPEND AROUND 1.3 TRILLION  RUBLES OR $17 BILLION CANADIAN,  JUST TO MAINTAIN INVESTMENT  LEVELS, THEY'RE PLANNING TO  SCALE IT BACK BY MORE THAN A  THIRD.  THAT MEANS SACRIFICING EXPANSION PLANS TO INSTEAD PAY BALLOONING  INTEREST PAYMENTS THAT HAVE  REPORTEDLY GONE UP ABOUT  $4 BILLION U.S. SINCE RATES  STARTED SHOOTING UP.  HERE'S THE BIGGER PROBLEM, THIS  TRADITIONAL LEVER OF COOLING  INFLATION BY HIKING INTEREST  RATES ISN'T WORKING.  WHAT'S ULTIMATELY DRIVING  INFLATION IN RUSSIA IS PUTIN'S  WAR MACHINE ITSELF.  SUPER CHARGING AN ECONOMY BY  GOING TO WAR CAN MAKE IT  VULNERABLE BECAUSE IT HAS ALL  THE APPEARANCES OF AN ECONOMIC  BOOM, RIGHT? EVERYONE IS WORKING, INCREDIBLE  AMOUNTS OF MONEY ARE BEING  SPENT, BUT IT'S NOT DRIVEN BY  THE MARKET, IT'S DRIVEN BY  GOVERNMENT SPENDING.  IT'S NOT SUSTAINABLE.  >> THE DEMAND IN THE ECONOMY IS  SKEW IN THE FAVOUR OF  UNPRODUCTIVE EXPENDITURES ON  MILITARY AND DEFENCE.  >> Andrew: THIS EXPERTS SAY, IS  THE CASE IN RUSSIA WHERE THE  GOVERNMENT HAS MADE THE WAR IN  UKRAINE THE SINGLE BIGGEST  PRIORITY.  MILITARY SPENDING NOW CONSUMES  ONE-THIRD OF THE COUNTRY'S  OVERALL BUDGET.  JUST FOR CONTEXT, ALMOST NO  OTHER COUNTRY SPENDS THAT MUCH  OF THEIR MONEY ON DEFENCE.  UKRAINE IS THE ONLY EXCEPTION.  THIS PUTS PRESSURE ON THE LABOUR FORCE.  I'LL EXPLAIN WHAT I MEAN.  WHEN THE DEFENCE MINISTER IN  APRIL TOURED A TANK PRODUCTION  FACILITY, THEY SAID THEY WEREN'T JUST MEETING, BUT EXCEEDING  PRODUCTION TARGETS.  THE PLANT JUST HIRED 1,200  PEOPLE, WORKING AROUND THE CLOCK TO PUMP OUT TANKS, ARMOURED  VEHICLES, AND FLAME THROWERS AND TO MAINTAIN THAT KIND OF  PRODUCTION SCHEDULE, YOU NEED  PEOPLE, LOTS OF PEOPLE.  LOOK AT RUSSIA'S UNEMPLOYMENT  RATE, DOWN NEAR 2%.  THAT'S DRIVEN BY TWO THINGS.  >> DEFENCE INDUSTRIES WHERE  ACCORDING TO RUSSIAN OFFICIAL  STATISTICS, OVER HALF A MILLION  JOBS WERE ADDED AND THE ARMED  FORCES WHERE SEVERAL HUNDRED  JOBS HAVE BEEN CREATED.  >> Andrew: AND THAT CREATES A  GAPING HOLE IN THE WORKFORCE  ACROSS EVERY OTHER SECTOR.  >> THERE IS NO INDUSTRY LEFT IN  RUSSIA, WHICH IS NOT FUELLING  LABOUR SHORTAGES.  2.4% UNEMPLOYMENT MEANS THEY ARE ABOVE FULL EMPLOYMENT AND  BUSINESSES ARE HAVING A LOT OF  TROUBLE ATTRACTING OR RETAINING  LABOUR.  >> Andrew: CONSIDERING WHAT  HAPPENS WHEN LABOUR IS IN HIGH  DEMAND, WAGES GO UP.  MORE THAN 9% IN 2024, AND THAT  IS ON TOP OF 8% GROWTH IN 2023.  EVEN IF THE AVERAGE WAGE HAS  GONE UP, EVEN OUTPACING  INFLATION, IT'S IMPORTANT TO  UNDERSTAND THAT THE MONEY IS NOT BEING SPREAD OUT EVENLY.  IF YOU MAKE TANKS AND ROCKETS,  IT'S GOOD NEWS.  >> WAGES HAVE GONE UP BY A  FACTOR OF 5 SINCE THE BEGINNING  OF THE WAR.  >> Andrew: MILITARY SALARIES  HAVE GONE UP.  SOLDIERS ARE PAID SIGNING  BONUSES, THOUSANDS OF DOLLARS  EACH FOR GOING TO WAR.  >> RUSSIAN SOLDIERS FROM THE  FINANCIAL POINT OF VIEW NEVER  HAD IT SO GOOD.  >> Andrew: AND EVEN IN DEATH,  THE FAMILIES OF RUSSIAN SOLDIERS ARE PAID FOR THEIR LOSSES.  TWO RESEARCHERS ESTIMATED WHAT'S BEEN PROMISED TO THOSE FAMILIES  OF THOSE KILLED AND INJURED ADDS UP TO 6% OF RUSSIA'S BUDGET.  SAY YOU SELL CARS, YOU'RE A  TEACHER, OR YOU MAKE FURNITURE.  >> YOU'RE LOSING YOUR LABOUR  FORCE OR YOU ARE CRANKING UP  WAGES TO REMAIN COMPETITIVE.  YOU ARE FACING A LIQUIDITY  CRISIS BECAUSE INTEREST RATES IS 21%, MEANING IT'S PROHIBITIVE TO BORROWING FOR ANYONE WHO IS NOT  IN THAT SECTOR.  >> THE PUBLIC SECTOR AND  PENSIONERS BECAUSE STATES CAN  NOT COMPETE WITH THE CORPORATE  SECTOR ON WAGES.  >> FOR SOME PARTS OF THE  POPULATION, ESPECIALLY THE  POORER SEGMENTS, THOSE WHO WILL  BE AFFECTED BY INFLATION,  THEY'RE SEEING THEIR COST OF  LIVING RISE TO AN UNCOMFORTABLE  LEVEL.  >> Andrew: WHAT THIS ADDS UP TO  IS AN UNIMAGINABLE AMOUNT OF  MONEY BEING PUMPED INTO THE  ECONOMY, BUT DISTRIBUTED VERY  UNEVENLY.  [SPEAKING ALTERNATE LANGUAGE]. >> PEOPLE HAVE STARTED TO NOTICE BECAUSE OF THE WAR, WHICH  REQUIRES MORE AND MORE  RESOURCES, HUMAN AND FINANCIAL,  PARTS OF RUSSIAN LIFE BECOMES  UNDER FINANCE.  >> Andrew: ADD TO THAT SANCTIONS FROM THE WEST, WHICH HAVE  ISOLATED AND RESTRICTED RUSSIA'S ECONOMY, SENDING THE VALUE OF  THE RUSSIAN RUBBLE TO NEW LOWS,  WHICH IN TURN IF YOU ARE A  RUSSIAN SPENDING RUBLES HAS MADE EVERYTHING IMPORTED MORE  EXPENSIVE, WHICH FURTHER DRIVES  UP PRICES.  NOW YOU SEE THE CHALLENGE THAT  RUSSIA'S ECONOMY FACES TODAY, AN ECONOMY TURBOCHARGED, BUT  IMMENSELY OFF BALANCE, INCHING  CLOSER TO A BREAKING POINT THAT  THE COUNTRY CAN'T SIMPLY GROW  ITS WAY OUT OF.  >> THE RUSSIAN ECONOMY IS  RUNNING EXTREMELY HOT.  VLADIMIR PUTIN MENTIONED IN  OCTOBER THAT RUSSIA NEEDS  ANOTHER MILLION WORKERS.  NOW, WHERE WILL THEY FIND THOSE? WHO KNOWS.  [â™ªâ™ªâ™ª] >> Andrew: THE FUNNY THING ABOUT INFLATION IS THAT IT'S ONLY  REALLY A PROBLEM WHEN YOU CAN'T  KEEP UP WITH IT.  IN RUSSIA RIGHT NOW, THERE IS A  SHRINKING NUMBER OF AVAILABLE  PEOPLE WHO CAN KEEP PUTIN'S WAR  MACHINE RUNNING.  DEPENDING ON THE ESTIMATES,  RUSSIA LOST SEVERAL HUNDRED  THOUSANDS, THREE-QUARTERS OF A  MILLION SOLDIERS, EITHER KILLED, INJURED, OR CAPTURED.  >> RUSSIA STARTED SENDING  INEXPERIENCED TROOPS.  >> ALL OF THOSE PEOPLE NEED TO  BE REPLACED, BUT RUSSIA'S LABOUR FORCE IS AT CAPACITY AND WE'RE  SEEING SIGNS THAT THE ECONOMY IS STARTING TO BUCKLE.  THE PRICE OF OIL HAS FALLEN  SHARPLY IN THE LAST SEVERAL  MONTHS AND IS EXPECTED TO FALL  FURTHER STILL IN 2025.  G.D.P. GROWTH HAS BEEN  FORECASTED TO SLOW FROM A VERY  HEALTHY HIGH OF 4% THIS PAST  YEAR, TO LESS THAN HALF THAT  NEXT YEAR.  HAVING SLOW GROWTH, A SIGN OF A  WEAKENING ECONOMY, BUT HIGH  INFLATION, A SIGN OF AN  OVERHEATED ECONOMY, THAT'S THE  WORST OF BOTH WORLDS WHERE YOU  HAVE UNSUSTAINABLY HIGH PRICES  THAT EVENTUALLY FEWER AND FEWER  PEOPLE CAN AFFORD.  >> AS THE WAR CONTINUES, EVERY  MONTH IT CONTINUES, WE GET  CLOSER TO A POTENTIAL TIPPING  POINT OF ESSENTIALLY  HYPERINFLATION AND A COLLAPSE OF THE WARTIME ECONOMY.  >> Andrew: NOW IT'S IMPORTANT TO POINT OUT THAT NO ONE IS  SUGGESTING THAT RUSSIA'S ECONOMY WILL IMPLODE TOMORROW.  IT HAS DEEP POCKETS AND CAN  CONTINUE PUMPING MONEY INTO THE  ECONOMY WHILE TAXING THEIR  PEOPLE MORE AND MORE AS THEY  HAVE DONE.  IT CAN'T DO THAT FOREVER.  ONCE RUSSIA DIALS BACK THE WAR  MACHINE, IT MAY FIND THAT ITS  CIVILIAN ECONOMY HAS BECOME A  DEEPLY DAMAGED ECONOMY.  [â™ªâ™ªâ™ª

output.script: I got this question on this channel hey msh I'm 30 and I was planning to start a career as a programmer do you think this is wise comment question a lot of people are worried that AI is going to replace software Engineers so is coding still worth learning in 2024 well depends who you ask if you ask certain folks the ones who always seem miserable and say everything is going to collapse they will say no coding has no future but I've got a different take backed up by real world numbers in this video I'm sharing data that shows the continued demand for software Engineers so to understand where we are now and what the future will look like for software engineers make sure to watch this video to the end first I want to be transparent I've been creating coding courses for the past 10 years and in that time I've been lucky enough to teach millions of people how to code and launch their careers in Tech so yes you could say I have a vested interest in this field but I want to assure you that this isn't a sales pitch it's about helping you make make an informed decision I want you to hear both side of the story and decide for yourself what you believe at the end of the day it's your decision whether you want to learn coding or not and even if you want to you don't even have to buy my courses or learn from me there are thousands of great options out there so yeah there is a lot of fear about AI replacing coders headlines scream about robots taking over jobs and it can be overwhelming but the truth is AI is not going to take your job instead it's the person who knows how to work with AI that will steal your job the reality is software engineering is not going away at least not anytime soon don't just take my word for it here's some data to back it up the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics often called the BLS is a government agency that tracks job growth across the country on their website you can see that the employment for software developers is expected to grow by 26% from 2022 to 2031 the average across all occupations is 3% so that's a strong indication that software engineering is here to stay but it'll most likely transform and that's what we'll explore in this [Music] video to better understand the impact of AI on software engineering let's take a minute and talk about the history of programming in the early days of computing programmers wrote code in a way that only computers understood long strings of zeros and ones it was incredibly tedious they had to keep track of of exactly where each piece of data and code was stored in the computer's memory and to do that they had to manually calculate memory addresses and make sure that different parts of the program didn't override each other compilers came to solve this problem with a compiler we can program in a human readable language like C++ without worrying about how that code should eventually get converted to zeros and ones and where it will get stored in the memory that's the job of a compiler now here here's a fact compilers didn't replace programmers they made them more efficient and the result of that the amazing websites and apps we have today that no one could even imagine in the past these days billions of people can communicate in real time AI will likely do the same in the future we'll be able to delegate routine and repetitive coding tasks to AI so we can focus on complex problem solving design and Innovation this will allow us to build more sophisticated software that most people can't even imagine today but even then just because AI can generate code doesn't mean we can or we should delegate the entire coding aspect of software development to AI because AI generated code has a lower quality and humans still need to review and refine it before using it in production in fact there's a study to support this they collected 153 million change lines of code between January 2020 and December 2023 and they found disconcerting trends for maintenance ability and listen to their prediction for 2024 Cod churn which means the percentage of lines that are reverted or updated less than 2 weeks after being authored is projected to double in 2024 so yes we can produce more code in less time with AI but more doesn't equal better humans should always review and refine AI generated code for quality and security before deploying it to production and that means all the coding skills as software engineer currently has will continue to stay relevant in the future you will still need the knowledge of data structures algorithms programming languages and their tricky parts tools and Frameworks you still need to have all that knowledge to be able to review and refine the AI generated code you'll just spend less time typing it so anyone telling you that you can use natural language to build software without understanding anything about coding is out of touch with the reality of software engineering sure you can make a dummy app but not the kind of software that runs our banks Airlines Healthcare the kind of software our life depends on we can't let a Code Monkey talk to a chat bot in plain English and get that software built at least not anytime soon in the future we'll probably spend more time designing new features and products with AI instead of writing boilerplate code we'll likely delegate aspects of coding to AI but this doesn't mean we don't need to learn to code think of it like a skilled architect using blue prints the architect doesn't need to handra the whole blueprint themselves but they still need to understand those blueprints in detail make sure everything works as designed and give clear instructions for those building the final structure as a software engineer you'll always need to understand the code review what AI generates and refine it either by hand or by guiding the AI to improve also keep in mind that coding is only one part of a software engineer's job we often spend most of our time talking to people understanding requirements writing stories discussing software architecture and so on AI cannot help with that aspect of our work it can only boost our programming productivity but not necessarily the overall productivity in fact another study by McKenzie found that for highly complex tasks developers saw less than a 10% Improvement in their speed so as we can see here AI helped the most with documentation and code generation to some extent but moving on to refactoring the the Improvement dropped to 20% and for highly complex tasks it was less than 10% and this happens when the coding task involves something the developer isn't already familiar with so if anyone tells you that software Engineers will be obsolete in 5 years they're either ignorant or trying to sell you something in fact some argue that the role of software Engineers may become more valuable as they will be needed to develop manage and maintain these AI systems they need to understand all the complex of building software and use AI to boost their productivity now some are worried that one senior engineer can simply use Ai and replace many Engineers essentially leaving no job opportunities for juniors but again that's a fallacy because in reality the time savings you get from AI is not as great as you are promised anyone who has used AI to generate code knows that it takes effort to get the right prompts for usable results and the code still needs polishing so it's not like like one engineer will suddenly have so much free time to do the job of many people now you might say but MOS that's the current state of AI look AI is rapidly advancing and in a year or two it will be able to build software just like a human well in theory yes AI is advancing and one day it may even reach and surpass human intelligence but in theory theory and practice are the same in practice they're not the reality is while machines may be able to handle repetitive and routine tasks human creativity and expertise will still be necessary for developing complex Solutions and strategies I strongly believe software engineering is going to be extremely important over the next several decades I don't think it's going away but I do think it's going to change in the future we'll have to learn how to input the right prompt into our AI tools to get the expected result it's not an easy skill to develop it requires problem solving capability as well as knowledge of languages and tools so here's the bottom line if you have already made up your mind and don't want to invest your time in software engineering that's perfectly fine Follow Your Passion but if you like building things with code if the idea of shaping the future with technology gets you excited don't let negativity and fear hold your back software Powers our world and that won't change anytime soon yes the tools will evolve but the true skill lies in learning and adapting the future software engineer needs today's coding skills and an understanding of how to use AI effectively the output of AI is only as good as the instructions you give it think about it programmers must work directly with zeros and once today's web developers need to know HTML CSS Tailwind JavaScript typescript react nextjs git automated testing and so much more my prediction is that the future brings even more complexity demanding more knowledge and adaptability from software Engineers if you found this video helpful please give it a like And subscribe for more useful coding advice

Following a summit in Ankara, Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto and President Recep Tayyip Erdogan announced their intention to establish a joint venture involving strategic defense companies from both countries.
Indonesia wants to be part of the Kaan fifth-generation national fighter jet project, and similarly, we are interested in developing submarines with Turkish defense industry partners, Subianto said at a joint press conference.
While details of specific companies or technology contributions remain confidential, the joint venture is expected to deepen defense industry ties.
The agreement follows a February collaboration between Turkish drone manufacturer Baykar and Indonesiaâ€™s Republikorp to establish a drone production facility in Indonesia.
Indonesiaâ€™s interest in Turkeyâ€™s Kaan Fighter Jet program is not without reason, amidst the apparent setbacks in its involvement in South Koreaâ€™s KF-21 fighter jet project.

output.script: following a summit in Ankora Indonesian President Prao Sububanto and President Reuptgan announced their intention to establish a joint venture involving strategic defense companies from both countries Indonesia wants to be part of the con fifth generation national fighter jet project and similarly we are interested in developing submarines with Turkish defense industry partners Subiendo said at a joint press conference While details of specific companies or technology contributions remain confidential the joint venture is expected to deepen defense industry ties The agreement follows a February collaboration between Turkish drone manufacturer BAR and Indonesia's Republic Cororb to establish a drone production facility in Indonesia Indonesia's interest in Turkey's Khan fighter jet program is not without reason amidst the apparent setbacks in its involvement in South Korea's KF21 fighter jet project While Jakarta initially committed to funding 20% of the development costs financial delays reduced contributions and unfulfilled payments have hampered the collaboration In addition allegations of technology leaks involving Indonesian technicians have strained relations but South Korea continues to engage Jakarta in part because of Indonesia's status as an early export customer for the KF-21 Indonesia's previous collaboration with South Korea's DEU ship building and marine engineering on submarines has also been played by Gallay Jakarta's potential partnership with Turkey on submarine production could offer an opportunity for a restart Although its track record raises questions about the long-term commitment and implementation of the project Turkey's defense ministry recently announced significant progress on its ambitious naval projects including the national submarine the TF2000 air defense destroyer and the national aircraft carrier Defense cooperation between Indonesia and Turkey appears to be entering a new more strategic phase with a more pragmatic and mutually beneficial approach with both countries recognizing the need to expand cooperation beyond the sale of military equipment to joint production and technology transfer This move not only demonstrates Indonesia's seriousness in building its defense independence but also strengthens Turkeykey's position as a major player in the global defense industry President Mdogen in his statement emphasized that Turkey is ready to share knowledge and technology with friendly countries such as Indonesia especially in strategic projects such as fifth generation fighter jets and submarines He highlighted the importance of cooperation based on trust and shared geopolitical vision Turkey and Indonesia are two big countries that have the potential to shape a new defense order in this multipolar world Herdogan said Turkeykey's national fighter jet project the Khan is currently in the advanced stages of development with its first successful test flight taking place in early 2024 The aircraft is designed to replace the F-16 and is projected to be the backbone of the Turkish Air Force in the coming decade Indonesia's participation in this program although still in the negotiation stage has the potential to open up great opportunities in the development of high-tech capabilities in the aerospace sector For Indonesia participation in the Khan project is also an effort to secure alternative partners after the uncertainty that overshadowed its involvement in the KF-21 project with South Korea By joining the con program Indonesia can ensure access to cuttingedge fighter jet technology while developing local production capabilities through clearer and more structured technology transfer In addition to the aerospace sector the maritime sector is also a major focus in the strategic dialogue between the two countries Indonesia views Turkey as an ideal partner in the development and production of modern submarines Turkey has proven its capabilities by building the riceclass submarine and developing its own national submarine program The success of these projects makes Turkey a country that is not only capable of producing but also designing naval weapon systems independently Turkey is also developing a new type of submarine with stealth technology and more advanced underwater combat capabilities This technology is very interesting for Indonesia which has so far relied on submarines in collaboration with South Korea but has not yet achieved optimal results The problems of delays delivery and even limitations in technology transfer are important lessons for Jakarta to choose partners with a more solid track record Indonesia's desire to strengthen its underwater capabilities is not without reason Indonesia's strategic geographical position as an archipelagic country and located on international sea lanes requires a submarine fleet that is capable of maintaining sovereignty and ensuring the security of its territorial waters Through cooperation with Turkey Indonesia hopes to accelerate the realization of the Navy modernization program As a NATO country that is not only a user but also a developer of advanced weapon systems Turkey provides a guarantee of stability and certainty in long-term cooperation This is important for Indonesia which has so far been looking for strategic partners outside the west and east in building the independence of its defense industry If realized the partnership between Indonesia and Turkey has the potential to change the landscape of the defense industry in Asia and Eurasia This collaboration will also strengthen the bargaining position of both countries in the increasingly competitive and complex global geopolitical arena With the right synergy both can be successful examples for other developing countries that want to pursue independence in the field of defense technology This strategic step emphasizes that both Indonesia and Turkey do not want to be just consumers but also major players in the global defense industry By strengthening this cooperation both countries send a message that a new era has begun An era in which developing countries begin to determine their own security future

output.title: Wall Plank Exercise Tutorial | complete beginner plank
output.description:
Wall Plank Exercise Tutorial is made for a complete beginner plank.  This video will help you safely achieve a plank without having to get down on the floor and without putting a lot of pressure on your wrists.  In this tutorial I will teach you how to plank on the wall and then show progressions for when you are ready for a little more.  The plank on the wall is a plank modified so that it is an accesible plank exercise for a beginner.

The benefits of plank exercises are not just strong abs but also your arms, legs, shoulders, and back get a great workout as well!

Let me know if there are any exercises you would like me to break down in another step by step exercise tutorial video in the comments.

Ready for the workout? Try the Beginner Wall Plank Workout here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-ykX98DcUi8

output.title: Artificial intelligence comes to farming in India | BBC News
output.description:
India has used traditional methods of agriculture for generations, but with 1.4 billion people now dependant on the crops farmers produce, some are turning to technology to boost productivity and profit.
 
For example on one vineyard, sensor devices are being used to check weather and soil health. 
 
Artificial intelligence (AI) can then figure out when it's time to water the crops, add fertiliser and tackle pests.
 
Nitin Patil, who works at the vineyard, says the AI advice has helped "save 50% of the water" the farm had been using previously.

output.script: hey friends it's Rylie i'm a former gymnast and current cheerleader if you wanna take your cartwheel from this or even this to one that looks good and follows proper technique follow along with this tutorial but first I'm super passionate about this so I wanted to remind you that Jesus Christ the Creator of this universe wants a personal relationship with you so reach out start praying and you'll see how much He can do in your life thanks for being willing to listen now let's get into it a proper cartwheel never starts with your chest forward in this starfish shape but instead what is called a lunge if you don't know which foot goes in front for your cartwheel try this method jump up and spin around if you spun with your left shoulder over or clockwise you'll likely be more comfortable on your right foot if you spun with your right shoulder over you're likely a lefty now back to the lunge place your preferred aka good foot in front of you with a slightly bent knee keep your back leg straight with fully locked out arms bring them up to cover your ears your hips and shoulders should not look twisted or uneven but instead be square think like you could draw a box using your hips and shoulders as the corners after lunge the next step in a cartwheel is to lever forward so to build good fundamentals practice this lever on its own notice how in my lunge my fingertips all the way down to my back foot makes a straight line at the same pace that your upper body is leaning forward your back leg should be tilting up like what happens in a seesaw slowly come back up to finish in a lunge we went over lunge then lever so the next step is how to place your hands for simplicity think of this as the front face the side in your lunge so that your front leg is closest to the back wall if your right foot is forward your right hand will be the first to be placed down lean over and reach your hands towards the ground turn your fingertips to point to the back wall and then place it on the ground in line with your foot do the same with the second hand placed shoulder width apart finally jump your legs around to land facing the opposite direction you started I like to call this a baby cartwheel practicing this a couple times will give you an understanding of the basic movement of this skill now let's turn this into a real cartwheel by learning how to kick our legs over it's crucial for a good cartwheel to hit this upside down starfish shape this part is technically a handstand so go check out that tutorial if you haven't yet the way to hit this straight handstand in your cartwheel is to think like you are cartwheeling between two walls so naturally find a large blank wall imagine for this exercise the wall is now the front turn to the side and stand only a couple inches away from the wall then lunge lean forward and start to lever actively reaching forward place your hands on the ground with finger tips pointing to the back which will naturally turn your body to face the wall it's important to note that power comes from kicking this first leg up and pushing off your base leg to finish swing your front leg down to your hand push off your hands and land in the lunge now try this speed this up and walk your toes along the wall in the starfish shape repeat trying to touch the wall less and less each time until you don't need to touch it all which should result in a cartwheel although less effective in my opinion if you're too nervous to try that method or you just want more practice you can also do this same process with your back against the wall just make sure your butt doesn't touch the wall only your feet and if you miss the wall like that you know your feet are too far in front of you when you can cartwheel straight against the wall from both directions with your back facing and also your stomach you should have a straight up and down cartwheel I hope this video was useful in helping you learn a cartwheel and stay tuned for more vidoes to come please like share and subscribe and thanks for watching

output.script: in the midst of tensions between Iran and Israel several independent and reputable Global News agencies along with some semi-reliable media Outlets reported that Iran has received the first batch of its purchased suco S35 fighter jets consisting of two Su 35s or S35 SE aircraft although these media Outlets did not provide specific details about the contract between Iran and Russia they noted that Iran and Russia have signed a 20-year Cooper op ation agreement that includes military collaboration based on this agreement it is speculated that Iran may have purchased a production and assembly line for either the suco S35 or suco s30 from Russia these media sources did not comment on other details such as the method of delivery or the Weaponry intended for these fighter jets however it is speculated that the Su 35s may be delivered to Iran in a manner similar to the yak 130 training combat jets with the assembly process carried out by both Russian and Iranian technicians within Iran according to Mr Kyle MO is in Iran is expected to receive a total of around 58 to 60 S35 fighter jets afterward Iran may consider purchasing fifth generation suco su-57 Fighters or joining the suco su75 project Mosen also mentioned that the first batch of su 35s has already been delivered to Iran and all of the Jets ordered from Russia are expected to be handed over to the Iranian Air Force in the near future these details indicate that Iran and Russia remain committed to the S35 deal and that the delivery pace of these Jets to Iran has accelerated this is seen as positive news for the Iranian Air Force especially given the current sensitive and critical circumstances Kyle moazen is one of Iran's most experienced International journalists a graduate of moscow's lomonosov Journal ISM University he has worked with news agencies such as irna turkey's trt Russia 1 and Sputnik recently he revealed significant information about the Iran Russia contract offering new details to the public although some of these claims such as the delivery of the first batch of S35 to Iran had already been reported by other Global media Outlets a lingering question has been whether Iran is prepared to accommodate the new Russian fighter jets for years Iran has been using aging Western and Eastern fighter jets with most of the Air Force's budget spent on overhauling and refurbishing these outdated aircraft this is a time-consuming and costly Endeavor making it challenging to establish the necessary infrastructure for operating new fourth generation Fighters domestically however with increased Financial Resources allocated to support the new Jets concerns about the lack of infrastructure Readiness for the Su 35s have diminished in recent years it appears that Iran has made progress in developing its airports and building the necessary infrastructure for new aircraft for example satellite images showing a S35 mockup at the Eagle 44 base and the construction of larger shelters at Shahed noj Airbase in hamedan suggest that the infrastructure is nearly ready for the arrival of the new Fighters according to the plans for finalizing the fighter jet purchase the process of construction and delivery will not begin until the Destin na country Iran is ready to receive the new Jets everything must proceed according to the plan schedule agreed upon by both sides the acquisition of 58 to 60 S35 Jets by Iran aims to create an integrated air defense network composed of Iranian groundbased systems such as the 15 cord and bavar 373 alongside the suco Su 35s and F14 Tomcats maintaining the the operational status of the f-14s is increasingly difficult but the addition of S35 could significantly enhance Iran's defense capabilities particularly in protecting its oil and nuclear facilities this measure significantly covers the existing air defense Gap in Iran although acquiring an awax Airborne warning and control system aircraft is also necessary to complete the defense ring given the current Financial conditions purchasing awax seems somewhat unlikely Additionally the S35 fighter jet can perform various roles in protecting the airspace including engaging awx and refueling tankers from long distances confronting enemy Fighters or completing the air defense ring to cover blind spots of course this is primarily the role of awax aircraft but due to the exorbitant cost of acquiring awax and Iran's Financial constraints the country could use the S35 in a mini awax role as as a temporary substitute naturally effectively countering fifth generation Fighters with a fourth generation jet is not feasible however not all of Iran's aerial threats come from fifth generation aircraft the backbone of the air forces of Iran's adversaries consists of fourth generation Fighters most of the current aerial threats Iran faces are posed by fourth generation aircraft such as the F15 Strike Eagle F-16 Viper typhoon and others although Iran has not officially announced when it finalized the S35 purchase agreement speculation that began in mid 2020 suggests that the negotiations might have taken place shortly before the lifting of arms embargos with the contract being finalized one or two years later the delivery timeline for the Jets to Iran is reportedly set for late 2024 or early 2025 in comparison to Egypt and China which were the main customers of this fighter jet Iran's contract process C is progressing relatively normally despite its political and Military tensions with Israel and the United States as well as the war in Ukraine for instance Egypt finalized its contract in late 2018 and Russia fulfilled the order 3 to four years later around 2021 or 2022 however the Egyptians refrained from accepting the Jets due to fears of us sanctions similarly when China officially finalized its S35 purchase from Russ R in 2015 it took 3 to 4 years for the contract to be completed notably the first batch of su 35s was delivered to China just one year after the contract was signed it is difficult to say whether the delivery of the Su 35s to Iran has been delayed due to the war in Ukraine as the exact date of the contract's finalization is unclear if Iran intends to fully rebuild its Air Force it will need between 140 and 204th and fifth generation Fighters along with a large number of awax transport and training aircraft this modernization effort could take place over a long period although the arrival of the suco Su 35s will significantly boost Iran's air power weaknesses will remain and some of the Aging Fighters will still be in service requiring replacement with newer Jets so far Iran has only officially acknowledged the purchase of a few Yak 130 training aircraft and around 64th generation S35 Fighters there is also a possibility that Iran May acquire some suco su30sm specialized training purposes which could also serve a limited offensive role however the acquisition of su30sm with certainty if you found this video informative don't forget to hit that like button share it with others interested in military Affairs And subscribe for more exclusive military content thanks for watching and we'll see you in the next one

output.script: well it's now being reported China has told its airlines to stop ordering US-made Boeing jets Comes as this trade war between the two superpowers keeps on rolling Elizabeth Economy is the senior adviser or was on China in the US State Department under Joe Biden's presidency Hello to you Elizabeth Hello It's good to be with you Thank you for coming and talking to us Elizabeth What what are your thoughts right now on the way that the the Trump administration is handling this policy with China including the changes of mind the changes of course by the president Yeah I mean I think um the president's administration is divided on how to approach China and I think that's reflected in uh the array of of uh the ratcheting up that we've seen um and the confusion around uh you know taking things off the tariff list saying oh I'm going to put them back on in another two days saying that the tariffs were initially about the fentanyl trade Uh I think he's been all over the map Um and I think that the the real issue here is what is the objective uh in terms of our trade with China I think the president came in said he wanted to do a big deal with China That was you know sort of what was anticipated Uh he began with tariffs I think in large part uh to gain some what he thought would be leverage But China didn't play ball the way that he thought that China would and you know they reciprocated with their own tariffs Um and now we're back in this you know tit fortat tariff war I think the challenge is that there are some in the administration that really do want to see a deal with China Uh and I think it's reasonable uh that we uh you know talk to China about the sort of unfair uh trading practices that they have the uneven playing field that they create for multinationals Um but at the same time I think there are other people in the administration that would be happy if the US and Chinese economies decouple And I think there's a third group that's interested really just in isolating China And I think you see the difference in the way the US has dealt with China as opposed to uh all the other countries that put the tariffs on So Elizabeth what is your best guess your best calculation of what is in the president's mind Do you think he maybe just misread the willingness of China to trade blows on tariff without backing down I think he absolutely misread the situation I think there was an assessment in the White House an incorrect assessment in the White House that the Chinese economy was struggling which is true but that this would be enough to bring Xiinping uh to his knees That and the fact that seemingly the Chinese economy is much more dependent on the US economy than vice versa given the in terms of the you know the level of exports um uh you know China exports much more to the US and the US exports to China What the administration didn't really consider was that we have a greater uh sole dependence on China for what it exports to us than China does for US exports Meaning that China can find many other sources of supply for its US for the uh what it imports from the US We have a hard time for about a third of the products that we import from China finding additional suppliers So it was a big uh mistake It was a big gamble and now we're paying the price I wonder if the the clearest sign of a miscalculation is the fact that uh that China is now halting the supply of those rare earth minerals which are so vital to high techch products including in defense A absolutely and I think you know we should have anticipated this you know beginning in the Biden administration China really developed a much more robust retaliatory toolkit uh you know for the kinds of export controls and tariffs that the US was placing on China We saw that they had they they already started um you know putting uh controls licensing controls on rare earths They went after individual US uh companies They put US companies on an entity list So it wasn't just responding with tariffs They have a whole array of tools at their disposal And I think this is a very significant blow And how do you how do you gauge the the capacity of China to ride out this storm and absorb the hits from falling demand from America I mean it's it's painful for sure and and certainly companies that um you know operate with low margins and apparel and toys and consumer electronics um all of them will be feeling the pain There is no market like the US market for these kinds of goods Um however uh we've also seen that that Xiinping has managed to transform what had been I think unhappiness with the way that the Chinese people were looking at their own government you know the owns their own problematic economy Now all of that negative uh you know attitude is directed at the United States I think Xiinping we provided Xinping essentially with a scapegoat for what really were the economic ills that his policies uh had engendered in the Chinese economy So I think at this point you have a much more nationalistic response you have a Chinese you know populace that is ready to do battle with uh the United States to demonstrate their resilience and I think to ride through what is going to be a painful uh transition if these tariffs stick They're estimating you know a 1 to 2% hit to China's GDP So it is consequential All right Elizabeth economy from advisor to President Biden Thank you So I'll go ahead First part the tariffs are necessary because we've been treated very unfairly by many many countries including our friends friend and foe but we've been treated very unfairly uh in trade uh at levels that nobody's really ever seen before And especially under the Biden administration they really took advantage of the United States Uh I put massive tariffs on China during my four years We had the best economy in the history of our country one probably the best economy maybe the best economy in the history of the world and I had I used tariffs to even things up and in particular with China we took in hundreds of billions of dollars and we had no inflation and it's a myth it's a myth that's put out there by foreign countries that really don't like paying tariffs and especially to even up so we've been treated badly by a lot we're using tariffs and I find and uh You just have to look at the numbers But I find that it's not about inflation It's about fairness And the inflation uh for us has not existed And I don't think it's going to exist We're going to bring our car industry back We're going to bring our chips back We're going to bring uh so many things back to our country including pharmaceuticals and drugs Uh and the thing that's going to get us there is tariffs And I say often it's my favorite word in the dictionary but I always preface that by saying now because I got into a lot of trouble with the fake news where they say uh that's not good So I say God love family wife they're all my favorite words but tariff is about number four or five on the list Uh but I will tell you uh it's going to make our country rich and it's going to stop us from being a laughingstock all over the world because we have been taken advantage of like no country has ever been taken advantage of Thank you very much And uh the one I told you

Conspiracy theories captivate millions, but why do people believe in them? In this video, we explore the psychology behind conspiracy thinkingâ€”from cognitive biases and pattern recognition to social influences and distrust of authority.

output.script: do you believe we never landed on the moon or maybe you've heard that the Titanic was sunk on purpose or that the government is hiding evidence of alien encounters in Roswell these are just a few of the many conspiracy theories that have captivated millions of people around the world but why do people believe in them even in the face of overwhelming evidence to the contrary let's dive into the psychology behind conspiracy theories and explore the mechanisms that make these beliefs so compelling one of the main reasons people believe in conspiracy theories is due to cognitive biases the way our brains naturally process information often leading us astray confirmation bias it is when people focus on information that supports their existing beliefs and ignore evidence to the contrary if someone is already suspicious of the government they might only seek out information that confirms their distrust reinforcing the conspiracy theory pattern recognition humans are hardwired to seek patterns even where none exist our brains are constantly scanning the environment for connections this is why conspiracy theories often appear convincing they present seemingly unrelated events as part of a hidden sinister plan elucory correlation this happens when people perceive a relationship between two unrelated events for example after a global disaster people may claim that the event was orchestrated or that it serves a hidden agenda even if there's no logical connection conspiracy theories also offer something that's incredibly appealing certainty life can feel chaotic and unpredictable and conspiracy theories provide a simple organized narrative to make sense of complex situations control in an unpredictable world when people face uncertainty they often seek explanations that give them control conspiracies offer a sense of order even if that order is based on a fictional narrative for example during times of crisis like pandemics or economic downturns conspiracies provide a way to blame someone for what's happening offering comfort that events are not just random and uncontrollable reducing anxiety believing in conspiracies can reduce anxiety by replacing chaos with a clear predictable enemy this can be empowering for someone who feels helpless or powerless in their own [Music] life people don't form conspiracy beliefs in isolation our social environment plays a huge role in shaping these beliefs group identity humans have a strong need to belong people who believe in conspiracies often find themselves in communities that reinforce those beliefs these communities provide a sense of social identity where believers see themselves as part of an exclusive group that knows the truth setting them apart from the rest of society echochambers on social media and other platforms conspiracy theories can spread rapidly because of echo chambers spaces where people only hear information that aligns with their beliefs these environments reinforce ideas and make them harder to challenge further solidifying the belief in the conspiracy conspiracy theories often thrive in environments where trust in authority is low when people feel alienated or distrustful of institutions like the government media or science they are more likely to entertain alternative explanations paranoia and distrust some people feel that the official story is being manipulated or hidden by powerful figures this leads to a general distrust of institutions and fuels the belief that those in power are hiding the truth from the public historical precedents in some cases past events like government cover-ups or corporate scandals can further validate these feelings for example events like the Watergate scandal or the release of documents showing misinformation about tobacco and cancer can make people more inclined to believe that current stories are similarly false or misleading one of the most powerful aspects of conspiracy theories is their ability to offer simplified explanations for complex events black and white thinking conspiracies reduce complex situations to a clear-cut us versus them narrative where everything is either good or evil this simplicity is comforting as it eliminates ambiguity and uncertainty giving people a clear view of the world cognitive closure some individuals crave cognitive closure the desire to make a decision or arrive at an answer even if that answer is incomplete or false conspiracy theories satisfy this need by providing a simple definitive explanation for confusing or chaotic events why conspiracy theories are so hard to let go of the reinforcement of belief once a person believes in a conspiracy theory it becomes incredibly difficult to change their mind even when presented with contrary evidence this is due to the self-reinforcing nature of these beliefs cognitive dissonance when faced with evidence that contradicts a conspiracy theory the brain experiences cognitive dissonance the uncomfortable feeling of holding two conflicting beliefs to resolve this discomfort people often double down on their beliefs dismissing contrary evidence as part of the conspiracy another phenomenon at play is the backfire effect where attempting to disprove a conspiracy theory actually strengthens belief in it the more you try to refute the theory the more the believer feels that they're being targeted by the establishment reinforcing their distrust so what can we do about conspiracy theories understanding the psychology behind them is a start promote critical thinking it's important to encourage critical thinking teaching people to question their beliefs examine evidence from multiple sources and seek out reliable information build trust in institutions addressing the root cause of distrust in authority and fostering trust in public institutions can help combat the rise of conspiratorial thinking engage with empathy finally when interacting with someone who believes in a conspiracy theory it's crucial to approach the conversation with empathy arguing or mocking won't change minds but having an open respectful dialogue can help people reassess their beliefs conspiracy theories are a powerful testament to the way our brains seek patterns certainty and control by understanding the psychological drivers behind them we can better navigate the complex world of information and help prevent the spread of misinformation what do you think have you ever encountered a conspiracy theory that seemed convincing let me know in the comments below

output.script:
I dropped out of college, was
in debt, working 60 hours a week, hated my job,
and most importantly, I felt stuck. This is the
story of how I learned how to code
within four months, and I got a job. I did it with no computer science
degree or a coding BootCamp I am going to explain
exactly what I learned, how I got
a job, and how much that job paid. Let's go. Before
I got into tech, I was working
a lot of dead end sales jobs, because I dropped
out of community college and
I didn't really have any other skills. I didn't like the
idea of always having to hop from
job to job If I didn't like something. I wanted something with a little
bit more career mobility long term. I didn't
even really know what coding was. I just
knew that the tech industry was,
let's say, a great environment for $180 grand now $200 ish $250,000 $400,000 annually growth... Yeah. By the way, I'm not knocking sales. I think sales
is a really important skill to learn. I just needed a change, and it
really just wasn't for me long term. And I wanted to gain the ability
to build something of my own. The idea of building
something from zero to one
seemed like a superpower to me. Day one, I just went on
Google and I typed in how to code. That's when I found a site called
FreeCodeCamp, and I started
to learn about web development. I quickly learned about HTML, CSS, and I learned
about my first real programming
language called JavaScript. There's
a bunch of different programming
languages that you could learn, but I personally
chose JavaScript because
I wanted to build web apps. Even
major companies like Uber and
Airbnb use it, and there's a massive
demand for it in the job market. By using FreeCodeCamp, I started
to learn the basics of coding. I learned things like variables,
loops, objects, and functions. But even after
doing the tutorials, I didn't really
feel like I could apply to anything. And I still didn't
even know how to do something
as basic as building a website. And I realized that I learned how to
code, not exactly how to program. I was writing
code to solve logic problems,
but I didn't know how to program, which is using
the code to build something useful. At this point, though, already
I was starting to love the journey. I really liked problem solving,
and I could see myself doing
something like this long term. So
I did what any sane person would
do and I quit my job and I moved
to Korea to minimize my expenses. And I decided to learn full time. Learning full time
was a lot harder than I thought. I've
actually never studied anything
this complicated or tough before, and I was quickly starting
to realize that I didn't really
know how to study at this pace. I would sit in front of my computer
and hours and hours would go by. That was when I went
online, I typed in how to learn. And
I found a course called "Learning
how to Learn" by Barbara Oakley. This course was life changing. My two main
takeaways were one, it taught me
how to learn in space segments,
A technique called Pomodoros. And the course
taught me that I needed to create
a dedicated space for learning. So I joined a Coworking
space, so I could focus better. Now,
armed with new knowledge, I got
back to studying. And it worked. Here's
what a normal day looked like. 08:00 a.m wake up. 8:30, Head to the train station. 09:00
a.m. Arrive at the coworking space. 9:15, Coffee Journaling
reviewing the curriculum. 9:30 to 12:30,
I would have my first study session, where I did 30
minutes increments of Pomodoros. From 12:30
to 1:30, I would eat lunch and take a
small break, then back to studying. From
02:00 p.m to 6:30, it was more 30
minutes increments of Pomodoros
until I was ready to head out. From 6:30 to 7:30,
I would gym three times a week, And then 8:30
to 9:00, I would eat dinner with
my grandma, then help her clean. This was my schedule
for six days a week, no exceptions. The next part of FreeCodeCamp
was a lot more challenging. Front end projects. They essentially give you a list
of projects that you have to build
using HTML, CSS and JavaScript. To me, this felt like
a massive jump because I never
actually built anything before. I felt stuck at this stage
until I found a YouTube channel
of this guy named Stephen who would stream himself
building these projects line by line. By copying him
and recreating what he was doing, I was able to
use that experience and build the
next couple of projects on my own. I also found a great resource
called watchandcode.com,
where you watch and code. By following along once again
and modeling others, the concepts
really started to take hold, and I was really starting
to understand what I was doing,
not just solving a math problem. In exactly one month, I ended
up earning my FreeCodeCamp
Front End Developer certificate. I was
learning a lot, but I never actually
built anything full stack before. Something with a
front end or an interface, the thing
that you see within the browser. A database where all
the information lives, essentially, and a server
which handles and manipulates
all the data in the back end by taking
in requests from the front end. So I still felt like an
imposter and not a real developer. You're not an intellectual.
You're a fake and a fraud. So to
become a programmer, I decided
to build my first full stack project. Remember
Stephen with a YouTube channel? I reached out to him
to get his assistance to help me
build my first full stack web app, we decided
to meet three times a week. Here's what we did. We picked one
major overarching project which
will teach me the basics of CRUD, which
is Create, read, update and delete. These are the foundations
for any web application. I decided to clone Pinterest. I honestly don't think
I would have gotten a job without
this next part, so pay attention. I asked Stephen
to treat me like a real junior
developer working at a company. We implemented a project
management tool called Jira. We used
Jira to compartmentalize the entire
project and write the requirements
of exactly what I'd be building. This taught
me how to estimate my work
and plan how to build an entire
web app from zero to launch. We also set
the project up on GitHub, which
is a version control application. This taught me how to develop
different branches for when
I was working on certain features, and I could learn how to control
different versions of the code. Most tech companies use some
version of the two applications because being a developer isn't
just about knowing how to code. It's about knowing
how to work collaboratively
with other people as well. Stephen grilled me on
our pair of programming sessions. He was
very strict about me keeping the
deadlines and the estimates that
I originally wrote out for myself. He would constantly question
why I was doing what I was doing. And
he even taught me the concept
of DRY, just Don't Repeat Yourself, or essentially
just making reusable code. I had to learn how
to build by Googling for answers
and using sites like Stack Overflow. And he
would leave me a lot of comments
on things that I needed to change. So I learned
how to debug my code on my own. This made
me feel like I was a real developer. at this time, I supplemented
my learning journey with
Udemy courses on React and Node because these
were the two frameworks that
I chose to build my Pinterest clone. As a result of building
my first full stack project, I ended
up learning how to do things like how to design a database, build
APIs, set up Auth, and eventually
push the app to a cloud server. These
are all things I would have never
learned by just doing tutorials. And
in around two months, I finished
my first full-stack web app. I remember when I finished the
app, I felt like a real programmer. That's when reality
set in and I realized I'm still broke. I haven't made a single
penny in over a couple of months,
and I still needed to find a job. It was time
to see if everything that I learned
was actually worth anything. First,
I defined the job that I wanted. I wanted to be remote. And most
importantly, I wanted to work for
a small to medium sized company, because I hate working
in a corporate environment. I found
all the jobs that fit my parameters
on sites like weworkremotly.com
and remoteok.io And instead
of just applying to these jobs, I found
the contact information of the
hiring managers and developers
who worked at the company, and I messaged
them to introduce myself. I explained
exactly what I had learned up until
this point,what I was looking for. I even included
the link to my GitHub so they could
see the projects that I had built. Most importantly,
I included an offer that
I know that they couldn't refuse. I offered to work for free. And I understand
guys, not everyone can afford to do
this, but I had originally estimated that this was going to take
me around four months anyways. And I had
another month of time that I could
essentially dedicate to learning. I knew all I had to do
was get my foot into a company,I
could essentially learn there and then prove
my worth over time to leverage
that into a real job long term. Overall, I found around
22 jobs I thought fit the parameters
of what I was looking for. I got
around six responses. From those
responses, I got four interviews. And out
of the four interviews, I ended up
getting three legitimate job offers. Even
though I had offered to work for
free, after the technical interviews, the employers thought that I had
enough skills at that point where I
was worth hiring for a full time job. I ended up choosing the company
with the best opportunity to learn, and that
also happened to have the best
compensation package as well. My first salary was $50,000 a year, and
then after my probationary period,
I was making $65,000 a year. My benefits
kicked in like health and dental. But the
biggest perk for me was that I got
to work remotely the entire time as
long as I worked the US time zone. I'm
not saying that you'll be an expert
developer if you follow this plan. I'm just sharing what I did to
learn just enough to land me a job, as
most of the progress that I've had
as a developer all came on the job. No luck here, just focused effort. Now, I've been
working in tech for over a decade, and let me
be the first to tell you that nobody
cares about your credentials. Learning
how to code was mainly two things learning how to solve problems,
and two, persisting until you find
the answer that you're looking for. If you're interested in seeing
us learn more cool stuff, make
sure to subscribe to the channel. And also, if you want
to see me apply these principles
to something other than coding, like something
artistic, click on this video. Where we're going to put it? Here?
