output.tags: Economics, central banking, finance
output.script:
Donald Trump
is back at the helm of the world's largest and most important economy, an economy
that is the main export market for the world's biggest economies, and,
crucially, an economy that produces the world's
reserve currency, the mighty U.S. dollar. So far, the dollar has jumped,
while currencies of major exporters like the Mexican peso and Japanese
yen have slumped. On top of that,
Trump has literally said that. under my leadership,
we are going to take other countries jobs. Did you ever hear that expression before? So does this mean that Trump's plans will enrich the US
and make the rest of us poorer? That is the question we'll be going over
for each of these two key economic policies,
starting with the one Donald Trump has been obsessing over since the 1980s. Trade policy where, while Trump
used to obsess over Japan, the United States has now been overtaken by China
as the world's most important producer. But crucially, as you can see here,
when it comes to being the most important source of demand, the US is still
the world's most important importer. Indeed, as you can see here in this graph
from the IMF, almost all of the surpluses
from systemic export to countries like China, Japan, Gulf states and Germany are absorbed by demand
from the United States, which is represented by the dark orange
bars. Therefore, continued demand from
the United States is crucial to the global economy and especially for systemic
exporters like China, Japan, and Germany. Ever since Trump first came to power
in 2016, the US has been trying to desperately decrease
its imports and increase its exports. Trump did this by imposing tariffs
on the world and especially China. On the other hand, Biden
preferred to dole out subsidies to U.S. based manufacturers while keeping in place
and even increasing some Trump tariffs against China. So what can the world
expect from Trump now? First of all, Trump
is likely to cut Biden's signature subsidies,
especially to green energy producers. The world's
exporters will be happy about that, but they will hate the fact
that tariffs are now back on the menu. Tariffs against China. But crucially, also against any country
that displeases Mr. Trump. And which country displeases
Trump the most? Well, it's mostly countries
that run a big trade deficit with the US, but notably countries can get in Trump's good graces
if they buy a lot of military equipment from the US, or if they do a lot of NATO
spending, we're leaving the US elsewhere. This is why trade surplus countries
like Saudi Arabia and Israel managed to stay in Trump's good graces, while
Mexico, Germany and Japan and of course, China were consistently under threat
of increased tariffs last time around. Surprisingly, though,
even these exporters could still end up exporting more to the United States
under Trump, not less. You see, while tariffs
will likely hurt exports to the US, last time around, Trump
turned out to be a big spender, slashing taxes for most Americans
and giving them stimulus checks. This made Americans richer, allowing them
to spend a lot of that on more imports. Therefore, despite his rhetoric,
the trade deficit doubled under Trump the last time. So will Trump again
be a paper tiger threatening with tariffs while implementing tax cuts
that increase US demand for global goods? I think that now, for a large part
depends on Trump's billionaire friend Elon Musk, Who Trump promised will had the newly formed Department
of Government Efficiency. This agency will be charged with sweeping
spending cuts, spending cuts that could be so drastic that
they will plunge the US into recession. At least
that is what Musk has hinted at on X. If the US ends up in a recession,
its citizens will of course have far fewer dollars
to spend on imports. In that case, Trump 2.0 could actually be
a disaster for the global economy. So, will Trump again be a big spender. Or will Trump and his new buddy
Elon crash global markets? So far, our financial markets are betting
that Elon's spending cuts plans will be more like his failed
Vegas tunnel than his SpaceX X rockets. As the mighty US dollar shot up right after it became clear
that Trump won the election. This likely happened
because currency traders were betting that Trump will spend more
because the inflation, and this then, will cause the Federal Reserve to raise
interest rates to counter that inflation. Then higher interest rates
will attract more foreign capital to U.S. markets, causing the dollar to rise. This is the second key effect Trump's
spending will have on the global economy, which relies heavily
on borrowing and lending in US dollars. So while increased spending on the one
hand may help the global economy, this will partially be offset by the fact
that the fed will have to raise rates, which will make global dollar
borrowing and spending more costly. This will especially hurt
global dollar borrowers like Egypt, Turkey and Argentina,
even though it may help global lenders like China, Japan, Germany. On the other hand, if the island scenario
happens and global trade crashes, we can expect the Federal Reserve to partially offset
this by lowering interest rates. Instead. So in. Conclusion Trump having won means that the global economy faces
two fairly extreme scenarios. The first scenario is the Trump 1.0 boom
scenario, with higher US imports and higher interest rates benefiting exporters
despite the threat of tariffs. The second scenario is
the Elon Musk austerity scenario, which will lead to lower trade and lower
interest rates ruining exporters while potentially providing some relief
for global borrowers. Right now, financial markets
believe the Trump 1.0 boom scenario with higher US spending, inflation
and interest rates is the most likely. I personally would not bet money on it
though, as Milei in Argentina has shown that the radical right wing spending cuts
do sometimes actually materialize, leading to a recession One thing is certain, though, and that is
that this type of radical uncertainty is bad news for the long term
attractiveness of the US dollar as a global reserve currency,
and for global trade in general. That being said, as this graph has shown, global
trade has been unbalanced for decades now. Key Trump economic advisor Scott Bessant
recently said that the US under Trump does actually not want to abandon the global economic order, but rather
reform it to make it less imbalanced. Indeed, many well-respected economists
have argued that the current dollar based economic order is ultimately unsustainable
and leads to increased inequality within both major exporters
and major importers. At least that was a major part of Mr. Besson's argument that he published in The
Economist, the sponsor of today's video. If you want to get into more depth about what the Trump
administration will do on a global scale, I highly recommend you check out the full
article in The Economist. Then I suggest you follow up with this
article published by a Trump aide, Nadia Shetler,
about how Europe can best work with Trump. Finally, I'd recommend this article about the tail risk of the new Trump
administration. Such extensive coverage of arguments
from both sides is exactly why I'm excited to share that many macro viewers can now
get 20% off an annual subscription to The Economist,
which gives you full access to their daily, in-depth global
reporting for an entire year. What I love about The Economist
is that they stand for independent journalism,
for independent thinkers. This is why they've been part of my media
diet long before I started this channel. Whether you prefer the print edition
or their Digital weekly edition, you'll always stay ahead of the news
no matter where you are. So don't miss out. Click the link in the description
or top comment or head over to economist.com/money Macro to claim
your exclusive 20% discount today.

output.script: [Music] following your requests today I bring you the third part of the K-pop Conspiracy Theory series many of you left suggestions in the comment section so I decided to make a video featuring some of the ones you suggested without further Ado let's dive into some more conspiracy theories aware that these are all just theories and we should not take anything as a fact [Music] whenever the topic of iconic visuals is brought up Yuna is one name that will always come up the center of Girls Generation left her Mark in K-pop being possibly the most popular female Idol of her generation in South Korea part of that comes from her quintessential Korean beauty Yuna captivated the country being considered by many the personification of the Korean beauty standard for fitting 100% of the criteria but there's some people who believe that the Incarnation of the KBS could have foreign Roots it all started many years ago thanks to a blind item for the ones unfamiliar a blind item is a news story that reveals details about a situation but doesn't identify the celebrities involved the blind item in question said that a very famous girl group member who was believed to be fully South Korean was actually half Vietnamese but her company was doing everything they could to hide it the blind item claimed that the idol was of Vietnamese descent on her mother's side people who believed it linked the idal to Yuna for the following reasons Korean Vietnamese couples are quite common marriages between South Korean men and Vietnamese women began to rise in the 1990s from 1997 to 2020 around 120,000 such marriages took place the increase in these marriages was partly fueled by the growth of the commercial marriage brokerage industry the mystery surrounding her mother yuna's parents divorced when she was still a child and she was raised just by her father to this day we know nothing about her mother or her maternal side of the family so the theory suggests that her mom could be living in Vietnam or that SM Entertainment could be hiding her identity Yuna loves Vietnamese culture she has mentioned several times that her favorite type of food is Vietnamese her members always choose Vietnamese cuisine when it comes to her she has shown that she even knows how to cook it impressing fans with how professional she looked doing it she has also visited Vietnam frequently including twice in 2014 for Cal exchanges childhood pictures unlike a lot of Idols Yuna has no pre-debut picture of her wearing a traditional Korean outfit which is pretty normal but there's one picture of her as a baby where she is wearing an outfit that resembles traditional Vietnamese clothing way before Yuna SM had already debuted Idols who come from a mix of nationalities but a big part of the appeal surrounding Yuna was her being this pure Korean beauty so learning that she has Vietnamese descent could have led to a lot of discrimination towards her and shattered the Illusion for the audience potentially preventing her from achieving such a high level of popularity and affection the theory has sparked doubt even among fans who have been following Yuna for years especially because they know that sm's pretty good at hiding information that they don't want [Music] out if you were into Power pop music around 2007 you most probably heard the song Jenny from the North American band and The Click Five the song is about a girl named Jenny who sends mixed signals to her partner making him uncertain about the relationship's Direction when the song first came out people wanted to know who was Jenny one of the songwriters Ben Romans was asked about it during an interview and answered Jenny is just a name a name that scans well in songs it's more a representation of anyone being fickle if you're wondering what this song has to do with K-pop well 9 years after its release a fan Theory started gaining a lot of traction within the community after connecting the dots people came to the conclusion that the Jenny that The Click Five had been singing about for all these years could be none other than K-pop icon Park bomb and here are the reasons why bombb in the front man of the click 5 Kyle Patrick were both students of the Berkeley College of Music in Boston during the late 2000s in the music video Jenny is played by an Asian actress which was pretty rare for an American rock band at the time Park bomb's American name is Jenny park with the same spelling as the title of the song although Kyle Patrick was not a part of the writing of Jenny the number of coincidences has led many fans to believe that bomb could still have been an inspiration for the hit after being bombarded with questions following the buzz of the theory Kyle Patrick tweeted we may never know the [Music] truth whether it's their birthday or debut anniversary we often see Idols celebrating a special date accompanied by a cake in the last few years several of them went viral for dropping or somehow ruining their [Music] cakes over time fans began to get weirded out as it just continued to happen to the point where there were compilation videos showing the same thing happening to various Idols after the phenomenon started gaining attention fans began to bring up old videos of the same thing happening years ago due to how often this has occurred a theory emerged suggesting that this is not just a weird coincidence the theory claims that the cakes are actually made to trick the audience and try to hide the fact that Idols are put on Extreme diets even during celebratory occasions is a well-known fact that K-pop companies put their artists under very strict diets which already caused controversy several times over the years so a lot of people believe that companies don't allow their artists to eat cake in order to avoid weight gain and tell them to ruin the the cakes and pretend it was an accident leading fans to believe that the reason they aren't eating is because they spoiled it and not because they're not allowed to have [Music] it I know this video turned out a bit short that's because I'm working on bigger projects that will be out soon and because I'm trying to create a schedule for my channel but I hope you still enjoyed it if you did please don't forget to give the video a like do you believe any of these theories let me know in the comments thanks for watching

of completion that's enough to convince me that something is working here you can get a tech education and actually have a job to show for it you can do the whole thing online remotely on your own the code easy you'll get 30% off on all of their courses and can save up to $3,400 on your education so don't hesitate to click the link in the description or scan the QR code for a free career consultation but anyway let's go back to looking at the softop road map whatever you do do not obsess over mastering a programming language programming languages are pretty easy to learn and once you know one language it doesn't take a whole lot of effort to learn other ones some are strongly typed meaning you have to bench press at least 200 lb to use them other languages are weakly typed like JavaScript because weak people use it sometimes the syntax is different some languages have faster performance in certain use cases some languages are easier for beginners some languages are used by only one company and meant to be run on a specific type of machine some languages shouldn't exist some languages are low-level meaning they're harder for humans to understand but easier for machines to read and other languages are high level meaning they're easy for hum to understand but they give you a little bit less control over the actual machine but yeah just just Learn Python you'll notice that the road maps they give you are pretty long and pretty detailed but I'm going to be honest no actual developer needs to have deep knowledge about all of these topics and you shouldn't try to do everything on the road map that's like trying to learn how to make grilled cheese by reading a book on bread and a separate book on cheese at some point it's just faster to make the thing and see what happens experience is what you need need but the nice thing about this website is that it always gives you somewhere to start No Nonsense no fluff no filler no watching thousands of videos called if I wanted to be a software engineer in 2079 here's what I would know all you need to do is start on the road map learn some of the stuff in the Yellow Boxes maybe take a course or two and read a couple articles and watch a couple videos and then immediately move on to step two make stuff think to yourself how can I use what I just learned to make something that I actually want to make for example if you're a beginner in web development and you really like pressure washing driveways then guess what you can make a website where a user can input how big their driveway is the surface type and where they live and it'll estimate how much they would have to pay to get a pressure washed it sounds simple but I guarantee you it'll be way more complicated than you expect you'll have to look up pretty much everything and you will 100% be tempted to give up halfway through when your eyes are getting dry your posture is deteriorating into free form shapes and the backs of your thighs are sticking to your chair but ask anyone who's actually Gotten Good at coding and they'll tell you once you can get that first project done you have now ascended from what's known as tutorial hell into the far superior project Heaven which is where all the accomplished developers live and breathe just look at neil. fun this collection of little mini games was made by a college student practicing coding and if you look at the first couple of websites he made many years ago they're pretty basic something a beginner can make in a few days but when you look at the newer ones it's pretty easy to tell that coding skills got a little bit more advanced and you can do the exact same thing as long as you put in the time and don't give up even when business school starts to look real tempting one big reason you might feel disappointed in yourself when you first start learning to code is because everyone else seems to know way more than you and they talk about Concepts you don't even know exist as if they're common sense sometimes you'll hear your favorite coding YouTubers talking about API calls and weird systems and acronyms and Niche Technologies and protocols that just make no sense because none of those things show up in an 8 Hour python for beginners YouTube tutorial and although it may seem like some people were born knowing how to set up servers and backend databases and websockets and how to create Bots out of thin air it's really just a gradual learning process that takes a long time you probably won't learn the stuff in school you probably won't see it in textbooks and probably won't get recommended on your YouTube homepage but you will learn it through projects and Googling and reading people's code and copying and pasting other people's code until you've created a fully functional final product you won't become a programming experts logging through 11-hour YouTube tutorials back to back to back at the same time one big issue is that everyone tells you to just build projects you're passionate about but what if you're not passionate about anything what if you're just coding to pay the bills and your only hobby is watching YouTube luckily there's an easy solution hover over the top left menu of this website and click on projects based on whatever language you know or whatever skill you're trying to practice they have actual useful projects that you can test your skills with and the best part is that they give you General guidelines on what to make how to put your project on GitHub and where to find help but unlike most places they don't just give you the solution unlike a YouTube tutorial where you're just watching someone build a project and then copying down every single line of code one by one this forces you to actually learn and if you can't find a good project on this website don't overthink it just start just do Google Search and pick whatever sounds the most fun by now you may be thinking if tutorial hell is step one and Project based Heaven is step two then what's step three lead code limbo if you don't know lead code is a website where you can practice staring at a computer screen with a coding problem and not understanding anything for weeks in a row unless you're applying to a company where you're the firstborn child of the CEO you're going to have to accept that leak code is law when you're applying to a top tech company being good at solving leak Cod problems is like a secret handshake between you and your interviewer there's a secret handshake that exists in all companies they want you to be able to jump through a set of Hoops to show that you are good enough to be there and so we don't have like a really good way to gauge how good someone actually is at coding in 20 minutes 30 minutes 50 minutes so instead it's like hey you come in here I'm going to do that secret handshake you better have done 300 leak code problems you've done 300 leak code problems you walk in you know how to use a map sets uh you understand trees we just know that you can do all the things now is it the best way to test people probably not there's no best way to grind lead code you can find many road maps for lead code online and ideally you would space it out over at least a few months instead of trying to do 75 problems in a week but the important thing is you just have to do it it might be intimidating to see people on YouTube coding up solutions to lead code hards before you've even finished reading the problem but it's important to know that everyone once started but solving two some in oent squared output.title: The most powerful way to think about money | Paula Pant
output.description:
Financial expert Paula Pant explains how you can afford anything, but not everything.

Subscribe to Big Think on YouTube â–º https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCvQECJukTDE2i6aCoMnS-Vg?sub_confirmation=1
Up next, William Ackman: Everything you need to know about finance and investing in under an hour â–º https://youtu.be/WEDIj9JBTC8

It's oh-so-easy to look at shiny, quickly rewarding options for your money as a ticket to financial independence. A big hit on the stock market; a hockey sticking cryptocurrency; an app that can put you on the path to easy street. But truly building financial independence is a life-long process, says Paula Pant, the host of the Afford Anything podcast. 

Think of your finances like a tree. While the leaves and fruit are grabby and exciting, they aren't where the tree's strength lies: that's in the roots. So too do healthy finances begin from a core base: figuring out what you value most, what you truly want to afford. 

From there, you can make the long term plans to see that come to fruition. With a stable, value-driven approach and some discipline, a world of freedom can open before you. You may not be able to buy everything, but you can buy anything.

0:00 Afford anything (not everything)
1:03 First principles thinking
2:30 Financial independence
3:35 Simple steps to independence
4:31 The 20% rule
5:18 Survive a scary economy

Read the video transcript â–º https://bigthink.com/videos/how-to-afford-anything/

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 

About Paula Pant:
Paula Pant is the host of the Afford Anything podcast, an award-winning show with more than 24 million downloads. It was named by the New York Times as one of â€œ7 Podcasts Your Wallet Will Love.â€

She is also the founder of Afford Anything, a personal finance brand with more than 75,000 newsletter subscribers.

She is a Knight-Bagehot Business and Economics Journalism Fellow at Columbia University.

Pant is frequently featured in financial media including Money Magazine, the Washington Post, Oprah.com, CNBC, Fortune, Marie Claire, Marketplace Money, Menâ€™s Health, Real Simple, Outside Magazine, Cosmopolitan, the New York Times, and more. Sheâ€™s spoken at the â€œTalks at Googleâ€ series and guest lectured at Georgetown University. She lives in New York City.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 

Read more of our stories on personal finance: 
Gamification: can video games change our money habits?
â–º https://bigthink.com/neuropsych/gamification/
5 realistic ways to save money, according to experts
â–º https://bigthink.com/neuropsych/realistic-ways-to-save-money/
How to become a millionaire
â–º https://bigthink.com/personal-growth/millionaire/

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 

About Big Think | Smarter Fasterâ„¢
â–º Big Think 
The leading source of expert-driven, educational content. With thousands of videos, featuring experts ranging from Bill Clinton to Bill Nye, Big Think helps you get smarter, faster by exploring the big ideas and core skills that define knowledge in the 21st century. 
â–º Big Think+
Make your business smarter, faster: https://bigthink.com/plus/

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 

Want more Big Think?
â–º Daily editorial features: https://bigthink.com/popular/
â–º Get the best of Big Think right to your inbox: https://bigthink.com/st/newsletter

output.script:
- Every choice that you
make comes with a trade-off. (cheerful music) Money is an invitation
to critical thinking. You can afford anything,
but not everything. So if there's something that you value, whether it's travel, food, or a house, you can have that thing. You just can't have an
endless series of ands. You might not be able to have
that thing and something else and something else and something else. And that doesn't just apply to your money. That applies to your time, your focus, your energy, your attention
- any limited resource. And life is the ultimate limited resource. So when you practice being
better at managing your money, you practice being better
at managing your life. My name is Paula Pant. I am the host of the
"Afford Anything Podcast." I want to help you reach
financial independence by making smarter
decisions with your money. (contemplative music) The mistake that I see
a lot of people make when they start asking questions about how to manage their money is that oftentimes people
will ask a question about a product or a tactic. So for example, they might say, "Should I use this app, or should I invest in cryptocurrency?" First-principles thinking
is stripping away everything and really getting to
the root of something. So if you think about a tree, the tactics and the products
are like the leaves of a tree. That's the most visible surface so, of course, it's what
people might ask about first. But first, let's start with
the roots of that tree. The roots of that tree are your values. It's that question of what matters most. And then from those roots
stem that trunk of the tree, which is your philosophy of life, the type of life that you want to lead. And from that philosophy, then your objective or your goals: How does that philosophy of living translate into specific goals? That's really that tree trunk. From there, you go out into
the branches of the tree, and they represent the strategy. Now that you know your
philosophy of living, you know your goals, now you
can come up with strategies for how to obtain those goals. And then once you have
that strategy in place, then those leaves are the
tactics and the products. So if you're starting with the question about tactic or product,
you've got a leaf in your hand, but you don't have that
root system built yet. When personal finance is framed in the context of delayed gratification so that you can have more
money when you're 75 years old, it's really hard to
get excited about that. But when we reframe that
as financial independence and how taking better care of your money leads to this flourishing of freedom, of opportunity, of choice, that becomes much more enticing. FI is the point at which your
potential passive income - money that comes to you
when you're sleeping, typically through investments - is enough to cover your basic bills. And the reason that matters is because then endless
options open up for you. You have the freedom to
do whatever you want - whether that's to stay in
your current profession, make a midlife career change,
become a full-time parent, or travel the world. Whatever
choice you want to make, you're able to make that
without having to sweat about how you're gonna keep the lights on, how you're gonna keep the fridge stocked. The pursuit of FI is for everyone, but the first steps that you
are going to take will differ depending on where you
are in your journey. There are really only three steps to achieving financial independence: Grow the gap, invest the gap, repeat. Grow the gap means to grow the gap between what you earn and what you spend. And there are only two
ways to increase that gap: earn more or spend less or both. If you don't make very much, like me when I was in my
first job out of college making $21,000 a year, at that stage of life, your
goal is to increase your income. If you're already making big dollars but you have a spending problem, the low-hanging fruit is to
curb that spending problem and to address the root
psychological issues that are leading to that spending problem. Step two is to then invest that gap. My personal feeling is
that everyone should aim to save and invest at
least 20% of their income. And when I say save and invest, that includes making additional payments towards the debt above and
beyond the minimum required, retirement savings, investments
in an investment account. It includes building
up your emergency fund. Start with the goal of saving 20%, and if you're nowhere close to that, increase your savings rate by 1% and do that every month or two. It will take a few years, but you will over time
get to that 20% mark. And then step three is repeat. This is a lifetime practice. This is not a quick hit or something that's going
to happen overnight. Money management happens for life. (contemplative music) There has never been a point in history when the world has not been volatile. A hundred years ago, there
was also a pandemic going on, and there was a first World War. A decade later, the Great Depression. After that was World War II. After that, event after event after event that affected the entire globe. I came to FI because I was scared and anxious about the volatility
in my life and the world. My response to that was to become obsessed with saving as much as I could because it allowed me to not
be so scared of the future. It felt psychologically
comforting to have these savings. Change is the nature of the
world, the nature of time. And so, if you're looking
out at the big global factors that are happening in the world today and you're feeling fear, embrace it and use that
fear as motivation, as fuel to make wise decisions about how you spend your
money, your time, your effort. That's how you build a life
that's more intentional. And there's a lot of joy in that. (cheerful music) - [Narrator] Get smarter
faster with videos from the world's biggest thinkers. (cheerful music) To learn even more from the
world's biggest thinkers, get Big Think Plus for your business. (cheerful music)

output.script: on December 26th China's Aerospace sector flew a sixth generation fighter design for the first time this video will go over its most obvious design features and try to deduce their implications it will also explore just where in the design process China is with its six gen fighter and we will explain just what are we actually looking at when we see the strange looking flying Diamond of a plane [Music] a video that's to come sometime later will go more in depth provide historical context and comparison with the US NextGen program and reveal what does the plane's appearance mean for China and what could it mean for the US for some days now the imminent flight of a Chinese 6G airframe was rumored and well it actually seems to have happened the plane seems to have flown over the city of changdu after the aircraft took off from the factory complex of changdu aircraft Corporation that's the maker of China's j20 fifth gen fighter which was appropriately the chase plane for this occasion so what's the new plane like thankfully the j20 chase plane gives us context due to telephoto lenses used over great distances sizes of two planes can be confidently compared and while j20 has a wingspan of around 13 M this new plane is visibly bigger in fact it's wingspan might reach 20 M which would basically be unheard of for a jet fighter even more so when we look at the planes configuration those are highly swept back Wings basically as one would expect for a supersonic fighter jet length can be estimated from other images suggesting 20 to 22 M that's without the nose Peto tube which is required for testing but the final design years later will not have it the wing trailing Edge is swept forward leading to a diamond Wing shape somewhat reminiscent of YF 23 for example though not as extreme in general the theoretical perfect stealth shape for a plane is one of a so-called hopeless Diamond a perfect rmo shape as flat as possible and with as few protrusions as possible it is obvious the volume of the plane is frankly massive its belly intake start quite forward and the body of the plane is very wide it's plausible ch as Air Force requirement was ranged to threaten Guam such requirement would have driven the design to grow so large coupled with a huge Wing area that plane is simply oversized not necessarily in a bad way but it is sized to accept a huge amount of fuel and a hint of the line where the weapons Bay should be suggests its weapons Bay might be almost 6 M long which is coincidentally the length of China's latest long range pl17 missile of course with such a huge body cruise missiles larger than the US jasm might also easily fit what also seems visible are sensor apertures around the nose not just the nose radum but also a few different cheek side arays the plane has a visible cockpit cover so it's manned so far images aren't good enough to deduce if it's big enough to seat two people the rumors before the flight did suggest the plane has side bys side seating meaning two pilot similar to F-111 or s34 that doesn't mean we are looking at the strike aircraft as six generation Fighters are going to wage air Warfare in a different way but given the size of the plane and its weapons Bay it's also quite plausible the shown design is really a multi-roll plane to cover all sorts of Air Combat and ground strike missions but we digress one of the most striking features perhaps unique in the world is its engine Arrangement this plan seems to have three engines lined up in the rear with the side engines using belly slash side intakes and the middle engine seems to have a separate dorsal intake such an arrangement is unheard of for an actual fighter jet that managed to get off a drawing board side intakes seem to be of carette type similar to say F22 and not of the worthless supersonic Inlet type which F35 and j20 use whether that suggests higher top speeds intended is for now unknown certainly the high sweep of the Wings coupled with the even higher sweep of one continuous line of the nose blending into the wing Roots suggests a fairly High theoretical mock figure now why three engines it's too early to tell but off the bat it could suggest designer simply could not make powerful enough yet compact enough engines for such a plane and keep the design confined to the more usual two Engine Solution this thing is massive one can clearly see double wheel Bogies used for main landing gear given its size it seems likely its Max takeoff weight is designed for maybe even 50 tons in the olden era that would be a tactical bomber but planes have been getting bigger over the decades and NextGen planes from all countries are likely to be heavier than their predecessors even so this thing is plausibly so big that even two of China's most powerful engines the ws15 which May in its future variants approach 200 kons of thrust may not be enough to power it hence possibly the need for three engines it's also plausible that the middle engine is somewhat different and that engine usage is managed for various situations and needs it is not known if China is going with variable cycle engines like the us but if it's not China may have optimized one engine for supersonic speed While others would be regular designs compromised to operate both both at takeoffs and supersonic speeds also three engines might be needed to supply the plane with enough electricity modern planes are so full of power demanding features that the power generation is becoming more and more of a bottleneck imagine a laser self defense feature is also added in the future that too would require tons of electricity finally the whole design should be a pretty big jump up in terms of stealth in 2022 US general Mark Kelly said China was on track with the development of their sixth generation fighter and that China is eyeing to make its stealth exponentially better it's a contextless statement but the plane we are looking at is clearly what a lot of six gen proposals have been proposing a tailless shape of simplified geometry the fact it doesn't seem to have any regular vertical control surfaces is very likely going to make it harder to control than previous gen planes almost certainly impacting its maneuverability but six gen designs don't seem to be about maneuverability that will likely be the job of unmanned drones flying in front of these big manned Fighters it's possible that three engines are also in some way there to help stabilize the plane certainly the split flaps near the wing tips are there to help control the plane the B2 bomber uses a similar concept but in a cruising stage of the flight those would close shut and be flush with the wings it's too early to speculate much more about this plane but it's seems to be a big step up in China's capability so we will leave that speculation for another video coupled with comparisons to us 6 gen and what all this might mean for both China and us right now it's just a prototype actually if rumors are to be believed it's more like a demonstrator kind of like yf-23 was or yf-22 was or the X32 and x35 War and rumor has it that China hasn't yet decided on the final manufacturer so this may be in fact a proposal from changu aircraft Corporation with another six gen plane proposal demonstrator plane from shangyang aircraft Corporation to fly soon some early images May indicate that has already happened but that's another story depending on where us 6G program is at China might have leaped frog the US Air Force a little bit if this is indeed a pre-selection prototype and if us has so far FL only concept and six gen technology demo planes then China might have actually flown the world's first six gen fighter [Music]

This is SpaceXâ€™s pride and joyâ€”the Falcon 9, designed under the visionary leadership of  Elon Musk.
Sitting atop the rocket is Crew Dragon, carrying four astronauts on a critical mission to rescue and replace two crew members aboard the International Space Station.
The reason these two NASA astronauts are stranded traces back to Boeingâ€™s Star liner.
On its first-ever astronaut mission, launched on June 5, 2024, the vehicle encountered unexpected issues, leaving the crew awaiting a safe return. 

During the docking procedure, the Star liner encountered issues with its Reaction Control System thrusters.

The spacecraftâ€™s software initially flagged five s as non-operational, affecting its ability to maneuver in all six degrees of freedom.

Although four of the thrusters were eventually restored, the underlying cause of the malfunction remains unclear.

We're here to take a closer look at how SpaceX's Crew Dragon rescue process works.

In the event of a rescue, a replacement crew would travel , where the Falcon 9 rocket stands ready for liftoff.

Falcon 9 is a two-stage rocket designed for reliability and efficiency.
Unlike rockets that rely on a single engine, its first stage is powered by nine Merlin engines.

This design provides an added layer of safetyâ€”if one engine fails, the remaining engines can compensate, ensuring a smooth and controlled ascent.

The second stage, responsible for propelling Crew Dragon into orbit, is power++ed by a single Merlin engine.

At the very top of the rocket sits the capsule named Crew Dragonâ€”designed to safely transport astronauts to and from space.

output.title: The Basics of Investing (Stocks, Bonds, Mutual Funds, and Types of Interest)
output.description:
In order to generate significant wealth, one must invest their money. But how does investment work? What does one invest in? What are stocks, bonds, and mutual funds? If you are earning money on an investment, what type of interest in being earned? What's the difference between simple and compound interest? Let's find out!

output.tags: investing, simple interest, compound interest, stocks, bonds, mutual funds, hedge funds, wealth, make money, personal economics, dividends, capital gains, capital loss, brokerage firms, bond maturity, coupon rate, par value, financial intermediaries, pension fund
output.script:
Most people have heard that investing is the bestÂ 
way to accumulate wealth. Investment is the act ofÂ Â  redirecting resources from being consumed todayÂ 
so that they may create benefits in the future.Â Â  More precisely, investment is the use of assets toÂ 
earn income or profit. The wealthiest individualsÂ Â  in the world became wealthy through successfulÂ 
investment of their assets. Letâ€™s go over theÂ Â  basics regarding common ways that people invest.
Stocks and bonds are two of the most common formsÂ Â  of investment. A stock is a representationÂ 
of ownership in a public company. They canÂ Â  be risky to purchase as their prices can changeÂ 
dramatically and unpredictably, but often theÂ Â  bigger the risk, the bigger the potential reward.Â 
There are two ways for stockholders to make money:Â Â  dividends and capital gains. Dividends areÂ 
profits paid out four times a year to allÂ Â  shareholders. The size of the dividend dependsÂ 
on the profit of the company. Capital gains areÂ Â  when a stockholder simply sells their stock forÂ 
more than they originally paid for it. If theÂ Â  stockholder made a profit, itâ€™s a capital gain.Â 
If they lost money, itâ€™s a capital loss. A marketÂ Â  for buying and selling stock is called a stockÂ 
exchange. Brokerage firms are businesses thatÂ Â  help stockholders trade stocks and sometimesÂ 
even deal out stocks. These days, anyone canÂ Â  easily access the stock exchange on their phoneÂ 
through apps that offer brokerage services.Â  A bond is essentially an IOU issued by aÂ 
corporation or by some level of government.Â Â  When you buy a bond, you are loaning moneyÂ 
in return for a guaranteed payout at a laterÂ Â  date. Bonds are usually a more stable investmentÂ 
than stocks. There are three components of bonds:Â Â  their coupon rate, maturity date, andÂ 
par value amount. The coupon rate isÂ Â  the interest rate that a bond issuer willÂ 
pay to the bondholder. The time at whichÂ Â  payment to a bondholder is due is calledÂ 
the bondâ€™s maturity. A bondâ€™s par value,Â Â  assigned by whoever issues the bond, is theÂ 
amount to be paid to the bondholder at maturity.Â  In order for investment to take place, anÂ 
economy first must have a financial system,Â Â  which is the network of structures and mechanismsÂ 
that allows the transfer of money between saversÂ Â  and borrowers. As we learned in the previousÂ 
tutorial, when people save their money,Â Â  they often are actually lending funds to others.Â 
Savers and borrowers may be linked directlyÂ Â  through whatâ€™s known as financial intermediaries.Â 
Financial intermediaries are institutions thatÂ Â  help move funds from savers to borrowers.Â 
They include banks, which we learned aboutÂ Â  in the previous tutorial, but they also includeÂ 
mutual funds, hedge funds, and pension funds.Â  A mutual fund pools the savings of manyÂ 
individuals and invests this money in a varietyÂ Â  of stocks, bonds, and other financial assets. AÂ 
hedge fund is a private investment organizationÂ Â  that employs risky strategies that can oftenÂ 
make huge profits for investors. In general,Â Â  these investors already have tremendousÂ 
wealth and are knowledgeable about investing.Â  A pension fund is income that some retireesÂ 
receive after working a certain number ofÂ Â  years or reaching a certain age. In some cases,Â 
injuries may also qualify a working person forÂ Â  certain pension benefits. Employers set upÂ 
pension funds by collecting deposits, andÂ Â  pension fund managers then invest those depositsÂ 
in stocks, bonds, and other financial assets.Â  In general, the best way to invest your money isÂ 
to put it in a diverse range of securities. ThisÂ Â  reduces risk, especially when stock or bondÂ 
prices drop. Therefore, people often investÂ Â  some of their money in more risky ventures butÂ 
invest the rest in more stable funds. It is alsoÂ Â  better to invest money earlier in life. ThisÂ 
is because one of the greatest assets is time.Â Â  The longer your money is invested in securities,Â 
the more it will grow. Put another way, you makeÂ Â  more money on the money your money already makes.
When investing money, itâ€™s important to considerÂ Â  the two types of interest, simple and compound.Â 
Simple interest is based on the principal amountÂ Â  of a loan or deposit. Compound interest is basedÂ 
on the principal amount and the interest thatÂ Â  accumulates on it in every period. Thus, it canÂ 
be regarded as â€œinterest on interest.â€ SimpleÂ Â  interest is only calculated on the principalÂ 
amount of a loan or deposit. The formula looksÂ Â  like this: A = P(1 + rt) where A is the finalÂ 
amount, P is the initial principal balance,Â Â  r is the annual interest rate, and t isÂ 
time, usually in years. Compound interestÂ Â  is calculated based on both the principal andÂ 
interest accrued. The formula looks like this:Â Â  A = P(1 + r/n)nt where A is the final amount,Â 
P is the initial principal balance, r is theÂ Â  interest rate, n is the number of times interestÂ 
is applied per time period, usually in years,Â Â  and t is the number of periods elapsed.
Letâ€™s look at an example. Say you loanedÂ Â  $10,000 to a friend and they agreed toÂ 
pay it back in five years with an annualÂ Â  simple interest rate of 5%. After five years, theÂ 
amount of interest you would get would be $2,500,Â Â  as the total amount they would repay would beÂ 
$12,500, which is the original principal plusÂ Â  the interest. Now say you loaned $10,000 to aÂ 
friend and they agreed to pay it back in fiveÂ Â  years with an annual compound interest rate ofÂ 
5%. Because you really want to make some money,Â Â  you also make sure that interest is compoundedÂ 
monthly, or 12 times a year. After five years,Â Â  the amount of interest you would get would nowÂ 
be $2,833.59, and your friend would have repaidÂ Â  you a total of $12,833.59. This example serves toÂ 
illustrate that compound interest is far superiorÂ Â  to simple interest when investing your money.
Whenever consumers evaluate an investment,Â Â  they must balance the risks involved with theÂ 
rewards they expect to gain from the investment.Â Â  In general, the higher the potential returnÂ 
on an investment, the riskier that investmentÂ Â  is. In the next tutorial, we will look at one ofÂ 
the riskiest ways to borrow money, credit cards.

output.script: AI investing the future of Finance unveiled imagine this you wake up in the morning grab your coffee and check your portfolio only to realize that an AI powerered investing bot has already made profitable trades for you while you were asleep no emotions no stress just pure data-driven decisions sounds like a dream right well it's not it's happening right now the world of Finance is changing faster than ever before artificial intelligence is no longer some futuristic concept it's here it's real and it's disrupting everything we thought we knew about investing we're talking about algorithms that can analyze millions of data points in seconds predict market trends with uncanny accuracy and execute trades at lightning speed this isn't just about making a quick Buck though AI has the potential to democratize finance making sophisticated investing strategies accessible to everyone not just Wall Street Hot Shots so buckle up because in this video we're diving deep into the world of AI investing ai's impact on Personal Finance artificial intelligence isn't just a tool anymore it's completely transforming personal finance and investing hedge funds are already pouring billions into AI powered systems that can outperform the market we're talking about algorithms that can process information millions of times faster than any human identify patterns we would never even notice and make decisions based purely on data eliminating emotional biases that can lead to costly mistakes but it's not just the big players who are benefiting Robo advisers powered by AI are making professional level portfolio management available to everyone these platforms use algorithms to create personalized investment strategies based on your risk tolerance financial goals and even your time Horizon they can automatically rebalance your portfolio Harvest tax losses and even adjust your Investments based on market conditions all for a fraction of the cost of a traditional financial adviser and then there's the world of cryptocurrency where AI powered trading Bots are Making Waves these Bots can monitor multiple exchanges simultaneously identify Arbitrage opportunities and execute trades 24/7 generating profits while human Trad are still analyzing charts now you might be thinking this all sounds great but I'm not a tech whiz how can I possibly keep up and that's the beauty of it you don't have to be a coding genius to Leverage The Power of AI in your financial life there are tons of userfriendly AI tools and platforms available that require zero coding experience these tools can help you automate your savings optimize your spending and even invest like a pro all with just a few clicks but here's the thing ignoring the AI revolution in finance is like sticking with a flip in the age of smartphones you might get by but you're missing out on a world of opportunities AI driven investing tools you need to use today let's get practical and talk about some specific AI powered tools that you can start using today to supercharge your investment strategy first up AI driven Robo advisors these platforms use algorithms to create personalized investment portfolios popular options include betterment wealth front and acorns next AI powered stock analysis tools they sift through data to identify investment opportunities ities popular options include trading view Trend spider and Cavo AI can also help manage your portfolio tools can rebalance assets and optimize for taxes popular options include personal Capital M1 finance and axos invest AI powered trading Bots can execute trades 247 they help with Arbitrage and complex strategies finally AI powered financial planning tools they help create comprehensive Financial plans popular options include mint wab and personal Capital as AI evolves expect more innovative tools chapter 3 future Trends in Ai and investing now let's shift gears and talk about the future of AI in investing what trends should you be aware of what gamechanging Innovations are on the horizon one major trend is the rise of hyper-personalization AI is going to enable financial institutions to offer highly personalized investment advice and products tailored to your unique financial situation goals and even your behavioral biases imagine receiving investment recommendations that are specifically designed to help you achieve your dream of early retirement or buying your first rental property another trend is the increasing use of alternative data in investment decisionmaking AI algorithms are becoming incredibly sophisticated at analyzing unstructured data such as social media sentiment satellite imagery and even weather patterns to identify investment opportunities this means that hedge funds and institutional investors are no longer just relying on traditional financial data they're using AI to gain an edge by tapping into alternative data sources we're also going to see a surge in the development of AI powered financial advisers that are virtually indistinguishable from Human advisers these AI advisers will be able to understand your financial goals answer your questions provide personalized advice and even empathize with you on an emotional level but perhaps the most exciting trend is the potential for AI to democratize access to sophisticated investing strategies historically these strategies have been reserved for the ultra wealthy and institutional investors however AI is leveling the playing field by making these strategies accessible to everyone through Robo advisors AI powered trading platforms and other Innovative tools now with all this talk about AI you might be wondering will human financial advisers become obsolete while AI will undoubtedly automate many tasks currently performed by humans I believe that human advisors will always play a vital role in finance AI can analyze data and make recommendations but it can't replace the human touch the ability to build relationships understand your unique circumstances and provide emotional support during times of Market volatility chapter 4 how to implement AI strategies in your Investments all right let's get down to Brass tax how can you actually start implementing AI strategies in your own Investment Portfolio first and foremost educate yourself the world of AI investing is constantly evolving so it's crucial to stay informed about the latest trends tools and strategies read books listen to podcasts follow industry experts and don't be afraid to experiment with different AI powered platforms and tools next determine your investment goals and risk tolerance AI is a powerful tool but it's only as effective as the instructions you give it before you start using any AI powered investing tools take the time to Define your financial goals time Horizon and risk appetite this will help you choose the right tools and strategies for your specific needs once you have a good understanding of your investment goals and risk tolerance start small don't go all in on AI investing overnight instead dip your toes in the water by allocating a small portion of your portfolio to an AI powered Robo advisor or experimenting with an AI powered analysis tool as you gain more experience and confidence you can gradually increase your exposure to AI investing remember investing is a marathon not a Sprint it's important to be patient disciplined and focus on the long term and finally don't be afraid to seek professional guidance if you're feeling overwhelmed or unsure about how to incorporate AI into your investment strategy don't hesitate to consult with a financial adviser who specializes in AI investing they can help you navigate the complexities of this rapidly evolving landscape and develop a personalized plan that aligns with your financial goals outro the future of finances here AI is the future of investing the question is are you ready for it the tools are out there the opportunities are endless and the potential rewards are enormous but AI is not a Magic Bullet it's a tool and like any tool it's only as good as the person using it do you think AI will make human investors obsolete let me know your thoughts in the comments below and if you found this video valuable hit that like button and subscribe for more AI investing insights don't miss our next video where we reveal the most powerful AI trading strategy that hedge funds don't want you to know see you there

into per month fluctuated a lot and it's very emotionally driven which I want to correct in 2024 if you take a look at this table November December I've done it diligently consistently investing into that is the emotion that I want to remove when it comes to investing into the S&P 500 at the end of the day I'm investing into this for the the next 20 to 30 years until the age of 50 60 70 years old I'm not sure when I will actually sell it off in 2023 the S&P 500 actually gave a return of 20 over per. had I invested per month consistently my returns on investment would have been so much more so that is what my mistake was and is what I want to correct in 2024 so now let's go into what my dollar cost averaging strategy will be in 2024 let's go I first considered how the S&P 500 will fit into my overall personal finance plan so from the lowest of risk to the highest of risk I have cpf there's also the bonds that I've invested into and will hold until maturity I do have dedicated videos I'll link up above and down in the description box below then there is also the Singapore Banks and rits of which I'm investing into build that portfolio size big enough so that you'll generate dividends then the highest of risk would be the S&P 500 and I'm also looking at the NASDAQ 100 I have not started on that yet but if you want me to share more subsequently if I do start let me know in the comment section down below my plan is monthly I will put in USD $400 into the S&P 500 an equivalent amount of SGD 50050 depending on the currency conversion at that point of time assuming a conservative average rate of return of about 8% on the S&P 500 in 32 years time when I'm 60 years old the portfolio would have grown to USD $730,000 my Capital would have been USD $150,600 I do need to plan on the plan not going according to BL so if you take a look at the S&P 500 it has given good returns in the past whether will it continue in 20 to 30 years time I'm not sure nobody knows nobody is 100% sure I just want a slice of the pie if things do go well and hence I'm not just invested into the S&P 500 and it is also not a significant size of the entire portfolio that I'm looking to build this emphasizes the importance of diversification which brings me to today's sponsor stash away more than this just being a sponsored portion of the video how I I think this would fit the majority of people is you want to invest your money in a more hands off approach meaning you don't want to have to spend time to research on a particular stock to invest into then every now and then have to check whether are these stocks still okay then a manag portfolio can actually work for you and that's where stash away comes in they are a wealth management platform helps to invest our money in a more hands-off approach have professionals manage the portfolio and you just go about doing your day-to-day activities stash away has two general investing portfolios one is powered by stash away another is powered by Black Rock and investment management company how are they both different the one powered by stash away is more catered towards the risk level that you are comfortable with so when you go to the app and you start a portfolio you do have to indicate what is the risk level percentage that you're comfortable with and they will cater that portfolio to the risk level that you have indicated the one with Black Rock You Have To indicate based on the equity and bonds allocation it has a broader Market exposure with more ETFs in that portfolio so depending on what your style of investing is is and what you're comfortable then go ahead and choose whichever portfolio that is more suitable to your needs if you want to sign up and you're new to stash away you can get your first six months investment managed for free for up to $20,000 so look for the details down in the description box below I hope that in today's video it has helped you gain a clearer picture of how you can also incorporate various Investments so that you are Diversified more than just thep 500 if you have any questions as always leave them down in the comment section below I hope today's video has been helpful for for you and I'll see you in my next video bye-bye

output.script: well let me just give you a sense of of of you know what we know so far about this there are still a few unanswered questions but finally we got the detail on what Donald Trump meant by this liberation day and let me just kind of start by showing you these bars are how high those tariffs the US tariffs are on various different countries around the world at the moment or rather before Donald Trump came into office and a quick kind of bit of revision on where we've come from so far also uh threatened tariffs uh on Mexico and Canada they were repeatedly threatened repeatedly rescinded uh or lifted um but they might well be back again who knows but for the time being they're gone uh we know we got an extra 10% uh tariffs on China China 1.0 then another extra 10% tariffs on China 2.0 you might call them uh and uh we're now kind of waiting to find out what will happen next and we finally did find it out um let's just start there are two parts to this okay so first of all there is going to be a 10% baseline tariff so you see all of these bars go up by 10% uh including of course the UK but that as far as the White House is concerned is just a baseline and then on top of that there are different tariffs for different nations what they call reciprocal tariffs and they say they've gone through the numbers they've looked at not just the tariffs that other countries around the world are charging the US but also uh what they call non-tariff barriers so other things uh and they've worked out uh by the way Canada those Mexico Canada tariffs might well come back so we might well start from that position but reciprocal tariffs might push all of these bars or will push all of these bars up considerably higher so just look at how the picture of trade and tariffs in the US has changed dramatically as a result uh of these measures which are coming in in the next few days and just to give you a few highlights of what we're talking about so uh you could look for instance uh over there at China so China that's a 34% reciprocal tariff but it takes the total amount provided that goes on top of the existing tariff it takes the total amount up above 50% and you're talking you know when tariffs are going above 50% that makes any trade very very difficult and far less likely to happen uh so that's China but you can probably see here uh Vietnam as well and the point here from the White House has been to say listen lots of Chinese goods going into the US but also going through being Vietnam and Cambodia as well being conduits uh for goods to go to America the point here from Donald Trump has that we the US wants to re-industrialize and so it's all about trying to make things domestically but finally uh look at the UK 10% on the UK and for many people uh here obviously it is a big increase on where things were before only a few percent uh the average rate for the UK but that goes up to 10% uh it is the best rate that anyone has uh amongst any nations in fact the best rate that uh any G7 any leading economy in the world uh has and certainly better than the EU all of whom are having to pay an extra 20% in total so 10% another 10% on top but even so all of this will potentially uh diminish the amount of trade going on around the world and diminish the amount of stuff going into the US and finally it's worth just saying what was the stock market reaction well this decision was made after markets had closed but we can look at the futures market this is the NASDAQ futures market and look at what happened it went up a little bit after the announcement and then it's come down quite considerably so a market reaction there which implies that when markets open in Asia and indeed when they were open uh across the US and Europe we're going to see some falls to come as people respond to this ed take a seat i've got another question for you uh there is an more coming out of the White House right now senior White House officials etc trump has to sign an order that closes the dimminimous loophole this is according to an aid tell us why that is significant and how it might affect a nation like China for example so this is and this is on top of all of those things we're showing you dimminimus basically means that for really small kind of low value items that are going in and out of countries you just a lot of that stuff just isn't charged a tariff so what is a tariff ultimately it is just you know we're going to charge you 20% on everything that comes into the country although it's it's it's the recipient that actually pays it but for fast fashion for items that are going in that are relatively cheap and this is a big thing for China you know you've got companies like Shien who who are sending stuff relatively cheaply from Guangong in different parts of China right now that's not subject to any tariffs donald Trump said earlier on so when he had one of his early kind of we're going to impose tariffs on China he said we're getting rid of dimminimus but then what happened was that suddenly uh in airports around the US you were seeing massive big piles of goods that no one was quite sure what to do with because it's it's an enormous administrative challenge and I think that Anna is the is the bigger issue here raising all of these tariffs different tariffs on different countries and a kind of extraordinary smog board of different numbers we've just seen and Donald Trump you know held up this this this chart of all the different numbers it is likely to just increase the amount of work that it takes for America to to to collect these tariffs but the point that Donald Trump wants to make can I show one more chart like as a bonus thing but the point that Donald Trump wants to make is that back in a long time ago the majority of federal revenues came from tariffs raising money from tariffs and right now that line is basically down you know close to zero kind of only a few percent and his point is always rather than raising money through income tax couldn't we raise it again through tariffs and I you know I'll spare you the next charts that point out that ultimately that is really really tough to do it's really tough in the modern world of 2025 when you have you know welfare states when you have Medicare when you have you know standing armies that are quite expensive you can't just raise all of your money through tariffs no one has been able to do that and so that is the challenge that he's faced with right now but what he wants to do is to be able to say we're going to try and re-industrialize hence all of those tariffs on China on Vietnam on Cambodia and we're going to try and raise a bit of money from it in the process and I think that's that's the selling point but what comes next is the retaliation you know we start to hear from you know Europe and we know they're going to retaliate what comes next is more market reaction and this is going to roll and roll even though we've got detail tonight we're going to be talking about this for for many weeks and months to

output.script: We have some big breaking news now coming in. We are learning uh India has sealed the Rafal fighter deal. It's the second mega deal for India and uh this is for 26 Rafal marine aircrafts that has been signed. We understand the deal is worth 63,000 cr rupees and more information now coming in. French defense minister is expected to visit India and that is when the deal is to be signed this month. My colleague Shivar is also now joining us on the broadcast here getting us more on that. Well uh Shiv, we understand uh that this is the second mega deal that's going to be signed by the end of the month. What more details do we have? Uh Kitty, this uh deal for 26 Rafal aircraft is for the Indian Navy. Remember it's India's second uh deal for the French Rafal fighters. The first deal was signed in 2016. That was for 36 Rafal for the Indian Air Force. Those fighters have already been delivered. Uh so this is the second. Uh the aircraft is the same. It's still the Rafal except that these fighters unlike the air force versions will be operating off an aircraft carrier deck. Uh that the INS Vikrant and the INS Vikramitya are the Indian Navy's two aircraft carriers right now which have been hungry for new generation fighters for many years now. The Indian Navy currently operates uh you know the Soviet era MiG 29K fighters off its aircraft carrier decks. Uh and the Indian Navy's air arm has been uh you know wanting next generation fighters for a very very long time. So this is a huge piece of good news for the Indian Navy and also very good news in terms of general Indian air power in the Indian Ocean region because uh these Rafal fighters while very similar to the ones already operated by the Indian Air Force uh you know come with uh uh you know many new capabilities. They will have anti-hship missiles which of course the Indian air force also has that capability but specifically in terms of deterrence fleet defense in the Indian Ocean at a time when the Chinese are being uh increasingly aggressive as far as trying to uh create a mark and create influence in the Indian Ocean. every bit of power and power projection actually matters and these Rafal fighters that the Indian Navy will you know will begin to uh uh receive delivery of maybe in the next couple of years will add to that air power allow the Indian Navy to reestablish its primacy in the Indian Ocean. Very very capable aircraft. This definitely comes as a big boost to the Indian Rafal fleet. That means uh our Rafal fleet is now going to increase to 62 when when these uh Rafal jets are delivered ship. That is correct. uh you you know the the Indian Navy and the Indian Air Force have for a long time you know suffered from uh uh the fact that they operate many disparate types of aircraft uh you know which brings in a nightmare of inventory and cost and I think this is one of the few times when the you know the Indian military have decided to acquire a similar kind of aircraft the air force going for the Rafal the Indian Navy also acquiring the Rafal uh you know similar or same aircraft bring with it lots of economies in terms of spare parts in in terms of maintenance repair, overhaul, uh, sustenance, ownership and that kind of thing. Quite apart from the fact kitty that there's going to be a huge amount of synergy obviously between the Indian Navy and the air force. The air force started receiving their Rafals uh during the pandemic uh and they've uh these aircraft have already been operationalized. They've been deployed in Ladak. Some of them are deployed in the eastern sector. Two squadrons with the air force. So over the last few years the air force has gotten very very valuable combat or uh you know preparedness experience with the Rafal. So with the Indian Navy now set to receive these aircraft, it's going to add to their combat potential. There'll be a lot of learnings from the air force, how they've been able to learn about how to use these aircraft in Indian conditions. And let me tell you, Indian combat conditions are vastly different from anywhere else. Uh definitely in France, you know, we're in the tropics. We've got uh the Himalayas to take care of. We've got the eastern sector to take care of. We've got the entire Indian Ocean to defend as well. And that's where these fighters are really going to plug in. So I can tell you it's going to be a very happy day for the Indian Navy. Yes, absolutely. So the deal includes 22 singleseater aircrafts and we understand four twin seater aircrafts which have been designed specifically for Indian Navy's operational requirements. All right, Shiv, we understand. So these Rafal jets uh uh that are uh specifically now designed for India's Navy's uh operational requirements are going to be tailored for operations from our aircraft carrier INS Vikrant. That is correct. Uh uh you know there are when the in when India signed the original deal for Rafals for the Indian Air Force uh a major component of that deal kitty was what was called India specific enhancements. Uh now these India specific enhancements were basically modifications to the original Rafal fighter to uh you know to make them much more compatible with Indian conditions uh Indian combat profiles, Indian threat perceptions uh what are called Indian threat libraries in terms of what India faces from China, Pakistan, the Indian Ocean etc. These are of course of a very classified nature but they have to do with software with different kinds of weapons certain cockpit and electronic equipment as well. uh that is not to be revealed. Uh those India specific enhancements will most certainly be part of the Indian Navy Rafal as well. So what we will be getting is informally called a Rafal I or a Rafal India. Uh because uh while it is the baseline aircraft that the French use and a few other customers have acquired as well. Uh it is customized and tailor made for the very very unique requirements that the Indian military has. Absolutely. Thank you so much for getting us all those details there. Well, of course, a big day for India and India is all set to acquire 26 Rafal jets. This is the second mega deal which is expected to be signed very soon between India and France. India will be uh acquiring these 26 Rafal marine fighter aircraft from France as the center now has cleared a government to government deal as per the information coming in. We are are also learning now the deal is valued at over 63,000 cr rupees and is expected to be signed in the coming few weeks.
